fields.headline: Spring boards
fields.standfirst: You haven't missed the boat to get away. Charlotte Atkins rounds up what's still on offer
fields.trailText: You haven't missed the boat to get away. Charlotte Atkins rounds up what's still on offer.
fields.body:
Greece

The biggest Easter party in Europe will, for the first time in several years, coincide with our own religious holiday. Easter is bigger than Christmas in Greece, with fasting on Good Friday followed by riotous partying and religious processions, fireworks and feasting nationwide.

 Greek Islands Club (020-8232 9780) has availability over Easter at Vamos House in Crete, departing April 10 for 14 nights (£795pp including house, flights, car hire and maid service).

 Easter on Amorgos in the Cyclades lasts for a full week, culminating on Easter Saturday. Nature Trail Amorgos (01993 700600) offers a range of activity holidays among the flower and herb-covered mountains and down by the sea, including walking, painting, cooking, botany, ornithology and photography. Prices for an Easter package cost from £1,248pp for 14 nights based on two sharing.

Madeira

A sub-tropical garden off Africa's Atlantic coast, with one of the mildest climates in the world. The British have been visiting for years, sipping Madeira wine in deckchairs around open-air pools while Britain shivers. All the big hotels are based in and around the mosaic pavements and squares of Funchal where the cathedral and flower market are the biggest draws, but it's easy to explore inland by walking alongside a levada, an irrigation channel that brings water from the mountain springs in the north down to the drier south.

 Cadogan (02380 828303) has a nine-night special offer in the five-star Crown Plaza hotel in Funchal for £799 per adult, £499 per child, departing April 12. (All other operators are reporting flights full.)

Cyprus

A popular all-rounder, currently basking in warm spring sunshine and balmy evenings. There are sandy beaches, good food in terraced tavernas, cool picnic retreats in the forested Troodos Mountains and plenty to do in an easy, English-speaking but thoroughly Mediterranean environment.

 Two of the island's best hotels are still bookable through The Mediterranean Experience (020-8445 6000): The Annabelle, set in six acres of palm-fringed gardens in the bay of Paphos (seven nights from £1,045pp based on two sharing a studio suite); and the Anassa resort at the foot of the rugged mountains of the Akamas Peninsula, which has a Roman-style Thalassotherapy Health Spa (one week from £1,140pp).

 The Hawaii Grand Hotel & Resort on the south coast is organising visits to local churches. After the Holy Mass on Saturday, there's a traditional Cypriot meal, followed by a gastronomic lunch with barbecue and Greek folk dancing on Easter Day. Cyprair's (020-8359 1234) Easter break, departing between April 9 and 12, costs £569 per adult, £285 per child.

Eilat

Although the town is modern and purpose-built, the setting is dramatic. The mountains behind turn red in the sunset, and temperatures hover around the mid-70s year round. The biggest pull is life underwater, which is superb. There are several good, large child-friendly hotels.

 Longwood Holidays (020-8551 4494) can take you and the children snorkelling in the warm Red Sea. A week at the four-star Sheraton Hotel will cost from £464 per adult, £328 per child between Easter Day and May 3, which includes flights, transfers and B&B.

The Canaries

Some sing more quietly than others; La Gomera, El Hierro and La Palma positively whisper. Because the majority of tourists wing their way to Tenerife, Gran Canaria and Lanzarote, the parts they don't reach are beautifully quiet and quintessentially Spanish. Their coastlines are mainly sheer cliffs, the interiors full of spectacular volcanic scenery. The islands bask in hot sunshine year round. Regular ferries dock on all three, and Iberia Airlines pops over daily to El Hierro and La Palma, all from Tenerife.

 Canary specialists Corona Travel (020 8530 3747 www.coronahols.com) has space left in the four-star Jardin Tecina hotel in La Gomera over Easter. One week from Good Friday costs from £529pp for flights and half-board. Allow £99 for a self-drive car for the week plus £60 for inter-island ferry fares for car plus two passengers and £19pp insurance.

Egypt

Luxor has wonderful winter and spring weather, plus the ruins of Karnak and the Valley of the Kings. From the comfort of a deckchair on board a luxurious cruiser, you can take a leisurely sail down the Nile and focus your binoculars on temples and tombs .

 Thomas Cook's (0870 4434443) 11-day Treasures of the Nile cruise departs April 20 and costs £1,295pp based on two adults sharing a twin room, including three nights in Cairo, three in Luxor and four on the river.

 Travelbag Adventures (01420 541007) offers a nine-day holiday departing April 22, including a sleepover on a felucca and swimming and snorkelling in the Red Sea. It costs £699 for adults, £558 for children.

Portugal

The Algarve is enchanting in spring, with enormous sandy beaches bathed in sunshine (although the Atlantic is still cold), lots of tavernas with outdoor lunch tables and, inland, the eucalyptus and pine-covered hills of the Monchique and Caldeirão range.

 The Villa Agency (01273 747811) has space at several properties over Easter. Casa do Moinho near Paderne, for example, is a beautifully-furnished villa sleeping six with views as far as the coast and a listed windmill in the courtyard. Seven nights cost £553 with maid - flights and car hire can be arranged.

 Can't ramble in the UK? Head to northern Portugal for a walking holiday among the poppies, anemones, heather, thyme and lavender with Explore Worldwide (01252 760100). A 15-day holiday departing April 6 costs £690pp, including flights, B&B and guide.

Kenya

Big game, vivid birdlife, spectacular scenery and relaxing beaches. It's affordable Africa, with the advantage of a seaside holiday after all that beating about the bush.

 Somak Holidays (020-8423 3000) has a combined beach and safari holiday. Four days spent on safari (highlight - the Masai Mara Game Reserve) and three nights at a Mombasa beach hotel costs £839 per adult, £587 per child, including flights, transfers and full board on safari, half-board on the beach.

Croatia

The elegant resort of Opatija at the top end of the Dalmatian coast was a favourite with the American dancer Isadora Duncan who took her young lovers there between 1910 and 1912. There's plenty to do, with shops, pavement cafés and restaurants spread along a five-mile promenade running through Botanic Gardens to the medieval town and resort of Lovran.

 Seven nights at Isadora's favourite, Villa Amalia, from April 12 costs £339pp including flights and half board, with Holiday Options (01444 244411)

Florida

Nowhere else in the world offers anywhere like Florida's permutation of family fun. As well as theme parks and beaches, the quality of the accommodation is high, with pools as standard issue. The food is also child-friendly, wth lots of "kids eat free" deals. A short-haul destination, therefore, in all but distance, looked upon almost as a west wing of the Med.

 Thomson (0870 5502555) has two weeks at the Quality Inn Plaza on International Drive in Orlando on April 12 for £835pp based on two sharing a twin room including flights and car hire, but not insurance.

Easter special

Emporio's new clothes
The bigger the name on the labels, the bigger the savings. Gillian Rhys goes for broke to get the new season's must-haves in the capital of cool

Many happy returns
Lots of people have magical places that keep calling them back. Every Easter, Ben Mallalieu and family lose themselves in the literary world of Hay-on-Wye

Cottage industry
Need a break from the daily grind of urban life? Charlotte Atkins has some suggestions

 Family breaks at Easter

Parc life
Can CenterParcs survive the teenager test? Julie Welch finds out at their Wiltshire site

Child support
Jane Cunningham on how to deal with kids on vacation, and avoid those holidays from hell

webTitle: Young Woman Powdering Herself, Georges-Pierre Seurat (c. 1890)

fields.headline: Young Woman Powdering Herself, Georges-Pierre Seurat (c. 1890)
fields.body:
· View the work online

Artist: Georges-Pierre Seurat (1859-91), acknowledged leader of the post-impressionists and inventor of pointillism. He combined the ideals of academic French art with a curiously distant commentary on modern life - he said he wanted to paint people as if they were figures on the Parthenon frieze.

Seurat grew up in La Villette, on the outskirts of Paris. He decided young to become an artist, and fused classical values - he trained at the Ecole des Beaux-Arts under a pupil of Ingres - with self-taught optical science. He made his name with his proletarian pastoral painting Bathers at Asnières (1884), now in the National Gallery, which became an avant-garde icon after it was rejected by the Salon exhibition and shown at the alternative Société des Artistes Indépendants. He guaranteed his immortality with Sunday Afternoon on the Island of La Grande Jatte (1886), now in the Art Institute of Chicago. He died of a heart infection at the age of 31.

Subject: Madeleine Knobloch, Seurat's lover, a working-class woman whom he kept a secret almost throughout their relationship, not just from his bourgeois family but also from his bohemian friends. They had a child who died at the age of one, not long after his father. Knobloch was given some of Seurat's paintings as an inheritance but she cut off all communication with his family after his death.

Distinguishing features: In this portrait, painted circa 1889 to 1890, Seurat both teases and adores his lover, depicting her against conventional traditions of portrait flattery as comically out of scale to her tiny rococo dressing table. Some have seen it as cold, even misogynistic, in its portrayal of the falsehoods of cosmetics, or snobbish in its mockery of a working-class woman's attempts to be bourgeois.

But how wrong they are. This is a loving portrayal, almost out of control in its enthusiasm. The painter's unhinged involvement is revealed by the story that the bamboo frame on the wall originally contained a portrait of Seurat himself, until a friend warned him it looked bizarre. When the painting was shown in 1890, Knobloch's identity was concealed. Yet this is a radical announcement of individuality: she may be acting according to fashion but there's nothing bland about her hair piled up like a brioche, her downcast eyes, her strong face. Her curvaceous presence is a source of visual ecstasy. Seurat delights in her toilette even as he registers the comically disjunctive shapes of real life. Roundness abounds in a rhythmic dance: hairdo, breasts, arms, the folds of her dress.

Seurat has passed into history as the founder of a scientifically objective art movement, aiming to imitate the way light behaves in nature. Pointillism takes into account complementary colours in a painting surface that is a field of chromatically balanced "dots". While Seurat's imitators may have taken this theory absolutely seriously, the master himself used it as it suited him.

Seurat's field of dots is a medium of expression, nowhere more so than in the speckled universe that immerses Knobloch. The multitude of white and red flesh colours, gold, brown and violet, captures the nature not just of perception but of fantasy and feeling. There is no "wall", no "table", just forms shaping and reshaping. The wallpaper behind Knobloch, with its spiralling pattern, vibrates and expands like a soufflé. Seurat creates an aesthetic utopia he shares privately with his lover.

Inspirations and influences: Seurat's influences were the classicist Ingres, from whom he got his sense of structure - see Madame Moitessier (1856) in the National Gallery - and the romantic Delacroix, from whom he learned the power of colour. This painting jokingly plays the gravity of a neoclassical portrait against the frivolous archetypes of rococo art - the toilette scenes of Watteau and Fragonard. While Seurat's belief in experiment influenced modernism, the true nature of his art, its playful cannibalism of genres and expressive abstraction, was matched only by the greatest: Picasso, in Les Demoiselles d'Avignon (1907).

Where is it? Courtauld Gallery, Somerset House, London WC2 (020-7848 2526).

fields.headline: Somewhere in Britain
fields.trailText: Water fight | Seascape | Gorillas in your midst | Ready, aim, fire | A river runs through it | Back to the future | With compliments
fields.body:
Water fight

The 147th Oxford and Cambridge boat race starts at Putney Embankment with the toss of the gold sovereign to determine which side of the Thames each crew will row on. Good viewing points on both sides of the river all the way to Mortlake with plenty of good pubs for refreshments.

 March 24, 1:30pm. Free. Visit www.theboatrace.org for more information.

Seascape

From the Cornish coastline to the underwater gardens of the Mediterranean and the tropical reefs of the Caribbean, the brand-new Blue Reef Aquarium brings to life the sights, sounds and smells of the sea.

 Open daily 10am-5pm. £4.95/£3.95/£12.95. The Blue Reef Aquarium, Towan Promenade, Newquay, Cornwall (01637 878134).

Gorillas in your midst

Get up close and personal to the big cats and one of the largest gorilla families in Europe in their new enclosures at the Trail of the Kings jungle-themed animal experience.

 Opens March 30, 9.30am- 6pm. £19.95/£16. Chessington World of Adventures, Chessington, Surrey (0870 4447777).

Ready, aim, fire

Housed in an 18th-century former armament's depot, the new museum of naval firepower tells the story of all that goes bang, from the Battle of Trafalgar to the Exocet missile.

 Open daily, 10am-4:30pm. £5/£3/£13. Explosion!, Priddy's Hard, Gosport, Hampshire (023 925 05600).

A river runs through it

Go with the flow at the Museum of the River Thames. Follow guided trails exploring ancient water systems, take part in boat-building workshops and watch films inspired by the river at a poolside cinema.

 Until July 1, noon-6:30pm. Free. Oxo Tower Wharf, Bargehouse Street, South Bank, London (020-7401 2255).

Back to the future

Find out what life will be like for a Canterbury resident in 3001 and what your Kentish ancestors really looked like at a hands-on discovery event.

 From Pagans to Ray-guns. March 24, 10am-12:30pm, 1:30-4pm. Free. Royal Museum and Art Gallery, High Street, Canterbury, Kent (01227 452747).

With compliments

Discover your true colours, delve into your past life and find out how homeopathy can work for you at the 11th Complimentary Medicine Festival, providing everything you need to know about natural remedies, including information, advice, treatments and demonstrations.

 March 24-25, 10am-6pm. £3/£2. Kings Hall & Winter Gardens, Station Rd, Ilkley, West Yorkshire (01943 609454).

fields.headline: A matter of course
fields.standfirst: Ski-racing not only tests your skill and courage but also improves discipline, says Martin Bell
fields.trailText: Ski-racing not only tests your skill and courage but also improves discipline, says Martin Bell
fields.body:
Once you've enjoyed the sport of skiing for a few years, and you begin to class yourself as an advanced intermediate, or possibly even an expert, you're bound eventually to encounter a racecourse. You may be a trainee ski instructor who needs to pass a "time test" through gates. You may be a ski bum who enters the weekly bar race; or you may simply be a holidaymaker who has an occasional run in one of the "pay to race" schemes, such as Nastar in North America or WISBI in Austria.

What you'll immediately notice is that there is a world of difference between free skiing, where you can choose when to turn, and ski-racing, where the location of your turns is dictated to you.

Ski-racing (sometimes called "alpine skiing" to distinguish it from the "nordic events" of cross-country and ski-jumping) is divided into four distinct "disciplines": slalom, giant slalom, super giant slalom, and downhill. All four consist of making turns of differing sizes through a series of gates, against the clock. Parallel slalom requires two skiers to race head-to-head down two identical courses, alongside each other. There is also a separate discipline called speed skiing, which consists of a totally straight course without turns. This requires much less skill than the four other disciplines, because turning is the hardest part of racing, but plenty of courage; even at the events open to normal holidaymakers in Les Arcs, it's possible to reach 100mph.

Slalom has the lowest speed of the four disciplines, but it's also where things happen the quickest, as you have to weave through the tight gates in a very rapid rhythm. A fully fledged course consists of two blue poles, followed by two reds, followed by two blues, etc. Each pair makes up a "gate". The rules state that your ski-tips and boots need to pass through each gate.

To ski slalom, you need to have mastered all the attributes of short turns in free skiing: rhythmic pole-plants, upper body facing down the hill, feet turning beneath you, short sharp bursts of edging. But you also need to deal with the poles. Good racers use "cross-blocking", where their feet get so close to the base of the pole that their entire upper body actually passes inside the line of the pole, because their speed imparts a certain amount of inward lean. They then punch the pole out of the way with their outside hand - modern poles are hinged, and bend over easily to allow the racer to pass. The less ambitious option is to ski around the pole with your whole body. The advent of ultra-short, curvy-shaped slalom skis in the past year has transformed slalom technique. No longer do racers pivot their skis between edge sets - they now carve round arcs through each turn.

Giant slalom, or GS, is the discipline you're most likely to encounter.This is the most accessible to non-racers, but at the top level it's also seen as the purest test of technique. The gates are similar to slalom but more widely spaced, allowing higher speeds. Each "pole" actually consists of two poles about a metre apart, with a "panel" of cloth stretched between them - this makes "cross-blocking" impossible, as you'd catch your head on the panel. You need to ski around the panel with your whole body, stretching your inside arm forward to deflect the pole. In GS, the "line" is crucial; you need to start each turn well before each gate. As you pass the panel, your skis should already be pointing towards the next gate. Your track should be a series of smooth arcs, more like an "S" than a "Z". To carry speed, you need to carve your turns, with plenty of hip angulation. Slalom and GS are called the "technical events" and usually consist of two runs, with both times added together.

Super giant slalom, or super G, is a higher-speed version of GS, with wider-spaced gates. It consists of just one run.

Downhill is the glamour event of skiing. Speeds reach 90mph, and racers have to negotiate turns, jumps, compressions (where the G-forces squash them downwards) and fast straight schusses, all over a two-mile course. A race usually consists of one run, occasionally two when the course is shortened due to bad weather.

Downhill and super G are known as the "speed events". Both require good turning technique, like the technical events, but also a low aerodynamic squat, called the "tuck".

fields.bodyText: Once you've enjoyed the sport of skiing for a few years, and you begin to class yourself as an advanced intermediate, or possibly even an expert, you're bound eventually to encounter a racecourse. You may be a trainee ski instructor who needs to pass a "time test" through gates. You may be a ski bum who enters the weekly bar race; or you may simply be a holidaymaker who has an occasional run in one of the "pay to race" schemes, such as Nastar in North America or WISBI in Austria. What you'll immediately notice is that there is a world of difference between free skiing, where you can choose when to turn, and ski-racing, where the location of your turns is dictated to you. Ski-racing (sometimes called "alpine skiing" to distinguish it from the "nordic events" of cross-country and ski-jumping) is divided into four distinct "disciplines": slalom, giant slalom, super giant slalom, and downhill. All four consist of making turns of differing sizes through a series of gates, against the clock. Parallel slalom requires two skiers to race head-to-head down two identical courses, alongside each other. There is also a separate discipline called speed skiing, which consists of a totally straight course without turns. This requires much less skill than the four other disciplines, because turning is the hardest part of racing, but plenty of courage; even at the events open to normal holidaymakers in Les Arcs, it's possible to reach 100mph. Slalom has the lowest speed of the four disciplines, but it's also where things happen the quickest, as you have to weave through the tight gates in a very rapid rhythm. A fully fledged course consists of two blue poles, followed by two reds, followed by two blues, etc. Each pair makes up a "gate". The rules state that your ski-tips and boots need to pass through each gate. To ski slalom, you need to have mastered all the attributes of short turns in free skiing: rhythmic pole-plants, upper body facing down the hill, feet turning beneath you, short sharp bursts of edging. But you also need to deal with the poles. Good racers use "cross-blocking", where their feet get so close to the base of the pole that their entire upper body actually passes inside the line of the pole, because their speed imparts a certain amount of inward lean. They then punch the pole out of the way with their outside hand - modern poles are hinged, and bend over easily to allow the racer to pass. The less ambitious option is to ski around the pole with your whole body. The advent of ultra-short, curvy-shaped slalom skis in the past year has transformed slalom technique. No longer do racers pivot their skis between edge sets - they now carve round arcs through each turn. Giant slalom, or GS, is the discipline you're most likely to encounter.This is the most accessible to non-racers, but at the top level it's also seen as the purest test of technique. The gates are similar to slalom but more widely spaced, allowing higher speeds. Each "pole" actually consists of two poles about a metre apart, with a "panel" of cloth stretched between them - this makes "cross-blocking" impossible, as you'd catch your head on the panel. You need to ski around the panel with your whole body, stretching your inside arm forward to deflect the pole. In GS, the "line" is crucial; you need to start each turn well before each gate. As you pass the panel, your skis should already be pointing towards the next gate. Your track should be a series of smooth arcs, more like an "S" than a "Z". To carry speed, you need to carve your turns, with plenty of hip angulation. Slalom and GS are called the "technical events" and usually consist of two runs, with both times added together. Super giant slalom, or super G, is a higher-speed version of GS, with wider-spaced gates. It consists of just one run. Downhill is the glamour event of skiing. Speeds reach 90mph, and racers have to negotiate turns, jumps, compressions (where the G-forces squash them downwards) and fast straight schusses, all over a two-mile course. A race usually consists of one run, occasionally two when the course is shortened due to bad weather. Downhill and super G are known as the "speed events". Both require good turning technique, like the technical events, but also a low aerodynamic squat, called the "tuck". I'd recommend wearing a helmet for all racing and there are specialised race skis for all four disciplines. Train hard; race well; and good luck! fields.headline: Snow show
fields.trailText: Most European resorts have had mild temperatures with rain below 1,800m and wet snow above. North America has had a light dusting of new snow refreshing the pistes and creating great off-piste powder.
fields.body:
Most European resorts have had mild temperatures with rain below 1,800m and wet snow above. North America has had a light dusting of new snow refreshing the pistes and creating great off-piste powder.

Austria

Light, overnight snow across the highest peaks, but daytime temperatures have been mild leading to soft snow. The best skiing is in St Anton (* * *) and Obergurgl (* * *) on the upper slopes. Conditions are deteriorating in Soll (* *) and Kitzbuhel (* *).

France

Still very mild. La Plagne (* * *) and Les Arcs (* * *), are best on the glaciers. Off-piste conditions are heavy in Argentière (* * *). New snow has refreshed the pistes at Serre Chevalier (* * * *) and Montgenevre (* * * *).

Switzerland

Spring conditions. The lower runs of Murren (* *), Grindelwald (* *), Crans Montana (* *), Verbier (* * *) and St Moritz (* * * *) are all suffering. Saas Fee (* * * *) is still excellent on the upper slopes and off piste.

Italy

Temperatures have stayed low and new snow has fallen. Cortina (* * * *), Cervinia (* * * *) and the Milky Way (* * * *) are excellent on-piste.

Andorra

Very mild temperatures and by midday most slopes are slushy. In Soldeu (* *), the best conditions being found first thing in the morning at altitude.

US

Excellent in all resorts. Aspen (* * * *) has fresh powder on the upper slopes. Scattered snow showers have also improved the pistes in Breckenridge (* * * *), but low cloud has led to poor visibility. In Killington (* * * *), some slopes become heavy towards the end of the day but on piste is generally very good.

Canada

New snow across the West Coast with up to 20cm for Panorama (* * * *). At Whistler (* * * *), the upper piste quality is excellent. In Sunshine Village (* * * *) near Banff, knee-high powder can be found among the trees.

No snowflakes = a serious lack of snow - no lifts open. * = poor snow conditions, very few lifts open. * * = conditions reasonable, some slopes in poor condition. * * * = plenty of good skiing. * * * * = good conditions. * * * * * = fantastic on and off piste.

webTitle: John O'Farrell on politicians and the army

fields.headline: The beastly foe
fields.standfirst:
When politicians are in trouble, they organise a military victory. It's like the Falklands

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: When politicians are in trouble, they organise a military victory. It's like the Falklands.
fields.body:
Word has got round the cow community recently; if you're feeling a little bit under the weather, you're best avoiding the vet's for a while. It all started when a cow popped into open surgery and told the vet she had a slight sniffle.

"Hmm..." said the vet, writing out a prescription, "well, it's not a life threatening illness or anything..."

"So what do you recommend?" asked the cow. "Shall I take an aspirin and go to bed?"

"Well, to be on the safe side I'm prescribing mass slaughter for you and all your family..."

"Oh. Er, actually do you know what? I suddenly feel a lot better."

"... And if you could give me a list of all your sheep and pig friends as well, we'd better slaughter them too."

"No really, I feel great. I think I might run the London marathon."

Suddenly we are told that the foot and mouth epidemic is now worse than the crisis of 1967. And then everyone nods and says: "Really?" pretending they knew there'd been a similar crisis 34 years ago (while a vague memory stirs of an edition of the Rock and Roll Years which featured black and white footage of some sick-looking sheep to the opening chords of A Whiter Shade of Pale).

Politicians about to lose an election call for the election to be postponed. A march for the right of country folk to kill animals is cancelled and instead the farmers stay at home and weep because they're having to kill animals. Finally the situation has the hallmark of any great national crisis; they've called in the army. The lads have been in training for this, but now it's the real thing. Collecting dead sheep. We all remember the Royal Tournament when we were kids; how quickly the Parachute Regiment could rush into the arena, dig a hole and chuck in a load of sheep carcasses. Well now we are going to see them in action for real.

"Great news lads! We're leaving Belfast."

"Hooray! At last, scuba diving in Bermuda like the advert promised."

"Er, nearly. Trudging around wet fields, picking up rotting sheep carcasses."

We are assured that the army will not be doing any shooting, but we're always told this when our soldiers are sent into a crisis. It will be just like Bosnia; they'll go into the Cumbrian hills not intending to get caught up in the fighting but soon it'll become impossible not to take sides. Once militant sheep factions start reprisals on the farmers, pressure will mount for British soldiers to intervene. You might presume that a flock of sheep would be no match for the British army, but these things are never quite so straightforward. The farm animals know the terrain better than the squaddies flown in from Aldershot, and like any well drilled military unit, the sheep tend not to think for themselves too much.

And what the animals lack in military hardware and discipline they make up for in numbers. It'll be like Zulu! only this time it's Sheep! "There's bloody thousands of them, Sah!" the sergeant major will exclaim as he scans the horizon. Regimental goats will be unmasked as spies for the other side. The Sun will describe the enemy as "no better than animals".

But eventually, British determination and military know-how will win through; the livestock will be overwhelmed, and a new spirit of species patriotism will prevail. Of course the moaning minnies will say that using depleted uranium has made the farms uninhabitable and there'll be rumours that some of the Welsh guards were fraternising with the enemy. But no one will want to listen to negative propaganda at a time of such national pride, when the prime minister's approval rating is breaking all records.

The foot and mouth crisis should not be misconstrued as an electoral problem for the government. By demanding the army be called in, William Hague has played right into the PM's hands. The one remaining piece of the jigsaw that needed to be in place before the general election was a historic triumph for the British armed services. Maggie saw off the Argentine navy; Tony Blair could seize this opportunity and secure a heroic victory over wheezy farm animals. An emotional homecoming for our boys would be followed by a triumphalist victory parade and a service of thanksgiving in Westminster Abbey. Cue a walkover for Labour at the general election called immediately afterwards (though Hague remains leader as he is the only Conservative MP left). This is the complex sequence of events that could unfold if Tony Blair decides against calling a May election next week.

So as the shepherd of his flock William Hague is faced with a tough choice. Support an election now and accept a limited cull of the sheep on his backbenches, or wait a few months and see his entire herd wiped out. It's the only thing that keeps the farmers going.

"Thank god!" They all say. "At least I haven't got William Hague's job."

webTitle: All to play for, insist Lib Dems, as PR is 'killed off'

fields.headline: All to play for, insist Lib Dems, as PR is 'killed off'
fields.standfirst:
Special report: election countdown
Special report: proportional representation
fields.trailText: Liberal Democrats yesterday denied suggestions that they had been "bought off" by a deal with Labour over electoral reform as trade unions claimed that the prospect of voting change had been "killed off" for the next parliament.
fields.body:
Liberal Democrats yesterday denied suggestions that they had been "bought off" by a deal with Labour over electoral reform as trade unions claimed that the prospect of voting change had been "killed off" for the next parliament.

Union sources made clear they believed the wording of Labour's election manifesto, which will commit the party to reviewing the success of new proportional voting systems in Scottish, Welsh and European elections, effectively kicked the issue of PR even further into the long grass. The Liberal Democrats, who wanted a renewed commitment to a referendum on voting reform - which Labour included in its last manifesto but ignored - insisted the pledge kept the issue on the agenda.

A senior aide to Charles Kennedy, the party leader, said: "Tony Blair is under no illusion that we want a review straight after the Scottish and Welsh elections, which in effect means starting by the summer recess in 2003."

The fact that both sides are claiming to have emerged victorious will please Downing Street, which finalised the wording on Wednesday, confirming it at cabinet on Thursday. The Labour leadership wants to avoid antagonising grassroots activists, who mainly oppose PR, while keeping the Liberal Democrats on board for unofficial cooperation against the Tories in the coming election.

Unions, however, are crowing that the commitment is too full of loopholes to have meaning.

They privately argue that a promise to review the workings of PR after the next round of Welsh and Scottish elections in May 2003 is all but worthless without a timetable.

Sir Ken Jackson, general secretary of the AEEU engineering union, said: "We are very happy with the wording. It reflects the deep reservations the Labour party has towards PR."

The AEEU will attempt to bury the issue once and for all in the next parliament with an intensified grassroots campaign against PR.

The Liberal Democrat leadership defends the agreement, arguing that only weeks ago, Mr Blair appeared to be turning away from any worthwhile mention of PR in the manifesto.

Foreign affairs spokesman Menzies Campbell told Radio 4's Today: "Proportional representation remains on the agenda. Charles Kennedy is well entitled to feel satisfied with this."

fields.headline: Doing time for your convictions
fields.trailText: A friend of mine has a friend who's a monk, somewhere in the north of England. She recently wrote to him and asked, among other things, whether monks had a vote.
fields.body:
A friend of mine has a friend who's a monk, somewhere in the north of England. She recently wrote to him and asked, among other things, whether monks had a vote. He set the record straight in a letter: "Yes, monks do vote. In no respect are monks like convicts, other than the following: - (a) we are confined to one place; (b) we live in all-male institutions; (c) we follow a precisely timetabled daily schedule; (d) we spend a lot of time in cells; (e) we are meant to be obedient; (f) we are all a bit anti-social; (g) we wear special clothes; (h) everyone here pretends to be religious in order to get special treatment. We will, of course, be more than happy to pay council tax the moment the British government returns to us, with interest, all the land and money it nicked in the 16th century."

I was sorry to see that Cranley Onslow, the former chairman of the Tory 1922 committee, has recently died, though my regret was tempered by the fact that he came closer than any other MP to driving me out of business. It began years ago, when I was writing a political column in the old Punch magazine. Onslow came storming into a bar to demand of my then boss, the Guardian political editor Ian Aitken, whether it was true that his nickname among the press was "Crapley Onslow". Ian, taken aback, hesitated, then said, no it wasn't. The correct version was, ahem, "Crapley Arsehole".

Short of material - and why else does one put anything into a column? - I sent this in to Punch. Onslow went berserk. He wrote to the parliamentary press gallery, which represents the journalists who work in the Commons, and demanded my banishment for bringing parliament into disrepute and contempt. My colleagues read the letter and immediately moved next business. There are times when I heartily approve of self-regulation.

But he did not give up, and briefed lawyers. Julian Critchley warned me that he was very determined, and that I should take his threats seriously. So I spent a morning going through the data base - shoe boxes full of clippings - assembled by the brilliant Parliamentary Profiles writer, Andrew Roth. Here I found just what I was looking for, and the following week Punch printed my favourite apology. First I grovelled to Onslow - grave distress caused to himself and his family, etc, quite inappropriate to compare an MP to a bodily part, especially that bodily part, and so on. In the next paragraph I was able to write: "Am I alone in regretting the passing of the grand old days of parliamentary invective? It was fully four years ago that Cranley Onslow publicly described Brian Sedgemore MP as 'the boil on the bottom of the Labour party; painful if sat upon, but best ignored' ...." I heard nothing more from him, or his lawyers.

Terror struck me at the party held for the new book by Carole Stone, the celebrated Networking. As you might expect the launch was full of quite famous people, including Lord and Lady Birt, Sue MacGregor, bruising home office minister Charles Clarke, tipped as a future Labour leader, and Maureen Lipman, who's lovely. Some readers might recall that last week I was rude about Esther Rantzen, who was supposed to be used by the Royal Opera House to drum up support for a rather difficult modern opera that's on now. I made the point that I would refuse free dress circle tickets to Cosi Fan Tutti or Madame Butterfly if I thought she might be in the audience.

So imagine my horror when a voice said, "hello, Simon, did you go to the opera?", spoken by a face which was, for one nano-second, only vaguely familiar, then resolved itself in my fuddled brain as the Queen of Willie-shaped Vegetables herself. "No!" I managed to croak, before running to find sanctuary with someone much less famous, but safer.

Now and again silly people claim this is not a class-based society. Then you read something which proves otherwise. This week we learned that Tesco has discovered that some people are embarrassed to have their vans drive up to their doors, and are testing the idea of having dark green Range Rovers do the deliveries instead. These prestigious vehicles will have a tiny, discreet Tesco badge somewhere on the bodywork.

The scheme is being rolled-out, as we say, in Norfolk, which is now one of our poshest counties, being full of wealthy people who buy property in the idyllic villages to the north and on the coast, and who frequent elegantly restored pubs in which men in Barbours and cord trousers offer guest ales and main courses of partridge and polenta.

I like the idea of the discreet badge. Presumably snoopy neighbours will use binoculars to detect it. But what Tesco's don't realise is that worrying about their vans is a very Hyacinth Bucket version of gentility. Proper toffs are obsessed with saving money and are quite happy for everyone to know it. Genuine nobs would demand that their groceries were delivered in a filthy white van marked "Ee-Zee-Save - food-style substances at lo lo prices" The nosey neighbours would be able to discern a small, discreet badge marked: "Fortnum & Mason".

I had a really nice evening a week ago, on Red Nose Day, reading out the questions in the 10 Downing Street charity quiz. The press office had assumed that their table would romp home, but the questions (not chosen by me) had been cunningly devised to have something for everyone, including the table of very jolly people who staff the switchboard and open the mail, as well as the chaps and chapesses with Oxbridge firsts. There was also a killer round in which you had to guess where in the building were photos of certain little difficult things, such as door handles. It was all great fun, and somewhat boozy, and I realised that in spite of the address they were just another bunch of nice, smarter than average office workers, enjoying a few matey drinks.
fields.bodyText: A friend of mine has a friend who's a monk, somewhere in the north of England. She recently wrote to him and asked, among other things, whether monks had a vote. He set the record straight in a letter: "Yes, monks do vote. In no respect are monks like convicts, other than the following: - (a) we are confined to one place; (b) we live in all-male institutions; (c) we follow a precisely timetabled daily schedule; (d) we spend a lot of time in cells; (e) we are meant to be obedient; (f) we are all a bit anti-social; (g) we wear special clothes; (h) everyone here pretends to be religious in order to get special treatment. We will, of course, be more than happy to pay council tax the moment the British government returns to us, with interest, all the land and money it nicked in the 16th century." I was sorry to see that Cranley Onslow, the former chairman of the Tory 1922 committee, has recently died, though my regret was tempered by the fact that he came closer than any other MP to driving me out of business. It began years ago, when I was writing a political column in the old Punch magazine. Onslow came storming into a bar to demand of my then boss, the Guardian political editor Ian Aitken, whether it was true that his nickname among the press was "Crapley Onslow". Ian, taken aback, hesitated, then said, no it wasn't. The correct version was, ahem, "Crapley Arsehole". Short of material - and why else does one put anything into a column? - I sent this in to Punch. Onslow went berserk. He wrote to the parliamentary press gallery, which represents the journalists who work in the Commons, and demanded my banishment for bringing parliament into disrepute and contempt. My colleagues read the letter and immediately moved next business. There are times when I heartily approve of self-regulation. But he did not give up, and briefed lawyers. Julian Critchley warned me that he was very determined, and that I should take his threats seriously. So I spent a morning going through the data base - shoe boxes full of clippings - assembled by the brilliant Parliamentary Profiles writer, Andrew Roth. Here I found just what I was looking for, and the following week Punch printed my favourite apology. First I grovelled to Onslow - grave distress caused to himself and his family, etc, quite inappropriate to compare an MP to a bodily part, especially that bodily part, and so on. In the next paragraph I was able to write: "Am I alone in regretting the passing of the grand old days of parliamentary invective? It was fully four years ago that Cranley Onslow publicly described Brian Sedgemore MP as 'the boil on the bottom of the Labour party; painful if sat upon, but best ignored' ...." I heard nothing more from him, or his lawyers. Terror struck me at the party held for the new book by Carole Stone, the celebrated Networking. As you might expect the launch was full of quite famous people, including Lord and Lady Birt, Sue MacGregor, bruising home office minister Charles Clarke, tipped as a future Labour leader, and Maureen Lipman, who's lovely. Some readers might recall that last week I was rude about Esther Rantzen, who was supposed to be used by the Royal Opera House to drum up support for a rather difficult modern opera that's on now. I made the point that I would refuse free dress circle tickets to Cosi Fan Tutti or Madame Butterfly if I thought she might be in the audience. So imagine my horror when a voice said, "hello, Simon, did you go to the opera?", spoken by a face which was, for one nano-second, only vaguely familiar, then resolved itself in my fuddled brain as the Queen of Willie-shaped Vegetables herself. "No!" I managed to croak, before running to find sanctuary with someone much less famous, but safer. Now and again silly people claim this is not a class-based society. Then you read something which proves otherwise. This week we learned that Tesco has discovered that some people are embarrassed to have their vans drive up to their doors, and are testing the idea of having dark green Range Rovers do the deliveries instead. These prestigious vehicles will have a tiny, discreet Tesco badge somewhere on the bodywork. The scheme is being rolled-out, as we say, in Norfolk, which is now one of our poshest counties, being full of wealthy people who buy property in the idyllic villages to the north and on the coast, and who frequent elegantly restored pubs in which men in Barbours and cord trousers offer guest ales and main courses of partridge and polenta. I like the idea of the discreet badge. Presumably snoopy neighbours will use binoculars to detect it. But what Tesco's don't realise is that worrying about their vans is a very Hyacinth Bucket version of gentility. Proper toffs are obsessed with saving money and are quite happy for everyone to know it. Genuine nobs would demand that their groceries were delivered in a filthy white van marked "Ee-Zee-Save - food-style substances at lo lo prices" The nosey neighbours would be able to discern a small, discreet badge marked: "Fortnum & Mason". I had a really nice evening a week ago, on Red Nose Day, reading out the questions in the 10 Downing Street charity quiz. The press office had assumed that their table would romp home, but the questions (not chosen by me) had been cunningly devised to have something for everyone, including the table of very jolly people who staff the switchboard and open the mail, as well as the chaps and chapesses with Oxbridge firsts. There was also a killer round in which you had to guess where in the building were photos of certain little difficult things, such as door handles. It was all great fun, and somewhat boozy, and I realised that in spite of the address they were just another bunch of nice, smarter than average office workers, enjoying a few matey drinks.

webTitle: All to play for, insist Lib Dems, as PR is 'killed off'

fields.headline: All to play for, insist Lib Dems, as PR is 'killed off'
fields.trailText: Liberal Democrats yesterday denied suggestions that they had been "bought off" by a deal with Labour over electoral reform as trade unions claimed that the prospect of voting change had been "killed off" for the next parliament.
fields.body:
Liberal Democrats yesterday denied suggestions that they had been "bought off" by a deal with Labour over electoral reform as trade unions claimed that the prospect of voting change had been "killed off" for the next parliament.

Union sources made clear they believed the wording of Labour's election manifesto, which will commit the party to reviewing the success of new proportional voting systems in Scottish, Welsh and European elections, effectively kicked the issue of PR even further into the long grass. The Liberal Democrats, who wanted a renewed commitment to a referendum on voting reform - which Labour included in its last manifesto but ignored - insisted the pledge kept the issue on the agenda.

A senior aide to Charles Kennedy, the party leader, said: "Tony Blair is under no illusion that we want a review straight after the Scottish and Welsh elections, which in effect means starting by the summer recess in 2003."

The fact that both sides are claiming to have emerged victorious will please Downing Street, which finalised the wording on Wednesday, confirming it at cabinet on Thursday. The Labour leadership wants to avoid antagonising grassroots activists, who mainly oppose PR, while keeping the Liberal Democrats on board for unofficial cooperation against the Tories in the coming election.

Unions, however, are crowing that the commitment is too full of loopholes to have meaning.

They privately argue that a promise to review the workings of PR after the next round of Welsh and Scottish elections in May 2003 is all but worthless without a timetable.

Sir Ken Jackson, general secretary of the AEEU engineering union, said: "We are very happy with the wording. It reflects the deep reservations the Labour party has towards PR."

The AEEU will attempt to bury the issue once and for all in the next parliament with an intensified grassroots campaign against PR.

The Liberal Democrat leadership defends the agreement, arguing that only weeks ago, Mr Blair appeared to be turning away from any worthwhile mention of PR in the manifesto.

Foreign affairs spokesman Menzies Campbell told Radio 4's Today: "Proportional representation remains on the agenda. Charles Kennedy is well entitled to feel satisfied with this."

fields.headline: Wettest 12-month spell since 1766
fields.standfirst: Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: England and Wales has endured the wettest 12 months since records began in 1766, the meteorological office said yesterday.
fields.body:
England and Wales has endured the wettest 12 months since records began in 1766, the meteorological office said yesterday.

Average rainfall across England and Wales was 1,299mm (51in) between April 1, 2000 and March 20, 2001, beating the previous record of 1,285mm (50in) set in 1872.

The met office had no need to wait until the end of March because constant deluges of rain have smashed the record already.

The year also broke two other records: last April was the wettest April, with 143mm (5.6in) of rain, and last autumn was the wettest on record, with 456mm (17.9in) of rain. Scotland and Northern Ireland were excluded yesterday because their records do not go back so far.

A spokesman for the met office warned there could be more extreme levels of rainfall in the future, leading to further flooding.

"The prediction is that we will start seeing a greater distribution change in the rainfall patterns.

"Winters will suffer from more rainfall. However, it is impossible to pinpoint one particular cause for the extra rainfall."

The spokesman added that the increased rainfall was not just caused by global warming but could be part of a larger climatic cycle.

webTitle: Back to school for abusive parents ordered

fields.headline: Back to school for abusive parents ordered
fields.standfirst:
Blunkett promises means to identify and punish problem adults

Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: Blunkett promises means to identify and punish problem adults
fields.body:
Violent and abusive parents who insist on causing "aggro" in schools face being sent back to the classroom alongside their children, the education secretary, David Blunkett, said yesterday.

In a wide ranging package of measures designed to curb discipline problems in schools, he told head teachers that he was looking at extending the use of parenting orders - already in use to combat crime outside school - to similar circumstances within the school walls.

Parents who fail to deal with their children's bad behaviour in class or who are themselves abusive on school premises could be sent back to school to take parenting classes under the terms of the orders. With the agreement of the school, they could even find themselves sitting next to their own child, Mr Blunkett told heads at the annual conference of the Secondary Heads Association in Newport, south Wales.

The orders would be issued by local magistrate's courts under the instructions of the education authority. In the most serious cases parents could face being fined. A new regime of tougher fines of up £2,500 for parents who condone their children's truanting has already been introduced by Labour, and came into force earlier this month.

In a wide ranging speech which many delegates saw as Mr Blunkett's parting shot before a likely move to the Home Office after the election, he told the conference that parents were the root of discipline problems, with a small minority making the lives of teachers "a daily misery".

In a message to such adults, he said: "If you give aggro to heads and teachers, if you come on to school premises and you behave in a way which sets an appalling example to your child and to others, if you prevent them from being educated properly and if you refuse to cooperate in making it possible for schools to do their work, we will take action against you."

At the same time, Mr Blunkett outlined a £4m plan to expand the number of in-school learning support units - so-called sin bins - to take disruptive pupils to be educated out of the classroom. An extra 50 units are planned, mainly for schools outside urban areas.

John Dunford, general secretary of the Secondary Heads Association, welcomed the plans to extend parenting orders, and said his members had experienced many problems at the hands of troublesome parents. He said that on one occasion, under the terms of the 1996 Education Act, he had banned a parent from school who had gone to the home of one of his teachers.

"This is good news for heads, and another weapon in their armoury," he said. "If you simply ban parents, you build up a degree of frustration with parents who are already difficult. Our feelings as heads has been that the balance of rights and responsibilities is wrong. We have all the responsibilities, and the parents have all the rights."

Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the National Association of School Masters Union of Women Teachers, said: "Clearly it is important to target the parents if they are the root of the problem. But much more needs to be done immediately, such as abolishing appeals panels which are still sending disruptive children who have been excluded back in to the classroom by the truck load."

Mr Blunkett also set out further details of the government's new secondary schools strategy, which it hopes will help stem the dip in achievement at the critical Key Stage 3 period for pupils aged between 11 and 14. But plans for schools to concentrate on a minimum of three hours a week in each of English and maths were criticised by heads as "too prescriptive".

In a questions and answers session Mr Blunkett said he wished he had been able to do more to raise teacher morale.

webTitle: Gerbeau gets £45,000 bonus for dome rescue

fields.headline: Gerbeau gets £45,000 bonus for dome rescue
fields.standfirst:
Frenchman rewarded for keeping show on the road as most payouts for senior personnel reflect failure to achieve targets

Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: Frenchman rewarded for keeping show on the road as most payouts for senior personnel reflect failure to achieve targets.
fields.body:
Pierre-Yves Gerbeau's bonus for helping to save the Millennium Dome from collapse is only £3,969 bigger than that of the ousted chief executive he replaced.

The New Millennium Experience Company yesterday announced that the Frenchman is to receive an extra £45,000 under a performance scheme that also triggered £41,031 for Jennie Page, who resigned in February last year.

Mr Gerbeau, hired to keep the show on the road within two months of the dome's disastrous opening last year, was judged a success, while Ms Page, forced to resign when the crowds stayed away, was judged to have largely failed.

Both were paid £150,000 a year, and dome officials said the bonuses appeared similar because directors were entitled to up to 30% of salary over their entire employment. Ms Page working three years to Mr Gerbeau's one.

His £45,000 represented nine-tenths of a maximum £50,000 while Ms Page's £41,031 was three-tenths of the £136,769 due if she had achieved targets set when she took control.

The dome board's approval of bonuses totalling £135,620 for five former directors reflected what a flop the project was. They would have been entitled to share £389,626 if it had lived up to the advance billing.

The managing director, Liam Kane, was awarded £31,559 of a possible £94,677, the commercial director, Kevin Johnson, got £8,768 of £52,608 and the finance director, Steve Brown, got £9,262 of £55,572.

Mr Kane, paid £150,000 a year during the 24 months he was in the post, immediately returned the bonus and asked for it to be donated to good causes supported by the millennium commission.

The dome was a £800m disaster zone. David James, the City troubleshooter appointed NMEC chairman in the middle of last year to salvage the project, said he had beenlegally advised of contractural obligations to pay the bonuses.

Mr James, who is still working unpaid to find a buyer for the Greenwich tent, paid tribute by name to Mr Gerbeau only. "The contract for PY Gerbeau, chief executive from February 2000 to January 2001, carried a maximum bonus entitlement of £50,000 measured against overall performance," he said.

"In making the award of 90% of the maximum entitlement the board recognised that PY had achieved a significant level of performance against his targets."

Ms Page declined to comment, but a colleague said she believed she had never received the recognition she deserved for ensuring the dome opened on time.

Although it had to be bailed out financially several times and little more than half the trumpeted 12m visitors turned up, Mr Gerbeau's enthusiasm prevented an even worse performance. The former Disneyland Paris executive said last night that he was "still waiting for the letter" confirming the bonus but viewed it as a vote of confidence in his performance.

"More important than the money is the recognition that I have done a good job," he said. "The board recognises I achieved all my objectives."

Peter Ainsworth, shadow culture secretary, said: "Most people would expect bonuses to be paid out from the earnings of their success. "Nobody could possibly imagine that the dome has been anything but a total failure. I have no doubt, however, that the people involved worked extremely hard, including the many people who are apparently receiving no additional bonus."

webTitle: Asylum curbs are biting, says Straw

fields.headline: Asylum curbs are biting, says Straw
fields.standfirst: Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: Ministers yesterday claimed their measures to clamp down on abusive asylum seekers were starting to bite as the   figures for February fell to 5,520, the lowest monthly total for nearly two years.
fields.body:
Ministers yesterday claimed their measures to clamp down on abusive asylum seekers were starting to bite as the figures for February fell to 5,520, the lowest monthly total for nearly two years.

At the same time a record 14,430 decisions on asylum cases in February helped to cut the backlog of asylum seekers waiting for an official answer to below 50,000 for the first time in seven years. The backlog of 49,690 outstanding asylum cases compares with more than 103,000 in January last year.

The sharp fall in the backlog of asylum applicants over the past 12 months has taken some of the heat out of the party political debate over asylum as it reduces the pressures on south-east England.

The home secretary, Jack Straw, yesterday insisted he would continue to maintain the pressure by making the return home of 30,000 failed asylum seekers, made up of 24,000 principal applicants and their families, the focus of official efforts over the next 12 months. "The task of restoring integrity to the asylum system will not be complete until we can ensure that people whose claims are unfounded routinely leave Britain at the end of the consideration of their claims," said Mr Straw.

He added that 700 new immigration staff had been recruited. The number of detention places is also being increased to 2,700 to ensure that failed asylum seekers do not disappear before they are deported.

The official monthly asylum figures show that the highest number of asylum seekers came from Iraq (710), Afghanistan (615), Sri Lanka (435), Somalia (380), and the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia (375). People fleeing Iraq have topped the list of countries for the last three months.

The 14,430 decisions taken last month is the highest number ever.

About 22% of those whose cases were decided were told they could stay in Britain either with full refugee status or as a result of being granted exceptional leave to remain.

A further 24% were refused asylum without full consideration of their case on technical "non-compliance" grounds, bringing the proportion refused refugee status after detailed consideration of their case down to about 50% of all applicants.

The Conservative home affairs spokesman, David Lidington, however, claimed Labour had little to boast about. "The figures show continuing chaos in our asylum system," he said."

webTitle: Roy Hattersley concludes series on local government

fields.headline: Prudent policies bring back pride
fields.standfirst: In the final part of his series Roy Hattersley visits a revitalised Preston
fields.trailText: In the final part of a series on the health of local government, I visit a revitalised Preston.
fields.body:
The initials on the ancient coat of arms salute the Prince of Peace. But around them has been built the legend of Proud Preston. And proud it remains even though it has come down in the municipal world. Thirty years ago it was a county borough with all the powers of a unitary authority. Preston police patrolled Preston streets and Preston schools educated Preston children.

Then the idea of "two tier" local government came into fashion and the Redcliffe Maud commission recommended the demotion of the west Lancashire town. Preston's most important and most exciting services became the responsibility of the Lancashire county council.

Back in 1974 there was at least the consolation of equality of suffering with Blackburn and Blackpool. But then, in 1996, when unitary authorities came back into favour, the two other towns became metropolitan boroughs. Preston did not. In the decaying but still imposing town hall there are three rival explanations for the humiliation. The first is lack of confidence combined with insularity. Preston was fearful about standing alone and unwilling to embrace the nearby boroughs of Chorley and South Fylde. The second is misplaced loyalty. Blackburn and Jack Straw, its MP, resisted both the pressure and persuasion of the county, but Preston's Labour leaders argued for "standing by party colleagues" whose authority would be emasculated by Preston's promotion. The third possibility was graphically expressed by a Labour councillor of long service and high reputation. "Nobody in their right mind would have given more authority to Preston then. The council had been destroyed by crazy politics".

During the mid-nineties, the reputation of Preston borough council was severely injured by a deeply divided ruling Labour group led by Councillor Valerie Wise, daughter of Audrey, then the town's MP. During one council meeting, Joe Hood, the leader of the Conservative group, asked Ms Wise if she wanted to create the Socialist Republic of Preston. She replied that she did. Local newspapers photographed her on the Guildhall steps acting out the proclamation of the borough's new status.

Communication failure

The damage done by simple silliness was compounded by the impression of chaos created by the suspension of Geoffrey Driver, the council's chief executive. Driver, now a Preston Conservative councillor, says that the only reason he was given for his suspension was "a failure to communicate" with his leader. He interprets that accusation as meaning that he rejected Ms Wise's view that he must not to communicate with anyone else. Ms Wise says that, after taking legal advice, she judged that her action was justified on the grounds of the chief executive's "incompetency" - unwillingness or inability to implement the policies of the ruling Labour group.

Wherever the blame lay, after a couple of months, the suspension lapsed and Driver made a formal return to duty. He then left the authority. Damaging though the era was, the behaviour of the Labour group was not the only (or even the first) blemish to scar Preston's municipal reputation.

A couple of years before Ms Wise was elected leader, Frank McGrath, the deputy Labour leader, was lent £125,000 by Balfour Beatty, the civil engineering company which was rebuilding Preston's inland dock. After a police investigation the director of public prosecutions decided not to prosecute Councillor McGrath. The council, believing that the £125,000 is a "surplus on the cost of the dock rebuilding scheme" is considering attempting to "reclaim" it through the civil courts.

Add to all this confusion and division, the behaviour of four "independent" councillors (one of whom changed his party three times) and Preston became a perfect example of all that is popularly believed to be wrong with local government - the combination of circumstances that makes the efficient provision of services impossible. Peter Rankin, who took over the Labour leadership when David Borrow left for Westminster, told his colleagues that what went on in the town hall was "more like a circus than a council".

Against that background of conspicuous absurdity it is quite extraordinary that, over recent years, Preston council has made giant leaps towards efficient and effective local government. Its total budget is only a fraction of Birmingham's £2bn but that does not reduce the importance of spending with care. All the indicators of financial probity now confirm its commitment to prudent management. Spending committees are obliged to respect cash limits. Council house rents have been increased (by the full amount recommended by the Treasury) with the agreement of all the parties. After some argument, the notion that all spending must conform to the government's view of "best value" - the obligation to examine every item of expenditure and make sure that the money is not wasted - has been accepted. The town's "balances", on which it can rely in times of trouble, stand at £4m.

Despite the new fiscal probity, Preston still pays a financial price for standing in the shadow of the county council. For years Blackpool and Blackburn levied a lower council tax - once by as much as two pounds a week in Band D. The Tory group leader Kenneth Hudson has every reason to blame the discrepancy on local socialist profligacy but he holds the county council responsible. Preston's council tax includes a "precept" which it levies to finance services provided by the county. Hudson believes that it is kept unreasonably high by the cost of bureaucracy. "After they lost Blackpool and Blackburn, they never thought of cutting down their administration" even though they were providing services for, and raising money from, half a million fewer people. Whether or not that criticism is justified, it typifies the widespread resentment that is felt in the town. Preston is an ancient borough with buildings which almost match its traditions. It stands where the M6 and M55 meet and it is the west coast mainline station for all of central Lancashire. It is well managed and likely to expand. Yet it is not allowed to run the most vital local services.

Rankin complains: "The county is too remote. It is a nonsense that Preston is not running its own schools". Since he must take some of the credit for the council's fiscal prudence he is entitled to complain about the wasteful duplication of services. Both town and county run information and welfare rights bureaux. When it was suggested that amalgamation was sensible, the county agreed. All that was necessary, they said, was for Preston to hand over its assets and responsibilities to the senior authority. Ian Hall, too loyal to criticise colleagues, takes a stand on principle. He "thought that the whole county should be divided into seven unitary authorities when the changes were considered in 1996". He thinks so still.
