It is hard to imagine Valerie Wise working happily with the Duke of Westminster. But during her last year on the council (when she was being rehabilitated in the chair of the Labour group) she was a member of the committee which examined the feasibility of the scheme. She concluded that "partnership with the private sector is the only way to improve a very run down area".

Years of exposure to local government often encourage a growth in the practicality gene which lies dormant beneath the surface of all politicians. But the obligation to accept hard facts comes naturally to the best municipal leaders. Preston is now fortunate to have two such men leading the Labour and Conservative groups. Kenneth Hudson, a poultry farmer who first contested his rural ward as an independent, became leader of the Conservatives when Joe Hood (who had done the job for a quarter of a century) became mayor.

Ian Hall, who led Labour in the early eighties, returned to office in 1999 when Rankin, the head of the careers advisory service in the University of Central Lancashire, decided that he could not risk his job for the uncertainties of leading a hung council in which his 27 Labour supporters were outnumbered by 29 Liberals, Conservatives and independents. Both Hudson and Hall are archetypal town hall figures and, even in their seventies, the spirit of service still obviously burns bright within them. Each of them also illustrates the difficulty of governing a "lower tier" council.

Hudson spends three full days a week on council business. He has "two men to help" on his farm but "works most days before council work starts and after it finishes". He entered local politics because he thought that the village in which he lived was being neglected. "The council barely knew it existed". He has stayed for almost a quarter of a century because he has "a mission to represent the rural areas which often miss out". Hall came into local government after being active in his union which "encouraged service and socialism". He led the council back in the eighties, but gave up because he was "in full time employment and the pressure was too great for anyone with a job". Both men are now able to serve the town well not despite their age, but because of it.

In larger authorities, leaders are paid an executive salary. Hall receives £1,000 a year for doing what, since he does it properly, absorbs his whole week. Hudson receives (on application and proof of attendance) the backbench councillors' allowance when he attends a meeting. In consequence, neither man is likely to be replaced by a councillor in permanent employment. Rankin, who anticipated the introduction of the cabinet system to Preston, says that the local government reforms "will make leading the council a full time job". Preston is going through the pilot stage of cabinet government. When the new constitution is confirmed, the council leadership will no longer be open only to men and women who are retired, self-employed, out of work or willing to sacrifice success and promotion in their primary occupation. It will become a job for a professional politician.

According to Hudson, "almost every councillor hates the cabinet system". Their complaint is that the rank and file are excluded from the consideration of policy. Rankin argues that "cabinets get things done" and avoid the hours wasted on unproductive discussion in committees and full council meetings. Hall, himself an enthusiast for the cabinet system, admits that there is "a good deal of feeling in the Labour group about it. Some of them say that they feel totally isolated. That may be partly true. But the process makes decision-making easier".

The new regime means that the cabinet can only be examined on subjects which do not appear in their report if "notice" has been given of the question. Hudson says that during the one council meeting at which the new standing orders applied: "We spent most of our time being told to sit down". It was often the informality of the old councils which made them at least seem accountable to their constituents. The new regime is intended to improve the workings of democracy by separating the executive from the rest of the council. Few people in Preston believe the cabinet system will produce the desired result.

Bus experience

Hall's enthusiasm for the government's white paper reforms is less concerned with accountability than with efficiency. He is immensely influenced, in his support for change, by his experience as a director of Preston Bus, a company set up when deregulation ended the municipal monopoly of transport companies. A few years after the law was changed, a local competitor bought half a dozen mini-buses and set up a cheap shuttle service. "In three weeks, Preston Bus had bought mini-buses of its own and the service was up and running. It would have taken the old council-owned company weeks. Meeting after meeting."

Hall - "basically New Labour", although he has been around for 30 years - repeats the reality of the local government white paper. The committee system was the chimera of democracy. "Decisions were always taken by the ruling political groups and that is still fundamentally the case". But party discipline may soon break down. After the pilot period is over, Preston will be expected to observe national guidelines for the conduct of its cabinet. One of them requires a public statement of all outside influences on cabinet decisions. An announcement, "as instructed by the Labour government", will damage both dignity and popularity.

Detaching the parties from the cabinets is part of New Labour's determination to make local government less political. On the evidence of Preston the cabinet system may not achieve that aim. The Conservatives, despite their instinct for consensus, prefer a one party administration. "It's what the opposition wanted", says Hall. There was a time when, had they wished it, the Tories could have formed a coalition with the Liberals. But when the numbers were right, the Liberal group included one councillor who, according to the Conservatives, "did not work in the borough's best interests". So they sacrificed the prospects of power. National policy on local government has to accommodate attitudes which Westminster finds difficult to understand.

Fortunately for democracy, the great enterprise to which Preston set its hand together with the Grosvenor Estate enjoyed the support of all the council's parties. The "media fact sheet" which publicised the Tithebarn Redevelopment feasibility study, began with endorsements from the Tories and Liberals as well as Hall. Bill Chadwick, the engaging Liberal Leader, says that he would still prefer more houses and flats to be mixed in with the shops, markets, cafes and cinemas that make up the present proposals. But he is not the man to oppose the scheme which commands such general support.

Liberals are never the same in any two local authorities. In Preston, after the Tories turned them down, they abandoned hope of coalition power because their growing ranks are often swelled by gains from Labour. Instead, they talk of a rainbow coalition of all the parties - knowing it to be unattainable - and allow the Labour minority to remain in power. With the justification which comes from inertia in the face of progress, Liberals will claim some credit for the city centre regeneration. It is a scheme which, as Hall, partly as an admission and partly as a boast, agrees: "No council would have thought was within its remit 30 years ago."

Hall, although a septuagenarian, moves with the times. He has joined the ranks of Labour leaders who want to divest their councils of the whole housing stock. In a sense, the government's conduct forced his hand. On the Callum estate, two thirds of the houses were repaired and improved under a government renovation programme. Then the scheme was abolished and Treasury funds for that sort of initiative dried up. "There was no way in which the council itself could bring the remaining properties up to the standards" which envious tenants knew were enjoyed by their more fortunate neighbours.

So the remaining houses were handed over to a housing association which the government allowed to raise the necessary capital. Hall is happy to see similar registered social landlords take over the remaining council estates. "Nothing" he says, "is more trouble. Nine out of 10 complaints to councillors are about repairs". He also has a less self-interested reason for welcoming the change. Free from borrowing restraint, "RSLs will do a better job". And, these days, councils have a different sort of regeneration on their minds. It is a process which they will only complete if they accept government restrictions on the way it is done.

Sudden changes in Whitehall plans and regulations - invariably accompanied by the immediate end to the funding which originally accompanied them - are a major hazard of life in local government. The risk of being damaged by an unexpected policy shift is increased with every extension of government influenced over individual council decision. External control reduces the internal flexibility. Hall, for all his loyalty to the government, is becoming concerned about the extent of London interference. Like Rankin, his predecessor, he has fought for the acceptance and real operation of "best value". It was, he said, necessary to destroy "Labour's reputation for throwing money away. No one would argue against the principle."

However, he wonders if the system has grown unreasonably restrictive. "Now we have inspectors to check that we're doing it in the right way. The bureaucracy is beginning to waste money not save it." He could not imagine "a government of any persuasion ever allowing councils a free hand especially to raise money on the market". Nor would he support total freedom. "Past results prove that there have to be some controls." Working councillors fear that the central government's obsession with regulation is illustrated by its attitude towards Preston's estate improvement schemes.

The Deepdale renewal strategy was launched in February 1997. To most people outside Preston, the name produces only the mental pictures of Tom Finney in long shorts, thick shin guards and heavy old fashioned boots making magical runs down the wing. To town planners it is an area of the town which qualified for designated renewal area status because immediate deprivation is combined with the prospect of improvement. And it met the government's other criteriaas 75% of its dwellings were privately owned. Rather more qualified for help under the 1989 Housing Act. A third of the resident households were entitled to state benefit.

So the council set out on an early exercise of combined public support and self-help. Housing grants were targeted at homes in greatest need and owner occupiers were advised both about the grants to which they were entitled and the way of raising private money for improvement. Businesses were encouraged to tidy up the appearance of their premises as a contribution to civic pride.

The physical change were combined with a drive to convince the beneficiaries that the area belonged to them. They were asked what changes they most wanted to see and encouraged to come together in groups which spoke up for the whole community. Few councils, 10 years earlier, would have thought it right or necessary to provide a forum for dissent.

These days councils rarely qualify for help, no matter how great their need, unless they can demonstrate that their proposals exactly meet the criteria of whoever provides the investment. The European Union is no less exacting than the Department of the Environment. Preston certainly qualifies for assistance from the European development fund. Eight of the town's wards are, as required under the scheme, amongst the 10% most deprived areas in the United Kingdom.

So what, in Euro jargon is called Objective II funding is available. The investment will have three purposes - the creation and development of small firms, the improvement of the economic infrastructure and the involvement of the local communities in partnership projects. More than £7m is already promised for "business and ideas" and "people and communities" and £10m from the strategic "economic development" fund is in prospect for the creation of an economic development zone.

Big money

For Preston, £17m is big money. But to obtain it, a plethora of rules have to be observed and a litany of technical requirements met. It is wholly unreasonable to expect part-time councillors to master the detail. On the rare occasions when discretion can be exercised, the choices have to be made by technocrats. It is hardly surprising that Hudson, the Conservative leader, says: "We are losing control of the nitty gritty of decisions. More and more is being delegated to officers. Soon there isn't going to be any democratic input".

The European Union has thought it right to make what, for the government, is the second straight trade off. Democracy has been sacrificed for efficiency. The same pattern of rules applies to almost all the government's regeneration initiatives, The neighbourhood renewal fund provides investment in deprived areas if, and only if, the recipient councils form a local strategic partnership which includes private companies and community groups. The partnership then has to agree a neighbourhood renewal strategy, produce a statement of how the strategy will employ the new funds, accept the performance targets set out by the government and prepare and acceptable best value performance plan. Preston council hopes to receive £5m during the next four years. It does not expect to use much of its own initiative.

Frustration at the death of democracy turns to anguish when new regulations require councils to do more, but fail to provide the extra funds. Preston provides the best concessionary fares scheme in the country.Some £2m, a barely credible 10% of the whole council budget, is spent on the service. A few councils provide no travel concessions. Others only give minimal help to very limited categories of pensioners. The government has decided that a concessionary fares scheme of its own construction must be implemented throughout the country and has set down very clear rules of who must qualify for free travel. Preston councillors insist that their home-grown scheme will remain the most generous in England. But the new regulations will require them to offer concessions to people who did not receive them before. It will cost them £140,000 just to print and distribute the new passes which the new system will require. Although the extra expenditure is brought about by government action, there is no extra government money to fund it.

All parties in Preston would have undoubtedly preferred to continue with their own scheme. But then, given the option, they would have chosen to go on raising and spending their own money with a freedom which they are not presently allowed. Hudson speaks for the whole council when he says: "We got elected just the same as they do at Westminster. We should have the same rights to represent the people who voted for us". His constitutional theory is less than perfect. Local government derives its powers from, and therefore is legally subservient to, parliament. But the spirit of his complaint typifies thousands of councillors throughout the country. Local government is not what it was when Joe Chamberlain - without consulting anyone except the Birmingham electorate - bought the town gasworks and the water company and used the profits from heat and light to rebuild the sewers.

Preston facts and figures

 The population is 135,400

 85% of local jobs are in the service sector; Preston is the commercial and administrative centre of Lancashire

 There are 8,000 council houses

 The borough encompasses the town of Preston, large areas of agricultural land, some of England's oldest enclosed public parks and a number of villages

 22,000 people commute to Preston to work

 Preston has benefited from recent investment including Riversway Docklands, a shopping, business and leisure redevelopment around the old port

 Tourism generated £32m in 1997

 Preston North End, was one of the founding clubs of the original Football League in 1885

Sudden changes in Whitehall plans and regulations - invariably accompanied by the immediate end to the funding which originally accompanied them - are a major hazard of life in local government. The risk of being damaged by an unexpected policy shift is increased with every extension of government influenced over individual council decision. External control reduces the internal flexibility. Hall, for all his loyalty to the government, is becoming concerned about the extent of London interference. Like Rankin, his predecessor, he has fought for the acceptance and real operation of "best value". It was, he said, necessary to destroy "Labour's reputation for throwing money away. No one would argue against the principle." However, he wonders if the system has grown unreasonably restrictive. "Now we have inspectors to check that we're doing it in the right way. The bureaucracy is beginning to waste money not save it." He could not imagine "a government of any persuasion ever allowing councils a free hand especially to raise money on the market". Nor would he support total freedom. "Past results prove that there have to be some controls." Working councillors fear that the central government's obsession with regulation is illustrated by its attitude towards Preston's estate improvement schemes. The Deepdale renewal strategy was launched in February 1997. To most people outside Preston, the name produces only the mental pictures of Tom Finney in long shorts, thick shin guards and heavy old fashioned boots making magical runs down the wing. To town planners it is an area of the town which qualified for designated renewal area status because immediate deprivation is combined with the prospect of improvement. And it met the government's other criteriaas 75% of its dwellings were privately owned. Rather more qualified for help under the 1989 Housing Act. A third of the resident households were entitled to state benefit. So the council set out on an early exercise of combined public support and self-help. Housing grants were targeted at homes in greatest need and owner occupiers were advised both about the grants to which they were entitled and the way of raising private money for improvement. Businesses were encouraged to tidy up the appearance of their premises as a contribution to civic pride. The physical change were combined with a drive to convince the beneficiaries that the area belonged to them. They were asked what changes they most wanted to see and encouraged to come together in groups which spoke up for the whole community. Few councils, 10 years earlier, would have thought it right or necessary to provide a forum for dissent. These days councils rarely qualify for help, no matter how great their need, unless they can demonstrate that their proposals exactly meet the criteria of whoever provides the investment. The European Union is no less exacting than the Department of the Environment. Preston certainly qualifies for assistance from the European development fund. Eight of the town's wards are, as required under the scheme, amongst the 10% most deprived areas in the United Kingdom. So what, in Euro jargon is called Objective II funding is available. The investment will have three purposes - the creation and development of small firms, the improvement of the economic infrastructure and the involvement of the local communities in partnership projects. More than £7m is already promised for "business and ideas" and "people and communities" and £10m from the strategic "economic development" fund is in prospect for the creation of an economic development zone. Big money For Preston, £17m is big money. But to obtain it, a plethora of rules have to be observed and a litany of technical requirements met. It is wholly unreasonable to expect part-time councillors to master the detail. On the rare occasions when discretion can be exercised, the choices have to be made by technocrats. It is hardly surprising that Hudson, the Conservative leader, says: "We are losing control of the nitty gritty of decisions. More and more is being delegated to officers. Soon there isn't going to be any democratic input". The European Union has thought it right to make what, for the government, is the second straight trade off. Democracy has been sacrificed for efficiency. The same pattern of rules applies to almost all the government's regeneration initiatives, The neighbourhood renewal fund provides investment in deprived areas if, and only if, the recipient councils form a local strategic partnership which includes private companies and community groups. The partnership then has to agree a neighbourhood renewal strategy, produce a statement of how the strategy will employ the new funds, accept the performance targets set out by the government and prepare and acceptable best value performance plan. Preston council hopes to receive £5m during the next four years. It does not expect to use much of its own initiative. Frustration at the death of democracy turns to anguish when new regulations require councils to do more, but fail to provide the extra funds. Preston provides the best concessionary fares scheme in the country.Some £2m, a barely credible 10% of the whole council budget, is spent on the service. A few councils provide no travel concessions. Others only give minimal help to very limited categories of pensioners. The government has decided that a concessionary fares scheme of its own construction must be implemented throughout the country and has set down very clear rules of who must qualify for free travel. Preston councillors insist that their home-grown scheme will remain the most generous in England. But the new regulations will require them to offer concessions to people who did not receive them before. It will cost them £140,000 just to print and distribute the new passes which the new system will require. Although the extra expenditure is brought about by government action, there is no extra government money to fund it. All parties in Preston would have undoubtedly preferred to continue with their own scheme. But then, given the option, they would have chosen to go on raising and spending their own money with a freedom which they are not presently allowed. Hudson speaks for the whole council when he says: "We got elected just the same as they do at Westminster. We should have the same rights to represent the people who voted for us". His constitutional theory is less than perfect. Local government derives its powers from, and therefore is legally subservient to, parliament. But the spirit of his complaint typifies thousands of councillors throughout the country. Local government is not what it was when Joe Chamberlain - without consulting anyone except the Birmingham electorate - bought the town gasworks and the water company and used the profits from heat and light to rebuild the sewers. Preston facts and figures  The population is 135,400  85% of local jobs are in the service sector; Preston is the commercial and administrative centre of Lancashire  There are 8,000 council houses  The borough encompasses the town of Preston, large areas of agricultural land, some of England's oldest enclosed public parks and a number of villages  22,000 people commute to Preston to work  Preston has benefited from recent investment including Riversway Docklands, a shopping, business and leisure redevelopment around the old port  Tourism generated £32m in 1997  Preston North End, was one of the founding clubs of the original Football League in 1885

webTitle: Standards committee to ease off in rebuking MPs for minor breaches of rules

fields.headline: Standards committee to ease off in rebuking MPs for minor breaches of rules
fields.standfirst: Special report: parliament
fields.trailText: The Commons standards and privileges committee yesterday recommended that MPs accused of minor ethical breaches should be prosecuted less rigorously after complaints from a minister and other MPs.
fields.body:
The Commons standards and privileges committee yesterday recommended that MPs accused of minor ethical breaches should be prosecuted less rigorously after complaints from a minister and other MPs.

The appeals to ease off came from all sides of the house, with Margaret Beckett, the leader of the Commons, sending a detailed memorandum setting out her concern that the rules were changed so often no one was quite sure what they were.

"Such a process of extension may well lead to members inadvertently and in all innocence falling foul of a new interpretation of the rules," she warned the committee.

William Hague, the former prime minister John Major, Treasury minister Stephen Timms, and the chairman of the standards committee himself, Robert Sheldon, have all been censured for failing to declare or register interests.

In recommendations published yesterday - which MPs will have to vote on - the committee now says that rather than the parliamentary watchdog Elizabeth Filkin reporting to the committee in cases of minor breaches, she should instead issue guidance.

That could let senior politicians off the embarrassment of a public rebuke from the committee. Mrs Beckett - who, her office insisted last night, was speaking as a senior MP rather than a member of the government - was critical of several recent findings, including the committee's implied criticism of Mr Major.

The committee found he had not followed the guidelines 'stringently' - while allowing that he had asked for and followed the official advice. Mrs Beckett said in those circumstances "it should surely be beyond question that members should not be retrospectively rebuked".

Ms Filkin and the committee have been under attack both for excessive zeal and - after the Vaz inquiry revealed Ms Filkin had not been able to stop the Europe minister obstructing her investigation - for inadequate powers. There have been bitter objections to allegedly partisan or frivolous complaints which have not resulted in serious charges. MPs who have been the subject of inquiry have protested that they don't know of the complaint until they read about it in the press.

Yesterday the committee proposed changes intended to make the rules clearer and to ensure the subject of a complaint would be informed at the same time as the commissioner is asked to investigate.

However, the committee does not address the case for wide-ranging reform called for by many observers in the wake of the Vaz inquiry, and an earlier inquiry into a constituency matter involving John Reid, now Northern Ireland secretary. In both cases, Ms Filkin reported that her work had been severely obstructed. In the Guardian last week, her predecessor, Sir Gordon Downey, wrote that new powers were needed to prevent such obstruction.

fields.headline: Larger than life Thatcher opposed
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Thatcher era
fields.trailText: Plans to erect a statue in the Palace of Westminster of Margaret Thatcher, complete with her trademark handbag, have run into opposition because the former prime minister is still alive.
fields.body:
Plans to erect a statue in the Palace of Westminster of Margaret Thatcher, complete with her trademark handbag, have run into opposition because the former prime minister is still alive.

Margaret Beckett, leader of House of Commons, has made it clear she will refuse to allow the larger than life tribute to be displayed until after Lady Thatcher's death.

Tony Banks, Labour chairman of the Commons committee which has already commissioned the £50,000 marble image of the Iron Lady, wanted agreement to stand the sculpture on an empty plinth in the members' lobby later this year.

But Mrs Beckett has told a number of MPs she considers that to be "inappropriate" under parliament's 10-year rule which traditionally bans statues of politicians in the first decade after their death.

Supporters and opponents of the proposed Thatcher statue are expected to call a truce until after the election when the battle is likely to recommence in earnest.

Mr Banks believes an exception should be made for Britain's first female premier, though he remains a critic of her policies. The Labour MP yesterday declined to comment on talks with Mrs Beckett and other Commons authorities but predicted the statue would eventually be accepted.

Mrs Beckett's office also declined to comment.

The members' lobby outside the Commons chamber is dominated by bronze statues of Clement Attlee, Lloyd George and Winston Churchill, with a fourth plinth vacant.

The £50,000 cost of the Thatcher statue was provided by an anonymous donor and the ex-Tory leader has sat on about half a dozen occasions for sculptor Neil Collins.

Lady Thatcher's office has refused to be drawn into the controversy, but the statue could go on loan to the National Portrait Gallery or another institution before it enters parliament.

fields.headline: The politics of vowel movements
fields.standfirst: Blair's transformation might have been scripted by Shaw
fields.trailText: Blair's transformation might have been scripted by Shaw.
fields.body:
Veteran critics and writers are prone to declare that there are only three or four basic plots from which all stories are spawned. Looking at culture at the moment, there sometimes seems only to be one: the tale of the physical and social transformation of a woman by a man.

Within a few recent days, I saw My Fair Lady at the National Theatre and the new Sandra Bullock movie Miss Congeniality, in which she plays a tough and laddish FBI agent given 48 hours to become a convincing beauty queen. The debt to Shaw's Pygmalion and its musical spin-off is made explicit when Michael Caine, as a camp makeover specialist, is compared to Professor Higgins. Another of last week's theatrical openings (a new version of Wedekind's Lulu) was unexpectedly revealed by this proximity to be a German precursor of the Shaw, written some 14 years earlier. Lulu, a "flower girl", is transformed economically and sexually through a series of relationships with older men.

Sustained exposure to the same legend in different forms led me to reflect on the extent to which Pygmalion is the governing myth of our times. We're surrounded by people who used to be somebody else. Most days in the newspapers there's a story of a celebrity whose features have been resculpted by a Californian surgeon, or a banker in Middle England who used to use the Ladies but now, after treatment, visits the Gents, or vice versa.

In television schedules already dense with shows in which houses and gardens receive makeovers, this year's most popular new television series - ITV's Popstars - was an exercise in taking people off the street and turning them into the early 21st-century equivalent of aristocracy: entertainment celebrities. The theme of personality turnover also extends, more subliminally, to the other current hot show, Anne Robinson's quiz, The Weakest Link. There can not have been a previous factual television programme in which the host was so close to a fictional character.

And, finally, the next general election will be contested between leaders who have been Higginsed into versions of themselves unrecognisable from what they were a decade ago.

The relevance of Shaw's plot is not entirely accidental. When he put together Greek legend with the current fashion for elocution lessons to create Pygmalion, he had a political impetus now overshadowed by the dominance of the later musical version. Understanding that accent was the great social indicator in England, he advocated widespread phonetic education as a means of dismantling the class system. Even so, he could not have guessed quite how protean society would become.

The Pygmalion myth, for example, underlies modern politics. Britain's two most vivid recent premiers - Margaret Thatcher and Tony Blair - were both, visually and vocally, constructions of their advisers. The political rise of Thatcher, although she'd never touted blossoms on the street, fitted Shaw's scheme almost exactly. Senior male smoothies (Gordon Reece and Ronald Millar) worked specifically on her voice, dress and manner. She even offered a Westminster equivalent of Eliza's "not bloody likely" verbal slip when she accused the opposition of being "frit", a word suddenly surging up from her carefully concealed Lincolnshire past.

With Tony Blair, the process is the reverse of Shaw's story. The journalist Anne Applebaum, who has been living in Poland, recently returned to interview Blair several years after a previous encounter. One of her comparative observations was that his accent had slipped several notches.

The prime minister's verbal journey towards a sort of tabloid mockney was also recently noted in this column and results from Alastair Campbell playing Rex Harrison to the electoral Audrey Hepburn of Tony Blair with the difference that this phonetics teacher has been softening up his pupil's vowels and consonants. Blair, were he to burst into song, would now sing that: "The ray in spay faws mailly on ver play." This is supposed to show his identification with the ordinary voter. The fact that Thatcher got posher in office, while Blair has tongued down makes its own point about the shifting of powerbases in British politics.

It also suggests that a leader in these times has to be a Pygmalion politician. William Hague will go before the voters in the impending election with a haircut, wardrobe and policies unrecognisable from 1997. It's possibly revealing in this context that the failed administration between Thatcher's and Blair's was run by John Major, who was almost pathologically determined to remain unchanged in office and whose main rabble rousing slogan in office was: "What you see is what you get." Voters were disappointed with what they got.

When nominations are invited for the most politically powerful play of the 20th century, the usual leaders in the survey are two by Arthur Miller: Death Of A Salesman, a critique of capitalism, and The Crucible, an examination of ideological tyranny which has applications to many decades and places.

It would, on the surface, seem not bloody likely that Shaw's little comedy of 1912 could compete, but Pygmalion was a play of unusual cultural perception. The dramatist anticipated our age of self-invention and transformation, in which a majority of the population would die in a different class from the one into which they were born, and in which operations are available to remodel your face and even your gender. Knowingly and unknowingly, our society throws bouquets to Shaw's flower girl.

webTitle: Balance tips in favour of vaccination

fields.headline: Hint from Brown as balance tips in favour of vaccination
fields.standfirst: Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Britain's slaughter-only policy to control the rising number of foot and mouth outbreaks was last night in the balance as the agriculture minister, Nick Brown, gave the clearest indication yet that emergency vaccination was now a preferred option
fields.byline: John Vidal and Andrew Osborn in Brussels
fields.body:
Britain's slaughter-only policy to control the rising number of foot and mouth outbreaks was last night in the balance as the agriculture minister, Nick Brown, gave the clearest indication yet that emergency vaccination was now a preferred option, and farm leaders, scientists and veterinarians debated innoculation.

"Speed is of the essence. There is a real sense of urgency about vaccination", said Mr Brown. "It could serve as a route to buy time. I am convinced mass vaccination would not solve the problem, but in local circumstances it is another matter. It may be the correct route to go"

Pressure was mounting on Britain to use vaccination for the first time after European veterinary experts agreed to breach their decade-old ban on vaccinating against the disease and allowed the Netherlands to innoculate animals earmarked for slaughter.

But faced with what EU scientists now call a unique situation with the world's first ever rapid spread of foot and mouth in an industrialised agricultural system, Mr Brown could ask permission from Europe within days.

Consensus is growing in scientific circles that vaccination would not solve the problem, but could significantly damp down the weight of outbreaks and buy time to identify instances and slaughter faster, the two priorities for government.

Of the three scientific groups asked by government to assess the rate of spread of the disease, only one was asked to look at vaccination.

They concluded that it would be "less effective" than culling, but still "useful."

Debbie Reynolds, deputy head of the food standards agency, yesterday agreed: "It would be less effective than a ring cull, but could be very significant in terms of reducing the size of future outbreaks".

Alex Donaldson, head of the Institute for Animal Health at Pirbright, which monitors foot and mouth around the world, said yesterday that he did not suport vaccination.

"Animals can still excrete the virus and remain carriers", he warned.

The government says it has three vaccination options, none of which would end the slaughtering.

The first is to vaccinate all animals in a ring around infected farms and then slaughter them, as the Dutch favour. The idea is to constrain spread of the disease before culling. This is seen as the most likely.

The second would be to use vaccinations as a "firewall" to damp down the diseases and reduce the weight of infection in order to give the authorities more time to cull.

The third option would be to start a mass vaccination programme, so as to protect a given region with an immunity barrier.

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: More than 4,000 farms could end up infected with foot and mouth disease, the epidemic will last well into the summer and the virus could spread across the whole country, three scientific groups predicted yesterday.
fields.body:
More than 4,000 farms could end up infected with foot and mouth disease, the epidemic will last well into the summer and the virus could spread across the whole country, three scientific groups predicted yesterday.

The teams of epidemiologists - specialists in how diseases spread - produced devastating confirmation that foot and mouth cannot be controlled by the government's existing methods.

They suggested three ways to reduce the scale of the disaster: cutting the delay between the discovery of a suspected outbreak and the slaughter of the infected animals; extending "firebreak" culls of animals around in fected farms; and, most controversially, vaccination.

One of the scientists, Professor Mark Woolhouse of the veterinary epidemiology department at the University of Edinburgh, said: "We are all agreed that it is going to get a lot worse before it gets better. It is clear that this epidemic is indeed out of control, and therefore we have to consider other options."

Besides the Woolhouse report, the other two groups were from Imperial College in London and the government's Central Veterinary Laboratory in Weybridge.

The details of their forecasts differ but Debbie Reynolds, veterinary director of the Food Standards Agency, said: "They all say roughly the same thing. They say this will be a large epidemic, that it will grow fast, and will continue for many months ... further action is needed to control the disease."

The Weybridge team forecasts an eventual toll of more than 4,400 cases, with the disease continuing "beyond June 1", although it goes on to say alarmingly that "no end is predicted."

The 1967-68 foot and mouth outbreak in Britain saw about 2,300 premises infected, and these were on average much smaller farms.

Weybridge dismisses government controls over the spread of the disease as "insufficient." More optimistically, it suggests the disease will be largely confined to areas of Britain infected now.

The Woolhouse report predicts that the disease will continue beyond July. It forecasts a much lower final toll - just over 900 - but suggests the epidemic is likely to double in size every eight days.

It calculates that no area of Britain is likely to remain free of the disease if present controls are not stepped up.

For every day cut from the average time gap between report of a suspected case and the slaughter of infected animals, the report says, the final size of the epidemic would be reduced by 25 to 50 per cent.

The Imperial College group said the disease would continue to rage "for many months" and also warned that present tactics would not keep it confined to parts of Britain.

It forecast an average of 70 new cases a day for the next fortnight. However a total cull of animals in a three kilometre ring around infected farms would cut the final toll by as much as 80 per cent.

Imperial was the only group to offer advice on vaccination, saying it would be less effective than culling but would still make a difference.

The three forecasts are relatively crude. Their calculations do not take account of regional differences across the UK, and deal with fictitious "composite animals", ignoring the steep variation in infectivity between sheep, cattle and pigs.

Government officials will be hoping this accounts for the gloomier predictions of the spread of the disease.

The agriculture minister, Nick Brown, said the government aimed to get all infected animals destroyed within 24 hours of the alarm being raised, but admitted this had yet to be achieved in Devon, Cumbria or Dumfries and Galloway, the worst affected areas.

"In Devon, we are very close to a 24-hour report-to-cull time, but in Cumbria we are not yet approaching this," he said. "This is why we are putting in extra resources."

There was confusion yesterday when the government's chief scientist, David King, and Mr Brown appeared to contradict each other over whether firebreak culling would be introduced nationwide, as the epidemiologists recommended.

Prof King appeared to confirm that the green light had been given for firewall culls across the country but Mr Brown said no decision had been taken.

fields.headline: Travel tips
fields.trailText: In Eastern Europe, don't be tempted by unofficial money-changers.
fields.body:
In Eastern Europe, don't be tempted by unofficial money-changers. Ten years ago, the black market offered much better deals than the official exchange rate, but today it's possible to get good rates from all local bureaux de change, whereas unofficial money-changers often pass off counterfeit or Communist-era banknotes to unsuspecting tourists.
Dougal Thomson

 Vegans or coeliacs can avoid confusion when ordering meals in another language by carrying a Dietary Alert Card, a concise translation of their requirements, available from dietarycard.com.
Sandra Russell

webTitle: Who lost their heart in Jamaica?

fields.headline: I lost my heart in ... Jamaica
fields.standfirst: Derrick Evans (aka Mr Motivator)
fields.trailText: Derrick Evans (aka Mr Motivator)
fields.body:
Why: I was born in Jamaica and left in 1962 but, for some reason, I keep getting drawn back there. Historically, it's very interesting, and, having travelled and filmed throughout the Caribbean, I reckon Jamaica's got the best of everything. There are beautiful beaches on the north coast, hills as lovely as those on St Lucia, and waterfalls as wonderful as the ones in Tobago. Of course, I'm not at all biased ...

The best thing: Firefly, where Sir Noel Coward used to live, is probably one of the most beautiful places on earth, and how he found it, I don't know. It's perched on a cliff-top and from it you can see the sea breaking against the rocks. There something about the way the sun hits the place, too.

My advice: Forget what you've read in the newspapers, Jamaica gets a much worse press than it deserves. But do try to avoid behaving like a tourist. Just be aware of your surroundings - as you would anywhere - and act accordingly. Once you're away from the tourist beaches you'll get a different perspective.

Getting there: British Airways (0845 7733377, www.britishairways.com) offers return economy class flights from London to Kingston from around £550.

 Mr Motivator's new series, The Fitness Zone, will air on Channel Health (Sky Digital, channel 193) throughout April.

fields.headline: Website of the week
fields.standfirst: globalfreeloaders.com
fields.trailText: www.globalfreeloaders.com
fields.body:
Another gap-year website? Very amusing. Didn't you know that Prince William raised thousands of pounds so that he could join the Raleigh expedition?

I thought his father helped out. That's not the point. This is emphatically not a website for gap-year travellers. In fact, unless you're a member of the property-owning classes, it could be quite beyond your means.

It's not house-swapping, is it? Frisky won't tolerate a stranger feeding him, and I can't endure people poking about in my cupboards. Not quite. It's house-hosting. When you sign up to join the Globalfreeloaders register for six months, you agree to host the occasional visitor in your home. You, in turn, can stay with other members all over the world.

Who vets these people? Do they have to provide references? No. You e-mail the person who you'd like to stay with. If they like the sound of you, they'll reply. The correspondence flies back and forth until both parties are happy, and you book the flight.

Once I've signed up, do I have to take in any freeloaders that apply? No - you can turn them down without a reason. If you don't like the sound of a 21-year-old Australian turning up on your doorstep, for example, you can refuse him housespace (or stipulate that you don't want under 25-year-olds in the first place). You can also reserve particular weeks or months when you don't want visitors.

Who's behind it? A 21-year-old Australian from Perth called Adam. But he assures us that some members are in their late 70s, while the average host is in their mid-30s. I'd guess that travellers looking for a cheap stay in Australia have a good chance of getting what they want.

webTitle: Preface: The War Against Cliche by Martin Amis

fields.headline: Battling banality
fields.standfirst:
Once, literary criticism was an elite vocation. Now, writes Martin Amis, we are all critics and in this new democracy, talent and integrity are the losers
Do you agree? Join the debate on our talkboards
fields.trailText: Once, literary criticism was an elite vocation. Now, writes Martin Amis, we are all critics and in this new democracy, talent and integrity are the losers.
fields.body:
At one time, "Literature and Society" was a phrase so much on everyone's lips that it earned itself an abbreviation: Lit & Soc. And Lit & Soc, I seemed to remember, had been for me a long-running enthusiasm. When complacently preparing my new collection of essays and reviews, The War Against Cliché, I planned to assemble my pieces on literature and society (pieces on FR Leavis and Lionel Trilling, and on lesser figures like Ian Robinson and Denis Donoghue). But when I leafed through the massed manuscripts I found only a handful of essays, all of them written, rather ominously, in the early 70s (when I was in my early 20s). Having re-read them, I toyed with the idea of including a nice little section called something like "Literature and Society: The Vanished Debate". Then I decided that my debate had better vanish too. The pieces themselves I considered earnest, overweening, and contentedly dull. More decisively, though, Lit & Soc, and indeed literary criticism, felt dead and gone.

That time now seems unrecognisably remote. I had a day job at the Times Literary Supplement. Even then I sensed discrepancy, as I joined an editorial conference (to help prepare, perhaps, a special number on Literature and Society), wearing shoulder-length hair, a flowered shirt, and knee-high tricoloured boots (well concealed, it is true, by the twin tepees of my flared trousers). My private life was middle-bohemian - hippyish and hedonistic, if not candidly debauched; but I was very moral when it came to literary criticism. I read it all the time, in the tub, on the tube; I always had about me my Edmund Wilson - or my William Empson. I took it seriously.

We all did. We hung around the place talking about literary criticism. We sat in pubs and coffee bars talking about WK Wimsatt and G Wilson Knight, about Richard Hoggart and Northrop Frye, about Richard Poirier, Tony Tanner and George Steiner. It might have been in such a locale that my friend and colleague Clive James first formulated his view that, while literary criticism is not essential to literature, both are essential to civilisation. Everyone concurred. Literature, we felt, was the core discipline; criticism explored and popularised the significance of that centrality, creating a space around literature and thereby further exalting it. The early 70s, I should add, saw the great controversy about the Two Cultures: Art v Science (or FR Leavis v CP Snow). Perhaps the most fantastic thing about this cultural moment was that Art seemed to be winning.

Literary historians know it as the Age of Criticism. It began, let us suggest, in 1948, with the publication of Eliot's Notes Towards the Definition of Culture and Leavis's The Great Tradition. What ended it? The brutalist answer would consist of a single four-letter word: Opec. In the 60s, you could live on 10 shillings a week: you slept on people's floors and sponged off your friends and sang for your supper - about literary criticism. Then, abruptly, a bus fare cost 10 shillings. The oil hike, and inflation, and then stagflation, revealed literary criticism as one of the many leisure-class fripperies we would have to get along without. Well, that's how it felt. But it now seems clear that literary criticism was inherently doomed. Explicitly or otherwise it had based itself on a structure of echelons and hierarchies; it was about the talent elite. And the structure atomised as soon as the forces of democratisation gave their next concerted push.

Those forces - incomparably the most potent in our culture - have gone on pushing. And they are now running up against a natural barrier. Some citadels, true, have proved stormable. You can become rich without having any talent (via the scratchcard and the rollover jackpot). You can become famous without having any talent (by abasing yourself on some TV nerd-othon: a clear improvement on the older method of simply killing a celebrity and inheriting the aura). But you cannot become talented without having any talent. Therefore, talent must go.

Literary criticism, now almost entirely confined to the universities, thus moves against talent by moving against the canon. Academic preferment will not come from a respectful study of Wordsworth's poetics; it will come from a challenging study of his politics - his attitude to the poor, say, or his unconscious "valourisation" of Napoleon; and it will come still faster if you ignore Wordsworth and elevate some (justly) neglected contemporary, by which process the canon may be quietly and steadily sapped. A brief consultation of the internet will show that meanwhile, at the other end of the business, everyone has become a literary critic - or at least a book-reviewer.

Democratisation has made one inalienable gain: equality of the sentiments. I think Gore Vidal said this first, and he said it, not quite with mockery, but with lively scepticism. He said that, nowadays, nobody's feelings are more authentic, and thus more important, than anybody else's. This is the new credo, the new privilege. It is a privilege much exercised in the contemporary book review, whether on the web or in the literary pages. The reviewer calmly tolerates the arrival of the new novel or slim volume, defensively settles into it, and then sees which way it rubs him up. The right way or the wrong way. The results of this contact will form the data of the review, without any reference to the thing behind. And the thing behind, I am afraid, is talent, and the canon, and the body of knowledge we call literature.

Probably some readers are getting the impression that I think these developments are to be deplored. Not so. It is the summit of idleness to deplore the present, to deplore actuality. Say whatever else you like about it, the present is unavoidable. And we, in the 70s, were frequently ridiculous, too, with our Fallacies and our Seven Types (and Leavis's besieged intensity was ridiculous. His shaping embarrassment, however, was to nominate as his model for sanity the person of DH Lawrence). Emotional egalitarianism, for example, looks hard to attack. I honour it, in a way, but it has to me the pale glow of illusion. It is utopian, which is to say that reality cannot be expected to support it. Then, too, these "feelings" are seldom unadulterated; they are admixtures of herd opinions and social anxieties, vanities, touchinesses, and everything else that makes up a self.

One of the historical vulnerabilities of literature, as a subject for study, is that it has never seemed difficult enough. This may come as news to the buckled figure of the book-reviewer, and to the literary critic, but it's true. Hence the various attempts to elevate it, complicate it, systematise it. Interacting with literature is easy. Anyone can join in, because words (unlike palettes and pianos) lead a double life: we all have a competence. It is not surprising, therefore, that individual sensitivities come so strongly into play; not surprising, either, that the discipline has rolled over for democratisation far more readily than, for example, chemistry and Ancient Greek. In the long term, though, literature will resist levelling and revert to hierarchy. This isn't the decision of some snob of a belletrist. It is the decision of Judge Time, who constantly separates those who last from those who don't.

Let me run, for a while, with an extended simile. Literature is the great garden that is always there and is open to everyone 24 hours a day. Who tends it? The old tour guides and sylviculturists, the wardens, the fuming parkies in their sweat-soaked serge: these have died off. If you do see an official, a professional, these days, then he's likely to be a scowl in a labcoat, come to flatten a forest or decapitate a peak. The public wanders, with its oohs and ahs, its groans and jeers, its million opinions. The wanderers feed the animals, they walk on the grass, they step in the flowerbeds. But the garden never suffers. It is, of course, Eden; it is unfallen and needs no care.

Readers of my book are asked to keep an eye on the datelines which end these pieces, for they span nearly 30 years. You hope to get more relaxed and confident over time; and you should certainly get (or seem to get) kinder, simply by avoiding the stuff you are unlikely to warm to. Enjoying being insulting is a youthful corruption of power. You lose your taste for it when you realise how hard people try, how much they mind, and how long they remember (Angus Wilson and William Burroughs nursed my animadversions - and no doubt the animadversions of others - to the grave). . . I am also struck by how hard I sometimes was on writers who (I erroneously felt) were trying to influence me: Roth, Mailer, Ballard.

You proceed by quotation. Quotation is the reviewer's only hard evidence. Or semi-hard evidence. Without it, in any case, criticism is a shop-queue monologue. Gallingly for the lit-crit imperialists (especially IA Richards), there is no means for distinguishing the excellent from the less excellent. The most muscular literary critics on earth have no equipment for establishing that:

"Thoughts that do often lie too deep for tears"

is a better line than

"When all at once I saw a crowd"

- and, if they did, they would have to begin by saying that the former contains a dead expletive ("do") brought in to sustain the metre. Yet quotation is all we have. To idealise: all writing is a campaign against cliche. Not just cliches of the pen but cliches of the mind and cliches of the heart. When I dispraise, I am usually quoting cliches. When I praise, I am usually quoting the opposed qualities of freshness, energy and reverberation of voice.

© Martin Amis, 2001. This is an edited version of the preface to The War Against Cliché - Essays and Reviews 1971-2000 by Martin Amis, published by Jonathan Cape on April 26.

The pieces themselves I considered earnest, overweening, and contentedly dull. More decisively, though, Lit & Soc, and indeed literary criticism, felt dead and gone. That time now seems unrecognisably remote. I had a day job at the Times Literary Supplement. Even then I sensed discrepancy, as I joined an editorial conference (to help prepare, perhaps, a special number on Literature and Society), wearing shoulder-length hair, a flowered shirt, and knee-high tricoloured boots (well concealed, it is true, by the twin tepees of my flared trousers). My private life was middle-bohemian - hippyish and hedonistic, if not candidly debauched; but I was very moral when it came to literary criticism. I read it all the time, in the tub, on the tube; I always had about me my Edmund Wilson - or my William Empson. I took it seriously. We all did. We hung around the place talking about literary criticism. We sat in pubs and coffee bars talking about WK Wimsatt and G Wilson Knight, about Richard Hoggart and Northrop Frye, about Richard Poirier, Tony Tanner and George Steiner. It might have been in such a locale that my friend and colleague Clive James first formulated his view that, while literary criticism is not essential to literature, both are essential to civilisation. Everyone concurred. Literature, we felt, was the core discipline; criticism explored and popularised the significance of that centrality, creating a space around literature and thereby further exalting it. The early 70s, I should add, saw the great controversy about the Two Cultures: Art v Science (or FR Leavis v CP Snow). Perhaps the most fantastic thing about this cultural moment was that Art seemed to be winning. Literary historians know it as the Age of Criticism. It began, let us suggest, in 1948, with the publication of Eliot's Notes Towards the Definition of Culture and Leavis's The Great Tradition. What ended it? The brutalist answer would consist of a single four-letter word: Opec. In the 60s, you could live on 10 shillings a week: you slept on people's floors and sponged off your friends and sang for your supper - about literary criticism. Then, abruptly, a bus fare cost 10 shillings. The oil hike, and inflation, and then stagflation, revealed literary criticism as one of the many leisure-class fripperies we would have to get along without. Well, that's how it felt. But it now seems clear that literary criticism was inherently doomed. Explicitly or otherwise it had based itself on a structure of echelons and hierarchies; it was about the talent elite. And the structure atomised as soon as the forces of democratisation gave their next concerted push. Those forces - incomparably the most potent in our culture - have gone on pushing. And they are now running up against a natural barrier. Some citadels, true, have proved stormable. You can become rich without having any talent (via the scratchcard and the rollover jackpot). You can become famous without having any talent (by abasing yourself on some TV nerd-othon: a clear improvement on the older method of simply killing a celebrity and inheriting the aura). But you cannot become talented without having any talent. Therefore, talent must go. Literary criticism, now almost entirely confined to the universities, thus moves against talent by moving against the canon. Academic preferment will not come from a respectful study of Wordsworth's poetics; it will come from a challenging study of his politics - his attitude to the poor, say, or his unconscious "valourisation" of Napoleon; and it will come still faster if you ignore Wordsworth and elevate some (justly) neglected contemporary, by which process the canon may be quietly and steadily sapped. A brief consultation of the internet will show that meanwhile, at the other end of the business, everyone has become a literary critic - or at least a book-reviewer. Democratisation has made one inalienable gain: equality of the sentiments. I think Gore Vidal said this first, and he said it, not quite with mockery, but with lively scepticism. He said that, nowadays, nobody's feelings are more authentic, and thus more important, than anybody else's. This is the new credo, the new privilege. It is a privilege much exercised in the contemporary book review, whether on the web or in the literary pages. The reviewer calmly tolerates the arrival of the new novel or slim volume, defensively settles into it, and then sees which way it rubs him up. The right way or the wrong way. The results of this contact will form the data of the review, without any reference to the thing behind. And the thing behind, I am afraid, is talent, and the canon, and the body of knowledge we call literature. Probably some readers are getting the impression that I think these developments are to be deplored. Not so. It is the summit of idleness to deplore the present, to deplore actuality. Say whatever else you like about it, the present is unavoidable. And we, in the 70s, were frequently ridiculous, too, with our Fallacies and our Seven Types (and Leavis's besieged intensity was ridiculous. His shaping embarrassment, however, was to nominate as his model for sanity the person of DH Lawrence). Emotional egalitarianism, for example, looks hard to attack. I honour it, in a way, but it has to me the pale glow of illusion. It is utopian, which is to say that reality cannot be expected to support it. Then, too, these "feelings" are seldom unadulterated; they are admixtures of herd opinions and social anxieties, vanities, touchinesses, and everything else that makes up a self. One of the historical vulnerabilities of literature, as a subject for study, is that it has never seemed difficult enough. This may come as news to the buckled figure of the book-reviewer, and to the literary critic, but it's true. Hence the various attempts to elevate it, complicate it, systematise it. Interacting with literature is easy. Anyone can join in, because words (unlike palettes and pianos) lead a double life: we all have a competence. It is not surprising, therefore, that individual sensitivities come so strongly into play; not surprising, either, that the discipline has rolled over for democratisation far more readily than, for example, chemistry and Ancient Greek. In the long term, though, literature will resist levelling and revert to hierarchy. This isn't the decision of some snob of a belletrist. It is the decision of Judge Time, who constantly separates those who last from those who don't. Let me run, for a while, with an extended simile. Literature is the great garden that is always there and is open to everyone 24 hours a day. Who tends it? The old tour guides and sylviculturists, the wardens, the fuming parkies in their sweat-soaked serge: these have died off. If you do see an official, a professional, these days, then he's likely to be a scowl in a labcoat, come to flatten a forest or decapitate a peak. The public wanders, with its oohs and ahs, its groans and jeers, its million opinions. The wanderers feed the animals, they walk on the grass, they step in the flowerbeds. But the garden never suffers. It is, of course, Eden; it is unfallen and needs no care. Readers of my book are asked to keep an eye on the datelines which end these pieces, for they span nearly 30 years. You hope to get more relaxed and confident over time; and you should certainly get (or seem to get) kinder, simply by avoiding the stuff you are unlikely to warm to. Enjoying being insulting is a youthful corruption of power. You lose your taste for it when you realise how hard people try, how much they mind, and how long they remember (Angus Wilson and William Burroughs nursed my animadversions - and no doubt the animadversions of others - to the grave). . . I am also struck by how hard I sometimes was on writers who (I erroneously felt) were trying to influence me: Roth, Mailer, Ballard. You proceed by quotation. Quotation is the reviewer's only hard evidence. Or semi-hard evidence. Without it, in any case, criticism is a shop-queue monologue. Gallingly for the lit-crit imperialists (especially IA Richards), there is no means for distinguishing the excellent from the less excellent. The most muscular literary critics on earth have no equipment for establishing that: "Thoughts that do often lie too deep for tears" is a better line than "When all at once I saw a crowd" - and, if they did, they would have to begin by saying that the former contains a dead expletive ("do") brought in to sustain the metre. Yet quotation is all we have. To idealise: all writing is a campaign against cliche. Not just cliches of the pen but cliches of the mind and cliches of the heart. When I dispraise, I am usually quoting cliches. When I praise, I am usually quoting the opposed qualities of freshness, energy and reverberation of voice. © Martin Amis, 2001. This is an edited version of the preface to The War Against Cliché - Essays and Reviews 1971-2000 by Martin Amis, published by Jonathan Cape on April 26.

fields.headline: The bleeding countryside
fields.standfirst: Adrian Mole, aged 33.
fields.trailText: I rang Pandora on her mobile; she was at Wells-next-the-Sea, trying to charm a crowd of suspicious whelk workers. Apparently, female whelks are still mutating and growing penises.
fields.body:
Friday, March 16
I went to visit my father today in the isolation ward. He was due to be discharged yesterday, but has contracted yet another hospital superbug. Some of his blood, and several of his mucous membranes, are in the hospital laboratory being tested. Tracy, his barrier nurse, was reading aloud to him an article on foot and mouth from the Daily Telegraph. When she quoted, "Farmers are the custodians of the countryside", my father roared, "The bastards have ruined the bleeding countryside. They have pulled up the hedges, polluted the rivers, fed their animals on shit, and bled the taxpayer dry." My father is wildly prejudiced against farmers. In the early days of their marriage, he suspected that my mother had an affair with a maggot farmer. It is strange how such a tenuous connection can colour our opinions. I, myself, have not stepped foot in the county of Kent since my enemy, Barry Kent, had his novel short-listed for the Booker prize.

I didn't stay long at his bedside, as I was anxious to get back to my prehistoric novel, Krog From Grok. I am enjoying the challenge of writing a book set in a time before language was invented. I tried to interest my father in the challenge, but could tell by the way he yawned and closed his eyes that he had little enthusiasm for my latest literary endeavour. After a desultory conversation about the umpiring in Sri Lanka, I left the stifling atmosphere of his isolation cubicle.

Tracy resumed her reading. As I got to the end of the ward, I heard my father shout, "Nobody compensated me when the electric storage heater industry collapsed. Nobody came to film the rusty heaps of storage heaters lying in the fields."

Saturday, March 17
My mother has been released from Holloway. The Crown Prosecution Service has lost the papers relating to her case. She was distraught to discover that her newish husband, Ivan Braithwaite, was back living at The Lawns with his ex-wife, Tanya. They claim that they are living like brother and sister.

Sunday, March 18, lunchtime
There was a farmer's wife on the midday news sobbing because her healthy baby lambs were going to be slaughtered. Me, William and Glenn watched with tears in our eyes. Then Glenn said, after blowing his nose, "Dad, what would 'ave 'appened to them little lambs if foot and mouth 'adn't broke out?"

I try not to lie to my sons. I replied, "Those little lambs would have been herded into a truck, driven to a far-away abattoir, killed and hung on a hook, before being cut into pieces." Perhaps I shouldn't have been so graphic, as both boys have since informed me that, from now on, they will eat only vegetarian food. This is extremely annoying. As I write, a leg of lamb is cooking in the oven.

Monday, March 19
I rang Pandora on her mobile; she was at Wells-next-the-Sea, trying to charm a crowd of suspicious whelk workers. Apparently, female whelks are still mutating and growing penises. "And the bloody cod have practically disappeared," she complained. I tried to comfort her by saying, "At least you were not called to give evidence in front of Elizabeth Filkin and her committee in the Vaz case." Her phone immediately cut off. The signal must be weak on the Norfolk coast.

Tuesday, March 20
Progress on the novel:

Krog squatted behind his wife, picking lice from her matted hair. Her belly was big with child. Krog did not know why. Krog wanted to tell his wife how much he loved her. He wished that somebody would hurry up and invent language and clothes and shampoo. Then Krog spoke to his wife: 'You woman, me man.'

fields.headline: Anthony Steel
fields.standfirst: Tragic life of British heart-throb movie star whose career collapsed into poverty and destitution
fields.trailText: Tragic life of British heart-throb movie star whose career collapsed into poverty and destitution.
fields.body:
The life of Anthony Steel who, alongside Dirk Bogarde, was the highest-paid star in the great 1950s peak of the British film industry, was a sad story of riches to rags. Steel, who has died aged 80, was the stiff-upper-lipped star of many distinguished British war films, and seen by the Rank Organisation as someone who could be promoted as a heart-throb - the British answer to Gregory Peck and Rock Hudson

But at the height of his fame, Steel - tall, handsome, well-connected, and gentlemanly off the screen as well as on it - suddenly broke his contract with Rank to go in pursuit of the voluptuous Swedish actress Anita Ekberg in Hollywood. He was never forgiven by Sir John Davis, the bull-headed chief of Rank at that time.

His career in Hollywood died in comparison with Ekberg's, and his marriage to her ended in bitter rows. His subsequent career was patchy, and, after stage tours in the 1980s, the next decade found him living, first in a seedy Earl's Court hotel, then in sheltered accommodation in a tiny council flat in Northolt, west London, with graffiti on the walls. Almost totally cut off from his past, he would never tell friends where he was, and never contact his agent, David Daly.

When he read of Steel's plight in a tabloid newspaper in the middle 1990s, Daly had £1,500 due to the actor in television residual payments and other fees, but had no idea where to send it. The newspaper told him the address, and Daly drove there. At first, Steel refused to answer the door bell, which Daly did not find inexplicable in view of the environment, but later he opened a window and recognised his personal friend of 31 years' standing.

Daly passed Steel £500 in cash, and told him he would find him somewhere better to live, ultimately getting him admitted to Denville Hall, the London home for retired theatrical people, and getting him a role as Dr Steven Hart, the guest lead in the television series The Brokers Man II.

But he was not entirely surprised to find that Steel had lived in the tiny council flat for seven or eight years, and had cut himself off from outside contact: "He was a very private man. He just decided that he would withdraw. He found a place to live and simply went into hiding. In some ways, it was not unlike him; if he decided that things weren't right, he would withdraw into himself and not contact anybody."

Such was the downbeat ending. In 1948, when Steel made his first film, Saraband For Dead Lovers, he was hailed as a more polished version of what was then thought of as the beefcake which would beat Hollywood idols at their own game. The following year, Marry Me was hailed as a principal showcase for his presence and, in 1950, when the wartime escape film, The Wooden Horse, appeared, he seemed to be well on his way to becoming an international icon.

For the next few years, Steel was continuously busy, making, among others, the comedy Laughter In Paradise (1951), Another Man's Poison, and the war stories, The Malta Story (1952) and Albert RN (1953). In 1955, it was The Sea Shall Not Have Them and, in 1956, Storm Over the Nile, The Black Tent and Checkpoint.

It might have continued like that, but Steel was accident prone - the worst being meeting Anita Ekberg in December 1955, though he had previously been run through the hand by Errol Flynn's sword in The Master Of Ballantrae and injured his leg, requiring an operation on his knee, after colliding with a tree while making Where no Vultures Fly, in which he played a game warden in east Africa.

Steel met Ekberg after making Storm Over The Nile, a remake of The Four Feathers, in which an apparent coward turns out to be a hero. After their initial encounter, at a film premiere, he called her the most beautiful woman he had ever met. They married in Florence in 1956.

But while Steel was reserved and not at all stagey, Ekberg liked displaying herself, and there were soon rumours of drink-fuelled rows. Steel became prone to what was called "hellraising"; he hit photographers who pursued his wife, and was twice arrested for drink driving.

It all seemed to be out of character. He had been born into genteel circles in Chelsea, the son of an Indian army officer, and gone to school in Ireland before Cambridge. When the second world war broke out, he joined the Grenadier Guards, all of which sat perfectly with the reputation he was to make in the Britain of the postwar years.

Some of his friends believe the collapse of his marriage to Ekberg was a disaster from which he never recovered emotionally; he had previously been married to Juanita Forbes and, after Ekberg, married Johanna Melcher, a former Miss Austria, in 1964. It is certainly arguable that he never recovered professionally, for when he returned to Britain at the end of the 1950s, the affronted British film industry showed little interest. His later films included Hard Core (1977), The Racing Game (1979) and the Swords Of Wayland (1986), none of them notable.

Apart from the stage tours of the 1980s, Steel's last assignments were polished guest appearances in pop-ular television series such as Bergerac, The Professionals, Tales Of The Unexpected, Robin Of Sherwood and Jemima Shaw Investigates.

He leaves two daughters and a son.

Anthony Maitland Steel, actor, born May 21 1920; died March 21 2001
