webTitle: Zap! Go to the top of the class

fields.headline: Zap! Go to the top of the class
fields.trailText: Children who become addicted to computer games may actually be more intelligent than the average and go on to university and higher-ranking jobs, according to a Home Office research review published yesterday.
fields.body:
Children who become addicted to computer games may actually be more intelligent than the average and go on to university and higher-ranking jobs, according to a Home Office research review published yesterday.

One British study surveyed found that such computer "geeks" who had been hooked on games for at least five years were highly intelligent, motivated and achieving people, but often misunderstood.

A follow-up study five years later found that they generally had done well educationally, gone on to to college and then into better than average jobs.

The review by Home Office researcher, Jessica Harris, of nearly 20 research studies into the effects of computer games on children show that many believe that playing or watching violent video games leads to a short-term increase in agressive behaviour.

But Ms Harris concludes that the lack of any evidence on the long-term effects on young children of playing computer games means that it is impossible, on present evidence, to say that the "gameboy generation" has suffered any lasting damage as a result of the use of video games.

The Home Office report says that originally little research was undertaken into the effects of video games, because they were seen as a harmless and enjoyable pastime. But as the popularity of the games grew in the 1990s, parents started to worry about their effects.

Nearly 20 research studies over the past two decades had come to different conclusions about whether the games were harmful.

Some of the research suggested that they caused aggression and low self-esteem, were addictive, and could lead to crime.

"Since the late 1970s, when computer game playing joined television as a preferred childhood leisure activity, one of the main concerns that has constantly been raised is that most games feature some kind of aggression," said Ms Harris.

"This has led some to believe that children become more aggressive after playing such games."

But she said that one study showed that 40 out the 47 most popular games had violence as their major theme.

Their popularity was based on their realistic effects and clever marketing strategies.

Her review says that this is not only true for human or fantasy violence games but also many sports, such as racing, karate and wrestling, which all focus on the player's level of aggression.

Some academic studies suggest that video games are more harmful than television because of the obvious point that children are actively involved in playing the games.

The research review says that while the majority of studies showed that children did become more aggressive after playing or watching a violent computer game, other studies found no evidence to this effect.

In fact, one survey had found that heavy game use had a calming effect on the grounds that it provided "an outlet for aggression and the open expression of competition."

Playing the game

 Children play computer games for an average of 45 minutes a day, according to the Department of Trade and Industry.

 The global games market is estimated to be worth more than $17bn. In Britain, almost 40m games were sold last year for over £934m.

 The Video Standards Council says that less than 1% of games are classified as suitable for over-18s, while 90% are suitable for children under 15.

 The best-selling computer game ever is Myst, in which players solve puzzles as they explore an imaginary world. It sold 5.5m copies worldwide.

 More than two-thirds of children prefer playing games with friends to playing alone.

 Doctors warned that children were suffering "nintendonitis" - repetitive strain injuries brought about by excessive gaming.

 The average age of gamers is 28, but over 40% of all console players are under 18.

Tania Branigan

webTitle: Back to school for abusive parents ordered

fields.headline: Back to school for abusive parents ordered
fields.standfirst: Blunkett promises means to identify and punish problem adults
fields.trailText: Blunkett promises means to identify and punish problem adults
fields.body:
Violent and abusive parents who insist on causing "aggro" in schools face being sent back to the classroom alongside their children, the education secretary, David Blunkett, said yesterday.

In a wide ranging package of measures designed to curb discipline problems in schools, he told head teachers that he was looking at extending the use of parenting orders - already in use to combat crime outside school - to similar circumstances within the school walls.

Parents who fail to deal with their children's bad behaviour in class or who are themselves abusive on school premises could be sent back to school to take parenting classes under the terms of the orders. With the agreement of the school, they could even find themselves sitting next to their own child, Mr Blunkett told heads at the annual conference of the Secondary Heads Association in Newport, south Wales.

The orders would be issued by local magistrate's courts under the instructions of the education authority. In the most serious cases parents could face being fined. A new regime of tougher fines of up £2,500 for parents who condone their children's truanting has already been introduced by Labour, and came into force earlier this month.

In a wide ranging speech which many delegates saw as Mr Blunkett's parting shot before a likely move to the Home Office after the election, he told the conference that parents were the root of discipline problems, with a small minority making the lives of teachers "a daily misery".

In a message to such adults, he said: "If you give aggro to heads and teachers, if you come on to school premises and you behave in a way which sets an appalling example to your child and to others, if you prevent them from being educated properly and if you refuse to cooperate in making it possible for schools to do their work, we will take action against you."

At the same time, Mr Blunkett outlined a £4m plan to expand the number of in-school learning support units - so-called sin bins - to take disruptive pupils to be educated out of the classroom. An extra 50 units are planned, mainly for schools outside urban areas.

John Dunford, general secretary of the Secondary Heads Association, welcomed the plans to extend parenting orders, and said his members had experienced many problems at the hands of troublesome parents. He said that on one occasion, under the terms of the 1996 Education Act, he had banned a parent from school who had gone to the home of one of his teachers.

"This is good news for heads, and another weapon in their armoury," he said. "If you simply ban parents, you build up a degree of frustration with parents who are already difficult. Our feelings as heads has been that the balance of rights and responsibilities is wrong. We have all the responsibilities, and the parents have all the rights."

Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the National Association of School Masters Union of Women Teachers, said: "Clearly it is important to target the parents if they are the root of the problem. But much more needs to be done immediately, such as abolishing appeals panels which are still sending disruptive children who have been excluded back in to the classroom by the truck load."

Mr Blunkett also set out further details of the government's new secondary schools strategy, which it hopes will help stem the dip in achievement at the critical Key Stage 3 period for pupils aged between 11 and 14. But plans for schools to concentrate on a minimum of three hours a week in each of English and maths were criticised by heads as "too prescriptive".

In a questions and answers session Mr Blunkett said he wished he had been able to do more to raise teacher morale.

fields.headline: Send the right signals
fields.trailText: Adrian Ashworth is a London-based television subtitler and a self-confessed late-starter on the career ladder, having worked in various seasonal jobs before taking a degree course in his mid-twenties. This presented certain problems with writing a CV when he first graduated - he did not want to come across as a drifter - but these receded as he gained a track record.
fields.body:
Adrian Ashworth is a London-based television subtitler and a self-confessed late-starter on the career ladder, having worked in various seasonal jobs before taking a degree course in his mid-twenties. This presented certain problems with writing a CV when he first graduated - he did not want to come across as a drifter - but these receded as he gained a track record.

Having been at both the sending and the receiving end of job applications, Mr Ashworth, 35, is convinced that as you gain experience, so your CV should be stripped down. What may be appropriate for a school or college leaver - those lists of achievements and hobbies to differentiate yourself from all the others in the same boat -starts to look embarrassing once you are past 30.

"Who needs to know that you swam 25 metres breast-stroke at primary school?" he said. "I once had a CV from someone who said he could play Blackbird by the Beatles on the guitar. I felt like writing back, 'If you could play Mother Nature's Son the job would be yours'."

A word of warning: some of the worst CVs Mr Ashworth has seen, those with two-page essays detailing every aim and ambition, often went down well with the directors of his last company. "It was a case of recognition - they'd think: 'That's what I was like 20 years ago'."

Mr Ashworth also feels you can send out misleading signals by leaving out your age or family details. "The employer starts to think age is a problem for you - and then it becomes a problem." Similarly, it is hard to second guess what an employer will make of your parental status: three children, for instance, may count against you with some employers, but others will see it as a sign of stability.

Val Ashby, who teaches design and French to teenagers in Oxford, is facing burn-out after 13 years in the teaching profession, and wants to change direction. So far she has sent out her CV to various employers on spec, without any success.

For her, total honesty in the CV is of paramount importance. She has two young children and wants to work part time until the youngest reaches school age - and there is not much point in hiding this aim. "I don't want to put myself in a position where I am under more stress," she says.

Before teaching Ms Ashby worked in marketing and the travel industry, in a culture where it was normal for staff to be at their desks until 7 or later in the evening. "It was like a competition, but I just can't play those games now."

What she wants in her new career is something that builds on the skills she has as a teacher, rather than starting from scratch at the bottom, and that can engage her passion and commitment in the way that teaching once did.

Fields she has explored so far include careers advice, personal development and project development within the education sector.

webTitle: The truth, the whole truth - and nothing like the truth

fields.headline: The truth, the whole truth - and nothing like the truth
fields.standfirst: You want a new job and that means telling would-be employers about yourself in a CV. But how much should you give away? And will any little white lies be detected? Bruce Millar reports
fields.trailText: You want a new job and that means telling would-be employers about yourself in a CV. But how much should you give away? And will any little white lies be detected? Bruce Millar reports.
fields.body:
Screen test: Many successful job applicants withdraw when they discover their CV is to be checked

The last time I sent off a sheaf of CVs in the hope of landing some more lucrative employment I didn't receive a single reply - not the tiniest nibble, let alone an interview. Let alone a job.

There had to be more to this state of affairs, I felt, than the unforgiveable rudeness of the modern employer; my CV must be to blame - but which bit? Had it become, as I entered my third decade in the job market, rather too extensive? Was it unnecessarily honest to admit baldly that I was 43 years old, or that I had resigned from a previous job partly to spend more time with my children?

Yes, yes, and yes, friends replied when I canvassed their advice, I had indeed been peddling quite the wrong resume. One fellow job-seeker 10 years further down the line than me boasted that he had just expunged the entire 1970s from his record. An American friend shrieked in horror when I admitted alluding to my family: "But that's none of their business - they've got no right to know and it's irrelevant to the job."

So, it seems, the trick is to highlight one's strengths while hiding the weaknesses; in other words, to spin. But how far should you go, and at what point does spinning cross the line into suppression of the facts, or falsification, or outright lying?

According to Control Risks Group (CRG), a security and risk consultancy which provides "pre-employment screening" among other services, at least one in four CVs are inaccurate - and the true figure is probably higher still. "We only see the CV when a prospective employer has selected the candidate for a job," said CRG spokeswoman Nicola Hudson. "But successful candidates are warned that their CV will be screened, so many of them withdraw at that stage."

Pre-employment screening originated in the US, partly in response to a vast labour market spread across a whole continent: it was impractical for employers to chase up references thousands of miles away. The practice is relatively new in Britain, where the City used to be run as an old boys' network in which everyone knew everyone else and a gentleman's word was his bond. But with the internationalisation of the financial sector and the growing importance of IT - all those blokes in systems can effectively eavesdrop on the boardroom - employee security has assumed far greater importance. As CRG warns in its sales pitch, 70% of fraud against companies is carried out by insiders.

Inaccuracies detected by CRG range from small slips of the memory which will probably be overlooked by a prospective employer - a dodgy A-level grade, a date mistyped - via exaggerated current salary claims, to outright lies which will certainly cost the perpetrator his job. "One candidate claimed a degree from a highly regarded university," says Ms Hudson. "When we checked, he had indeed studied that subject at that university during those three years, but each year he took the first year exams, and each time he failed. Another candidate had worked in the City for several years, then spent five years in New York before coming back. What she didn't mention was that she'd spent the last 18 months in America in jail for fraud."

Then there are the plausible fantasists who talk themselves into top jobs on the basis of false claims. "We had one chap who had landed a big job in the City. He professed to be a Falklands war veteran who had a limp from a land mine. We found out that he had changed his name, his limp was from a motorcycle crash, he had never been in the Royal Marines and he had even bought his campaign medals in Portobello Road."

Interestingly, for the fundamentally honest among us who would nevertheless consider relegating certain less-than-glorious episodes from their CV, omission of key information does count against you. As Ms Hudson explains, CRG will check references to ascertain the real reasons why you left a job or to make sure the dates add up - if there's a missing 10 months, you'll have some explaining to do.

So what of the temptation to massage your CV when there is little danger of it being raked over by experts? The biggest danger is that the lies will come back to haunt you - after all, it is easier to be consistent with the truth. One friend recalls a colleague who was doing well at work until he applied for an internal promotion. "He had to submit a new CV, and when they checked his records they saw it didn't match his original CV. Then they noticed that he was claiming six A-levels in unusual subjects - no one does six obscure A-levels, but he was apparently worried the other people he worked with had university degrees and wanted to compensate."

So if honesty is the best policy, how should you go about writing that CV? According to Nina Grunfeld, a career and life-change consultant, it doesn't pay to fire off a batch of CVs. Better by far to target a job or company, find out all you can about it, and write a one-off letter - whether or not there is a job going.

If a CV is then demanded -and it usually is - it should be tailored to that particular job and be minimal, elegantly laid out on no more than two sides of paper, and with plenty of white space. "Less is definitely more with a CV," she advises. "Your CV needs to flirt, not to reveal all. It should make you sound so attractive that they want to find out more about you."

This does not mean it should be gimmicky. Attempting humour may show you don't take the job seriously, while the current trend for adding a photograph or a paragraph of what you hope is elegant prose at the top -"who I am, what are my goals" - can be off-putting.

Ms Grunfeld also advises that you shouldn't worry too much about keeping personal details such as age, marital status and parental responsibilities to yourself, if only because they are bound to find out sooner or later. "And if their only interest is in getting more out of you for less money, then you have to ask if you really want to work for these people."
fields.bodyText: Screen test: Many successful job applicants withdraw when they discover their CV is to be checked The last time I sent off a sheaf of CVs in the hope of landing some more lucrative employment I didn't receive a single reply - not the tiniest nibble, let alone an interview. Let alone a job. There had to be more to this state of affairs, I felt, than the unforgiveable rudeness of the modern employer; my CV must be to blame - but which bit? Had it become, as I entered my third decade in the job market, rather too extensive? Was it unnecessarily honest to admit baldly that I was 43 years old, or that I had resigned from a previous job partly to spend more time with my children? Yes, yes, and yes, friends replied when I canvassed their advice, I had indeed been peddling quite the wrong resume. One fellow job-seeker 10 years further down the line than me boasted that he had just expunged the entire 1970s from his record. An American friend shrieked in horror when I admitted alluding to my family: "But that's none of their business - they've got no right to know and it's irrelevant to the job." So, it seems, the trick is to highlight one's strengths while hiding the weaknesses; in other words, to spin. But how far should you go, and at what point does spinning cross the line into suppression of the facts, or falsification, or outright lying? According to Control Risks Group (CRG), a security and risk consultancy which provides "pre-employment screening" among other services, at least one in four CVs are inaccurate - and the true figure is probably higher still. "We only see the CV when a prospective employer has selected the candidate for a job," said CRG spokeswoman Nicola Hudson. "But successful candidates are warned that their CV will be screened, so many of them withdraw at that stage." Pre-employment screening originated in the US, partly in response to a vast labour market spread across a whole continent: it was impractical for employers to chase up references thousands of miles away. The practice is relatively new in Britain, where the City used to be run as an old boys' network in which everyone knew everyone else and a gentleman's word was his bond. But with the internationalisation of the financial sector and the growing importance of IT - all those blokes in systems can effectively eavesdrop on the boardroom - employee security has assumed far greater importance. As CRG warns in its sales pitch, 70% of fraud against companies is carried out by insiders. Inaccuracies detected by CRG range from small slips of the memory which will probably be overlooked by a prospective employer - a dodgy A-level grade, a date mistyped - via exaggerated current salary claims, to outright lies which will certainly cost the perpetrator his job. "One candidate claimed a degree from a highly regarded university," says Ms Hudson. "When we checked, he had indeed studied that subject at that university during those three years, but each year he took the first year exams, and each time he failed. Another candidate had worked in the City for several years, then spent five years in New York before coming back. What she didn't mention was that she'd spent the last 18 months in America in jail for fraud." Then there are the plausible fantasists who talk themselves into top jobs on the basis of false claims. "We had one chap who had landed a big job in the City. He professed to be a Falklands war veteran who had a limp from a land mine. We found out that he had changed his name, his limp was from a motorcycle crash, he had never been in the Royal Marines and he had even bought his campaign medals in Portobello Road." Interestingly, for the fundamentally honest among us who would nevertheless consider relegating certain less-than-glorious episodes from their CV, omission of key information does count against you. As Ms Hudson explains, CRG will check references to ascertain the real reasons why you left a job or to make sure the dates add up - if there's a missing 10 months, you'll have some explaining to do. So what of the temptation to massage your CV when there is little danger of it being raked over by experts? The biggest danger is that the lies will come back to haunt you - after all, it is easier to be consistent with the truth. One friend recalls a colleague who was doing well at work until he applied for an internal promotion. "He had to submit a new CV, and when they checked his records they saw it didn't match his original CV. Then they noticed that he was claiming six A-levels in unusual subjects - no one does six obscure A-levels, but he was apparently worried the other people he worked with had university degrees and wanted to compensate." So if honesty is the best policy, how should you go about writing that CV? According to Nina Grunfeld, a career and life-change consultant, it doesn't pay to fire off a batch of CVs. Better by far to target a job or company, find out all you can about it, and write a one-off letter - whether or not there is a job going. If a CV is then demanded -and it usually is - it should be tailored to that particular job and be minimal, elegantly laid out on no more than two sides of paper, and with plenty of white space. "Less is definitely more with a CV," she advises. "Your CV needs to flirt, not to reveal all. It should make you sound so attractive that they want to find out more about you." This does not mean it should be gimmicky. Attempting humour may show you don't take the job seriously, while the current trend for adding a photograph or a paragraph of what you hope is elegant prose at the top -"who I am, what are my goals" - can be off-putting. Ms Grunfeld also advises that you shouldn't worry too much about keeping personal details such as age, marital status and parental responsibilities to yourself, if only because they are bound to find out sooner or later. "And if their only interest is in getting more out of you for less money, then you have to ask if you really want to work for these people."

webTitle: Leader: Postponement of election will not serve national interest

fields.headline: Yes, it must be May 3
fields.standfirst: Delay will not serve the national interest
fields.trailText: If the prime minister has learned nothing else from the foot and mouth crisis, perhaps the latest twist might have taught him a useful lesson: keep mum whenever a camera is around.
fields.body:
If the prime minister has learned nothing else from the foot and mouth crisis, perhaps the latest twist might have taught him a useful lesson: keep mum whenever a camera is around.

Yesterday the PM was engaged in agreeable pre-summit chit-chat in Stockholm with his Irish counterpart, Bertie Ahern, and the president of the European commission, Romano Prodi. As the three men small-talked, a TV cameraman hovered, gathering the usual "wallpaper" shots that are seen, but rarely heard, on the evening news. This time, however, the camera's microphone picked up more than the usual low hubbub of clinking glasses. It caught Mr Prodi asking the PM how long he had left before he must decide the date for the election. The Italian guessed about a month. "Ten days," came back the exasperated reply, in a voice that said, "Now do you see the pressure I'm under?" Mr Prodi rocked back on his heels and, in perfect English idiom, said "No kidding."

The fact that Mr Blair's candid admission came less than an hour after his official spokesman had told reporters the PM was not "remotely" interested in election timing - only the media and the Tories discussed such trifles, he said - added to the embarrassment of the episode. But it also confirmed what many had already suspected: that Downing Street is racked by its dilemma over when to call the general election. That anxiety deepened yesterday when the government's own panel of epidemiologists warned that, on current trends, foot and mouth will soon be a massive epidemic, with the current 500 cases becoming 4,000 by June. The original line from Number 10 - that everything is under control with no need to change plans - seemed to be eroding.

The shape of the dilemma will be very clear in Mr Blair's mind this weekend. He will have heard the case for delay from Conservatives, farmers and their supporters in the press. They insist that, with the countryside paralysed by foot and mouth, to call a general election for May 3 would be to disenfranchise rural voters. Their movement would be restricted, barring them from the town meetings and village square hustings that are the heart of any campaign. Even turning up at a polling station would be impossible for men and women confined to their farms, say the delay camp.

Beyond the humdrum matter of logistics, there is the less definable question of national mood. The country is in bleak spirit, distressed by the sight of funeral pyres and mass animal slaughter. To call an election now would be like holding a knees-up 24 hours after a death in the family: it would be unseemly. Besides, as Hugo Young has argued on these pages, elections are more than mechanical exercises aimed at replacing MPs and ministers. An election should be a national jamboree, a celebration of democracy. If Mr Blair were to call one now, it would be a sombre affair, depriving the nation of the right to enjoy its moment of decision. Only narrow party interest and a determination to cash in on Labour's current poll lead would compel Mr Blair to go to the country now - a full year before he must.

These are substantial arguments, but they should not prevail. As we have set out before, the logistical objections soon melt away. Movement is not as severely restricted as the TV pictures suggest: rural schools, which double as polling stations, are still open. People can still get about. Most campaigning these days is not on the village green but on TV and radio and, where necessary, voting can be done by post. As for the matter of self-interest, this argument can be turned on its head. For calling an election now would not be in any party leader's interest. For one thing, there is bound to be a rural backlash, which could hurt Labour in the 120-odd rural seats it won in 1997. Those who say the mood is sombre are right. But that, too, would cost Mr Blair, depriving him of the emotional lift of a fresh mandate granted from a cheerful, hopeful nation. An election victory against the backdrop of foot and mouth will not be the festive, confirming moment of Labour dreams.

So it would not be self-interested to call a May 3 election. But Mr Blair should do it all the same - in the national interest. For one thing, a postponement will be seen worldwide as a declaration that Britain is in crisis; tourism would suffer even more than it is doing already. More seriously, all this speculation about timing is hobbling the government, weakening its authority - turning it into an administration effectively at the end of its term even though there is one more year left to run.

The foot and mouth outbreak requires a government with strength; so too does the coming recession, now being shaped in the United States and Japan. Labour cannot lead if it is constantly fending off questions about dates with destiny. Mr Blair should nerve himself for the wave of abuse that will surely follow, but do the brave thing all the same. Call it for May 3.

fields.headline: Blair's election countdown
fields.standfirst:
 PM lets slip 10-day deadline  Scientists say foot and mouth out of control

Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: Tony Blair yesterday let slip that he will decide within 10 days whether to call a May 3 general election amid scientists' warnings that the foot and mouth epidemic is spiralling out of control.
fields.byline: Lucy Ward, Anne Perkins, James Meek, John Vidal, and Ian Black  in Stockholm
fields.body:
Tony Blair yesterday let slip that he will decide within 10 days whether to call a May 3 general election amid scientists' warnings that the foot and mouth epidemic is spiralling out of control.

As Downing Street was insisting that the prime minister was focusing fully on tackling the crisis, Mr Blair was caught on camera at the European Union economic summit in Stockholm revealing his self-imposed deadline to EU commission president Romano Prodi.

The remarks further fuelled controversy over whether the government should go to the country in the midst of the epidemic.

One team of scientists yesterday forecast an eventual high of more than 4,400 cases - almost twice as many as the 1967-8 outbreak, while another team warned that the whole country could be affected. All three teams reporting on the outbreak agreed that existing measures were failing to cope.

As Mr Blair acknowledged that eliminating the disease would be "a long haul", the agriculture minister, Nick Brown, gave the clearest signs yet that the government is about to order a limited livestock vaccination programme.

Mr Blair's comments, made while he was unaware that he was being filmed, came in response to a question from Mr Prodi over how long the prime minister had before deciding whether to go to the country on May 3.

His reply - "10 days" - which he confirmed publicly later, prompted fresh pressure from the Conservatives over election speculation.

The party called for the setting up of a crisis cabinet along the lines of a war cabinet, in which the prime minister would chair daily meetings of key ministers.

Tory chairman Michael Ancram said: "Once again he has shown his contempt for the British people. Mr Blair doesn't have to hold an election for another year, yet he is already telling Mr Prodi that he has 10 days to call an election.

"This is despite the fact that the countryside and the rural economy is being devastated by foot and mouth."

A survey carried out in Mr Blair's Sedgefield constituency by the Northern Echo newspaper showed more than half the voters were against a May 3 poll.

The severity of yesterday's scientific forecasts prompted new questions within Labour ranks over the likelihood of a May 3 general election, though insiders still indicated that Mr Blair would go to the country then, as planned. Some sources suggested that an escalation of the crisis in fact made a deferred date less likely, since the epidemic was expected to continue for months.

In Stockholm, Mr Blair told reporters: "There comes a point in time when you have to decide whether the election date of May 3 can go ahead or not. We will have to look at that at a later date. For the moment the important thing is to get on with the job in hand."

Scientists yesterday said the government should cut down the delay between the discovery of infection and slaughter, and increase culls of uninfected animals at risk.

But Mr Brown made clear that he was also considering vaccination. Inoculation would be an alternative to logistically difficult mass "firebreak" culls of healthy animals close to infected farms. But it would close the door on British meat and livestock exports, worth an annual £570m, for anything from three months to two years.

"I think it would be reasonable for me to consider use of the vaccine in specific local circumstances, to damp down the epidemic and act as part of the firebreak strategy," said Mr Brown. "Essentially, it could serve as a route to buy time, so some animals are 'on hold,' while others are being culled."

He held out the possibility of a long-term division of Britain into infected and disease-free regions, with East Anglia and northern Scotland, for instance, applying for European permission to restart exports of meat and livestock while other areas were still off limits.

The epidemic had already cost the government £460m, Mr Brown said - much of it compensation, but including £40m for disinfectant.

France and Finland were the first to respond to a direct appeal from Mr Blair in Stockholm for badly needed veterinary expertise.

The army also confirmed that it had identified three disused airfields where slaughtered animals could be taken and burnt.

webTitle: Raising the standard for an army of borrowers

fields.headline: Raising the standard for an army of borrowers
fields.standfirst: A staggering number of people who have been excluded from improved home loan deals by the Halifax and Nationwide have contacted us, as Patrick Collinson reports.
fields.trailText: A staggering number of people who have been excluded from improved home loan deals by the Halifax and Nationwide have contacted us, as Patrick Collinson reports.
fields.body:
The Office of Fair Trading and the banking ombudsman both confirmed this week that they are examining complaints from a growing number of Halifax and Nationwide mortgage holders angry at their exclusion from the lenders' new standard variable rates (SVR).

In one of the biggest postbags received at Jobs & Money for some time, readers have bombarded us with letters and emails expressing their frustration with Halifax and Nationwide, after an article last week alleging "double standards" at the lenders. Over the next three pages we highlight some of the letters, plus (opposite) the formal response from the two lenders to some of the correspondence.

At issue is the much-trumpeted interest rate cuts by the lenders; Nationwide introduced a new 6.49% "base mortgage rate" and then the following day Halifax cut its rate by 0.75% to 6.75%. Hun dreds of thousands of borrowers have benefited, in a move that has cost the lenders around £300-400m.

But both lenders decided to keep their many borrowers (300,000 in the case of Nationwide) who have discount and capped mortgages on the "old" SVR. The result has been an explosion in anger, with many alleging that the lenders have breached contract terms which promised that their discounts would be tied to the SVR.

It also emerged this week that 30,000 homeowners who took out loans through Halifax's broker subsidiary, Halifax Mortgage Services Limited (HMSL), will not see any of the benefit from Halifax's rate cut. Like Anne Rannie from Edinburgh, featured overleaf, many will have taken out a mortgage with documents "plastered" with the Halifax logo.

But last year Halifax reversed HMSL into another one of its subsidiaries, the former building society Birmingham Midshires. Callers to Halifax are told that, no matter the origin of the loan or the logo on their documents, their mortgages are now with Birmingham Midshires - Midshires is maintaining its SVR at 7.5% compared to Halifax's new SVR of 6.75%.

Halifax spokeswoman Alison Kellington says: "Many HMSL mortgages were inherited when we bought BNP Mortgages or they have come to Halifax through brokers. It has always been made clear that although HMSL is a subsidiary of Halifax, it has had its own products and distinct terms and conditions. At no time could you have bought such products from a Halifax branch. In any case, most of the 30,000 are on special deals at rates below 6.75%."

Nonetheless, the OFT and the banking ombudsman are now planning to cast their eyes over the Halifax and Nationwide contracts. An OFT spokesman said: "We have had quite a few complaints from borrowers about this matter. There are questions of fairness that need to be looked at." The OFT is likely to focus on the interpretation of what "standard variable rate" means. Another reader featured overleaf, Peter Davies of London, claims he has already established from the OFT that SVR means "openly marketed competitive rate". If so, then borrowers with contracts which promise a discount from the SVR should be able to have that discount applied to the new SVR. However, the OFT declined to comment on the interpretation to Jobs & Money.

The banking ombudsman also confirmed that it has already begun to receive complaints in the form of "deadlock" letters which have to be issued by the lender before a borrower can take their case to the ombudsman. Judging from the number of letters to Jobs & Money threatening to go to the ombudsman, its case load is about to increase rapidly. However, a spokeswoman for the ombudsman says the average case takes six months before it reaches adjudication. But unlike the OFT, the ombudsman can force lenders to make direct compensation payments of up to £100,000. The banking ombudsman, which says it would need to see mortgage offer letters plus the terms and conditions, can be contacted at PO Box 4, South Quay Plaza, 183 Marsh Wall, London, E14 9SR. Its consumer helpline is 0845 766 0902.

Nationwide may also face challenges in other forms. Unlike Halifax, Nationwide is a mutual which is owned by its members - and is currently facing yet another attack from carpetbaggers. Many readers who contacted us this week said the move had betrayed their trust in mutuality and that they would now be voting in favour of the carpetbaggers.

One or two readers are even considering legal challenges against the lenders based on contract law, and have asked us to print their email addresses overleaf to mount a joint action.

What the Halifax says

Halifax's new variable base rate of 6.75% is available to all customers, but has immediate relevance to those existing customers who are paying the standard variable rate of 7.5% and those applying for new mortgages.

The vast majority of our mortgage customers who are already on special deals are paying at a rate below the new variable rate. There is no immediate need for these customers to transfer to the new rate as this would mean they would lose out financially. Once their special deal comes to an end they will be helped to move over to the new rate, which includes daily interest, the fairest method of mortgage calculation.

As with all lenders who have followed our move to narrow the gap between new and existing customers, existing special deals, such as capped or discounted rates linked to the standard variable rate, will remain in place until the deal comes to an end. Halifax's standard variable rate will mirror any rate changes to the new Halifax variable base rate.

Halifax is the only lender to provide customers who are currently in an extended repayment period with the flexibility to move to the lower variable base rate immediately, and take their 'repayment' fee with them. All these customers have to do is telephone their local Halifax branch.

The new Halifax variable base rate does not apply to Halifax Mortgage Services Limited (HMSL) customers. This mortgage book was acquired from BNP and it has always offered its own branded products sold through selected intermediaries. Interest rates have always been set independently from the Halifax and customers have separate terms and conditions.

HMSL is now part of Birmingham Midshires, the specialist mortgage lending arm of the Halifax.

Halifax says it believes that two of the readers featured overleaf may have misunderstood or been misinformed and that they may qualify for a switch to the new standard variable rate. For more information about its new variable rate, Halifax can be contacted on 08456 00 10 00. Local branch numbers can be found on Halifax.

fields.headline: Sycamore House, Cambridge
fields.standfirst: Matthew Fort finds home comforts at Sycamore House
fields.trailText: Matthew Fort finds home comforts at Sycamore House.
fields.body:
It was like going into someone's home. Come to think of it, Sycamore House, quietly resting beside a quiet street in the quiet village of Little Shelford just outside Cambridge, probably is someone's home. A nice home, too, though there's nothing particularly special about it; nothing to attract the eye of a Pevsner, say, or a Meades. It's decent, trim, almost handsome, in a modest kind of way, and it is the domain of Michael and Susan Sharpe - he cooks, she looks after you.

She looked after Humphrey and me with the pleasantness of true hospitality. There was nothing showy in the performance - if anything, it was a bit understated - but we felt in good, kindly hands. Then again, there's nothing really showy about Sycamore House, unless you count the wine list. It is a long, long time since I've come across one that is so stuffed with goodies and at prices that even your local wine shop would be hard to match. Humphrey and I made do with a bottle of Les Fiefs de Lagrange 1996, the second wine from the impeccable Chteau Lagrange, which was the knockout drop I knew it to be and, at all of £22, well, almost a giveaway.

Sycamore House's menu itself does not rhapsodise or indulge in menu poetry. It is penny-plain. Four first courses - onion tart with olive pastry, sweet potato, leek and chickpea soup, that kind of thing. Four main courses along such lines as roast fillet of cod with a herb crust, and grilled fillet steak with melted Cashel Blue. And a salad course in between. Not to mention a pudding or two to close. The nearest thing to a theatrical flourish were the roasted pigeon breasts, which were "flamed in Armagnac" before being placed on a blackcurrant and orange sauce.

Now, this may not be the stuff of romance, exactly, or dishes to set the pulses racing, but to my eye there is a quiet, insistent edibility to them. So we set out to eat them: Humphrey steamed spicy chicken with lemon and chive dressing and, as back-up, the fillet steak and melted Cashel Blue; I for the onion tart with olive pastry and then the pigeon breasts.

The steamed chicken was something of a surprise. What arrived were balls of chicken, indubitably steamed, incontrovertibly spicy, but more chicken cakes in the mould of fishcakes than what had been expected. After the initial shock, however, Humphrey declared himself rather pleased: a touch on the solid side, he said, but they tasted of real chicken and the fillip of chilli was grand, as was the rocket salad.

Which it was, because I had one, too, to go with my onion tart, which also had a surprise tucked up its sleeve: it was cold. I think it would have been even better hot, as this would have brought out the melting sweetness of the onions even more, and also suited the olive pastry, which was shorter than a guardsman's haircut. But never mind: had my last attempt at onion tart turned out half so well I would have been well chuffed.

Then, after a pause for an obligatory salad to give the kitchen breathing space, along came my pigeon breasts, grouped on a plate with artless sincerity. They must have come from a mighty-bosomed bird, and not one of the hand-reared squab variety, because the meat was too dark for that. And they had none of the rank chewiness of poorly cooked wild ones, the cooking being as pure as the provenance, because they had a firm but acquiescent texture and a full but well-mannered flavour. In other words, this was another case of first-rate raw materials being treated with admirable simplicity. I was not sure about the Armagnac, but the blackcurrant and orange sauce was judicious.

Humphrey's steak was presented with a similar lack of visual razzle-dazzle, but benefited from Mr Sharpe's superlative supply line. On the whole, I am a sirloin man - too often, the look of a fillet steak proves more substantial than its flavour. But not those served at Sycamore House. I was not quite convinced by the thatch of Cashel Blue, but there could be no quibbling with the pedigree and potency of the protein underneath. It was a tremendous piece of meat, and cooked to a juicy nicety.

So we came to some tip-top cheese for Humphrey and to Toblerone ice cream in a brandy-snap basket for me. I have thought long and hard about the ice cream, and it seems to me to be, in a kind of way, emblematic of Sycamore House's style. It was terribly toothsome, not too sweet, with those nice little chippy bits of chocolate with those chippy bits of honey inside. But really, it's a dinner party dish, a Delia dish, or maybe a Jamie dish, if you see what I mean, and that's what the food at Sycamore House is like: domestic dishes cooked by an unusually competent home chef with a true passion for food. I don't say this by way of criticism, because I have eaten in a great many restaurants of greater pretension and less achievement. No, I am only trying to pin down the exact nature of the pleasure that eating there gave me.

And the pleasure was considerable, from which the bill did not detract: £73, or two meals at £23.50 each, a bottle of water at £2, the £22 wine and £2 for coffee. A fair price for a fair place

webTitle: US told to make China its No 1 enemy

fields.headline: US told to make China its No 1 enemy
fields.standfirst:
US told to target China

Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: A historic shift of emphasis in United States military deployment from Europe to Asia, with China supplanting Russia as America's principal foe, is at the heart of the Bush administration's long awaited defence strategy review, according to reports in Washington.
fields.body:
A historic shift of emphasis in United States military deployment from Europe to Asia, with China supplanting Russia as America's principal foe, is at the heart of the Bush administration's long awaited defence strategy review, according to reports in Washington.

Outlines of the potentially epochal rethink of the US's global strategic priorities were given to President George Bush by his defence secretary Donald Rumsfeld at a private meeting at the White House on Wednesday, the Washington Post reported yesterday.

"The president was complimentary, he appreciated the policy discussion, and gave the indication that the topics were indeed what he had in mind," a Pentagon official told the paper.

More than 50 years after the struggle to deter the Soviet Union in Europe became the centrepiece of US military strategy in the aftermath of the second world war, the Rumsfeld review has concluded that the Pacific Ocean should now become the most important focus of US military deployments, with China now perceived as the principal threat to American global dominance.

The review says, in effect, that Washington should abandon the long-standing doctrine that the US military must always be prepared to fight two major world conflicts simultaneously, the reports quote officials as saying.

By elevating China to the status of global enemy number one, the review clearly foreshadows an American turn away from Europe, or at least from the levels of US engagement and attention which have existed for the lifetime of most Europeans.

Mr Bush ordered the strategy review immediately on taking office. It is the most important of three complementary reviews intended to shape US military priorities in the 21st century. The other two are on nuclear weapons and missile defence options, and on service pay and conditions.

The huge distances involved in the Pacific mean that the Pentagon must give additional priority to "long-range power projection", the report says.

This means putting fresh resources into airlift capacity to enable the US to move troops, vehicles and weapons many thousands of miles from bases in America to the frontline in Asia at short notice.

The report says the threat from hostile missiles is likely to become so serious that the US can no longer afford to risk its largest and most expensive ships, the Nimitz class aircraft carriers, in forward positions. As a result, the navy will be told to stop building big ships and to concentrate on speed and manoeuvrability, including a new generation of smaller carriers, to avoid them becoming targets.

The threat from weapons of mass destruction, such as nuclear, chemical and biological weapons, against American military targets means that US allies may begin to question the advisability of allowing Washington to have bases in their countries, the Pentagon suggests. The report says this is another reason why long-range supply capacity needs to be increased.

The review does not make recommendations about particular weapons systems, but there is no doubt in Washington that missile defence shields will form a central part of the new strategy.

Other key elements of what would be, in effect, a rearming of the US military are likely to include a greater role for long-range bombers and for unmanned aircraft. The F-22 fighter programme is likely to face cutbacks, though there is speculation that it will not be scrapped.

The sweep of the review is so comprehensive and its conclusions so radical that the publication of the final report later this year is likely to set off a whole series of turf wars within the US military, as the armed services scrabble for influence and funding in the new era.

Washington's decision to turn more of its guns and missiles towards China came as it was confirmed that a senior colonel in the Chinese people's liberation army has defected to the US while visiting as part of a military delegation. The defection, which apparently took place at the end of last year or in January, involved an unnamed officer in the foreign affairs department of the army general staff.

fields.headline: Much of the old incentive to serve has gone
fields.standfirst: Council houses loss will leave big hole
fields.trailText: Council houses loss will leave big hole
fields.body:
New Labour came to power determined to make radical changes in both the powers and structure of local government. Hilary Armstrong, the local government minister and a member of the party's national executive when the reforms were devised, says that the policymakers set out to remedy two separate but related problems. "Councils were becoming more and more irrelevant as they were bypassed by the Tories." And their "poor quality" produced an "inadequate delivery of services".

So there was a real desire to rehabilitate, as well as to improve, the town and county halls. But Labour's reputation was suffering from "the continuing bashing of councils" by the Conservative government. Ms Armstrong's judgment on the esteem in which local government is held is confirmed by the polls which Kent, like other major authorities, regularly conducts. They show that, although the services which councils provide are highly valued, the councils themselves are regarded with very little respect. Reinstating their old powers would have provoked the allegation that the party of moderation and probity was encouraging municipal extremists who subsidised their wild habits by claiming expenses for civic trips to exotic locations. Rehabilitation and change had to go hand in hand.

A new council constitution was devised which, it was hoped, would reconnect local government to the people it aimed to serve and by encouraging real democracy guarantee both popularity and efficiency. It required councillors to work more closely with community leaders and regularly consult the communities themselves. The popular will was to be efficiently implemented by a system which, instead of wasting time on endless committee meetings, defined what Ms Armstrong called, "clear aims and objectives" and put in place "mechanisms both for achieving them and scrutinising the efficiency with which they are delivered". Cabinets - some of them led by elected mayors - were to become the executive branch of local government. Councillors who were not included in the inner circle would "probe" the cabinets' decisions and "guarantee that the services were being delivered effectively".

The problem, for Ms Armstrong and her government, is that most councillors do not believe that the municipal future will be improved by the separation of powers. Council leaders love the cabinet system. But the rank-and-file - both opposition members and majority group "backbenchers" - say the new efficiency is just an acceptable way of describing the democracy bypass.

The cynicism of the excluded majority is increased by Whitehall's silence on the subject of local government reorganisation. Real efficiency and genuine accountability require unitary authorities. In the two-tier system most voters do not know where the county's powers begin and the borough's end. Ms Armstrong "accepts the logic" of abolishing the counties, but a battle with the shires is not to New Labour's taste.

Ms Armstrong also accepts that, despite the reforms, the party caucus still dominates a handful of councils. "That", she says, "is because we have not changed the culture of many of our councils." Perhaps so. But culture takes time to change. And before the adjustment is made there is not much incentive to sacrifice family and job prospects for the privilege of "probing" a council's cabinet. It does not compare, in interest or esteem, with running schools or managing a town's housing estate.

Yet the government has explicitly excluded local authorities from the control of education, and hard economic reality is forcing the sale of municipal housing. Much of the old incentive to serve has gone. It is hard to imagine that the reforms will attract many men and women of conspicuous talent apart from a handful of potential full-time town and county managers. Local government - for better or worse - is about to become a career rather than a public service.

A s things stand, even the professional managers will be deeply frustrated by the limitations which are placed on their freedom to manage. Hilary Armstrong concedes that "there is too much ring fencing". The notion that councils should only receive government grants in return for the performance of specific tasks is as old as the Public Health Act of 1875. But over the years the demands have grown more detailed, without a clearly defined purpose.

If the rules, tests and checks are intended to guarantee the local implementation of national policy, councils have become no more than agents of central government. The alternative explanation is that the injunctions and interdicts are necessary to prevent councils from squandering still scarce resources. But the age of local government extravagance is past. In that one particular, the culture has already changed. Whitehall still possesses powers to "cap" unreasonable increases in council tax. But it is years since ministers thought it necessary to use them. Councillors dismiss the claims that the regulations are intended to ensure efficiency and argue that excessive controls are inhibiting, rather than enhancing, the effective provision of services.

The problems of bureaucracy and flexibility explode into a budget crisis when new regulations increase local authorities' responsibilities - either setting new tasks or improving the standards at which the old ones must be performed - without providing the extra funds to finance the extra duties.

Peter Gilroy, of Kent, quotes the local government association's judgment on a whole financial year. There is a national overspend on social services of £205m. It represents inadequate government funding, not unacceptable local extravagance. Often, when councils fail to live up to the government's expectation, it is because they cannot afford to improve.

Nor can many boroughs afford to maintain the service which has been at the heart of local government since Disraeli's Artisans Dwelling Act. The reduction in municipal housing is largely the result of increased prosperity. But Ms Armstrong and Albert Bore, leader of Birmingham council, believe that there is no immediate hope of removing "the stigma of council tenancy". Both realise that to end that it is necessary to spend millions of pounds on improvements.

Improvement in the quality of council housing requires the estates to be separated from the general control of the councils which now own them. The repairs and renovations have to be financed by borrowing money against the actual property. That is not possible while they are just another division of the local authority with their mortgageable assets lumped in with the other council property. So most council houses will change ownership over the next half dozen years because of necessity rather than ideology. It will leave a big hole in the municipal policy agenda.

All the signs are that it will be filled with the idea of the moment, urban regeneration - a policy which councils can pursue under the legal umbrella of their new duty to promote "economic, social and environmental well-being". When Hilary Armstrong told Sandy Bruce-Lockhart (the leader of Kent county council) the phrase must be interpreted "in the head of the beholder", she was doing more than pay homage to local autonomy. The government is not certain how far down the commercial road councils can go without the courts - English and European - ruling that they are acting ultra vires. Councils will be expected to see how far they can extend their frontiers into ground previously occupied by private developers.

So far they have played safe by pursuing partnership arrangements. But if Michael Lyons, Birmingham's chief executive, is to be believed, when the new reforms are implemented and all the big cities have directly elected executive mayors, the major boroughs will "score more highly as businesses than as democratic institutions". The risk will then be that councils will become more concerned with commerce than welfare, particularly if the executive mayors have no party allegiance. It is unlikely a municipal business would accept Joe Chamberlain's aim for local government - "equalising the condition of men and limiting the extremes which now form such a blot on our social system".

The leaders of Birmingham and Preston councils will both argue that their regeneration plans have a direct social objective. Councils still think of themselves as agencies of social welfare. But for how long?

The chilling commercial language used by Kent's social services director to describe the purchase of home care - combined with the gap of £206m between what the government calculates needs to be spent on welfare and the funds it makes available - shows that the new culture will have a harder edge. Since most welfare services seem likely to be bought for private agencies, there will be very little incentive to become councillors in the hope of directly removing the "blots for a social system". Local government may only attract men and women with an enthusiasm for procurement and accountancy.

To describe a change is not, necessarily, to condemn it. Society has moved on and local government must move with it. But the Civil Gospel, as preached by Joe Chamberlain, is dying. The hopes and ideas of men and women who wanted to clear the slums, clean the air, improve the schools and care for the sick cannot be realised by councils acting as agents for the government and employing outside contractors. It is hard to imagine a modern Joe Chamberlain believing that it is a "sorry exchange to give up the council chamber for the cabinet".

It represents inadequate government funding, not unacceptable local extravagance. Often, when councils fail to live up to the government's expectation, it is because they cannot afford to improve. Nor can many boroughs afford to maintain the service which has been at the heart of local government since Disraeli's Artisans Dwelling Act. The reduction in municipal housing is largely the result of increased prosperity. But Ms Armstrong and Albert Bore, leader of Birmingham council, believe that there is no immediate hope of removing "the stigma of council tenancy". Both realise that to end that it is necessary to spend millions of pounds on improvements. Improvement in the quality of council housing requires the estates to be separated from the general control of the councils which now own them. The repairs and renovations have to be financed by borrowing money against the actual property. That is not possible while they are just another division of the local authority with their mortgageable assets lumped in with the other council property. So most council houses will change ownership over the next half dozen years because of necessity rather than ideology. It will leave a big hole in the municipal policy agenda. All the signs are that it will be filled with the idea of the moment, urban regeneration - a policy which councils can pursue under the legal umbrella of their new duty to promote "economic, social and environmental well-being". When Hilary Armstrong told Sandy Bruce-Lockhart (the leader of Kent county council) the phrase must be interpreted "in the head of the beholder", she was doing more than pay homage to local autonomy. The government is not certain how far down the commercial road councils can go without the courts - English and European - ruling that they are acting ultra vires. Councils will be expected to see how far they can extend their frontiers into ground previously occupied by private developers. So far they have played safe by pursuing partnership arrangements. But if Michael Lyons, Birmingham's chief executive, is to be believed, when the new reforms are implemented and all the big cities have directly elected executive mayors, the major boroughs will "score more highly as businesses than as democratic institutions". The risk will then be that councils will become more concerned with commerce than welfare, particularly if the executive mayors have no party allegiance. It is unlikely a municipal business would accept Joe Chamberlain's aim for local government - "equalising the condition of men and limiting the extremes which now form such a blot on our social system". The leaders of Birmingham and Preston councils will both argue that their regeneration plans have a direct social objective. Councils still think of themselves as agencies of social welfare. But for how long? The chilling commercial language used by Kent's social services director to describe the purchase of home care - combined with the gap of £206m between what the government calculates needs to be spent on welfare and the funds it makes available - shows that the new culture will have a harder edge. Since most welfare services seem likely to be bought for private agencies, there will be very little incentive to become councillors in the hope of directly removing the "blots for a social system". Local government may only attract men and women with an enthusiasm for procurement and accountancy. To describe a change is not, necessarily, to condemn it. Society has moved on and local government must move with it. But the Civil Gospel, as preached by Joe Chamberlain, is dying. The hopes and ideas of men and women who wanted to clear the slums, clean the air, improve the schools and care for the sick cannot be realised by councils acting as agents for the government and employing outside contractors. It is hard to imagine a modern Joe Chamberlain believing that it is a "sorry exchange to give up the council chamber for the cabinet".

fields.headline: Safety net for chat rooms
fields.standfirst: New guidelines should help teachers and parents protect children from predators who stalk the web.  Hazel Southam  reports
fields.trailText: New guidelines should help teachers and parents protect children from predators who stalk the web. Hazel Southam reports
fields.body:
It's been a big week for internet safety. On Tuesday, the Home Office's internet crime forum published Chat Wise, Street Wise, a report highlighting the dangers posed to young people using chat rooms. And industry insiders report that the government is set to announce a spring internet safety summit.

But from today, chat rooms will be safer. At least, they will be if you follow an eight-point guideline issued by the Department for Education and Employment.

The new guidelines, written for the DfEE by the internet safety agency, Childnet International, are aimed at parents and teachers, but also send a message to the industry.

They recommend that children only use chat rooms that are moderated by a known moderator. They highlight the use of rooms that have topics advertised in advance, as the BBC does. And they warn against the use of rooms with advertising or other links that can draw children away from a group environment.

Safety is at the top of the list with checks for safety issues and password verification so that adults cannot pose as children.

One in five children who use computer chat rooms have been approached by paedophiles, according to the head of the internet crime forum. Detective chief superintendent Keith Akerman said: "There is clearly a problem out there of which parents are not yet fully aware. The aim of this report is to highlight the dangers and suggest ways the risk can be reduced."

But not all chat rooms are dangerous places, are they? Many are simply full of kids talking about their favourite bands and TV soap stars?

"If a parent went into a chat room, they might think it's harmless fun," says Stephen Carrick-Davies, of Childnet International, who wrote today's guide. "It's a good way to relax and have fun. We don't say that chat rooms should be shut down. They are here to stay and they have good educational opportunities.

"But the key thing that parents need to be aware of is that children have to lie to get online. It only works by giving an alias."

This means that people can pose as anyone else. I could call myself Bugs Bunny in a chat room. The potential for disaster is becoming clearer.

According to an NOP poll last November, almost 5m seven-to-16-year-olds in the UK use the internet and a quarter of those use chat rooms. But 10% have heard things in these rooms that embarrassed or upset them.

The main danger is that an adult may try to develop an inappropriate relationship offline with a child.

Last October, Patrick Green, 33, a divorced exports clerk from Iver Heath in Buckinghamshire, was sentenced to a five-year jail term for abusing a 13-year-old girl. He had met her in a chat room called Younger Girls for Older Men and exchanged messages with her for two months before meeting her.

He was arrested in Cumbria on his way to meet another 14-year-old girl he had met online and arranged to spend a weekend with. Judge Christopher Tyrer described him as a "predator" and ordered him to remain on the sex offenders' register for life.

Childnet is now lobbying the government to make enticement on the internet a recognised crime.

Last month, seven members of a global child pornography ring were jailed for distributing more than 750,000 images of child sex abuse. The club, which police believe had been operating for at least five years, required new members to provide 10,000 new images of child pornography as an entry fee.

The Wonderland Club involved the rape of boys and girls live on camera and the torture of children as young as two months. The images were so appalling that the National Crime Squad officers who had to look through them had compulsory counselling. To date, only two of the 1,236 Wonderland victims have been traced. It is feared that one of the two has been murdered.

Police and probation officers now fear that a wave of internet porn is sweeping the country, encouraged by light sentencing, some as lenient as 80 hours' community service. A financial adviser earning £100,000 a year recently received a three month prison sentence when police discovered that he often spent 18 hours a day downloading obscene images from the net.

But, says Carrick-Davies, the guidelines are not a knee-jerk reaction. "There are wonderful things that children can pick up in chat rooms. It introduces them to other cultures. However, we need to put the dangers in context.

"We are not saying the internet is evil and we must shut it down. We want to portray the brighter things but we want to say there is a dark side and these are the types of steps you can take to ensure that your children are really safe."

The guidelines

1. Is the chat room moderated?

2. Who are the moderators?

3. Has the chat room got a clear terms and conditions policy?

4. Does the chat room have a clear topic/subject timetable?

5. Does the chat room have advertising or external links?

6. Does the chat room give young people genuine opportunities for students to interact and shape the chat?

7. Does the chat room have appropriate access control and password verification? Can anyone join?

8. Does the chat room remind users about safety issues?

webTitle: Political editor who quit Express dies

fields.headline: Political editor who quit Express dies
fields.trailText: The political journalist, Anthony Bevins, who resigned from the Daily Express after it was taken over by Richard Desmond, died yesterday, writes Michael White.
fields.body:
The political journalist, Anthony Bevins, who resigned from the Daily Express after it was taken over by Richard Desmond, died yesterday after contracting a virulent form of pneumonia which had left him unconscious for most of the past week.

Mr Bevins remained unaware that his wife, Mishtu, who had flown from the US to be with him at Wexham Park hospital in Slough, was also taken ill and died in the same hospital on Wednesday. The couple had two adult children and lived in Cookham, Berkshire.

Mr Bevins was the son of Reg Bevins, the virtually token working-class minister in the patrician Conservative government of Harold Macmillan (1957-63) and later the author of an outspoken autobiography, The Greasy Pole, on his experiences with his party. His son, a fiercely independent reporter, inherited those instincts.

At the time of his death Mr Bevins, aged 58, was freelancing after spending 30 years working as a Westminster lobby correspondent for five national daily newspapers, as well as the Observer in the late 1990s. On all of them he dealt with colleagues and editors in the same uncompromising way that he dealt with politicians of all parties, promoting what he regarded as the real issues of the day, often retrieved from his own extensive reading of official documents. That won him both enemies and intensely loyal friends among journalists and politicians. Andrew Marr, now political editor of the BBC, was one of his proteges. "He was a very straight man," one leftwing Labour MP said last night.

A graduate of the London School of Economics, Bevins started work in his home city, Liverpool, where his father had been a MP. But he moved to Fleet Street, initially working for the Sun. Over the years he was also a political journalist on the Daily Mail, the Times, the Independent - which he joined at its inception - the Observer and, latterly, the Express where he was political editor.

webTitle: Farming what is it good for?

fields.headline: Farming what is it good for?
fields.trailText: David Cox (News, last week) courageously dares to express what most of us who live in the countryside, and who are not farmers, have been disputing for many years.
fields.body:
David Cox (News, last week) courageously dares to express what most of us who live in the countryside, and who are not farmers, have been disputing for many years. We are tired of being held to ransom by an industry so in decline and one that the majority of citizens no longer want to support. Traditional farming is finished and it is time to realise the future and release the past.
Tony Brown
Falmouth, Cornwall

Why should farmers be treated so differently from other people who live, work or wish to visit the countryside? Thousands of businesses, from pubs to B&Bs, are losing money hand over fist with no chance of compensation and many of them will go broke. All this, mainly due to the fact that walkers have been denied their rightful access to public footpaths. No walkers, no profits. Although I reluctantly agreed with the Government's actions at the beginning of the crisis, it is clear that their tactics are not working. It's time to stop compensating one small group of workers at the expense of everyone else!
David Stanton
Lea, Derbyshire

No doubt the position of farming has something to do with the effective lobbying of the NFU in times of crisis; it cannot possibly be because agriculture plays an important role within the economy. Farming contributes 1.5 per cent of gross national product and yet it receives, by way of financial aid, more than all other industries combined. This can only be described as obscene.
D.J. Merrick
Biggleswade, Bedfordshire

While deeply sympathising with the beleaguered farming community, I cannot but wonder whether those farmers who export their animals for slaughter are the same farmers who weep for them now? They cannot be unaware of the unshakeable evidence of the misery endured by these creatures.
Margaret Danks
Droitwich, Worcs

David Cox wants Britain to stop farming and buy in cheap stuff from around the place, as they did from 1850 to 1939. He thinks that was a good time for the countryside. Certainly as a kid in the 1930s I used to love the flapping corrugated iron, the rusting machinery in ditches and the mad-looking people apparently making a living from a few chickens in tumbledown barns.

Of course farming has got to change. But when the ridiculous global finance racket collapses and we're not growing any food, we'll look pretty stupid (not to mention hungry). There'll also be no countryside to tour, because timber merchant David Cox and his friends will have the whole place planted down to sitka spruce, with all the pesticides a monoculture needs. No, farming is what humans have done for the last 10,000 years, and there's too many of us to go back to hunting and gathering.
Robin Oakley-Hill
Sevenoaks, Kent

webTitle: Clearing debts while you're still a young one

fields.headline: Clearing debts while you're still a young one
fields.standfirst: Five-step guide to graduating out of the red
fields.trailText: Five-step guide to graduating out of the red
fields.body:
Money, money, money, might be funny in a rich man's world. But in the world of the debt-laden graduate? Paying back loans and credit card bills is no laughing matter and nine out of ten graduates face financial difficulty according to official figures.

A recent government survey reveals that student debt has trebled since 1995, rising from £777 a year to almost £2,500 per annum. And that's not including extra bank loans, overdrafts, credit cards and store cards.

So, if you're several thousand in the red, how exactly do you start to repay it? And is it possible to escape from debt without being reduced to a social outcast who can only afford to stay at home, existing on TV, own-brand baked beans and one bottle of Blue Nun a week?

It's difficult, make no mistake. But you can claw your way out of debt and still have a life. Just not an extravagant one.

Step one

Admit that you're in a bit of mess, and then figure out just how much of a mess. Collect all your financial details together. Figure out who you owe money to, how much you owe them, and how overdue any of it is.

"This is by far the hardest part," says Graham Duckett, an independent financial adviser with the Millfield Partnership. "Most of us", he continues, "have a tendency to be ostriches. But if you want to regain control of your finances, you have to take your head out of the sand."

Step two

Work out your most important creditors. Sue Edwards, social policy officer at the Citizens Advice Bureau, explains who these are: "Important creditors are the ones who can impose the harshest sanctions on you for not paying. For example, if you don't pay your mortgage or rent, you can be evicted, if you don't pay your council tax, you can be put in prison, and if you don't pay your fuel bills your supply can be cut off. Other creditors, like credit card companies, can only sue you in the county court for non-payment." Oh, so that's all !

Step three

Make your debts easier to pay off. Try renegotiating the payment terms. This is quite possible says Gill Hankey, head of the Bankruptcy Advisory Service.

"If you go to them, creditors are usually quite willing to accommodate you," she says. "It's in their interest to do so."

Also try consolidating your debts. Instead of having several creditors to contend with, some of them applying top whack penalties, it may be more cost-efficient to take out a single loan to pay everyone else off all at once.

And as for credit card debt, look at switching banks. Instead of paying 18 to 20% interest you could be paying nothing under an introductory offer.

As always, shop around for the best deal and read the fine print.

Step four

Take stock of your outgoings. Yes, it sounds boring. Yes, it sounds time consuming. It is. But there is no way round it. "It's just one of those things', say Adrian Moss, managing director of thedeal.net, an online finance service. "You just can't see how to save money unless you first know where you're spending it."

Step five

Tighten your belt. But don't overdo it. It is possible to economise without causing too much discomfort, says Sophie Brooks of the National Debtline.

She insists that you won't have to cut out all of your pleasures, but you will have to trim some of them. And you will have to keep them in trim until you've seen off your creditors.
