webTitle: An ABC guide to following intuition in the office

fields.headline: An ABC guide to following intuition in the office
fields.trailText: Moving on up
fields.body:
A. Trust in me
Dare you do what feels right rather than what you're told? Many working environments discourage such behaviour by providing a procedure for everything. Pre-packaged solutions may not always work, but if you just

follow orders you can be sure of surviving accountability audits. Whether you're prepared to trust your intuition often depends on how much trouble you're going to end up in if things go wrong. A pity - intuitive abilities can really help you cut through the crap.

B. Good sense

Intuition is not guesswork. The ability to make sound judgements without agonising endlessly over every last fact is the result of experience. When something feels right it's because your subconscious has processed the

results of many similar situations and is now providing you with a shortcut.

Don't be discouraged by those who dismiss your insights as illogical. Some situations are immune to seemingly rational approaches. All problems benefit from a combination of the logical and the inspired.

C. Personal development

Doing things right is safe, but doesn't always mean you do the right thing. If you're to flourish in circumstances where there are no guidelines you need to have faith in your ability to evaluate options without a handbook produced by someone in authority. To develop your sixth sense you need to exercise and educate it. That includes making mistakes and learning from them.

webTitle: Help: I really need to get a life!

fields.headline: Help: I really need to get a life!
fields.standfirst: I've never done anything really interesting so have trouble filling in the personal statement sections of applications. Everything I think of sounds pathetic. I'm sure that's why I'm not getting interviews.  TL, final-year student, Leicester
fields.trailText: I've never done anything really interesting so have trouble filling in the personal statement sections of applications. Everything I think of sounds pathetic. I'm sure that's why I'm not getting interviews. TL, final-year student, Leicester
fields.body:
It's not what you do but the way that you tell it. Feeling defeated before you start will show in what you write and will work against you far more than lack of adventure or achievement. It's easy to undervalue seemingly ordinary activities that reveal your strengths and reassure employers you'll fit into their organisation.

If you're into embroidery rather than bungee

jumping, use it to show you're methodical and able to pay attention to detail. Not all employers are impressed by applicants who indulge in death- defying activities -they're thinking of the sick-leave angle.

Don't list your interests; explain their benefits. Instead of sheepishly admitting to collecting stamps, boldly state "my passion for stamps has enabled me to ..."

fields.headline: Sixty seconds in: Pharmacy
fields.standfirst: Nick Trollope, a community-based chemist in Bristol, talks to Miles Brignall
fields.trailText: Nick Trollope, a community-based chemist in Bristol, talks to Miles Brignall
fields.body:
I know everyone always says they are busy, but this morning we dispensed 350 prescriptions and that is fairly typical. The chemist I work for is based within a health centre that includes several doctors, nurses and health visitors and it fits into the Government's plan for one-stop health shops.

In the past, pharmacists tended to just mix up the drugs and hand them out, but today we take a far more proactive approach. The majority of today's medicines are pre-packaged, often in cycles of treatment, and the only things we mix up are children's antibiotic syrups.

This allows us to focus on making sure the patient is getting the correct medicine at the right dose and to counsel them in its use. For example, a diabetic might need talking through some aspect of his medication.

When a patient arrives clutching a prescription there are a set of questions we have to ask to establish that they're getting the right medicine, and if there is any doubt it's referred back to the doctor.

Pharmacists are trained to recognise most minor ailments, and the health authorities and NHS Direct have been keen to encourage those with non-serious problems to go to pharmacists as a first point of contact. To this end we get a steady stream of people asking about everything from spots to pregnancy.

I like the fact that we are part of the health centre and a bigger team. Often a doctor with a query about a particular medicine will call me while the patient sits there in his or her office - it's something I wouldn't get if I were based in a remote shop. I do get out into the wider community to dispense and offer counselling in patients' homes -I'm off to fit a truss straight after this.

Another side of my work is helping local drug addicts. We have a big drugs problem around here and have a scheme to prescribe methadone to heroin addicts. In the past, prescriptions were often taken away and sold on. Now they come into the centre and receive the dose and have to take it on the premises. We've had 45 addicts in today and I'm fine with it - I see it as just another part of my work.

I studied pharmacy at Portsmouth and split my year of clinical practice between working in a hospital in Bury St Edmunds and a drugs company near Thetford. I spent two years in an office in Saudi advising local GPs, and had a spell in a Bath hospital before becoming a community pharmacist in1988.

I don't quite know why I like the job, but I do. I've been here six years now and have become part of the scenery.

webTitle: How to... work nights without losing sleep

fields.headline: How to... work nights without losing sleep
fields.standfirst: Take exercise and steer clear of the coffee maker
fields.trailText: Take exercise and steer clear of the coffee maker Take exercise and steer clear of the coffee maker
fields.body:
Early to bed, early to rise makes a man healthy, wealthy and wise - so said the American philosopher, Benjamin Franklin. If this maxim held true then the growing army of workers who toil through the night would not only be poor, but ill and stupid.

Researchers writing for the British Medical Journal put this hypotheses to the test. With tongues placed firmly in cheeks, the researchers found no evidence to suggest that night owls who go to bed after 11pm and wake up after 8am are poorer than the early birds who get up before 8am and are tucked up in bed by 11pm.

Jesting aside, around 17% of all employees in the UK, some 4.1m people, work shifts be this evenings, nights or weekends. Some industries such as the medical profession and security work have always been associated with shift work, but the advent of 24-hour banking and shopping has led to an increase in the number of people who work shifts.

Unfortunately, our bodies weren't designed to be awake at night and asleep during the day. So how difficult is it for shift workers to adjust to working nights?

According to Simon Folkard, professor of psychology at the University of Wales, Swansea: "People working shifts can make adjustments to ensure that they can cope with working nights, particularly during the early hours of the morning when people are most likely to fall asleep."

He advises: "It's important during these twilight hours at around two or three in the morning for night workers to make sure that they have enough stimulating work to do. Also simple, basic things like not being too warm or comfortable and having plenty of light all help to maintain alertness."

Staying awake and alert is what night workers find most difficult. But relying on stimulants such as caffeine to keep awake is not the answer.

"While it's true that drinking lots of cups of coffee will keep you awake, it will also prevent you from going to sleep in the morning. The key to adjusting to night work is for people to take their time off work seriously; and make sure that they get enough sleep during the day so that they remain physically and mentally healthy," explains Alexander Wedderburn, a retired psychology professor.

Fortunately for Shaun Stacey, a gas operations shift team member at Powergen, sleeping during the day when he is working night shifts is no problem. "I'm quite lucky because I never get disturbed during the day so I always manage to get a good days sleep," he says.

Shaun joined Powergen's graduate trainee scheme in September 1999 and began his current job last September. He was aware that he would have to work nights once he completed the training scheme and now works a shift system of one week of nights, a week of mornings and a week of afternoons.

"While I was training, I actually asked to do extra nights to prepare me and help me adjust. There are different challenges at night compared to working during the day. There are fewer people around so you have to be resourceful and be able to react and make decisions quickly," he says.

During the night shift he has plenty of work so there is no opportunity to get bored, but he has also developed strategies to stay alert. "I often go to the gym before a night shift because this not only gives me energy but breaks up the monotony of doing nothing but sleeping during the day and working at night."

A short stint working nights suited Shaun Trainor, production manager at British Nuclear Fuels. "I didn't have any problems adjusting. I have a young family and working nights meant that I could spend more time with them in the evenings before going to work."

So, if you have to work night shifts how can you make sure that you stay awake, alert and stimulated?

Don't eat big meals at night, this will only make you feel sleepy and sluggish.

It's not a good idea to go out before a night shift; this will make you feel tired especially if you have had alcohol.

Doing some form of exercise before your night shift will give you energy and keep you alert.

Try to keep busy - saving demanding tasks for the early hours of the morning will ensure that you have to stay alert.

Don't rely on stimulants to keep you awake if you're feeling sleepy. Go out for a walk and get some fresh air.

Make sure that it isn't too quiet - put the radio on.

If you don't remember anything else...

Working nights may be against our natural rhythms but millions of people do it and manage to adjust. If you have to work nights, there are many changes you can make in your life to adapt - find out which ones work for you.

 Sneak preview: Subscribers to the Guardian Graduate Email are joining in droves, but there's room for more. Offering exclusive career advice and previews of forthcoming features in Rise, the weekly email also brings the hottest new jobs to an in-box near you. To add your email address to the list, simply sign up at the website www.theguardian.com/graduates

 Scientific measure: Careers in science remain unattractive, according to a Mori survey which claims 21% of 20-somethings find the subject matter too difficult, 10% think it too boring and 1% consider it too poorly paid. One crumb of comfort is that the poll found respondents were inspired more by Marie Curie and Albert Einstein than by Posh and Becks.

 Stuffed shirts: The internet bubble may have burst, but its dress-down culture is here to stay - among men at least. Almost two out of three men - 63%- are in favour of relaxing the formal dress code as against 45%of women, according to the survey by Austin Reed. Around 3% said they were in favour of wearing no clothes in the office.

 Play private investigator: Do some detective work before the job interview, suggests career counsellor Karl Shinn. "Act like a sponge collecting information," he says. Notice how employees dress - you'll get a sense of how formal or informal the work environment is to help you gauge how you might fit in. At the same time, seeing how people interact (do they greet each other or walk to the door with their heads hanging?) reveals a lot about how enjoyable the place is. Karl says he also likes to chat informally with receptionists and security guards to gauge their degree of satisfaction and long-term interest in the company.

fields.headline: Wales in danger zone
fields.trailText: By Thursday morning Wales will have added considerably to both their collection of air miles and an understanding of the footballing strengths of former Soviet nations.
fields.body:
By Thursday morning Wales will have added considerably to both their collection of air miles and an understanding of the footballing strengths of former Soviet nations.

Whether their prospects of qualifying for the World Cup have grown in equal measure will largely depend on whether they can beat Armenia tonight and then throw a fit Ryan Giggs into the second test of this intense five-day period, when Ukraine visit the Millennium stadium on Wednesday.

Another poor performance here and the prospect of Andriy Shevchenko and Sergei Rebrov arriving in Cardiff to hunt goals will be even more depressing than a visit from Anne Robinson.

"Armenia must not be taken lightly," said Mark Hughes, the coach. "They are competitive, organised and work hard for each other. It is a very, very big game and we definitely need something from it.

"People will say this is the easier of the two fixtures but, just because Armenia don't have the recognised names that Ukraine have, it does not mean they won't be dangerous opposition."

A worrying portent of what may lie ahead came with the Under-21 side's 1-0 defeat yesterday, after which the manager Jimmy Shoulder accused the Armenians of "kicking my players from pillar to post".

Although John Hartson and Craig Bellamy are likely to continue their Coventry partnership up front, Dean Saunders will be hoping to take his number of representative appearances to 74. He would then become Wales's most capped outfield player, behind only the former goalkeeper Neville Southall's 92.

Wales (probable, 4-4-2): P Jones (Southampton); Robinson (Charlton), Page (Watford), Melville (Fulham), G Roberts (Tranmere); M Jones (Leicester), Speed (Newcastle), Pembridge (Everton), Barnard (Barnsley); Hartson , Bellamy (both Coventry).

webTitle: Scottish talisman hoping that 50 will be his lucky number

fields.headline: Scottish talisman hoping that 50 will be his lucky number
fields.standfirst: A man for all seasons proud to lead his team at Hampden today, reports  Mike Wilson
fields.trailText: A man for all seasons proud to lead his team at Hampden today, reports Mike Wilson
fields.body:
When Colin Hendry pulls on the captain's armband for Scotland's crucial World Cup qualifying game against Belgium this afternoon he will ensure there is enough space on his sleeve to wear his heart. With each of his previous 49 caps for his country collected with more than usual pride, his 50th today is bound to exert an extra tug on his emotions.

Those possessed eyes will surely squint with a tear as Scotland march on to the Hampden Park turf for a game that, were Scotland to win, would put clear, dark blue water between them and the rest for a place in the finals next year.

It could hardly be a more appropriate setting: at Hampden Park, in a game of towering importance; a setting tailor-made for a captain's performance in front of his ain folk. His would never have been a foot-soldier's destiny in the Tartan Army had his stuttering early career at Dundee turned for the worse and he had been lost to international football, perhaps even the domestic game. His leadership skills are there for all to see and, soon enough, may manifest themselves in the managerial dug-out. And with Hendry, what you see is what you get.

He cherishes every appearance, remembering his Scotland debut - against Estonia in 1993 at the comparatively late age of 27 - with vivid recollection. He counsels that the result this afternoon is more important than his personal milestone, but cannot help conceding the extra significance. "It will be a big day, bigger than most, for me and my family. But the most important thing is the result. We are in the middle of a campaign to qualify for the World Cup. I would love to be part of it."

It will be a strange feeling for the Bolton Wanderers defender in more ways than one. For the first time for the best part of two years, he enters a Scotland game uninhibited by concerns about his club future or by injury. He harbours no malice against Rangers, even though the manager Dick Advocaat made it clear he was third-choice central defender.

However, his move to Coventry City was a disappointment. "Sent to Coventry" after only one outing at the start of the season, he was playing more international games for Scotland than league games for the Midlands club. Determined not to allow his mental sharpness to falter, he admits to playing for his country less than 100% physically fit. Regular first-team football with Bolton - whom he joined on loan in December, the move becoming permanent in February - has ensured his match fitness.

Belgium and Scotland each sit on seven points from three games, Scotland's undefeated record courtesy of a 1-0 win over Latvia, a 2-0 victory over San Marino and a 0-0 draw in Croatia. Belgium's superior goal difference, aided by a 10-1 thrashing of San Marino last month, has them topping the group. With goals clearly in their system and Scotland performing better away from home than at the revamped Hampden, the popular suggestion that Robert Waseige's side intend to tough it out for a goalless draw seems misplaced.

Hendry says: "I got away with the games against Croatia and San Marino, the Latvia game as well since it was at the beginning of the season and I had just finished my pre-season training. Up to the Croatia and San Marino games I played in two or three reserve games, and the good thing was that the San Marino game came before the Croatia one. So that gave me 90 minutes. I was quite good; I wasn't 100% because I wasn't playing regular football. I don't know how I got through the Croatia game, the last 10 minutes. But the pitch was probably a bigger hindrance than my fitness."

The Scotland manager Craig Brown's assessment of the player began with a statistics lesson. "I am always accused of quoting statistics," he said, "but the fact is that in 34 competitive games, with Colin playing, we have lost only 20 goals. That is some record. It is not just an opinion that Colin is a good player, the facts bear it out. Either that or the others have carried him, which I am not prepared to concede." Brown's assessment of Scotland's chances of qualifying in the event of defeat are naturally upbeat. "Anything other than a win would be disappointing. But the group is wide open. We don't want to go to Belgium having to win, though I believe we are capable of winning in Belgium, but I just don't want us to have to be in the position of having to do it."

Against Waseige's expected 4-4-1-1 formation, Brown will probably stick with 3-5-2, perhaps adapting to 4-4-2 should Belgium - especially on the left, through Bart Goor - take control of the flanks.

Though Brown would not reveal his starting line-up, what can be assumed is the overdue pairing of Barry Ferguson and Paul Lambert, due to win his 25th cap, in midfield. Much anticipated but scuppered by frequent injury to Lambert, the partnership is poised to make its first competitive appearance since being given an airing against the Republic of Ireland in a friendly 10 months ago.

Another likely name to start is Leeds United's Dominic Matteo. His very presence in the Scotland camp ought to be proof enough of his desire to play for the country of his birth rather than for England, whom he has represented at lower international levels.

Whereas Matteo theoretically could still opt for England, no one would dare doubt Hendry's tartan affections.

fields.headline: Banks' World Cup medal fetches £124,750
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Football
fields.trailText: A mystery phone bidder yesterday bought former England goalkeeper Gordon Banks's 1966 World Cup winner's medal for £124,750.
fields.body:
A mystery phone bidder yesterday bought former England goalkeeper Gordon Banks's 1966 World Cup winner's medal for £124,750.

The sale kicked off at the Christie's auction house in London at £42,000. Bidding quickly shot past the £70,000 estimate and the medal eventually went to an anonymous telephone bidder.

Banks, 63, described as one of the world's best goalkeepers by former England manager Sir Alf Ramsey, said he was selling the medal to help his family.

The footballer, who was not at the sale, said recently it would be a sad day but that the pleasure of helping his family would make up for the loss. Banks also had five other lots up for auction and in total they made £171,690.

TV personality Nick Hancock secured Banks's blue World Cup 1970 international cap with a bid of £8,225. He said that he wanted to take the cap back to Stoke and he would possibly be displaying the cap at Stoke City football club.

He said: "I was very interested in buying the World Cup medal, but I'm just not rich enough."

He added that he made up his mind to buy the cap after meeting Mr Banks's daughter Wendy, with whom he had gone to school, at the sale.

"I've met Mr Banks a few times at a few sporting dinners - he's a great hero of mine. Seeing Wendy simply strengthened my resolve."

He explained that Banks had been a Stoke City player when he was awarded the 1970 cap in Mexico.

Banks played in the side which beat West Germany 4-2 at Wembley to claim the 1966 World Cup trophy. He also pulled off a remarkable save against the Brazilian Pele in the 1970 World Cup.

Sheffield-born Banks retired from international football after a car accident in 1972.

The goalkeeper said he hoped the winner's medal, which had been expected to make between £70,000 and £90,000, would be bought by a keen England supporter.

When the sale was first announced, he said: "It is not because of any financial problems or anything like that, but I cannot keep it in my house for obvious security reasons, so I don't get to see it much anyway. It will be a sad day - if I did not have to do it I would not do it. Unfortunately that is not the way it is, but this is the way I can help my family out in today's society."

He added that his children, Robert, 40, Wendy, 37, and Julia, 32, would be happy to benefit from the medal while he was still alive rather than receiving it in a will.

The gold-coloured medal was sold in its original presentation box. The back of the medal reads: "World Championship Jules Rimet Cup in England 1966".

Among the other lots Banks put up for sale and the price they raised were:

A West German shirt swapped with goalkeeper Hans Tilkowski after the 1966 final (£7,638); a white England shirt swapped with Bobby Charlton (£998.75); caps awarded to him in 1966 and 1970 World Cup finals (£27,025 and £8,225); and a football signed by the 1966 England squad and Sir Alf Ramsey (£850). Press Association

fields.headline: Gillespie brings relief
fields.trailText: Keith Gillespie, the Blackburn Rovers winger, has recovered from a neck injury and is in Northern Ireland's squad for today's Group Three qualifier against the Czech Republic at Windsor Park.
fields.body:
Keith Gillespie, the Blackburn Rovers winger, has recovered from a neck injury and is in Northern Ireland's squad for today's Group Three qualifier against the Czech Republic at Windsor Park.

That brought relief to the Northern Ireland manager Sammy McIlroy, who had formulated a tactical plan in which Gillespie and Wimbledon's Michael Hughes, recalled after a nine-month absence with a broken leg, were the key figures.

McIlroy believes that memories of the 4-0 defeat by Norway last month have been banished and there is a genuine feeling they can shock the Czechs despite the fact they are ranked 94th in the world and the Czechs fourth.

Now approaching 18 months in the job, McIlroy brushed aside all questions about the sectarian abuse to which Neil Lennon, the Celtic midfielder, was subjected in the Norway game.

"We've all condemned it. That's in the past now, let's concentrate on football," he said."Lennon is in the team; there was never any question of him being omitted. A minority doesn't nominate the squad and Neil is ready to play a major role for us."

A new code of conduct and stringent security measures have been introduced by the Irish FA in an attempt to eliminate the sectarian abuse, which came from a small number of spectators.

Closed-circuit television cameras have now been equipped with sound and anyone breaching the code will be ejected from the stadium and banned from future internationals.

Northern Ireland (probable, 4-5-1): Carroll; Hughes, Williams, Griffin; Nolan, Gillispie, Magilton, Lennon, Hughes, Elliott; Healey.

Czech Republic (probable, 4-4-2): Srnicek; Fukal, Latal, Namec, Tyce; Bejbl, Nedved, Poborsky, Roscky; Smicer, Koller.

Referee: M Gonzalez (Spain).

webTitle: No slip to fire Irish ire

fields.headline: No slip to fire Irish ire
fields.trailText: Having reeled in a couple of big fish, Mick McCarthy and his Republic of Ireland players travelled to Cyprus determined not to let any minnows through the net.
fields.body:
Having reeled in a couple of big fish, Mick McCarthy and his Republic of Ireland players travelled to Cyprus determined not to let any minnows through the net.

After holding Holland and Portugal away, followed by a comfortable defeat of Estonia at Lansdowne Road, Ireland's impressive toils must not now be negated by a slip-up at the GSP stadium. As the Irish know from bitter experience, however, the improbable can happen. Failing to overcome the likes of Macedonia and Liechtenstein has been pivotal in their absence from the past three major tournaments, so it was natural that McCarthy struck a note of caution.

"I think Holland and Portugal will beat Cyprus, Andorra and Estonia home and away, so we must emulate that," he said. "Nine points from the next three games is a must. I can't guarantee it but I think we will get them."

This week the Republic manager dined with Ronnie Whelan, the former Ireland player now with Olympiakos Nicosia. Score first, McCarthy was told, and there was a tendency among the home players to hoist the white flag.

"When they played Holland recently they lost 4-0, which would come across as something of a thrashing," Whelan said yesterday. "But it was 0-0 after 70min and it wasn't until Holland scored that they actually looked the better side."

 The Football Association of Ireland has agreed a four-year, £3.7m extension to their deal with BSkyB, which will now broadcast live all their home games until 2006.

Cyprus (probable, 4-4-2)): Panayiotou; Theodotou, M Charalambous, Konnafis, C Charalambous; Ioakim, Spoljaric, Engomitis, Malekkos; Okkas, Constantinou.

Republic of Ireland (4-4-2): Given; G Kelly, Cunningham, Breen, Harte; McAteer, Kinsella, Roy Keane, Kilbane; Connolly, Robbie Keane.

Referee : F de Bleeckere (Belgium).

webTitle: Clubs suffer £150m fall in TV deal

fields.headline: Clubs suffer £150m fall in TV deal
fields.trailText: The Premier League has reached agreement in principle to sell pay-per-view football rights to the main cable, satellite and digital broadcasters for about £180m.
fields.body:
The Premier League has reached agreement in principle to sell pay-per-view football rights to the main cable, satellite and digital broadcasters for about £180m.

The sum falls far short of the £328m that the cable company NTL offered last summer for an exclusive deal to show 40 pay-per-view matches a season. NTL pulled out of the agreement in October, complaining that the Premier League had altered the terms of its contract.

Proceeds from the new three-year package will be split among the clubs, and broadcasters warned that continuing negotiations might see the figure drop still lower.

The Premier League chief executive Peter Scudamore and his advisers have been under intense pressure from the clubs to find a buyer to replace NTL. Several chairmen are known to have been furious when the original deal collapsed. They thought it was signed and sealed and they had already started planning for, and even spending, the money.

The decision to pursue individual deals with BSkyB, NTL, Telewest and ONdigital was taken at a meeting of the club chairmen this week.

"The sum is lower but I think the Premier club chairmen are fully aware of what has happened to the financial markets since that deal was struck," a Premiership source said.

The pay-per-view deals are expected to be tied down within 90 days, in time for the start of the next season. Each of the broadcasters will offer its subscribers 40 matches a year. It is not yet clear whether each company will be able to choose its matches or whether only one game will be available across all four of the platforms.

BSkyB will still have first choice of two games a week under the terms of its record-breaking £1.1bn deal for the live rights to 66 games a season which it agreed last summer.

Further pressure was heaped on to Scudamore when it emerged that several big companies had dropped out of negotiations to replace Carling as the Premier League's sponsor. Pepsi and Budweiser are among a number of blue-chip brands thought to have found the league's asking price of £15-20m a year too steep.

Scudamore last month went some way to calming his critics by selling the overseas broadcasting rights to Premier League games for £178m to a consortium of four companies made up of Sport Plus, Rupert Murdoch's News Corp, TWI and Octagon CSI.

The Premier League could still swell its coffers through the video-on-demand rights to screen matches. The talks are understood to be with Video Networks, which runs the Home Choice service, UDirect, Yes Television and Kingston Communications.

The league had considered holding on to the pay-per-view rights and either selling them to broadcasters on a match-by-match basis, selling exclusive rights to a single company, similar to the previous agreement with NTL, or selling to a "gatekeeper" which would then broker deals with the broadcasters.

The climbdown may suggest that the inflation in sports rights has reached some kind of ceiling. As well as the £1.1bn BSkyB is paying for the live rights, ITV paid £183m for weekend highlights, squeezing the BBC out of the picture.

But the lower price may also be a more direct reflection of the unproven market for pay-per-view. NTL was said to have pulled out of the original deal through fears that it would not be economically viable.

webTitle: Ailing single currency struggles to bridge credibility gap

fields.headline: Ailing single currency struggles to bridge credibility gap
fields.standfirst: Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: The Stockholm summit has been confronted with an unpleasant reality: the euro, centrepiece of closer economic integration, has failed to establish its credibility.
fields.body:
The Stockholm summit has been confronted with an unpleasant reality: the euro, centrepiece of closer economic integration, has failed to establish its credibility.

The bloodbath on Wall Street and America's slide into recession should have been tailor-made for the euro to rival the dollar as the world's premier currency.

Instead Europe's single currency hit a three month low against the dollar this week as dealers and investors decided that a shell-shocked US economy was a better bet than the eurozone.

The latest demonstration of the euro's fragility left European leaders, not for the first time, reduced to berating the fickleness of financial markets.

The mood was summed up by the economic affairs commissioner, Pedro Solbes, who claimed that foreign exchange traders were backing the wrong horse.

"Europe is the economic safe haven of the developed world at the moment and this has to be recognised by the markets," he said.

He was backed by the commission president, Romano Prodi, who told an Italian newspaper: "If I had money I would still bet on the euro without any difficulty."

The euro has had a rough ride from the foreign exchange market since its launch. Its initial exchange rate against the dollar was $1.17 but America's zippier economic performance compared with that of the 12-nation eurozone - at least until late last year - saw it sink like a stone, hitting a low of little more than 82 cents.

Though it subsequently recovered to 95 cents, the recent turbulence in the financial markets has seen it slump back to below 90 cents.

"There is certainly a paradox in the dollar being seen as a safe haven when it is the US stock market which has been leading the way down," said Ken Wattret, an economist at the French bank BNP Paribas

Euro supporters can draw some comfort from the knowledge that the strength of the dollar could be a kneejerk reaction as investors favour the greenback in order to buy US government bonds - traditionally regarded as probably the world's safest investment.

The market mood may be influenced, too, by a belief that America's slowdown will prove short-lived and that the recovery will be more marked on that side of the Atlantic than in Europe.

But as Mr Wattret points out: "You have the US stock market falling and very serious worries about a recession in the US, yet we still have the euro being sold against the dollar. It is a symptom of the credibility of the euro that it is still struggling."

fields.headline: A picture house when you buy from drawings?
fields.standfirst: Deals for new properties can often mean a £500 deposit securing an option at artist's impression stage.  Elizabeth Langton looks at the advantages and disadvantages of purchasing "off-plan"
fields.trailText: Deals for new properties can often mean a £500 deposit securing an option at artist's impression stage. Elizabeth Langton looks at the advantages and disadvantages of purchasing "off-plan".
fields.body:
Competition for reasonably priced houses in prime areas has always been fierce. And when it comes to new houses, some buyers are so keen to secure a slice of newly built real estate that they will slap down £500 to secure the option of buying a home that is little more than an artist's impression.

Typically, four weeks later, buyers will be expected to exchange contracts and stump up a 10% deposit. Then you have to sit back and wait for the property to be built - a process than can take up to two years with apartment blocks.

Buying a home "off-plan" before the first brick has been laid is increasingly popular, say builders, who are keen to find buyers for their properties at the earliest possible stage.

There are financial advantages for buyers from this. Committing yourself at such an early stage means you get to buy the property at the initial offer price - prices are usually lower during the first phase of the development and increase once the developer has some sales under its belt.

Also, on some developments, early bird buyers get to choose the best plot and even dictate the position of some fittings.

However, buying off-plan can be a risky business. If the bottom falls out of the property market, buyers may find themselves committed to purchasing a house that is worth less than they paid.

But in the current market, according to Nicholas King, managing director of Nicholas King Homes: "Buying off-plan enables purchasers to create their own home allowing them to choose fittings and finishes that directly appeal to their personal tastes and preferences.

"Provided they reserve their property at an early enough stage, changes can be incorporated into the build schedule. By giving purchasers the opportunity to buy off-plan, we give them the choice of creating a home that has its own individuality."

Three of the company's homes at Curvare, a development of eight properties in the heart of the Chiltern hills, were sold off-plan to purchasers who were able to make changes to the initial design.

"They chose to lengthen the size of the existing wine cellar and introduce different styles of kitchen and they could, in fact, have designed the interior themselves, provided their specification remained within a pre-deter- mined budget, otherwise extra costs could be incurred," says Mr King.

While Mr King says that the advantages of off-plan buying are substantial, there can be a downside as home counties resident Paul found out after purchasing a terrace town house from another developer.

Paul is an engineer and is in the fortunate position of being able to make sense of builders' plans. Straight away he spotted a couple of drawbacks after careful inspection of the plans such as dormer windows that would eat into the roof and cut down on the amount of wardrobe space. But generally he felt he knew what to expect.

Later on, while looking around a show home on a similar development, which he was told would have a similar layout to his own, he noticed that the design of the stairs meant he wouldn't be able to get their three-seater sofa up into the middle-floor sitting room.

"I was assured by the sales rep that the staircases were built to current standards and that it would be possible to get a three-seater upstairs."

Reassured, he and his family awaited the completion of their new home.

The building world is notoriously optimistic about completion dates. Yet delays are frequent. As part of the move, Paul's children were changing schools and having a firm completion date was important to the family.

Selling, buying and moving schools can be a recipe for stress and as time went on completion dates slipped further and further back. The family was originally told they could move in late October. In the end, the house was ready at the end of January. They spent six weeks camping out with relatives in the interim.

When moving day came they were led to believe it was little more than a case of getting the keys from the developers. As it turned out, there was a mountain of documentation to deal with. There were no lightbulbs in the house and Paul's wife had to complete the paperwork before darkness fell. "It all had to be done in a rush. Had I known there was so much to do I would have taken the day off work and been better prepared."

Once in, the family was disappointed to find the standard of finishing left a lot to be desired. "You think when you buy a new house that there's going to be nothing to do. The house we moved from was due to have the boiler, the kitchen and other fittings replaced so we thought moving to a new home would mean we'd avoid major jobs. The workmanship isn't anything like the show home. The walls are thinner, the floorboards creak. The thermostat is in the wrong place."

Paul continues: "The soil pipes leaked, the banisters didn't quite join properly, there were scrapes on the wall. For the first four weeks we had a tradesman in every day."

And as the family feared, their sofas would not go up the stairs. "When we complained they sent in workman to chop the bannisters out. We took the sofas up and new stairs went in."

Despite the creaking floorboards and other niggles, he is glad that he purchased the new house. He thinks the builders may have been let down by its sub-contractors. Different workmen were brought in for the second phase of the development - and after a stern letter to the chairman the builders are being "relatively helpful" and glitches are gradually being ironed out.

Paul's advice to off-plan buyers is not to expect your new home to look like the show home, scrutinise plans and find out exactly what will be included in your home. Be prepared to argue with the developer and fight your side. Also, get all your complaints down in writing as soon as you discover problems."

Buyers who purchase early on in the process need to be happy to live on what is likely to be a building site for some time. But on the plus side, families like Paul's can gain financially. Buying off-plan seals the price of the home, even if the property is completed a year later when prices have risen. "We'd bought the house before Christmas and properties went up by around £12,000 by January."

Experts advise buyers to get a full specification of the home they have reserved to protect themselves against major changes.

Also ensure the developer is protected by the NHBC (the regulatory body for the housing industry), or a similar guarantee which protects buyers from their new homes developing specified defects. For details: www.nhbc.co.uk

Three of the company's homes at Curvare, a development of eight properties in the heart of the Chiltern hills, were sold off-plan to purchasers who were able to make changes to the initial design. "They chose to lengthen the size of the existing wine cellar and introduce different styles of kitchen and they could, in fact, have designed the interior themselves, provided their specification remained within a pre-deter- mined budget, otherwise extra costs could be incurred," says Mr King. While Mr King says that the advantages of off-plan buying are substantial, there can be a downside as home counties resident Paul found out after purchasing a terrace town house from another developer. Paul is an engineer and is in the fortunate position of being able to make sense of builders' plans. Straight away he spotted a couple of drawbacks after careful inspection of the plans such as dormer windows that would eat into the roof and cut down on the amount of wardrobe space. But generally he felt he knew what to expect. Later on, while looking around a show home on a similar development, which he was told would have a similar layout to his own, he noticed that the design of the stairs meant he wouldn't be able to get their three-seater sofa up into the middle-floor sitting room. "I was assured by the sales rep that the staircases were built to current standards and that it would be possible to get a three-seater upstairs." Reassured, he and his family awaited the completion of their new home. The building world is notoriously optimistic about completion dates. Yet delays are frequent. As part of the move, Paul's children were changing schools and having a firm completion date was important to the family. Selling, buying and moving schools can be a recipe for stress and as time went on completion dates slipped further and further back. The family was originally told they could move in late October. In the end, the house was ready at the end of January. They spent six weeks camping out with relatives in the interim. When moving day came they were led to believe it was little more than a case of getting the keys from the developers. As it turned out, there was a mountain of documentation to deal with. There were no lightbulbs in the house and Paul's wife had to complete the paperwork before darkness fell. "It all had to be done in a rush. Had I known there was so much to do I would have taken the day off work and been better prepared." Once in, the family was disappointed to find the standard of finishing left a lot to be desired. "You think when you buy a new house that there's going to be nothing to do. The house we moved from was due to have the boiler, the kitchen and other fittings replaced so we thought moving to a new home would mean we'd avoid major jobs. The workmanship isn't anything like the show home. The walls are thinner, the floorboards creak. The thermostat is in the wrong place." Paul continues: "The soil pipes leaked, the banisters didn't quite join properly, there were scrapes on the wall. For the first four weeks we had a tradesman in every day." And as the family feared, their sofas would not go up the stairs. "When we complained they sent in workman to chop the bannisters out. We took the sofas up and new stairs went in." Despite the creaking floorboards and other niggles, he is glad that he purchased the new house. He thinks the builders may have been let down by its sub-contractors. Different workmen were brought in for the second phase of the development - and after a stern letter to the chairman the builders are being "relatively helpful" and glitches are gradually being ironed out. Paul's advice to off-plan buyers is not to expect your new home to look like the show home, scrutinise plans and find out exactly what will be included in your home. Be prepared to argue with the developer and fight your side. Also, get all your complaints down in writing as soon as you discover problems." Buyers who purchase early on in the process need to be happy to live on what is likely to be a building site for some time. But on the plus side, families like Paul's can gain financially. Buying off-plan seals the price of the home, even if the property is completed a year later when prices have risen. "We'd bought the house before Christmas and properties went up by around £12,000 by January." Experts advise buyers to get a full specification of the home they have reserved to protect themselves against major changes. Also ensure the developer is protected by the NHBC (the regulatory body for the housing industry), or a similar guarantee which protects buyers from their new homes developing specified defects. For details: www.nhbc.co.uk

webTitle: Blair's options remain open in theory but key concern is national mood

fields.headline: Blair's options remain open in theory but key concern is national mood
fields.standfirst:
Delay brings risk of declining economy

Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: When Tony Blair gets back from Stockholm tomorrow it will be for a final review of the options. In theory, everything is still possible: local elections, census and general election could technically all still be shelved.
fields.body:
When Tony Blair gets back from Stockholm tomorrow it will be for a final review of the options. In theory, everything is still possible: local elections, census and general election could technically all still be shelved.

But around Whitehall and Westminster, preparations for a May 3 general election continue. If it is to go ahead, the prime minister has to declare it by April 5.

On Monday nominations open for county council elections in England. They could still be stopped, although it becomes increasingly hard to unravel the legal processes of lodging nomination papers and appointing returning officers. On paper, the elections could be held and subsequently annulled.

The Conservatives are now arguing for postponement, at least in the worst-hit areas, Cumbria and Devon. They know that once campaigning is seen to be under way their argument for delaying the general election could be weakened.

It is only in the first week in April that timing for May 3 becomes critical. Parliament has to be prorogued by April 5 to allow for the full 17 campaigning days, excluding weekends, Good Friday and Easter Monday. But an announcement will almost certainly have to come by April 2 as legislation on the key parts of the finance bill, which implements the Budget, will have to be rushed through - as the Tories did in 1992.

Privately, all parties admit that door-to-door campaigning is no longer essential, and with the much easier availability of postal and proxy votes there is no technical reason for stopping every adult from voting, even if they are marooned on their farm. The post is still getting through.

Even Liberal Democrats, the most assiduous of canvassers, acknowledge there are ways of reaching voters other than driving up to their doorsteps. The biggest logistical problem is the census at the end of April, which does involve door-to-door visiting. But it is reckoned that delaying it would cost up to £100m.

A bleak warning from the epidemiologists analysing the spread of foot and mouth was not unexpected. "The outlook is for a very large epidemic," they said. "It will grow fast in the next few weeks and continue for many months." But strategists see the latest statistics as a reason to push ahead with May elections against a background of the fight to contain the disease.

The evidence now suggests that even by October 4, the most likely autumn election date, foot and mouth will still be raging. There are other considerations: as the financial markets plummet, by autumn the economic outlook could be much less rosy.

But the biggest consideration for Mr Blair is not the logistics but the national mood. For 10 days opinion has moved steadily against a spring election. In the past couple of days there has been a decided wobble about the wisdom of pressing ahead. But among Labour's significant minority of rural MPs opinion appears to be hardening in favour of May.

Diane Organ, whose Forest of Dean constituency now has 13 cases, said it must go ahead. "Farming and tourism are both really feeling it. There is a powerful emotional feeling that this is some kind of plague, a sort of medieval curse. But there is also a recognition that life does go on. People are still going to work and going to school. Elections are part of ordinary life."

The crisis is now inextricably tangled with party politics. Today the Tory leader, William Hague, will call for an inner "crisis cabinet" and renew his attack on what he claims was the government's lack of vigour early in the outbreak.

webTitle: US and Cuba in a rum war over brand

fields.headline: US and Cuba in a rum war over brand
fields.trailText: Rum may be part of the image of the friendly, laidback Caribbean but it is threatening to send Cuba hurtling into another trade row with its enemy to the north, the United States.
fields.body:
Rum may be part of the image of the friendly, laidback Caribbean but it is threatening to send Cuba hurtling into another trade row with its enemy to the north, the United States.

Fidel Castro has ordered Cuban distilleries to begin producing rums bearing the Bacardi name for sale abroad, in retaliation for a US court decision to allow another manufacturer to market rum under one of Cuba's most famous brand names - Havana Club - for sale in the US.

"We have given instructions for our industry to start producing Bacardi, because it is ours ... and there are a lot more things we can do to respond to banditry and abuse," President Castro said in part of a wider speech attacking the embargo this week.

"So we will then benefit from the millions that they have spent on advertising; it is really easy to produce."

The Havana Club brand is one of the communist state's most famous brands and is marketed internationally by the French company Pernod-Ricard, selling up to 38m bottles a year. But it cannot compete in the lucrative US market because of the US trade embargo against Cuban-made products.

Its main competitor is Bacardi & Co, which is owned by a Cuban exile family now based in Bermuda. Courts in the US ruled in 1999 that Bacardi could distribute rum under the Havana Club brand, because Cuba's distilleries were nationalised after Castro's 1959 revolution. Bacardi bought the rights to the trade name from its pre-nationalisation owner in 1995.

Pernod-Ricard, which contested the case, has taken the issue to the World Trade Organisation, with backing from the European Union.

Relations between the US and Cuba are difficult at present following the battle for custody of the Cuban refugee Elian Gonzalez .

President Castro's order to resume production comes as the 40th anniversary of the imposition of the embargo, after the botched Bay of Pigs invasion, approaches.

webTitle: Judge backs editor over Shayler case

fields.headline: Judge backs editor over Shayler case
fields.standfirst:
Special report: David Shayler
MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: A senior judge yesterday accused the attorney general, Lord Williams, of behaving like a press censor and cleared Punch magazine of contempt for publishing an article by David Shayler, the former MI5 officer, which criticised the security and intelligence agencies' handling of the IRA's bombing campaign.
fields.body:
A senior judge yesterday accused the attorney general, Lord Williams, of behaving like a press censor and cleared Punch magazine of contempt for publishing an article by David Shayler, the former MI5 officer, which criticised the security and intelligence agencies' handling of the IRA's bombing campaign.

In a judgment with wide implications for the press and security services, Lord Phillips, Master of the Rolls, roundly attacked the practice whereby the attorney general obtained broad injunctions preventing the media from publishing information without first getting clearance from him.

"It subjects the press to the censorship of the attorney general," he said. Such a practice, he added, "results in the imposition of a restriction on the freedom of the press that is disproportionate to any public interest and thus in breach of article 10 of the European Convention on Human Rights."

Last July, Punch magazine published an article by Mr Shayler about the performance of MI5, the police anti-terrorist branch and GCHQ - the government's electronic eavesdropping centre - before the IRA bombed Bishopsgate in London in 1993.

The article carried the headline: "MI5 could have stopped the bomb going off". It referred to "unarmed" surveillance operations and operational mistakes by the security and intelligence agencies. Mr Shayler alleged they could have stopped the IRA bombers up to six months before the Bishopsgate blast, which killed one person, injured 44 and caused £350m of damage. He identified four Irishmen he said were involved in the bombing.

On its cover, Punch reproduced a letter in which government lawyers warned James Steen, the then editor, that the article would break a 1997 injunction against Mr Shayler and the Mail on Sunday banning publication of any material obtained by him as an MI5 officer.

Mr Steen was fined £5,000 for contempt of court last October by Mr Justice Silber though government lawyers admitted the 1997 injunction had previously been ignored.

In the appeal court yesterday, Lord Phillips and Lord Justice Longmore, Lord Justice Simon Brown dissenting, ruled that the attorney had produced no evidence that Mr Steen intended to damage national security, the stated purpose of the injunction.

"The contempt is committed not because the third party is in breach of the order - the order does not bind the third party," said Lord Phillips. "The contempt is committed because the purpose of the judge in making the order is intentionally frustrated..." he added.

David Price, solicitor-advocate for Mr Steen, said the ruling showed judges were now becoming more sympathetic to the media. "It is not good enough for the government merely to rely on confidentiality assurances from an employee," he said.

Mr Steen, who appealed in a personal capacity, said he was delighted by the ruling. "We published a letter on the front cover which humiliated them. That was the reason they came to court," he said.

The attorney was ordered to pay costs, estimated at more than £200,000.

fields.headline: What's in a name?
fields.trailText: The BBC is bringing back Children's Hour. Except that it won't be called Children's Hour: that's so very 15th century. They held a competition which was won by an eight-year-old boy who proffered the title: Go 4 it. Well, better that than To Die 4, I suppose.
fields.body:
 The BBC is bringing back Children's Hour. Except that it won't be called Children's Hour: that's so very 15th century. They held a competition which was won by an eight-year-old boy who proffered the title: Go 4 it. Well, better that than To Die 4, I suppose.

What I can't understand is why they are planning to include excerpts from Dr Dolittle, by Hugh Lofting. I mean, how antique can you get? "Once upon a time": the first of these stories begins (that line will have to go for a start), "many years ago - when our grandfathers were little children - there was a doctor..." "Like, get on with it," I can hear the customers shouting already. Soon after this, we get our first burst of dialogue. "The doctor's sister," Lofting writes "came to him and said, 'John, how can you expect sick people to come and see you when you keep all these animals in the house?... We are getting poorer every day. If you go on like this, none of the best people will have you for a doctor.' 'But I like the animals better than the "best people",' said the doctor."

All that goes out. I expect to see it rewritten with the help of a guide to how the young talk published in last Sunday's Observer on the following lines. "The doctor's sister goes, like, 'I mean, what is this? This house is, like, full of Brad Pitt*. I mean, what kind of saddo are you? You make me want to Wallace and Gromit*.' And the doctor, he's like 'Are you, like, some sort of Slayer** or something? These animals are, like, well wicked...'" Dr Dolittle will be played by Leonardo DiCaprio, Sarah by Britney Spears, Gub-Gub the pig by John Prescott, the Pushmi-pullyu by Michael Portillo, and Puddleby-on-the-Marsh by Milton Keynes.

 One of the virtues of not being able to sleep beyond 5 o'clock (there are very few) is that you can tune into Farming Today, which through the foot and mouth crisis has been essential listening. Several newspapers, including this one, have run diaries by farmers' wives, but Farming Today has found one who has got the plague on her farm. The trouble is that this is transmitted at 5.45am, when most of the people who write anti-farmer tirades are tucked up in their urban beds. When I am dictator - a circumstance which cannot now be deferred for much longer - I shall order the BBC to transmit Farming Today immediately after the 8am news, and keep it there until the last sheep has been slaughtered and the countryside has returned to normality.

 Wherever I go nowadays, I am pestered by people of every shape and size plangently asking: do you think Cowdenbeath peaked too soon? Has their bolt been shot? In other words, have they blown it? For most of the season, buoyed up by Smallweed's support over the years, they have been proudly placed at the top of the Scotish third division. But last Saturday they needed an 85th-minute goal to save their unbeaten home record, and on Tuesday they shed two more precious points with another home draw, against Hamilton. I begin to expect the worst. Perhaps they fear playing at a higher level? Incidentally, I see the Times has now joined its companion paper the Sun in marking premier league players out of 10. The more people attempt this exercise the more dubious it looks. Take, for instance, Robert Molenaar (Bradford City). The Telegraph put him in its "team of the week", made up of the day's top perfomers as assessed by its pundits. The Sun and the Sunday Mirror gave him six points; the Times a mere four, with the very abrasive comment that even then he was less accident prone than usual. Bridge, of Southampton, got the same treatment: six out of 10 in the Sun and the Sunday Mirror, a mere three in the Times.

The Times is notably stingier than the rest. Its expert gave the much-feared Everton and Scotland striker Duncan Ferguson a rating of two. If I was this expert I would hope not to bump into Ferguson for at least seven years.

 This week the Winston Churchill Memorial Trust named more than 100 winners of its travelling fellowships. They ranged in age from 19 to 61, which was pleasing. I sometimes wonder what the old boy would have made of some of the topics they will be exploring. Web-based cultural ethnography as a creative medium, for instance: that would have thrown him, since web-based in those days had something to do with ducks' feet. Quilting: the heritage of the "sewing bee" might have been something to take up with Clemmie. I dare say he might have raised an eybrow, but then put it down again, over The Origins of the Lute in Scotland. And then there's Community Involvement in papier mché. I think that might have needed a bit of explaining.

 In one of those wearisome trailers which now make up approximately 17.38% of Radio 4's output, I heard someone promising that John Peel would this morning be taking a wry look at the foibles of family life. What, I asked my radio (which never replies) are his qualifications for that? Is he not a mere amateur? I've already had a couple of worried calls from the British Foible Assessment Society, which would willingly proffer its services if the BBC asked. Any government seriously interested in the nation's mental and moral wellbeing, one of these people told me in an unattributable undertone, would by now have set up a proper inspection system with the title Offoible.

I was also touched this week to find there is something called the British Sandwich Association. Does it hold annual conferences? If so, are they always held at the same seaside town in Kent? Are they advertised by men wearing sandwich-boards? Are only sandwiches served, even at dinner? Are there blind tastings? And vast ideological disputes between the proprietors of Pret a Manger and those of Mona's Sarnie Bar? I looked the British Sandwich Association up in the phone book but failed to find it.

Any sandwicheer reading this note, by the way, might like to clear up a mystery. It is often said the object of these people's attentions is called a sandwich because the Earl of Sandwich invented it. Yet I've several times read in the past year or so that this isn't true. What is the truth of this matter? I think I shall steer clear of sandwiches until the question has been resolved. *rhyming slang, they tell me. **An assertive, attitudinal female. Also a woman who hunts vampires; but not I think in this case.

Smallweed@Guardian.co.uk

It is often said the object of these people's attentions is called a sandwich because the Earl of Sandwich invented it. Yet I've several times read in the past year or so that this isn't true. What is the truth of this matter? I think I shall steer clear of sandwiches until the question has been resolved. *rhyming slang, they tell me. **An assertive, attitudinal female. Also a woman who hunts vampires; but not I think in this case. Smallweed@Guardian.co.uk

webTitle: Ian Mayes on Martin Amis's hard-core porn exposé

fields.headline: Sex lessons
fields.standfirst: The readers' editor on .. Martin Amis's hard-core porn exposé
fields.trailText: On Martin Amis's hard-core porn exposé.
fields.body:
One of the first of these Open Door columns, published in November 1997, was written in response to complaints about an article on hard-core pornography in the US which appeared in our Weekend magazine. Last week the magazine published as its cover story another piece on the same subject, this time by the novelist Martin Amis. It excited another flurry of complaints. Had nothing changed?

Well, yes, it had. One of the main causes of complaint last time was the pictures, chosen, I was told at the time, to give some idea of the tackiness of the industry. Readers felt they more than achieved their purpose. There was particular objection to them because it was felt they exposed the subject to children in an immediate and unacceptable way, and indeed to others who did not wish to read the piece. I agreed with the objectors and said that although I thought it a perfectly legitimate subject, I felt it demanded a greater awareness and sensitivity than it received.

No pictures were used this time, although the piece had originally been published with photographs in Talk, the American magazine, copies of which had been available in Britain (in some supermarkets, among other places). Instead, the Guardian used typographic headings through the five pages of text. The cover, similarly, was entirely taken up with the words: Amis on Porn. This form was devised, partly with the objections raised three years ago in mind, and because the editor of the magazine made it clear that she wanted the presentation to be as unsensational as possible. Her misgivings, which were still unresolved when the editor of the paper took the final decision to publish, were shared by some of her colleagues: I will come to some of their views in a moment.

Some of the readers who objected to the piece felt that the plain statement of the cover was insufficient indication of the uncompromisingly explicit nature of the content, and that additional warning should have been given.

Amis, indeed, spared his readers little. He spoke to the performers and producers of hard-core pornography, described or allowed them to describe the practices which define hard-core pornography in a way in which they had never before been described in the Guardian and, in my view, he demonstrated how degrading and destructive it all is.

The person who bought the piece for the Guardian (not the editor of Weekend), although she foresaw objections, felt that Amis's tone was "one of shock and incredulity at a multi-million dollar, multi-national industry based on systematic abuse and degradation". She added: "This is a world-class writer addressing a subject which is both pervasive and taboo, and which has always presented a particular dilemma to the libertarian left."

I have read all the letters to the Guardian about this article: 20 strongly objecting, 10 applauding it or simply making interested comment. A couple of those who objected said they were cancelling their Guardian. One of these said she was no longer prepared to run the risk of "top shelf" material hitting her doormat.

Here are other comments: "I could find no literary or moral justification for the graphic descriptions in the article"; "I don't buy pornography or present it to my children. I do buy the Guardian and encourage my children to read it. After Saturday's pornographic piece by Martin Amis I have a very real dilemma." Amis was accused of claiming to hate pornography "while lasciviously paying attention to all of its detail". The Guardian was asked by another reader: "Do you think that using a famous author means that you can legitimise this gratuitous filth?"

At one of the editor's morning conferences earlier this week, I invited comment on the piece from staff journalists. Fifteen responded, seven in favour and eight strongly against: not against its publication, but its publication in the Guardian. One felt it would be "a great loss" if parents felt they could no longer encourage their children to read the paper.

The editor of the Guardian remains convinced that the decision to publish was the right one, and his views coincide with those expressed above by the commissioning editor. He argued that it was one of those extremely uncomfortable areas of life that we may not want to know about but which the paper could not, and should not, ignore.

One reader said he expected the Guardian to think before it published this kind of material. It did, and the paper presented it in a way that, in my view, provided an adequate opportunity for it to be withheld from children. But one final thought from a reader: "Newspapers and their writers - heroes of our time. You must be so proud of yourselves."

webTitle: Eriksson wakes up to England's different demands

fields.headline: Eriksson wakes up to England's different demands
fields.trailText: Sven-Goran Eriksson received an English wake-up call yesterday, but not the kind he might have been expecting. The moron from a Manchester-based radio station who bothered him with an impersonation of Kevin Keegan before the friendly match against Spain three weeks ago did it again yesterday - at 7.30am, less than 36 hours before the start of his first World Cup match as England's coach.
fields.body:
Sven-Goran Eriksson received an English wake-up call yesterday, but not the kind he might have been expecting. The moron from a Manchester-based radio station who bothered him with an impersonation of Kevin Keegan before the friendly match against Spain three weeks ago did it again yesterday - at 7.30am, less than 36 hours before the start of his first World Cup match as England's coach.

Needless to say, this sort of thing never happened to Eriksson in Italy or Portugal, let alone in his native Sweden. But, being a civilised man with a sense of humour, his public reponse was restrained. "He might have left it until I'd had a glass of water," he said. "Eight-thirty would have been better."

Humour, however, has its time and place, and it was left to the Football Association to take the necessary action, by withdrawing the station's accreditation for this afternoon's match. The sanction seemed far too mild. If Eriksson manages to get England through their remaining Group Nine games and into the World Cup finals, Century-FM should have its nationality revoked.

There was, in fact, a more serious side to the affair. With some reluctance, Eriksson mentioned that his habit of telephoning the club managers of his players had been disrupted by the first incident. Several of them are now in the habit of asking for his number and ringing him back, as a safeguard against another hoax. "That's happened a few times, and it's not nice," he said. "Maybe we'll have to think of a code word."

His day was also punctuated by another unexpected incident, when he was presented with a set of golf clubs in a bag bearing his name in large letters and invited, for the benefit of photographers, to play a shot near the 10th green of the Carden Park Hotel course, where the squad are staying. He is not, he confessed, much of a golfer. "I have the maximum handicap," he said. Nevertheless he obliged the snappers - and the England sponsors, who had provided the bag and whose name was prominently displayed in the vicinity. Given his salary of £2m a year, Eriksson probably has little choice, although he must sometimes wonder what kind of people he has come to live among.

He gave a rare clue to his methods yesterday when he indicated that his last pre-match team talk will be given at half past noon, before the squad leave the hotel for the coach journey to Anfield. "Some coaches like to give the last talk in the dressing room," he said. "I prefer earlier, so that when we get to the stadium they can concentrate on their boots, their equipment, and so on. It's a very individual thing. If there are 18 players, there are perhaps 18 different ways of concentrating. I think that's very important."

Of the limited amount of information on Eriksson's methods that has emerged from inside the squad, quite the most interesting is the outline of his last talk to the players before the Spain match, as described by Chris Powell, his surprise choice at left-back, to the Sunday Times. "Everybody was at ease with what he was trying to put over," Powell said. "He told us that the staff were there to help us, that we were there to help each other, and that we were all there to make the nation proud. It was a simple message, but it stuck in my mind, and I know from talking to them that it stuck in the minds of everyone present."

A simple message, yes, but the simplicity of a man who understands that footballers do not need to be burdened with an excess of information in the minutes before a match, and that if tubs need to be thumped and flags waved, there is probably something wrong with the players' inherent quality or their preparation.

As for his own attitude, he seems to be finding exactly the right combination of commitment and detachment. Had he ever been, someone asked yesterday, in a win-or-bust position before? "Many times." But surely this would be the most important match of his career? "With no competition at all."

Even at Benfica, he said, only 120,000 people were concerned about the result. "But tomorrow 120,000 will be nothing. Nothing at all. Tomorrow there will be 50 or 60m. Well, maybe not all of them will be watching the match. But I've never had so many supporters before. In that way alone it will certainly be the most important match I've ever faced."

And, he promises, not the easy one that some expect. Nevertheless he expects to face the day refreshed by a decent night's rest. "I'm not suffering because I'm too nervous," he concluded. "I will sleep well."

webTitle: England have no margin for error

fields.headline: England have no margin for error
fields.trailText: For England's football team the shape of things to come over the next five years may well be decided by what happens in the first half-hour of this afternoon's World Cup qualifier against Finland at Anfield. By then Sven Goran Eriksson will know if the side he has picked for his first competitive match as England coach is a team in the real sense of the word.
fields.body:
For England's football team the shape of things to come over the next five years may well be decided by what happens in the first half-hour of this afternoon's World Cup qualifier against Finland at Anfield. By then Sven Goran Eriksson will know if the side he has picked for his first competitive match as England coach is a team in the real sense of the word.

His selection will be finalised when Steven Gerrard wakes up this morning. If the 20-year-old Liverpool midfielder is free from the stiff back which raised fresh doubts about his fitness 48 hours ago he will play.

"Gerrard did well in training this morning," Eriksson said yesterday, "and if he doesn't have a bad reaction he will be fit for the match. We will know when he awakes tomorrow but it was important he practised today." Nicky Butt is the obvious alternative.

David Seaman, another back sufferer, was declared fit yesterday and will probably be recalled, although Eriksson's reaction to the news - "It will be a difficult decision because I now have three equally good goalkeepers" - suggests that the Arsenal man is no longer an automatic choice. That at least is the hope to which Leeds United's Nigel Martyn will be clinging.

If whatever team Eriksson fields beats Finland in style, doubts about England's chances of appearing in Japan and South Korea next year will start to ease. A convincing victory would set England up for a win in Albania on Wednesday and seven points from four qualifiers is decidedly healthier than one from two.

Yet for the nation's first foreign coach, the margin of error is narrow almost to non-existence. Germany's 1-0 win at Wembley last October, which was immediately followed by Kevin Keegan's resignation as coach, has all but ruled out the likelihood of England qualifying automatically as group winners. A further setback now would endanger their chances of reaching the play-offs as runners-up. At present they are bottom of Group Nine, behind Greece and Albania.

An historic first Finnish victory over England would spell finis for most of what remains of English optimism and a another draw after the barren scoreless affair under Howard Wilkinson in Helsinki would not be much better. But a Finn win would still be a delicious irony for Anfield, seeing that Jari Litmanen and Sami Hyypia are playing on home ground.

Eriksson's approach has quickly shown refreshing signs of rationality. He has not had time to build a successful England side from new foundations so he is constructing a team from prefabricated sections of the best English parts available.

Today's likely team, and the one to face Albania on Wednesday, might have been delivered as a flatpack from Ikea. The midfield and attack is drawn almost exclusively from Manchester United and Liverpool - even the one exception, Steve McManaman, was an Anfield regular.

The goalkeeping and defensive positions will be more diverse, with men from Arsenal, Leeds and Tottenham in crucial positions. Equally, much will be asked of a 31-year-old from Charlton Athletic who, as everyone keeps reminding Chris Powell, was once on loan to Aldershot.

England are expected to start today's game with seven of those who started against Spain in last month's friendly at Villa Park, when a 3-0 victory ensured Eriksson of a successful launch as England's first foreign coach, even if the opposition's half-hearted approach did much to grease the slipway. It could be eight if, against expectations, Eriksson prefers to play Phil Neville at right-back instead of his brother Gary. If the predictions are correct, however, Gary Neville will join Rio Ferdinand, Sol Campbell and Powell in the back four with Gerrard and Paul Scholes in midfield flanked by David Beckham and McManaman.

Andy Cole will lead the attack with Michael Owen dropping off, a combination that showed promise against Spain. Cole gave his best England performance in that game, although the player's protestations this week that none of Eriksson's predecessors understood him was a bit rich coming from striker who has not scored in 11 international appearances.

That should change this afternoon provided England get an early grip of the midfield. Gerrard and Scholes will be important both in linking defence to attack and preventing Litmanen in particular from getting behind them.

"I never mark man-for-man," Eriksson explained yesterday, "but we must try not to give Litmanen too much space. Then he can be a danger. Finland are a very organised team with two quick players up front and central defenders who are good in the air. We must not allow ourselves to become stretched. You cannot play good football when that happens."

Cole and Owen are entitled to demand a solid platform from which they can take on defenders who know all too well what to expect. At the same time Eriksson is entitled to expect Cole to hit the target at least when the opportunity arises. With both Cole and Owen in form for their clubs it is hard to believe that one or the other, or even both, will not score today.

In any case, Scholes's penchant for getting beyond the front runners to find the net is always a useful alternative.

Eriksson's appointment continues to have its critics. The strident cries of England for the English will not easily be silenced. All that this quietly knowledgeable Swede can do is win matches and give the nation's football followers something better to look forward to than a spot of flagwaving followed by inevitable failure amid water-cannon accompaniment.

The Football Association believes, reasonably enough, that England cannot seriously consider winning another World Cup until the 2006 tournament in Germany. But for that to happen it is essential that the present crop of players, plus any budding talents waiting in the wings, get tournament experience. Which is why England cannot afford to drop more points at home now.

 Fifa ruled yesterday that England's World Cup qualifier in Albania on Wednesday will go ahead. Violence in neighbouring Macedonia had left the match in doubt.
