webTitle: Cole comes in from the cold

fields.headline: Cole comes in from the cold
fields.standfirst: England's striker is finally coming to terms with his troubled past, writes  Richard Williams
fields.trailText: England's striker is finally coming to terms with his troubled past, writes Richard Williams
fields.body:
Andy Cole was at it again this week, scowling at the world and pouring scorn on those who had doubted him, thwarted him, and generally hindered his development into the top-class international forward he has always believed himself to be. The temptation to yawn was almost overwhelming. But whereas sometimes a player lets rip in order to get himself noticed, or to earn a few grand from a red-top tabloid, at least Cole's motives seemed relatively unsullied by arrogance or avarice.

Probably all he wanted to say was that the new England coach seems like a decent chap who is willing to give him a fair shake. But he was unable to say it without making the comparison between Sven-Goran Eriksson and his predecessors, who - in Cole's version - wantonly inflicted varying degrees of damage on the Manchester United striker's international career. So far that career is mainly celebrated for yielding no goals in 11 appearances stretching back six years, a time during which he has scored 115 goals for Manchester United at an average of just under one every two matches. In expressing his pleasure in being granted, at last, a decent run in the national side, he chose to preface the award of his 12th cap, which seems certain to come against Finland today, by aiming another stream of bile out of the rear window.

"It's the first time I've had this backing at international level," he said. "Other England managers have talked rubbish. They're entitled to their opinion, but it means nothing to me. I always knew I could cut it at international level."

If there is some justice in what he says, it hardly needed saying. Above all, now is not the time to say it. After being treated with caution by Terry Venables, Glenn Hoddle and Kevin Keegan, his chance is here at last, thanks to Eriksson, who said after the match against Spain three weeks ago: "Andy Cole is a great international football player." Having evidently convinced the man who matters, all Cole needs to do is demonstrate the truth of the assertion to the rest of us.

A convincing performance this afternoon will undoubtedly lead to a 13th cap in Albania on Wednesday. And success in Tirana will set him up for a crescendo that should reach its climax at the World Cup finals in Japan and South Korea in the summer of 2002, when he will be 30 years old and facing his last chance to make a significant impact at the very highest level. He should be looking ahead, not giving the impression that he still broods on the slights administered in the past.

We expect top athletes to show some gratitude for their good fortune, and find it hard to make allowances when the occasional Cole or Christie refuses to let go of the suspicion and resentment that influenced their earlier existences. Someone who worked with Cole at Manchester United, for example, remembers that immediately after his much-publicised arrival at Old Trafford, their first conversation was conducted without a single meeting of the eyes. Such a self-assessment might be suspected of over-dramatisation were it not for the validation provided by Cole's record of turbulence. During three years as a member of the Arsenal first-team squad, he was restricted by Graham to only one brief appearance as a sub.

"The whole experience was invaluable," he reflected later. "You had to forget any notion that you were owed an easy living. It was a case of buckling down and taking the discipline. If I had retained my earlier independent, even insolent attitude, I couldn't have survived."

By this time next week it may seem particularly significant that his mentor at Lilleshall was Dave Sexton, the much-loved veteran whom he describes as "one of the best coaches I have ever worked under". Sexton joined the senior England camp this week, and was immediately listed in the official personnel roll beneath Eriksson and Tord Grip but ahead of Peter Taylor and Steve McClaren. After being, in his view, so comprehensively misunderstood at senior England level, Cole may feel doubly reassured by the presence of Sexton alongside McClaren, his current coach at Old Trafford.

Cole's scoring record with his club is impeccable, but so is that of Kevin Phillips at Sunderland. Eriksson is banking on the Manchester United man's ability to produce the extra touch of class that defines a true international. Unlike Phillips, after all, he has scored goals against Barcelona, Juventus, Fiorentina, Marseille, Valencia and Sturm Graz in the six years since he moved to Old Trafford, plus hat-tricks against Feyenoord in 1997 and Anderlecht last September. It might be pointed out by sceptics, however, that he has scored in only two of the eight Champions League matches in which he has played this season.

His inability to register his first international goal is only one of the mysteries that tend to hang around Andy Cole. Why did Venables find it necessary to pretend, in 1994, that the forward was injured when he left him out of an England squad? Cole, to his credit, blew protocol apart by publicly exposing that apparently convenient fiction. Why did Keegan show such curious alacrity in accepting Ferguson's offer of £6m for a man who had scored 55 goals in 69 games for a Newcastle United side on its way back to the top? Why did Hoddle choose to remark so cruelly that Cole required five or six chances to score a goal? Why did he announce last year that he wished henceforth to be known as Andrew Cole? (The answer to that, it is said, is due less to a sudden access of late-blooming gravitas than to a sudden discovery that the website andycole.com had already been registered.)

At 29, with a long-term partner and a growing son, he is no longer the "plain and simple tearaway" whose unattractive exploits he ruefully chronicled in his autobiography. The first sign may have been the way he grew into his United shirt after the retirement of Eric Cantona, whose headmasterly glares had held his early errors up to harsh exposure. The second may have been the maturity with which he appeared to ease naturally out of his initially close friendship with his fellow striker Dwight Yorke, an unreconstructed party animal. The next sign - but don't hold your breath - might be a rebuilding of bridges with Teddy Sheringham, the United and England colleague to whom he has not spoken off the pitch since an argument two years ago, apparently concerning Cole's alleged reluctance to do his share of the defensive chores.

Now he faces, in quick succession, two chances to establish himself as England's first-choice strike forward, alongside a younger man, Michael Owen, with whom he may yet establish a fruitful partnership. Neither has the world's sweetest first touch. But both have speed across the ground, quick feet, a willingness to improvise, and the sort of football brain that is visible in the angles of the darting runs they make when the ball is elsewhere. And, finally, the urgent, unshakeable belief that this is where they truly belong.

webTitle: Amiable Swede who says little with great elan

fields.headline: Amiable Swede who says little with great elan
fields.trailText: The greater the acquaintanceship with Sven-Goran Eriksson the less foreign he seems. In fact so rational is the public persona of England's Swedish coach that, by comparison, it is his predecessors who now appear alien.
fields.body:
The greater the acquaintanceship with Sven-Goran Eriksson the less foreign he seems. In fact so rational is the public persona of England's Swedish coach that, by comparison, it is his predecessors who now appear alien.

Eriksson's English may not be perfect but unlike Alf Ramsey he does not play hide-and-seek with his aspirates. Occasionally he wears a blue suit but it is safe to assume that it does not possess the mystical powers of good fortune woven into Don Revie's blue two-piece.

His footballing beliefs are probably comparable with those of Ron Greenwood but he will be less easily upset by adverse headlines. In La Manga and Athens this summer he may, like Bobby Robson, warn his squad not to lie out in the hot sun but is unlikely to caution them against the dangers of "ultra-ray violets".

With Tord Grip as his amiable Viking shield Eriksson will not need to hire a public relations man to ward off the slings and arrows of tabloid tormentors, which is what Graham Taylor did, once he had been recast as a turnip. Nor will he become a subject of interest for the Department of Trade and Industry, as did Terry Venables.

Eriksson's religious convictions, if he has any, will remain a matter for him alone but it seems safe to assume that he does not see himself as the reincarnation of Greta Garbo, will not be encouraging his injured players to put themselves in the hot, healing hands of a former pub landlady, and does not intend keeping a diary of his England experiences to be serialised in a national newspaper for a six-figure fee. Glenn Hoddle reborn he is not.

Unlike Kevin Keegan he has not taken the England job backed by a wave of public enthusiasm, far from it. Yet already, compared with Keegan, Eriksson's promises to be a reign in the proper sense rather than a cardboard coronation followed by abdication at the first rocking of the throne.

He clearly intends to take England to the next two World Cups and the 2004 European Championship in between but if he fails he will likely depart as calmly and with as equally good grace as he came. Already, and to his credit, Eriksson is proving a one-man disaster area for the sports pages. As with prime ministers, newspapers prefer their England coaches to be bookies or bishops; either sharp and streetwise like Revie, Venables and Keegan or remote but vulnerable like Ramsey and Hoddle.

Eriksson falls into neither category. Nearly 20 years spent keeping company with the Latin footballing passions of southern Europe have taught him the wisdom of saying not very much to reporters, but nicely.

All he has said of significance so far is that on the field he does not believe in trying to use players out of their usual club positions and off it he trusts that the England squad will not act like drunken sailors on shore leave.

The rest has been a series of polite banalities, much in the tradition of the foreign visitor who expresses admiration for the greenness of the English countryside, the politeness of our policemen, the quaintness of driving on the left-hand side and the ingenuity of the plumbing.

England, Eriksson insists, should be up among the leading European football nations like France, Germany and Italy. Quite right, but this will never happen because English football is entirely club-oriented and restricts the national team and its coach to a handful of days to prepare for even the most important internationals.

Eriksson considers himself fortunate to have taken the job at a time when such a healthy crop of talented youngsters, including Steven Gerrard, Joe Cole, Michael Carrick and Wes Brown, are coming on to the international scene. This is undeniable but 11 years ago Paul Gascoigne held the key to the nation's dreams of future glory only to have trouble finding the lock.

Maybe, for Eriksson and the media, this has just been a period of phoney war which will end when England take the field against Finland at Anfield this afternoon. Certainly the friendly against Spain at Villa Park amounted to little more than peacetime manoeuvres.

When the revelation that the players' wives will be allowed to visit their menfolk during the lull between the Finland game and Monday's departure for Albania becomes an issue for urgent debate in the sports columns it really is all quiet on the Swedish front. One of this week's back-page banners, Grip relishes potential, smacked of Lord Gort talking up the bayonets of the British Expeditionary Force in May 1940.

This is not to suggest that the Eriksson-Grip line is about to be breached by the forces of Finland and Albania or that the Greek campaign will be an odyssey without an Odysseus. The reality, however, is that Eriksson is picking up the fragments of England's worst start yet to a World Cup qualifying competition knowing that he will almost certainly have to win a play-off later this year to go through.

And if, after all this, he can retain his calmness and affability and continue to disarm loaded questions with a modest smile he might well be the government's man to persuade us to join the Euro.

webTitle: Macedonia is on knife edge, Nato chief says

fields.headline: Macedonia is on knife edge, Nato chief says
fields.standfirst: Special report: Macedonia
fields.trailText: Macedonia is on a knife edge, with its coalition government facing the dilemma of trying to offer concessions to ethnic Albanians without provoking the Slav majority, Lord Robertson, the Nato secretary general said last night.
fields.byline: Richard Norton-Taylor and Ian Black in Stockholm
fields.body:
Macedonia is on a knife edge, with its coalition government facing the dilemma of trying to offer concessions to ethnic Albanians without provoking the Slav majority, Lord Robertson, the Nato secretary general said last night.

However, progress was being made in areas bordering Serbia and Kosovo, he said. This included the promise of peace talks this weekend between Serbia and ethnic Albanian leaders fighting in the Presevo valley - an area bordering Kosovo, southern Serbia, and Macedonia.

Lord Robertson also said an agreement had been reached with Nato-led K-For peacekeepers which would allow lightly-armed Serb forces to enter two buffer zones along the northern and western border with Kosovo.

It was essential, he said, to "marginalise" ethnic Albanian extremists whose objective - as it had been previously in Kosovo and southern Serbia - was to provoke a disproportionate reaction that would drag in outside forces.

Nato, the UN, and the EU are all pressing the Macedonians to reach a political solution, including a higher status for the Albanian language, more Albanians in public administration and more money for the Albanian university in Tetovo, Macedonia's second city.

Lord Robertson said the UN had estimated that 18,000 ethnic Albanians had left their homes in Macedonia, 11,000 of them displaced inside the country.

At a London briefing, he conceded that some Nato governments were reluctant to move more of their troops to Kosovo's border with Macedonia. Though he did not name the countries concerned, they are believed to include the US.

Asked if K-For troops could not have done more to police the border, he replied: "It is very, very difficult territory".

However, the Macedonian president, Boris Trajkovski, made his view quite plain yesterday. "We think they [K-For] have to improve their presence on the border," he said in Stockholm where he is attending the EU summit.

Lord Robertson said he was optimistic that Nato countries would send extra troops to Kosovo, although he has scaled down his request from an extra 1,400 soldiers to what he called yesterday "six companies " - about 600 troops.

Germany yesterday announced plans to send around 130 extra soldiers from its artillery battery in Kosovo to Skopje on Sunday to reinforce German K-For patrols on the border. The defence ministry spokesman, Detlef Puhl, said the new troops would take charge of four self-propelled guns which would be brought out of reserve. A company of 100 to 150 men which had been due to be withdrawn from the area would also be kept in place.

EU leaders welcomed Mr Trajkovski yesterday to support him in his conflict with ethnic Albanian rebels and push him toward reforms that ease tense ethnic tensions.

The leaders heard a report from Javier Solana, the EU's foreign policy supremo, its external affairs commissioner Chris Patten, and Anna Lindh, the Swedish foreign minister, who have all visited Skopje in the last few days to discuss ways in which the violence could be contained.

Mr Trajkovski was urged to meet demands for a greater role in Macedonian society for the ethnic Albanians and call on Albanians in neighbouring countries - especially in Kosovo - to distance themselves from the fighting.

EU leaders have a significant carrot to offer: next month the union is to sign a "stabilisation and association agreement" with Macedonia that requires it to work for peaceful resolution of its internal conflicts.

The Macedonian leader was told of Brussels' backing for his country's territorial integrity and Nato's pledge to step up efforts to prevent guerrilla infiltration across the Kosovo-Macedonia border.

fields.headline: Kosovo leaders urge rebels to quit
fields.standfirst: Special report: Macedonia
fields.trailText: The leaders of Kosovo's three main political parties, including two former guerrilla chiefs, have signed a declaration urging ethnic Albanian gunmen in Macedonia to lay down arms and go home peacefully.
fields.body:
The leaders of Kosovo's three main political parties, including two former guerrilla chiefs, have signed a declaration urging ethnic Albanian gunmen in Macedonia to lay down arms and go home peacefully.

The statement was drawn up by European Union diplomats with the implicit threat that unless the leaders condemned the violence in Macedonia, Kosovo would lose the financial aid it has been getting from western countries for reconstruction, as well as support for self-government.

Diplomats described it as a breakthrough in their efforts to end the insurgency which erupted in villages on the border between Kosovo and Macedonia and spread to the hills above Tetovo 10 days ago.

In a sign that the Macedonian gunmen may be heeding the new pressure from their former comrades-in-arms in Kosovo, yesterday's funeral of two men killed by Macedonian police on Thursday when they tried to throw a grenade at a checkpoint was kept low-key. No Albanian flags were flown and none of the hundreds of mourners displayed guerrilla insignia, let alone weapons.

The most significant signatory to the Pristina declaration calling for an end to the insurgency was Ramush Haradinaj, leader of the Alliance for the Future of Kosovo. In 1998 and 99, he commanded the Kosovo Liberation Army in western Kosovo, which saw some of the fiercest fighting against Yugoslav forces.

Ali Ahmeti, the only identified leader of the National Liberation Army which has been operating in Macedonia, was a local commander under Mr Haradinaj in western Kosovo and a key figure in organising the KLA' s gun-running and logistics. Like many other Albanian Macedonians, he studied in Kosovo at Pristina University and was imprisoned by the Serbs before going to Switzerland.

The statement was due to be signed on Thursday night, when the EU's top officials, including Javier Solana and Chris Patten, spoke to the Kosovo leaders, but Mr Haradinaj asked for more time to consult. The other signatories were Hashim Thaci, the KLA's former political leader and Ibrahim Rugova, a longtime supporter of non-violence who heads Kosovo's largest party, the Democratic League.

"We, the leaders of the political parties in Kosovo, call on the extremist groups which have taken up arms on the territory of Macedonia to lay them down immediately and return to their homes peacefully," the statement said. "We urge the Macedonian government to show restraint and to address and resolve the grievances through peaceful and democratic means."

Kosovo's leaders have made ringing statements under donors' pressure on various issues in the past, including calls for an end to violence against the territory's Serbs and Roma - without visible effect. So the new statement will have to be tested on the ground. But there have been signs that the guerrillas may be scaling down the fighting, although it is unclear if they are dispersing to different parts of Macedonia or lying low until the international focus shifts. They offered a unilateral truce earlier this week and have not responded to sporadic government shelling around Tetovo for several days.

Meanwhile, for the first time since the fighting began, Macedonia admitted attacking guerrilla positions inside Kosovo. "We attacked targets inside Kosovo because they were fortifying positions to launch a grenade attack on our forces," a defence ministry spokesman said. "Macedonia has a right to defend itself."

The gunmen have been using Kosovo as a rear supply base, although Nato-led forces have now started to make good on their promise to try to seal the mountainous border between the two countries.

webTitle: Duke gets bullish over protection of prize beasts

fields.headline: Duke gets bullish over protection of prize beasts
fields.standfirst: Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: The Duke of Westminster has taken drastic measures to protect his prize herd of bulls during the foot-and-mouth crisis, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
The Duke of Westminster has taken drastic measures to protect his prize herd of bulls during the foot-and-mouth crisis, it emerged yesterday.

The 140 Holstein bulls are being kept inside a specially sealed barn along with a vet and studman on the duke's Grosvenor estate in Chester.

Filtered oxygen is being pumped into the tents where both the men and the bulls are expected to remain until Cheshire is given the all-clear by ministry officials.

It is hoped the cattle would escape slaughter even if foot-and-mouth were confirmed within the government-imposed exclusion zone.

It is understood the measures were introduced a week ago by breeding company Cogent to protect the bulls, which produce high-quality semen in demand by exporters. Managing director Tim Heywood said: "We normally have 28 people in the area looking after the bulls but we were forced to take these extraordinary measures to make sure our prize herd remains free of any chance of infection from foot-and-mouth.

"No exterior air is allowed to enter, except that pumped in through special Ministry of Agriculture-approved filters. For the past week, our company vet and our studman have been locked in with the bulls. We deliver groceries to them and even the odd beer to help them feel more comfortable."

So far just two cases of foot-and-mouth have been confirmed in Cheshire - both on farms at Baddiley, near Nantwich.

fields.headline: Stunned livestock 'left to die'
fields.standfirst:
Maff official claims animals are suffering

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Animals being culled because of foot and mouth are suffering because they are not being properly slaughtered, an animal health officer claims.
fields.body:
Animals being culled because of foot and mouth are suffering because they are not being properly slaughtered, an animal health officer claims.

The official for the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food, who did not want to be named, said that livestock were being stunned and left to die without further assistance.

The RSPCA said it was being bombarded with calls from farmers and members of the public worried about animal welfare during the cull.

Slaughterers use captive bolts - metal bars that are fired into the skull and immediately retract - to knock out animals. But they need to have their main arteries cut or be "pithed" with a metal rod inserted into the hole created by the bolt to destroy the brain stem.

"Some farm animals are not being pithed," said the animal health officer. "I have been told that by both farmers and colleagues. A cow which has not been pithed could be alive for hours." He blamed inadequate training and the fact that slaughterers were not used to such high-pressure situations.

According to government slaughter regulations, animals may be killed with a captive bolt "provided that the animal is either pithed or the blood vessels in its neck are severed without delay afterwards, and in any event before the animal regains consciousness".

The RSPCA has written to Maff to express worries about the cull. Chris Laurence, the society's chief vet, said it wanted assurance that animal welfare was "not being compromised in any way. For example, using rifles increases the possibility of the animal not being killed immediately."

A Maff spokesman said that if animals were not being bled or pithed if a stun gun was used "we would need evidence of that. If [the animal health officer] brings evidence to us we will act on it.

"Rifles fired at close range through the head are permitted as a method of slaughter."

webTitle: Under the dark shadow of the slaughterman

fields.headline: Under the dark shadow of the slaughterman
fields.standfirst:
As his herd's destruction nears, a Scottish sheep farmer tells of personal horror and warns of disease's long-term effects

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: As his herd's destruction nears, a Scottish sheep farmer tells of personal horror and warns of disease's long-term effects
fields.body:
When the killing has to start, Gordon Rae will lure his sheep to slaughter with their last bag of feed.

It is the only way. The maternal instinct is so strong in his 650 ewes, newly lambed, that they would attack his dogs if he tried to round them up.

The thought of what will follow haunts him. "You are immediately given a choice: muck in and keep busy or disappear until they have finished," he said.

"I think I will be needed. The sheep will come to a bag of feed and the lambs will follow. It's dreadful to think you are rounding them up with feed to lead them into this situation.

"I imagine it will be a captive-bolt gun for the ewes and I have heard they use lethal injection for the lambs. There will be no order. I don't imagine they will take a ewe with its lamb by its side.

"There will just be a big pen and there will be enormous distress among the animals. You only need to try and move 10 sheep out of the shed and they are spinning around in panic looking for their lambs.

"I go out on the field now and I feed them and the lambs are leaping around and the fields are peaceful, and you can't comprehend that they are going to turn into fields of fire."

The Raes have farmed here at Muirhead, on the edge of Lockerbie, for more than 50 years - first Gordon's father, Hastings, and now Gordon himself.

The pink-washed farm sits on a small rise to the west of the town. In better days the views will be stunning. In these altered times the scene is marred by smoke from giant pyres, like preparations for some monstrous feast the Raes are compelled to join.

Muirhead is clean but the infection is all around and so its flock must die. They are waiting for the call.

It has been a thriving business. Each year they produce around 1,100 lambs for market and they have a second farm where they winter cattle for other farmers, and a sheep-shearing business that serves the county.

Gordon, 38, knows that livestock farming can be a brutal affair. "Normally we look to sell the lambs at about 16 weeks old in May and June. The ewes are not feeding them by that time but it is the same as humans - the bond is still there. It is an unfortunate thing, but we are in business and that is the way the system works. The bond has to be broken."

But this feels different; this feels wrong. Most of the lambs, around 800, are already here. Most are only days old.

"I'm fairly hardened to a lot of things but it will be very difficult," he said. "I don't know how to accept it. I don't know if my father will be able to take any part in it."

The children know. At eight, Jennifer has taken it on board. George, five, has a fair idea. Two-year-old Calum tells visitors: "Baa's dead."

"They all have pet sheep," said Gordon. "They've asked me if we could use one of the sheds to hide their own sheep, until the men have gone."

Life has taken on a grotesque routine. Gordon has had to lamb the young ewes with a towel around his head, so thick was the smoke from a neighbour's pyre. He sleeps no more than four or five hours a night and spends his days checking for lesions and lameness. They have already had one scare.

The feed is running out, but the feed company will not deliver more; it says it is pointless. "But it's not bred in you to just neglect them," said Gordon. "It's not the fault of the sheep. You keep looking after them."

His face is a study in fatigue and frustration. He has stopped watching the news. He does not think Tony Blair or any of the others have truly understood what this crisis means. He has started to feel that the world is tumbling in.

"I really don't think people have a clue. I was speaking to one of our local auctioneers the other day and he said, 'Give me the top brass for a day and I will put them back in their cars in tears'. We have farms here where the hardest men are on their hands and knees. They are chasing the disease but it is running away from them."

He wonders if politicians know the most basic things; that wiping out the hill stock will throw everything off kilter for years. "If you cull them all and put new stock on, they will be totally lost. They will get killed in the snow, they will disappear. That's an enormous problem facing the industry."

He cannot even think about the financial side. He will have to sign a valuation minutes before the flock is slaughtered and has heard the going rate is £90 per ewe. That is not enough. His flock is young and robust - prime stock. He wonders what they will do with empty fields in a silent spring. It could be late summer before he can restock. It could be as long as a year.

He worries, too, about his dad. "My father has been here all his life. In 1952 there was an outbreak and this farm was one of only three that escaped it. He's a man of few words, but he said the other day that he wondered if we could ever escape it this time." Outside, Hastings Rae, 66, is looking to the horizon. "We just live day to day," he said. "We have no idea what is coming." Then he smiled gently. "Let's talk of something else," he said, and the subject changed to the comforting banalities of a normal life.

But behind him, the line of fire on the skyline is moving closer.

The time for killing is almost here.

webTitle: Russia evicts 4 diplomats in growing battle of wills

fields.headline: Russia evicts 4 diplomats in growing battle of wills
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Russia
Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: Four American diplomats were ordered to leave Russia yesterday in the first retaliation for the expulsion of 50 Russian diplomats from Washington. Kremlin officials, however, warned that more "painful" reprisals were imminent.
fields.body:
Four American diplomats were ordered to leave Russia yesterday in the first retaliation for the expulsion of 50 Russian diplomats from Washington. Kremlin officials, however, warned that more "painful" reprisals were imminent.

The four diplomats, accused of "activities incompatible with their status" - a diplomatic euphemism for spying - were told that they must leave Moscow in the next few days.

The foreign ministry said the US could expect further measures aimed at stopping "illegal activities of official US representatives in Russia".

What form these measures might take was not clear, but the foreign minister, Igor Ivanov, previously had said that the expulsions from Moscow would mirror the number of Russian diplomats ordered out of the US.

"However many are expelled from the US will be expelled from Russia," a senior aide to the president, Vladimir Putin, said.

As the worst spy row since the end of the cold war intensified, the US ambassador to the Russian federation, James Collins, chose to retreat from the capital for a 10-day railway tour of southern Siberia, visiting regional public libraries.

His deputy, John Ordway, was summoned instead to the foreign ministry to receive details of the initial expulsions.

Undisclosed security sources said that they had already drawn up a list of other US officials who were spying under cover of diplomatic immunity.

Mr Putin, who was in Stockholm yesterday to meet European heads of state during an EU economic summit, played down the developing crisis in Russian-American relations, responding curtly to reporters' questions.

"I have no particular opinion about that," he said of the spy row.

Asked if he thought it would seriously strain relations between the two countries, he replied: "I do not think so."

The tit-for-tat expulsions were triggered by the arrest of senior FBI official Robert Hanssen, charged with passing secrets to Moscow for the past 15 years.

The US president, George Bush, announced his decision to banish four Russian diplomats on Thursday; another 46 Russians have until July 1 to leave the country.

Senior figures within the Kremlin did not share the president's relaxed attitude, however. The head of the security council, for instance, reacted angrily to the expulsions.

Sergei Ivanov, in the US for bridge-building meetings last week, added that the move marked the end of cooperation between the two countries on problems such as international terrorism or drug smuggling.

Dismissing American suggestions that the incident would not affect bilateral ties, he accused George Bush's administration of adopting "cold-war stereotypes".

"The current spy scandal is a clear political step aimed primarily at showing off the new administration's strong muscles, and at demonstrating what tough guys have arrived in power in the USA," he said during a visit to Poland.

"We can easily find a response that is more painful to the United States," he warned. "We have time to think, to carefully pick from among more than 1,000 US diplomats in Russia, to choose those who are most precious to the Americans."

The former prime minister and KGB head, Yevgeny Primakov, also reacted irritably.

"They think that they can treat us like some sort of Latin American country - not just any Latin American, but as a banana republic," he said.

Most Russian newspapers interpreted the crisis as a serious step in an ongoing process of deteriorating relations between the two former cold-war enemies.

webTitle: Potholes litter path to economic reform

fields.headline: Potholes litter path to economic reform
fields.standfirst:
EU leaders grapple with their differences and a euro stuck in the shadow of the dollar

Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: European Union leaders were struggling last night to make progress on liberalising their economies in the face of disagreements about pace, a weak euro and diversions over foot and mouth disease and Macedonia.
fields.body:
European Union leaders were struggling last night to make progress on liberalising their economies in the face of disagreements about pace, a weak euro and diversions over foot and mouth disease and Macedonia.

Tony Blair and fellow summiteers were able to declare one Stockholm success by agreeing a reform of financial services which will make access to capital easier in the EU's single market and offer wider consumer choice.

But they admitted to differences over other targets set at last year's Lisbon summit. And President Jacques Chirac of France complained that precious time was being used up in talks about the Balkans and Russia.

Despite continuing worries about the stock markets and the poor performance of the single currency, there was agreement that, although the economic fundamentals of euroland were strong, much modernisation was needed to allow it to better compete with the US.

Pedro Solbes, the EU's economic affairs commissioner, argued that relatively strong growth in Europe made it "a safe haven" for investors.

Yet there was no hope of reaching agreement by the summit's end this afternoon on liberalising the electricity and gas sectors - a key Lisbon demand - or of opening up postal services to EU-wide competition.

Hans Eichel, the German finance minister, predicted there would be no action from France before the 2002 elections. Laurent Fabius, his French colleague, said he did not want to see "deregulation for deregulation's sake" but wanted to ensure that any liberalisation would not come at the expense of the cost or quality of services to consumers.

European commission proposals for a "single European sky" to ease air traffic congestion - held up by an Anglo-Spanish row over Gibraltar - and for a European patent, also appeared to be in trouble.

Romano Prodi, president of the commission, began the day by saying that eurozone policy would be easier to coordinate if the 12 members of the single currency appointed a "Mr Euro" to represent them - an idea strongly opposed by the European Central Bank.

Mr Prodi made waves even before the summit began by suggesting that Sweden, its host, would find life easier if it joined the eurozone. Like Mr Blair, prime minister Goran Persson faces a tough decision on whether and when to call a referendum.

It was at last year's Lisbon "dot.com" summit that the EU pledged to create 20m new jobs by 2010 and make the union "the most competitive and dynamic knowledge-based economy in the world".

Stockholm's main purpose is to assess how far the Lisbon targets have been met and how Europe is faring in adapting to the digital age and putting new technologies to profitable use. It will also review progress on pushing ahead for fuller employment.

Thursday's complex eve of summit deal on financial services, pushed by Britain's chancellor, Gordon Brown, was always likely to be the easiest item to resolve, despite objections by Germany.

"It ensures that European industry and commerce as a whole have easier access to cheaper capital for innovation and the creation of jobs," said the internal market commissioner, Frits Bolkestein.

But Mr Bolkestein, an influential thinker, was sharply critical of the lack of progress elsewhere. "We continue to hark back to what was discussed at Lisbon but we should be anything but complacent on the progress that has been achieved," he said.

"Progress is spotty and that gives cause for concern. Brave words were spoken on liberalisation. They have not been followed up to a sufficient extent."

Brussels wants to push governments to go further, acknowledging that it is its historic role - however thankless - to set the pace. Mr Prodi's spokesman, Jonathan Faull, warned on Thursday that the summit was the "moment of truth" for EU leaders.

Yesterday he denied that he was making any link to the troubles of the euro. But leaders are aware that progress towards streamlining the economy could help prop up the ailing currency during a slump in financial markets.

Governments sought to put a more positive spin on the likely summit outcome today. "This is a 10-year plan and this is year one," said one senior British official. "You are talking about 15 member states and you need to gear people up politically."

webTitle: Russian president welcomed to EU gathering

fields.headline: All smiles
fields.standfirst:
Russian president welcomed to EU gathering

Special report: European integration
Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: Vladimir Putin turned the tables on critics of his Chechnya policy by suggesting in Stockholm last night that Nato use helicopter gunships to wipe out Albanian rebels in Macedonia.
fields.body:
Vladimir Putin turned the tables on critics of his Chechnya policy by suggesting in Stockholm last night that Nato use helicopter gunships to wipe out Albanian rebels in Macedonia. But if the Russian president enjoyed making a point about the unfinished business of Nato's war with Yugoslavia, he didn't show it.

Mr Putin used a carefully controlled press conference to rebuff calls for an investigation into human rights abuses in Chechnya. Amnesty International had called on the EU to keep its distance until the Chechen issue was tackled.

Goran Persson, Sweden's prime minister, hosted Mr Putin at a working lunch to review the economic and legal reforms the Europeans are pressing for.

Boris Yeltsin was the first Russian leader to attend an EU summit, but Mr Putin is viewed as more stable than his mercurial predecessor.

Before the president arrived, officials endorsed the principle of providing up to 100m euros (£62m) in loans to help Russia clean up environmental blackspots in the Baltic region. "That's what he really wanted," said one diplomat.

webTitle: Europe pleads with US over eco deal

fields.headline: Europe pleads with US over eco-deal as the lights go out in California
fields.standfirst:
EU calls for Bush to honour Kyoto agreement on greenhouse gases despite growing power crisis

Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: EU calls for Bush to honour Kyoto agreement on greenhouse gases despite growing power crisis
fields.body:
The European Union has warned President George Bush that the US must honour its agreement to cut greenhouse gas emissions blamed for causing global warming.

The call to Mr Bush to show the "political courage" to stick to the deal made in Kyoto comes just as the president is dismaying environmentalists with his energy policies and as California plunges deeper into a power crisis.

A letter to the White House - signed by the European commission president Romano Prodi and Goran Persson, the prime minister of Sweden which currently holds the rotating EU presidency - stresses the importance of the 1997 United Nations deal that commits developed countries to cut their greenhouse gas emissions.

"The global and long-term importance of climate change and the need for a joint effort by all industrialised countries in this field makes it an integral part of relations between the USA and the EU," it said.

Attempts to finalise the details of the Kyoto agreement, which would require the US and other developed countries to cut their emissions of six greenhouse gases by an average of 5.2% by 2010, foundered last November.

Both Mr Bush and his vice-president Dick Cheney are from oil business backgrounds as are many of their heaviest financial supporters.

They have made it clear from the start of their administration that they are willing to waive environmental regulations in the pursuit of better energy supply. Mr Cheney has already said that he does not support the Kyoto approach.

The EU would have found a more sympathetic ear had Al Gore been elected president because of his commitment to environmental issues but it is already clear that Mr Bush feels no obligation.

The letter emphasises the role that the US has to play as the major consumer of energy in the world.

"Since a reduction in our dependency on fossil fuels goes straight to the heart of the functioning of our industrial societies, there is no doubt that this transformation will be difficult to achieve," it says. "It will require a vision, political courage, and an extraordinary effort of international cooperation."

On the home front, Mr Bush has made it clear that he believes that the current black-outs which have been affecting California this week are in part to do with the state's environmental policies, which impose strict guidelines on the creation of new power plants.

The blackouts have continued to affect the state and more are anticipated. This being Oscar week, there was particular interest in a power cut in a courtroom in Ventura north of Los Angeles.

There, a lawyer was listening to the charges that he personally had conspired to extort $310,000 from the legal worker Erin Brockovich by threatening her with tabloid exposure by falsely claiming that she was a bad mother. Suddenly, the power went out in the court building and the case was halted.

Ms Brockovich is the subject of the eponymous Steven Soderbergh film which starred Julia Roberts and Albert Finney. It is hoped it will scoop at least one statue at Sunday's Oscar ceremony. The lawyer facing charges, John Reiner, is accused of conspiring with Ms Brockovich's ex-boyfriend and ex-husband to blackmail her.

Lawyers for both sides had planned a multimedia presentation to the court but that was temporarily foiled when the rolling blackouts that have engulfed the state over the past week hit Ventura. All was silent until an extension lead could be found for an emergency generator.

The chances of the Oscars ceremony being blacked out are remote but throughout California there have been indications of what may be in store as the summer arrives and the air conditioners are turned on.

To the rest of the world it may seem that a power crisis in the wealthiest state in the union means only a sudden tumble on the treadmill or a loss of power while putting wheatgrass in the juicer for most Californians, but the blackouts are already having much wider effects on both a personal and political level.

"You look around you here and there are people with money falling out of their pockets, so much money they don't know what to do with it," said a media executive in Westwood on the second day of the blackouts. "And yet you have blackouts - it's mad."

The Governor, Gray Davis, is also mad - mad at the utilities companies whose actions have ultimately led to the blackouts.

One exacerbating factor of the crisis is that cash-strapped utilities companies have failed to pay smaller alternative generators of power via wind and solar panels, so they are not supplying electricity.

"It's wrong and irresponsible of the utilities to pocket this money [from consumers] and not pay the generators," Mr Davis said.

While the electricity crisis has caused political problems for Mr Davis, Californians are divided on its true causes.

Max, a Russian immigrant who works now as a driver in Santa Monica, is one of many who believe that the blackouts are all part of a conspiracy. "It's all just an excuse so that they can put our bills up and we won't make a fuss about it," he said.

"They can say 'Hey, do you want more blackouts or do you want to pay more?' They know what they're doing."

There are fears that water and natural gas supplies could be curtailed in the future. Attempts to persuade people to conserve power - or indeed anything - have been largely unsuccessful.

To rub salt into the wound, Vicente Fox, the Mexican president, has offered to supply energy from Mexico, California's poor neighbour.

webTitle: iii labels itself a sell after failing to make service pay

fields.headline: iii labels itself a sell after failing to make service pay
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Interactive Investor International yesterday underlined the difficulties that financial news websites are having trying to turn users into paying customers by putting itself up for sale.
fields.body:
Interactive Investor International yesterday underlined the difficulties that financial news websites are having trying to turn users into paying customers by putting itself up for sale.

Britain's most popular source of news about stocks and shares online might now be bought by a big stockbroking firm or a bank so that users would be able to buy a share or Isa once they have read about it on the site, said chief executive Tomas Carruthers. "Transactional capabilities are the key to this model and a link with a brokerage would make real sense. The sale of the company is absolutely a possibility."

iii, as it is better known to its 1.2m registered users, was one of the darling stocks of the dot.com boom. Its popular bulletin boards helped transform the way private investors found out about companies and swapped tips.

At one stage shares in iii were changing hands for 472.5p but as the market turned south and big firms reined in their advertising spend, its revenues began to dry up. Fewer people now trade shares online and the number of Isas being bought is less than half last year's tally, analysts say.

Shares in iii have fallen as low as 19p but yesterday's news that it might be sold saw the price rally 6% to 25p. iii's decline comes after the closure of rival thestreet.co.uk, and the merger of sharecast.com and nothingventured.com

"The entire sector has turned 180 degrees since we listed last year," Mr Carruthers said. "Market conditions are challenging to say the least and we've moved to cut costs across the business."

Staff numbers have fallen from 128 to 95 over the past four months and less is being spent on marketing.

Monthly cash burn has been reduced from more than £1m to around £500,000 as a result, Mr Carruthers said. iii had £51m cash in the bank yet the stock market valued the company plus its cash reserves at just £40m.

Shares in iii have fallen as low as 19p but yesterday's news that it might be sold saw the price rally 6% to 25p. iii's decline comes after the closure of rival thestreet.co.uk, and the merger of sharecast.com and nothingventured.com "The entire sector has turned 180 degrees since we listed last year," Mr Carruthers said. "Market conditions are challenging to say the least and we've moved to cut costs across the business." Staff numbers have fallen from 128 to 95 over the past four months and less is being spent on marketing. Monthly cash burn has been reduced from more than £1m to around £500,000 as a result, Mr Carruthers said. iii had £51m cash in the bank yet the stock market valued the company plus its cash reserves at just £40m.

webTitle: Punters spit venom in management's brave face

fields.headline: Punters spit venom in management's brave face
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Vitriol was flowing on the online bulletin boards yesterday, much of it aimed at internet business directory company Scoot.com.
fields.body:
"This is a disaster", "The gutter beckons for Scoot", "Latest results are dreadful".

Vitriol was flowing on the online bulletin boards yesterday, much of it aimed at internet business directory company Scoot.com.

On numerous occasions investors have piled into Scoot on the back of takeover speculation which came to nothing. With results out yesterday showing losses piling up but the management resolutely upbeat, they were in no mood to be charitable.

On personal finance website iii's bulletin board, UtterTripe reckoned the stock was a strong sell, claiming that with a 15-month net loss of £71.5m it was a case of "wakey wakey Scooters or you'll be left holding the baby".

Spitting Cobra said: "This is a disaster. The whole thing stinks; someone or some individuals knew all this six weeks ago Scoot is now definately [sic] finished ... Vivendi won't bid until after July so its going to be one long wait to see if we can salvage anything from this mess."

Mozeddy, who has held Scoot on and off for the past 18 months, said the latest results were "dreadful," adding: "Surely such a poor performer must be coming under pressure from major shareholders to change the top management?"

Abval1 said he baled out of the company "when I used the Scoot service for the first time and found that it was very poor indeed".

fields.headline: Scoot for sale
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Scoot, the much heralded internet directory service, yesterday capped a miserable year for investors who have seen the value of their shareholding slump by 94% by effectively putting itself up for sale.
fields.body:
Scoot, the much heralded internet directory service, yesterday capped a miserable year for investors who have seen the value of their shareholding slump by 94% by effectively putting itself up for sale.

Shares in Scoot fell a further 30% to 14p yesterday following an announcement that investment bank Merrill Lynch had been appointed to review "all strategic options" and agreement had been reached to issue 60m new shares "to strengthen its financial flexibility".

The news was accompanied by the resignation of Scoot's chief technology officer Charles Webb and the release of worse than expected financial results for the 15-months to December 2000.

Merrill Lynch, which also acts as Scoot's stockbroker, responded to the flurry of new information by lowering its recommendation on the stock from "accumulate" to "neutral".

Among its reasons for doing so, Merrill cited lower than expected revenues at Scoot, higher than expected exceptional costs and limited information on current subscriber numbers.

Scoot chief executive Robert Bonnier expressed disbelief at the fall in the share price, insisting that the company had delivered upon it promises and was showing good under-lying growth.

"The whole market has lost its complete sense of reality," he said in response to the share price fall. "I was always told that the market knows best but now I'm not so sure."

Mr Bonnier feels that Scoot shares have been over-sold by institutional investors and that the price has been adversely affected by a group of offshore investors taking "short" positions on the stock.

The most likely bidder for Scoot is Vivendi Universal, a 22% shareholder and a takeover has been rumoured for months. The French media giant paid 230p per share to buy into Scoot last year but analysts believe that following the dramatic fall in Scoot's share price it may now only want to pay 30-40p per share to buy the company outright.

Mr Bonnier it thought to believe that Scoot shares are worth much more than that and by appointing Merrill Lynch he thinks he may be able to find another bidder and force up the price.

Including last year's acquisition of free newspaper group Loot, net losses climbed from £21m in 1999 to £71.5m during the last 15 months. Group revenue climbed from £15.4m to £24.1m.

However, the Scoot UK businesses saw revenues fall 40% to £11.5m due to delays to the introduction of a new technology platform.

Despite the widening losses and the potential issue of new shares Mr Bonnier said Scoot had no plans to cut any of its 1,400 staff and would continue to aggressively expand into Europe.

Scoot now has 55,658 paying subscribers which is less than the 60,000 it targeted a year ago. Merrill Lynch said it remained "concerned" about the high-proportion of non-charging customers which it said appeared to be undermining the utility of the new service and "could lead to further delays".

Scoot has been dogged by negative rumours over the past year and has complained of a smear campaign against it. It recently took legal action against its former chief technology officer but that action, which is understood cost an estimated £300,000 in legal fees, has now been pulled.

webTitle: Netheads reveal a directory of disasters

fields.headline: Netheads reveal a directory of disasters
fields.standfirst:
Market is in no mood for hype

More net news
fields.trailText: Market is in no mood for hype.
fields.body:
As demonstrations of the destruction of value go, Scoot.com is something very special. Capitalised at a cool £2.5bn at one stage last year, this self-styled "infomediary" company was worth £90m last night after the publication of a preliminary results statement which simply defies parody.

That market valuation includes £31m of cash and also takes in Loot, the hugely successful free advertising title which Scoot bought for £177m last summer.

Why has the market torched this stock? Well, here is a taster from yesterday's results: "Over the last year everyone at Scoot has continued to work hard to create a unique value proposition for our buyers and sellers. Effectively deploying our growing proprietary intellectual assets in our core business and integrating them with quality services, such as Loot, will over time enable Scoot to become the premier infomediary in Europe."

Alternatively, the curious could take a look at Scoot's subscriber figures - the businesses which advertise their services through the company's online and talking directories.

Here we have the novel concept of the "non-charging" subscriber, of which Scoot has 36,191 in Britain who are either "still in a free three-month trial period or were not yet uploaded due to back office constraints". Fewer than 20,000 subscribers actually pay for the service in the UK, yet the company breezily predicts that this base will rocket to 110,000 here by the end of the year and to 85,000 in Europe.

This seems particularly heroic when "charging subscribers" in Britain have grown by less than 10% over the past 15 months and when Scoot's technological infrastructure has struggled to cope with the level of business that it has managed to bring in.

Investment bank Merrill Lynch has now been appointed to "conduct a review of all strategic options"- presumably to find a buyer for the company. There was some entertainment yesterday as Merrill's media analyst, Meg Geldens - showing her independence and clearly scornful of Scoot's finances - promptly downgraded the stock.

The City no longer buys new-economy bullshit. This company is caught in some sort of dot.com time warp, where it does not seem to think it matters that just about every segment of the business is haemorrhaging cash or that the director in change of technology (which is central to Scoot's corporate health) has just resigned. The only asset making any money seems to be Loot in the UK, which has brought in £100,000 since the publication was acquired; Loot Overseas, meanwhile, has lost £1.2m.

Yet Robert Bonnier, Scoot's youthful chief executive, was insisting yesterday that the business has never been in better shape.

Why shareholders have continued to allow this man to draw his pay cheque is a mystery.

Similarly, the tactics deployed by the French media conglomerate Vivendi, which has a 22% stake in Scoot, continue to bemuse. It paid up to 240p a share for its holding and seems to have pumped close to £200m into the business. With the share price now at 13p, that must hurt.

Need to know

Setting aside the market's dead cat bounce, yesterday was not a good one for several of the great names of the internet boom.

Take Baltimore Technology, the London-listed Irish software group which did more than most last year to encourage hundreds of thousands of amateur investors to believe that they really could make their fortunes by setting up an online trading account and following a few bulletin board tips.

Yesterday, the company demonstrated its utter naivety by flying a group of analysts to Dublin to hear a presentation which, the company said in advance, would not include any new (potentially inside) financial information. Chairman Fran Rooney took to his feet and made some comments about how rocky the US economy was proving, causing all the analysts present to phone their offices to get their investment clients out of the stock.

With the price down 20% the company was forced to issue a formal statement confirming rumours that Baltimore has missed out on a number of key orders. The shares ended the day 30% lower.

The company continued to insist that it had not released anything price sensitive in the morning and that it actually intended to release the news on poor trading in the afternoon. Perhaps Baltimore's joint corporate brokers, Lehman Brothers and Merrill Lynch, need to explain to the directors how the rules associated with being a listed company work: price-sensitive information must be released to all market participants at the earliest opportunity.

webTitle: Lorry driver denies closing air vent

fields.headline: Lorry driver denies closing air vent
fields.standfirst: Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: A Dutch lorry driver, accused of the manslaughter of 58 Chinese illegal immigrants found dead in the back of a truck at Dover, yesterday told a court he could not explain how their only air supply was cut off.
fields.body:
A Dutch lorry driver, accused of the manslaughter of 58 Chinese illegal immigrants found dead in the back of a truck at Dover, yesterday told a court he could not explain how their only air supply was cut off.

Sixty Chinese people tried to illegally enter Britain hidden in the back of a sealed lorry container laden with tomatoes on June 18 last year.

Port officials discovered the bodies of 54 men and four women after inspecting the lorry on its arrival at Dover's eastern docks in Kent. They also found two men who had survived.

Perry Wacker, 33, is accused of "sealing the fate" of the Chinese by closing the only air vent on the side of the container so as to avoid detection by immigration officials.

Wacker, of Rotterdam, is charged with 58 counts of manslaughter and four counts of conspiracy to smuggle people into Britain.

Maidstone crown court in Kent had earlier heard that the air vent being closed for the six hours it took the lorry to get from Zeebrugge in Belgium to Dover had caused them to suffocate.

Victor Temple QC, prosecuting, said the air vent was tied open with a piece of string when Wacker started his journey in Rotterdam. He said: "You used it to tie the vent back before starting off?" Wacker replied: "I did not use any string." The court heard that a ball of string was found inside the cab of the lorry.

Mr Temple said the lorry stopped at a petrol station shortly before reaching Zeebrugge at 5.50pm, which was when the vent must have been closed.

The court heard that Wacker said he was delivering a load of tomatoes to an address in Bristol, but the location did not exist.

Ying Guo, 30, of South Woodford, Essex, is jointly charged with Wacker on another count of conspiracy to smuggle immigrants into this country. Both accused deny all charges.

The trial continues.

fields.headline: Why tolerate Haider?
fields.standfirst:
It is time to usher the Freedom party out

Special report: the Austrian far right in power
fields.trailText: Austria's leading bigot Jörg Haider and his followers are at it again, stirring up racist and xenophobic sentiment in Vienna ahead of municipal elections tomorrow.
fields.body:
Austria's leading bigot Jörg Haider and his followers are at it again, stirring up racist and xenophobic sentiment in Vienna ahead of municipal elections tomorrow.

Mr Haider has been busy insulting Jews at beer hall rallies. He uses codewords to mask his bigotry, puts up posters linking crime and drugs to immigrants, whinges on about "überfremdung" (over-foreignerisation) and "Muslims in the park, cooking lamb", and is, generally speaking, making a pig of himself. Mr Haider is not standing in the polls. But his Freedom party is. The Vienna results will provide a key measure of the far right's possibly fading national appeal just over a year after it first forced its way into power with 29% support.

His antics are not unexpected. What continues to surprise is the tolerance extended to this odious man and his cronies by Chancellor Wolfgang Schüssel. He notably failed to condemn Mr Haider for anti-semitism after his beer hall tirade, arguing instead that "these are very delicate things".

President Thomas Klestil clearly believes Mr Schüssel should be more robust. So do the 67 leading international academics who yesterday publicly lambasted Mr Haider. And so, too, we believe, does most European opinion. Just how much longer can Mr Schüssel continue to pretend that these shaming episodes are anything other than deeply damaging to Austria's interests and reputation?

His best course would be to have a word with Mr Klestil and the Social Democrats about ways to form a new government excluding the Freedom brownshirts. A weakened showing by the Haider mob in Vienna may provide the impetus.

fields.headline: Belgrade sends suspect to tribunal
fields.standfirst: Special report: war crimes in the former Yugoslavia
fields.trailText: A Bosnian Serb sought by the UN war crimes tribunal for the alleged torture and death of Muslims during the Bosnian war was arrested and handed over to the court in the Hague yesterday.
fields.body:
A Bosnian Serb sought by the UN war crimes tribunal for the alleged torture and death of Muslims during the Bosnian war was arrested and handed over to the court in the Hague yesterday; the first suspect to be surrendered by Yugoslav authorities.

A tribunal spokesman identified the suspect as Milomir Stakic, the former mayor of Prijedor, and said he was wanted for atrocities allegedly committed between April 1992 and January 1993 at several detention camps set up in Bosnia for Muslims during the war.

"He's alleged to have planned, organised and implemented the creation of a number of detention facilities or camps, including Omarska, Keraterm and Trnopolje camps," the spokesman, Jim Landale, said.

"As far as the court is concerned this is a concrete sign of cooperation from the authorities in Belgrade and we hope it is the start of a process which will see the transfer of all fugitives residing on the territory of the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia."

The transfer of the suspect comes just days after a delegation of Belgrade officials visited the Hague to discuss cooperation with the court.

A 1997 report on the Omarska camp, which was compiled by Human Rights Watch, cites Mr Stakic as saying that any deaths at Omarska were few and "were natural deaths, with medical documentation of death, but not from murder".

Yugoslavia has been under heavy pressure to cooperate with the tribunal, and the government in Belgrade had been given a March 31 deadline for improving its record of dealing with war crimes suspects, or the United States would cut off aid.

Washington is primarily interested in the arrest and extradition of the former Yugoslav president, Slobodan Milosevic, sought by the tribunal for alleged atrocities in Kosovo.

While the new Yugoslav authorities say they want Mr Milosevic to stand trial in Belgrade, their decision to hand over Mr Stakic showed that they appear willing to extradite more minor suspects in an attempt to appease the US and its allies.

Zoran Djindjic, the prime minister of Serbia, the dominant Yugoslav republic, travelled to Washington this week in an effort to persuade the US administration to give his government more time to deal with key American demands.

On Thursday, justice officials in Belgrade urged war crimes suspects living in the country to surrender voluntarily to the tribunal. There are about 15 war crimes suspects thought to be living in Yugoslavia, including Mr Milosevic and four of his top allies.

Returning from the Hague, the Serbian justice minister, Vladan Batic, said that the court was "a reality, maybe a harsh reality, but something that cannot be ignored".

Earlier this month, Blagoje Simic, a former Bosnian Serb mayor accused of instigating ethnic cleansing in his town of Bosanski Samac, surrendered to the war crimes tribunal. Mr Simic pleaded not guilty.

webTitle: Official urged London to fake New Year's Eve fireworks for TV

fields.headline: Official urged London to fake New Year's Eve fireworks for TV
fields.standfirst: Special report: Livingstone's London
fields.trailText: The depth of the fiasco over London's cancelled New Year's Eve celebrations is revealed today in leaked documents which show how a desperate official suggested that London should fake fireworks at midnight.
fields.body:
The depth of the fiasco over London's cancelled New Year's Eve celebrations is revealed today in leaked documents which show how a desperate official suggested that London should fake fireworks at midnight.

The bizarre plan would have seen fireworks graphically superimposed on television screens to convince the world that the capital was enjoying a spectacular night.

Bob Geldof, who had been contracted to organise the celebrations, scorned the idea in a letter seen by the Guardian.

"For one shining moment, London could have been on par with North Korea for shameless media manipulation," Mr Geldof wrote.

The former pop star added that plans to "have a show worth putting on the world's TV screens to rival Paris, Sydney and New York" were dashed when the fireworks scheduled for midnight had to be moved to 5pm instead.

He disclosed that an official of one major public agency "apparently seriously recommend to a minuted meeting that we should fake the fireworks at midnight with TV graphics".

An inquiry by the Greater London Assembly on Monday will blame the fiasco firmly on the dome minister, Lord Falconer, a close ally of the prime minister, and three leading members of the cabinet - John Prescott, the deputy prime minister; Jack Straw, the home secretary and Chris Smith, the culture secretary.

Confidential Whitehall documents reveal that all four ministers approved London's fireworks display, but only Mr Smith, took action to get extra funds for the event - by writing personally to Tony Blair.

Letters from Keith Hill, the minister for London, show how the contract for the display was signed by the Department of the Environment before it was handed over to Ken Livingstone, London's mayor.

When Mr Livingstone objected to the terms, ministers used statutory powers to force him to accept the deal.

In one letter, Mr Hill told Mr Prescott: "The idea of a London new year event was launched by Charlie Falconer, on behalf of No 10, and is very much a central initiative."

fields.headline: I'd just like to say...
fields.standfirst: Let's hope tomorrow's Oscar winners exploit the chance for provocative speeches
fields.trailText: Let's hope tomorrow's Oscar winners exploit the chance for provocative speeches
fields.body:
The winner of a special award at the Oscars ceremony in Los Angeles tomorrow could well be Sacheen Littlefeather. She does not have a supporting role in Erin Brockovich nor does she vanquish wild animals in Gladiator, but her place in the Oscars' history is already assured. She was the woman who, in 1973, appeared on behalf of Marlon Brando, a winner for his performance in The Godfather, and rejected the award in protest against Hollywood's treatment of native Americans.

This year the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences is running a competition to discover "My favourite Oscar memory" and asking members of the public to vote by clicking on the "fun and games" section of oscar.com. The results will be announced just in advance of the ceremony itself, and the spectacular intervention of the woman who described herself as Sacheen Littlefeather has been included as one of 15 contenders, along with rather less political moments such as Roberto Benigni climbing over the seats to receive his prize for Life Is Beautiful in 1999, Cuba Gooding Jnr's enthusiastic acceptance of the best supporting actor award in 1995 and the streaker who appeared behind David Niven in 1974. While Littlefeather (she is described on the official Oscar site as the Mexican-American actress Maria Cruz) may not have imagined that her intervention would one day appear in the "fun and games" section of an Oscar competition, the fact that it is recognised as a possible favourite memory is encouraging.

Barely a day seems to pass now when an award ceremony is not screened on television. If we had a dollar for every "humbled" and "honoured" and for every time God had been credited with playing a part in the winning of this or that prize, we would be able to start our own award ceremony. Over the past few years, the chance to use the occasion to make a point - any point - seems to have been almost lost.

During this year's Emmy music awards in Los Angeles, the musician Robbie Robertson, formerly of The Band, was able to slip in a reference to Leonard Peltier, the native American many feel to have been wrongly imprisoned for the last quarter of a century for the murder of two FBI agents and whose supporters had campaigned for a pardon from Bill Clinton. He was not, suggested Robertson at the Emmys, "Marc Rich" enough to win a pardon. In the Golden Globes earlier this year, George Clooney used his award for his role in O, Brother Where Art Thou? to make a witty "confession" that he was the illegitimate love-child of the sternly rightwing and anti-abortion new US attorney general, John Ashcroft. The year after Littlefeather's appearance, Bert Schneider and Peter Davis, the producer and director of the award-winning documentary Hearts and Minds, used their prize to talk about the war in Vietnam and read a telegram from the Vietcong delegation to the Paris peace talks. But since then the edge has largely gone and it seems a long time since a genuinely provocative acceptance speech was made on Oscars' night.

Winners are kept under tight reins in both content and time. Gone are the days when Greer Garson could speak for 10 minutes, as she did after winning for her portrayal of Mrs Miniver in 1942. Now the swelling orchestral music will cut off the wordier speakers after 45 seconds and so anxious are the organisers for short and sweet addresses that they are offering a free television set to the makers of the briefest speeches; although offering a free telly to some of the richest people in the world may seem a bit like offering a chocolate to a crouching tiger to persuade it not to eat you.

Could this year be different? Already there is news that the red carpet pre-ceremony session might be enlivened by people protesting George Bush's dodgy victory in Florida last year. Veteran funster and campaigner Bob Kunst is arriving tomorrow morning to award Bush an Oscar for "best performance in a coup" and to warn Hollywood that a "new McCarthyism" is coming.

This week Norah Vincent, a commentator in the LA Times, urged gay and lesbian actors to use the occasion to come out, arguing that thousands of gay teenagers are taking their lives every year out of isolation and desperation. "Imagine what it meant when Rock Hudson was outed," she wrote, "and finally boys whose fathers had ridiculed them as sissies could point to this archetype of masculinity and say, he and I are the same ... C'mon, Hollywood, show us you're not just limousine liberals. Stand up and be counted."

The awards ceremony takes place this year in the shadow of two potential strikes which could stop filming for months and dramatically cut the choices for next year's ceremony. The writers' strike will start on May 2 and the actors' the following month unless a settlement is reached in the meantime. The predictions are gloomy. So the ceremony could provide either side with an opportunity to advance their case before the world and they are being urged from the wings to take it.

One film that could win a bunch of Oscars is Traffic. Will it really be possible for one of the Traffic winners not to make a reference to the subject on which the film is based, the American "war on drugs" which has imprisoned a generation of young black men, seen 400,000 people locked up at present for non-violent possession of drugs and now threatens to spill into bloodiness and environmental destruction in Colombia? One imagines not.

Taking such steps requires some courage, of course. It is not easy to risk the mockery of commentators and the ire of organisers by pouring some spice into the sugar bowl. But whoever breaks ranks will win the gratitude of a television public that is mature enough to take it as a given that the winners love their mums, dads, spouses and agents, although not necessarily in that order, and thus do not need to be reminded of the fact. One prays that this year's winners will avoid thanking the Almighty. As that fine actor Matthew Broderick (why no nomination for his supporting role in You Can Count On Me?) said in this newspaper a couple of weeks ago: "I don't like it when someone thanks God. I always thought God should be busier than to do the Oscar fix."

From drugs policies to stolen elections, from racism to industrial action, from miscarriages of justice to the Zapatistas, there is no shortage of candidates for a nod from the stage. And if winners want to make sure they will be remembered for ever they can always dedicate their prize to "Fidel, Saddam, Yasser and Gaddafi.... Thank you - and goodbye."

(I would like to thank David Leigh for commissioning this article and having faith in it during the long, dark nights of the soul; Prudence Hone and Cathryn Atkinson, who subbed it, for their humbling generosity of spirit; the editor for his inspirational belief in this project and the printers for being the best printers in the world. I feel blessed.)
