webTitle: 10 ways to survive a deadly market

fields.headline: 10 ways to survive a deadly market
fields.standfirst: In a week when tumbling share prices made page two of the Sun, our City agony uncle offers advice on Things To Do In A Crisis
fields.trailText: So it's official. We're in a bear market. Why? Because stock markets have fallen by 20% from their record highs, that's why.
fields.body:
So it's official. We're in a bear market. Why? Because stock markets have fallen by 20% from their record highs, that's why. At least, this is the definition of a bear market that journalists have seized upon this week to justify front page billing in the broadsheets.

My preferred definition is when stock market falls make it onto page two of the Sun. Arbitrary, I know. But no more arbitrary than a 20% Rubicon. Are things so much worse after a 20.1% fall than a 19.9% one?

I don't think so. Indeed they may be somewhat better. Bringing falling share prices to the attention of a wider audience can only accelerate the catharsis that typically marks the turning point in equity markets.

What is an investor to do now that his or her suffering has been laid bare to the casual observer? With apologies to director Gary Fleder, here is my guide to Things To Do In Markets When You're Dead.

1. Flick the switch

You'll never make rational investment decisions if you're mesmerised by the gyrating prices on your screen. Steel yourself not to look at prices, read market reports or talk to stockbrokers during trading hours. Markets are not going to turn for the better just because you will them to. And prices have fallen so far that it matters little if you miss the first inch of their eventual recovery.

2. Pound the streets

You don't just need a sense of perspective; you need the widest possible perspective. The best investment opportunities will be those you discover by observation of the workings of the economy in the aftermath of the stock market collapse. If you can bear it, take the taxi driver litmus test.

3. Read a good book

History never repeats itself exactly, but you owe it to yourself to be acquainted with the bear markets of yesteryear. At least if history does then repeat itself you can't say that you weren't warned. I'd recommend JK Galbraith's The Great Crash, a brief but insightful analysis of 1929 and all that went before and aft.

4. Avoid collateral damage

In 1987 the real economy emerged from the crash virtually unscathed. This time the world may not be so lucky. It will take time for share price damage to have its full effect elsewhere. Use this opportunity to pull out of that house move, sell your granny's Gaugin and ask your boss for an extended contract.

5. Dust off the abacus

Down and dirty financial analysis has been out of vogue for a couple of years. As share prices fall, so value emerges. But you'll only spot it if you are looking for it. And this means poring over the numbers not chasing dreams. You can afford to keep it simple. Thoroughness will pay greater dividends than sloppy sophistication.

6. Beware false prophets

Nobody knows where markets are going - not me, not you, not Abby Cohen at Goldman Sachs or the anonymous authors of Lex in the Financial Times. Your view has as much or as little validity as anyone else's. Keep this in mind and, when your analysis tells you it's time to buy, you'll find you have the requisite bravery.

7. Don't shoot the analysts

The backlash against investment bank analysts is in full swing. Don't be diverted by the spectacle, however enjoyable it might appear. Use the research available dispassionately. As in all human life, you'll find there's good and bad there. Just be sure, once you've digested, to formulate your own conclusions.

8. Rebase to zero

Ignore charts of historic share price performance. How a company was valued at its peak is no guide to its value today. Those shares that have fallen furthest may yet have further to fall. Start with a blank sheet of paper - no prejudices or preconceptions - and build an investment argument that reflects today's reality as you perceive it.

9. Yield to temptation

Equities are but one tidbit on the investment smorgasbord. One way of comparing them with other asset classes is through their dividend yield. Seek out shares whose yields are approaching those on government bonds. Although unfashionable, this could prove the way back into the market with the least risk. Just be sure those dividends can be met out of the companies' profits.

10. Look for leverage

Courage mon brave! When you decide the time has come to invest, be sure to do so with conviction. Use leverage to your advantage - be prepared to borrow; consider the use of derivative instruments. You could be a hero of the next bull market, if only in your granny's eyes.

In this column last week I declared that my intuition was to begin to buy equities. Now we're in a bear market (Wapping definition), that intuition remains the same. Please accord the gut feeling of this single observer the minuscule weight it merits (see Things To Do No 6 above). And good luck!

 Edmond Warner is chief executive of Old Mutual Securities

fields.headline: Enodis caters for market downturn
fields.trailText: The US economic downturn yesterday drove Enodis, the catering equipment maker, to sack its chief executive, slash 900 jobs and cut its dividend.
fields.body:
The US economic downturn yesterday drove Enodis, the catering equipment maker, to sack its chief executive, slash 900 jobs and cut its dividend.

The group, formerly known as Berisford, issued its third profits warning in four months - its second this year - and watched the market wipe out around a third of its value.

Senior executives warned that they could be forced to cut more plants and jobs if the US gloom spreads to the UK and mainland Europe later this year.

David Williams, chief executive, quit as the full impact of the US downturn - a 10% drop in the market for catering equipment - became clear. He is due to be replaced "shortly".

Enodis said profits for the year to March 31 would be £32m, £20m below last year's £51.6m, with the interim dividend cut from 4.4p to "not less than" 2p.

Andrew Allner, finance director, said the north American market had deteriorated significantly since January (the time of the previous profits warning), with restaurant chains such as McDonalds cutting back on new stores and replacement equipment.

Around three-quarters of Enodis sales, and 80% of operating profits, are in north America and Mr Allner said the economic prospects there were highly uncertain, with the knock-on effects for Europe unknown.

"We are battening down the hatches, taking out costs, simplifying and streamlining the organisation, and removing a layer of management, with across-the-board job cuts from senior management downwards," he said.

webTitle: BT property sell-off aims to cut debt

fields.headline: BT property sell-off aims to cut debt
fields.trailText: BT's besieged board of directors has begun a complete rethink of its strategy for reducing the group's £30bn debt after this week's debacle over talks with shareholders and is unlikely to reveal its hand until mid-May at the earliest.
fields.body:
BT's besieged board of directors has begun a complete rethink of its strategy for reducing the group's £30bn debt after this week's debacle over talks with shareholders and is unlikely to reveal its hand until mid-May at the earliest.

This emerged yesterday as the former state monopoly confirmed it hopes to raise up to £2bn by a sale and lease-back of its 7,500 properties - a plan masterminded by new finance director Philip Hampton.

BT had planned to reduce its debt - not far short of the group's market value of £33.8bn - by a third through the flotation of BT Wireless and the full or partial demerger of its directory business, Yell.

But this strategy, blown off course by the global free-fall of technology stocks, led to new plans for a record £5bn rights issue.

These in turn incensed leading investors who are said to have been limbering up this week to demand the heads of Sir Peter Bonfield, chief executive, and Sir Iain Vallance, chairman, at a hastily cancelled dinner this week.

Insiders said the pair now planned a series of one-to-one meetings with shareholders as directors went "back to the drawing board" on disposals and debt-reduction. The outcome should be disclosed with fourth-quarter results on May 17.

BT yesterday named Land Securities Trillium and Mapeley, a consortium backed by George Soros, as short-listed bidders to divest its property estate, mainly telephone exchanges, covering 6m square metres.

Some analysts were doubtful of the sale and lease-back plan as unlikely to make much of a dent in BT's debt because the group would have to lease back the properties and pay rent.

But officials said debt-reduction was not the prime aim. Pointing out that the two bidders had experience in managing properties for, respectively, the social security department and the inland revenue, they said the aim was to generate cash.

"We're keeping the freehold on 70% of the buildings and looking to them to come up with a progressive, radical plan for managing the sites. It's sale-and-lease-back plus," they said.

The group might also dispose of stakes in Japan Telecom and J-Phone.

fields.headline: At this price?  Telewest
fields.trailText: The history of cable TV in Britain is a pretty sorry affair. Just about every street in the land was dug up to lay what was promised as the information and entertainment pipe of the future.
fields.body:
The history of cable TV in Britain is a pretty sorry affair. Just about every street in the land was dug up to lay what was promised as the information and entertainment pipe of the future. The future never quite arrived. Instead, the cable industry was seen to adopt a unique business model which amounted to a refusal to communicate with potential customers.

Products to send down the cable were always late, subscribers to the limited service available were actively discouraged.

Some in the market believe all this is about to change. Witness the price of Telewest, which shot up from 105p to 120p yesterday in the wake of Thursday's year-end figures.

Those showed earnings up 11% before interest, tax and depreciation and, crucially, were accompanied by news that digital TV subscriber figures had reached 500,000.

The massive infrastructural spending of the past is still weighing on the balance sheet, with a £400m depreciation charge last year pushing losses at the old-fashioned pretax level out to £700m. But analysts are now predicting that Telewest will be truly profitable within three or four years.

It is accepted that the government handicapped the cable industry from the outset by imposing a fragmented franchise system. Both Telewest and its Nasdaq-listed rival, NTL, have been distracted by the furious consolidation necessary to create two strong, viable businesses. Along the way, customer service suffered.

With the structural work out of the way, there is a feeling that Telewest can start grabbing market share and push into new markets, such as broadband internet services.

This volatile stock is trading at levels not seen since 1998, having been caught in the general tech slaughter. Potential investors should forget about the 500p-plus levels reached a year ago, but the shares do look an attractive - albeit relatively high risk - medium term investment.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: £90m plan to save steel jobs
fields.body:
£90m plan to save steel jobs

The Iron and Steel Trades Confederation yesterday gave trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers details of a last-ditch plan to save some of the 6,000 steel jobs that face being lost at Corus. The £90m scheme will be put to the company during a meeting with union officials next Tuesday.

The plan is believed to include the payment of half of Corus's wage bill for the 6,000 workers in return for a stay of execution for a year. Unions believe that the trading position will improve later this year, leading Corus to retain capacity at threatened plants, including Llanwern and Ebbw Vale in South Wales and at Teesside.

Neta start date confirmed

Energy regulator Ofgem said the government had confirmed March 27 as the start date for the New Electricity Trading Arrangements (Neta), a restructuring of the wholesale power market designed to bring down prices.

Under Neta, the existing electricity "pool" will be replaced with commodity-style short-term markets and a central market for balancing supply and demand.

AOL acquires French 'gem'

US-based internet service provider America Online has agreed to take 55% of AOL France, owned by two units of French media conglomerate Vivendi Universal, in exchange for preferred shares in AOL Europe.

The preferred shares, valued at $725m (£495m) and representing an undisclosed minority stake in AOL Europe will be entitled to a 6% annual return until April 2003 when they will be redeemed by AOL with cash or AOL Time Warner stock.

"We bought a gem in a buyers' market," one AOL official told Reuters.

Fortnum's feels rail impact

The autumn rail chaos hit sales of groceries and tea at Fortnum & Mason's store in Piccadilly, London. For the six months to January 20, its grocery and tea departments were 1% behind last year in sales, failing to recover fully from the lack of visitors to London in the autumn.

Overall, the store managed to shake off the negative effect, and posted a near-6% rise in sales against the same period in the previous year, with sales in the run-up to Christmas particularly strong. Group pretax profits for the six months rose from £2.1m to £2.4m, while turnover rose 8% to £27.6m.

Micron grows into large host

Computer products and internet hosting company Micron Electronics said it had agreed to buy Interland for $130m (£89m) in stock, a transaction that would form the third-largest web hosting company in the United States.

Web hosting providers offer equipment and services to help companies set up and maintain a presence on the internet.

fields.headline: Inflation hawks take flight
fields.standfirst:
European bankers offer hope of rate cuts to steady battered euro and falling markets

Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: European bankers offer hope of rate cuts to steady battered euro and falling markets.
fields.body:
A sharp u-turn by central bankers on their hawkish inflation stance in the single currency zone raised hopes yesterday that the European Central Bank will join international efforts to bolster the global economy by cutting interest rates.

The message that the ECB is now less concerned about inflation and more worried about slowing growth helped revive the ailing euro and inject confidence into battered stock markets.

Jean-Claude Trichet, the governor of the Bank of France and a member of the ECB's interest rate committee set the tone when he told French radio: "While we were very concerned about inflation a month ago, we're not any more today."

His comments reflect concern in the 12-nation single currency zone that growth will fall and echo remarks from the ECB's chief economist Otmar Issing. He said in an interview on Thursday that: "Risks to growth have certainly increased to the downside."

In Europe's financial markets the expectation is that the decision to cut rates from the present level of 4.75% will be taken at the meeting of the governing council on April 11. However some analysts believe the move could come as early as next Thursday.

"If the ECB does pull a rate cut rabbit out of the hat next week it could certainly help overcome some of the stock market jitters and euro weakness we have seen recently," said David Brown, chief European economist at Bear Stearns.

Yesterday as Europe's political leaders at the Stockholm summit queued up to criticise the financial markets for undervaluing the single currency it rose a third of cent to just over 89 cents.

The ECB has been forced to change its stance because a string of weak economic data has cast doubts on its forecasts of 3% growth for this year. Eurozone member states have been trimming back their own growth expectations. In Germany business confidence has fallen to a two and a half year low and France is now expecting 2.9% growth rather than the 3.3% predicted earlier.

Hopes of a rate cut came as stock markets in Europe steadied after Thursday's free fall. The FTSE 100 share index closed up 87.5 points at 5402.3 while Paris's CAC 40 index was up 126 points at 4951.

But in the New York the mood was more fragile. Motorola announced that it is to axe another 4,000, bringing total lay-offs at the mobile phone maker this year to 22,000. The news served as a reminder that the market rout which, according to City investment bank ING Barings, has so far wiped $7.6 trillion off global wealth may still have further to run.

"Let's not mistake this for a beginning of a bull market move," said Charles White, portfolio manager at Avatar Associates. "There's not too much to be made of what's going on today."

In midday trading the Dow Jones industrial average was up 38 points at 9429 just a whisker above 9378-level which marks a 20% fall from its peak - the definition of a bear market.

In the UK the shadow chancellor Michael Portillo sought to capitalise on the market turmoil: "Contrary to what the Chancellor of the Exchequer has been leading us to believe, we are not immune from what goes on in the rest of the world, we have not abolished economic cycles and that is why he is so imprudent to commit himself to increases in government spending well ahead of what the country can afford."

The Treasury declined to comment.

fields.headline: French eye 'cheap' London
fields.trailText: London's standing as Europe's leading financial centre has received a boost from top French bankers who complain that overbearing business taxes could see them leave Paris for the Square Mile.
fields.body:
London's standing as Europe's leading financial centre has received a boost from top French bankers who complain that overbearing business taxes could see them leave Paris for the Square Mile.

One banker told the French upper house that the costs of employing someone in London were less than half those for a Paris employee on the same net salary.

In a bid to bolster the city's standing as a financial centre Paris Europlace, an umbrella organisation representing the financial services industry, is demanding the French government cuts tax and social security costs.

This week it submitted a report to the government outlining a strategy to make Paris more competitive and underlining the importance of the financial services industry to the French economy.

"For us taxation and social security costs are a very important part of this [strategy]," a spokesman said.

In an interview with Le Figaro newspaper Jean Peyrelevade, the head of Crédit Lyonnais, one of France's biggest banks, acknowledged that there was very strong pressure from staff within the bank in Paris to relocate them to London. His remarks have been interpreted as a sign that the bank could be thinking of moving to the UK.

However a spokesman for the bank said yesterday: "He did not say that a lot of people were going to move to London or that Crédit Lyonnais was going to move to London. What he did say was that there was a lot of demand from people interested in working in London."

The newspaper quoted the president of BNP Paribas, Michel Pébereau's comments to a committee of the French senate: "For an annual income of £90,000 after taxes and social charges an unmarried executive costs his employer Ffr3.663m (around £366,000) if he is employed in France, Ffr2.095m if he is employed in Germany, Ffr1.584m in the United Kingdom and Ffr1.35m in Switzerland."

In its report to the government Paris Europlace argues that the industry deserves support because it accounts for 3.7% of jobs in France and makes a bigger contribution to the French economy than the agri-food sector or the car industry.

fields.headline: Protest over Royal Bank bonuses
fields.trailText: Several of Royal Bank of Scotland's leading shareholders are ready to protest at pay packages for top directors.
fields.body:
Several of Royal Bank of Scotland's leading shareholders are ready to protest at pay packages for top directors.

Some are unhappy with the small print of a new medium-term incentive scheme, which they believe will reward average performance with bumper bonuses. Others are focusing disapproval on bonuses awarded to senior executives for successfully winning control of NatWest bank last year.

Details of the bonus scheme emerged in a letter sent to shareholders with the bank's annual report and accounts. A select band of senior managers could receive up to six times their annual salary as a bonus if they can top a list of 11 rival companies. If they rank only sixth, they will still qualify for bonuses of 150% of salary.

Several directors have already banked payments for taking over NatWest. Deputy chairman Sir George Mathewson received £814,000, chief executive Fred Goodwin £759,000 and corporate banking director Iain Robertson £773,000. Sir George made £1.8m on his share options last year and Mr Robertson cashed in options for a £1.4m windfall.

Stuart Bell, of Pensions and Investment Research Consultants, said the payouts contravened their guidelines. "We believe that maximum bonus scheme rewards should never be more than 100% of salary, and they shouldn't kick in at all for median performance."

PIRC's guidelines to its clients are likely to suggest they protest by voting against the re-election of any of the members of the remuneration committee at the bank's agm.

The Association of British Insurers, whose investment committee represents the interests of some of the UK's biggest shareholders, was shown details of the scheme by the bank and gave its approval. However, the ABI is still concerned about the independence of the remuneration committee, which is headed by chairman Lord Younger.

The Royal Bank of Scotland said it did not envisage any problems. "The MTIP has got to go to the agm so shareholders will be able to vote on it. It was developed with Andersen Consulting (now Accenture). We are the third largest bank in Europe and the renumeration committee needs a flexible package to retain and motivate key executives."

webTitle: Media watch: Elisabeth Murdoch bounces back

fields.headline: Shine on
fields.standfirst: Elisabeth Murdoch bounces back
fields.trailText: Elisabeth Murdoch bounces back.
fields.body:
Elisabeth Murdoch is back in business. Just under a year since she quit the family firm, the daughter of Rupert Murdoch yesterday unveiled her new venture, a production company called Shine Television.

The company will launch with two contracts already in place including a £10m film and TV output deal with her former employer, BSkyB.

The old family ties are also evident with BSkyB, which is 37% owned by her father's News Corporation, taking a 5% stake in the new venture.

Ms Murdoch has recruited Lord (Waheed) Alli, a joint founder of production company Planet 24, as an executive director of the company. Ms Murdoch, who will be chairman and chief executive owns 80% of Shine and Lord Alli, 15%.

The second deal already secured by Shine is to provide an original daytime format to IPC Media.

Ms Murdoch said the consolidation in the production industry was providing growing opportunities for smaller independents. The past couple of years have seen a wave of independent production companies bought by broadcasters, including Planet 24 which was acquired by Carlton.

"We intend to be the home for the best creative talent in the industry," she said. Hirings include Kenton Allen, a producer on shows including The Royle Family and the Mrs Merton Show, who becomes creative director of entertainment and comedy. Other recruits to Shine include Sally Anne Howard, the launch editor and executive producer of Trisha, who becomes executive producer of lifestyle.

While at BSkyB, Ms Murdoch championed original programming. Her decision to quit was said to have been in part informed by the more rapid progress of her two brothers in the News Corp empire.

Ms Murdoch is also a non-executive director of troubled magazine publishing group Future Network.

Ms Murdoch is also a non-executive director of troubled magazine publishing group Future Network.

webTitle: Market forces: Collapse of stout party

fields.headline: Collapse of stout party
fields.trailText: When Baltimore first dreamt up the notion of a "teach-in" seminar for the City's top internet security analysts in Dublin, it probably seemed like a good idea.
fields.body:
When Baltimore first dreamt up the notion of a "teach-in" seminar for the City's top internet security analysts in Dublin, it probably seemed like a good idea.

After all, the company had been dogged by rumours and the chance to set the record straight, having softened the boffins up over a few pints of Guinness, made sense. Putting the theory into practice proved more difficult.

The seminar began yesterday morning with remarks from Baltimore boss Fran Rooney on the challenging trading conditions facing the software industry in North America. Apparently misinterpreting his comments, some analysts rushed out of the presentation to relay to their brokerages what they believed to be bad news.

The feedback received by traders was that the company was being very cautious about its prospects in the North America market, which accounts for 25% of group business, and had suggested that a number of deals might be delayed.

From there the situation descended into farce, with the company maintaining that nothing price sensitive had been said; the shares went down 20%; Baltimore decided a couple of hours later to issue a trading update.

That statement said that Mr Rooney would tell the assembled analysts that the company had "experienced some sales being delayed due to the prevailing economic climate". As a result of these delays, first-quarter revenues would be about £25m, which would be £5m below expectations.

"This stinks. This is Cable & Wireless all over again," said one trader, referring to the recent bungled profits warning from the telecoms group.

A spokesman for Baltimore played down claims that it had violated stock exchange rules by privately briefing the analysts on current trading. "Nothing was said in the morning that should have been interpreted as a profits warning. People misconstrued it."

Investors were taking a different view of the debacle, marking the stock down 46p, or 30.5%, at 104.5p. There could be further pain to come. Just over 11m Baltimore shares are released from a lock-up on April 25 and, given yesterday's disaster, dealers reckon the holders have every reason to sell.

Events in the wider market were proving much more straightforward. The FTSE 100 rebounded from Thursday's 29-month low as overnight gains for the Nasdaq tempted investors to back into bombed-out tech and telecom stocks.

With Logica, up 136p to £10.76p, and Colt Telecom, 92p higher at 830p, setting the pace, the premier index settled 87.5 points higher at 5,402.3. That still left the index down 160.5 points over the week. Elsewhere, the FTSE Tech mark 100 rose 72.38 to 1,936.98.

Traders were not reading too much into the gains, calling them a technical recovery from an oversold position. "It is a nice way to end a bad week," commented one.

The positivism was marred by another spate of profits warnings. In addition to Baltimore, catering equipment maker Enodis, down 54p to 101p, and storage group Mentmore Abbey, 56p worse at 118p, made such announcements.

Dealers were, however, relieved to see Cable & Wireless, bounce back. C&W shares rose 14p to 444p on word that it is preparing to loosen the purse strings and return some of its £4bn cash pile to shareholders.

Lower down, software systems group XKO shed 77.5p to 78.5p after warning that a "material" slowdown in sales would hit profits, but Esporta, the health club outfit, climbed 2.5p to 101p on news that golf club operator Crown Sports, unchanged at 26.5p, had increased it its holding to 10%.

The chemical engineering group Ascot rose 56p to 321p after it confirmed that it was in talks about a possible takeover.

fields.headline: Iceland wins admirers
fields.trailText: Issuing three profits warnings is hardly an auspicious start to a new job, but the fan club of Bill Grimsey, recently installed chief executive of frozen food retailer Iceland, just keeps growing.
fields.body:
Issuing three profits warnings is hardly an auspicious start to a new job, but the fan club of Bill Grimsey, recently installed chief executive of frozen food retailer Iceland, just keeps growing.

The food retail team at Schroder Salomon Smith Barney became members yesterday when they upgraded their rating on Iceland, set a 200p target price and predicted the meltdown might be over.

Although Schroder remains sceptical about the benefits of merging Booker with Iceland, it says Mr Grimsey has recruited a heavyweight management team that is capable of re-establishing Iceland as a successful niche retailer with good prospects.

Schroder thinks Iceland is a good business that made mistakes under previous management. The broker reckons all the bad news from the previous regime is now out of the way.

Iceland closed 7p higher at 161p yesterday.

fields.headline: Odds stacked against Stanley Leisure
fields.trailText: A combination of the foot and mouth crisis and an unexpected number of high-rollers winning at its Crockfords casino is expected to wipe around £5m off full year profits at gaming group Stanley Leisure.
fields.body:
A combination of the foot and mouth crisis and an unexpected number of high-rollers winning at its Crockfords casino is expected to wipe around £5m off full year profits at gaming group Stanley Leisure.

The Liverpool based firm admitted yesterday that a number of wealthy clients had done well at the dealing tables over the past few weeks and that their winnings could cost Stanley's gaming division an extra £3m.

Crockfords is one of the most popular destinations in London for wealthy punters like Australian media magnate Kerry Packer.

The disruption that the foot and mouth virus has caused to the horse racing programme has also unsettled the group's betting division and is likely to cost £1.5m. Start-up costs associated with Stanley's internet betting operations will add another £500,000.

Analysts had been expecting pretax profits of around £30m for the year before yesterday's warning. "This type of trading fluctuation is not unusual but coming so late within our financial year, it will almost certainly affect the group's final results," chief executive Bob Wiper said.

Stanley said it remained nervous about the prospects of the Grand National being cancelled. The race and the start of the flat racing season comes at the end of Stanley's financial year and further cancellations could damage profit forecasts.

However the company is betting on a solid future. Chancellor Gordon Brown's decision to end duty on betting is expected to increase turnover significantly while the introduction of longer casino opening hours should also increase trade, Mr Wiper said. "The prospects for the group have never been better."

Shares in Stanley Leisure closed down 25.5p at 216.5p.

fields.headline: The Liberty belle
fields.trailText: The door opens and a dead ringer for Dynasty's Krystle Carrington glides in. There is the perfect blonde bob, enhanced by a set of West End highlights, and a row of dazzling teeth that would put an Osmond to shame.
fields.body:
The door opens and a dead ringer for Dynasty's Krystle Carrington glides in. There is the perfect blonde bob, enhanced by a set of West End highlights, and a row of dazzling teeth that would put an Osmond to shame.

The black coat and dress is understated Bond Street designer elegance. It is set off with fine silver jewellery - or maybe it is platinum - and a fresh French manicure.

This is Fiona Harrison, new chief executive of the Liberty department store in London and the sort of woman who makes 99.9% of other females feel like Nora Batty. "Do let me check your cup," she says, slowly spinning the fine bone china teacup. The dishwasher is playing up and the odd drip mark might not have been eradicated - she simply cannot countenance a guest taking a sip out of anything that is not sparkling.

The dishwasher has done its stuff and we can proceed. Mrs Harrison is a daunting and towering woman, 5ft 10in, with enough charm to fill anexecutive suite. She is Liberty's third chief executive in as many years and her mission is to put the renowned Regent Street store back in the fashion shopping superleague - and to create a global luxury brand at the same time. Founded in 1875, Liberty should be the West End's answer to Harvey Nichols and Harrods in Knightsbridge. While the latter, and more recently Selfridges and DH Evans, have grown and prospered, Liberty has fallen into the red.

Creaking floors

The store, with its Tudor-style frontage, is a London landmark. It is, in fact, two buildings. The Regent Street building is a bland bit of concrete and glass, but it is connected to the lovely mock Tudor building, complete with creaking wooden floors and an almost ecclesiastical atmosphere, around the corner in Great Marlborough Street.

It is opulent, full of colour and extravagance, contrasting with the minimalist interiors favoured by many retailers. The merchandise ranges from pewter and prints to furniture one-offs, famous fabrics and fashion labels such as Joseph, Joe Casely-Hayford and Dries Van Noten.

"They are a set of values not shared by any other department store in London," says Mrs Harrison, "but we need an environment up to modern standards." She has called in the builders and 20-20, the retail design gurus who decorated Sainsbury's supermarkets with pictures of cut oranges and have been hired to come up with a new look for M&S. It is not a straightforward job because the buildings are listed and both English Heritage and the Crown Estate - which owns Regent Street - have to be consulted.

Mrs Harrison wants to cash in on Liberty's distinct character. "It is not difficult for us to be different and unique. We have an absolute point of difference to our rivals just because of the building."

She envisages a store unlike any other in London, where the customer service is more like that found in designer boutiques than traditional department stores. She wants a different atmosphere - and is toying with playing soft jazz in the background to help create it. A destination restaurant would rival the capital's trendiest celebrity eateries and Mrs Harrison also aims to pull in the big power brands not stocked.

"We don't have the glitzy brands like Gucci and Prada, but they are traffic drivers." A quick walk around points up the problem. There are too few chic women and too many Japanese students and elderly couples. Mrs Harrison reckons 20% of the business is generated by tourists, mainly Japanese and American. The Regent Street side of the store, previously housing menswear, has already closed for a revamp and will reopen in November with different merchandise on each level. Phase two of the Harrison plan will see the builders move in to the Tudor building for a two-year update. Not that there has been a shortage of such ideas in recent years. Liberty has had more cunning plans than Baldrick, some so grand they ran aground before you could say silk scarf. Six years ago the founding Stewart-Liberty family called in Denis Cassidy but his proposals, including a £40m revamp, so infuriated family shareholders they joined forces with corporate raiders to oust the former Bhs boss. A new chairman and chief executive took over, planning to shut the Regent Street building but, before work could start, property developers Marylebone Warwick Balfour bought the business and hired Mrs Harrison. It is her first foray into luxury brands.

The 50-year-old daughter of a panel beater and a secretary, Mrs Harrison was brought up in Hertfordshire. After grammar school and a chemistry degree at Leicester University she joined packaging group Metal Box, before moving to Boots as a buyer. "I was the first woman to buy electricals at Boots," she says. The company is still close to her heart and she is now a non-executive director.

In 1977 Mrs Harrison joined Clairol to develop electrical personal care products. The green hairdryer, footspa and flexible hair rollers were all her babies. "I had three years at Clairol, spending two weeks in the US and then two weeks in the UK. I used to wake up in the morning and look at the curtains to see what country I was in," she said. Her lifestyle remains international. Her husband of 25 years works for packaging group Crown Cork & Seal and is based in Paris, so the couple, who have no children, alternate between homes in Paris and London. Spare time is spent listening to jazz, blues and opera or watching rugby.

After Clairol she was headhunted by textiles group Coats Viyella to run their Van Heusen, Berghaus, Viyella and Jaeger clothing businesses. She left in 1998 "after several depressing years characterised by closing factories". After three months looking at educational action zones in the East End of London, she joined Stork & May, a career consultancy group for senior executives. "I was off on a new career," she says, "and then I got the call about Liberty." Staying put

She started in December and her mission has been compared to the challenge Burberry faced three years ago. Burberry has risen to that so well that it is now valued at up to £2bn.

Mrs Harrison bristles at the comparison. "People say I am going to do a Burberry. In so far as we are going to grow our brand, it is true. But there the comparison stops".

She gets out a pen and paper and draws a long line, with Burberry at one end and Harvey Nichols at the other. She stabs at the middle and says: "We are here. We are a retailer with a brand capable of development. The opportunity I see is to develop a range of luxury products branded Liberty to be sold around the world from other outlets."

She swiftly stamped on plans to pull out of Regent Street. "It is very important to us because it is a major thoroughfare. It has been Liberty's address for ever, it is a window on the world and it provides a lot of the traffic into the Tudor."

Mrs Harrison has axed the Liberty ready-to-wear high fashion label, along with the e-commerce and mail order businesses. "We were stretching our resources and our investment funds too thinly. We have to have greater clarity and focus on our core activity. Twothirds of the Liberty business is in this store and the London store has been starved of investment."

Turning the store around, she says, will be a long job - two years to get the retailing right, then much more to build a global, big ticket brand. The fusty, posh image needs work too. "We need to be a little less precious," she says, "then people will want to shop the Liberty name."

fields.headline: How the Dream Team stole £15m
fields.standfirst: Europe's most daring robbers aped movie crooks portrayed by Robert De Niro in a string of raids
fields.trailText: Europe's most daring robbers aped movie crooks portrayed by Robert De Niro in a string of raids
fields.body:
They called themselves "the Dream Team" - a band of armed robbers so skilled, daring and meticulous that their average haul for a five-minute raid, with no clues left behind, was a million pounds.

For four years this tight-knit band tormented police in Spain and France, carrying out swift and brutal raids from Paris to Malaga. They struck at security vans, airport cargo zones, security company vaults - even a passenger plane as it taxied on a runway.

They always employed massive firepower, explosives, body armour and fast cars. They always disappeared without trace. Their hauls, usually cash or jewels, were so huge that they only needed to do two or three jobs a year. Nine raids netted them £15m.

The gang's spectacular heists often appeared to come straight out of a Hollywood script. In fact, police say, the Dream Team hero-worshipped Robert De Niro and modelled themselves on the gangs he led in the films Heat and Ronin. They even gave themselves code-names based on the films' characters and used the same Audi 8 get-away cars as in Heat.

Police across Europe were baffled by the brilliant robbers.Were they Serbs, Albanians, Italians, French, Spaniards, Moroccans or a mixture? Interpol was called in. Underworld sources from Hamburg to Marseilles and from Naples to Marbella were quizzed. Nobody had heard of them.

For Inspector Daniel Bernabe, head of Barcelona's armed crime group, they became an obsession. Just 33 years old but prematurely aged by his job, and with two bullets wounds from shoot-outs with armed robbers, he found it hard to believe they were so good.

"They are simply the best that Europe has ever seen," he says. "They were the best-organised, the most disciplined, the most security-conscious and most tightly-knit group anybody had come across." Now, after a series of raids in Marbella, Barcelona and Paris last December, he believes he has the nine Dream Team members behind bars. A massive arsenal of weapons and munitions, including 20 sub-machine guns and a hand-held anti-tank rocket launcher, as well as the evidence of witnesses and wiretaps, form a large body of evidence which Insp Bernabe hopes will send them to jail for up to 30 years each.

The Dream Team members, allegedly led by a Frenchman, Daniel Bellanger, are charged in Spanish and French courts with belonging to an armed group, robbery and possession of arms. They have all denied the charges.

Mr Bellanger led a life of unostentatious luxury. He shared a villa with his wife and children in the resort of Sitges, south of Barcelona. He partied with Spanish aristocrats and film stars, telling them he was a successful luxury car dealer.

"We believe Bellanger was the chief - an ice-cold, intelligent, superior character who picked the targets and planned the jobs," Insp Bernabe says. "They were a small army, united by quality and friendship. They knew they were all good."

Like the rest of those charged, which included two former rugby players from the French club Perpignan, Jean-Jacques Naudo and Karim Maloum, he was obsessive about personal fitness. "They were a close group. They would go to see Barcelona play football, then they would go out nightclubbing. But it did not matter what they had been doing the night before, they would be in the gym, playing tennis or golf, riding or jogging the next morning."

Nobody knows how the Dream Team, most of whose alleged members do not have significant police records, was brought together. However, their first job showed just how inventive and disciplined they could be.

An Air Inter Airbus carrying 200 passengers was taxiing towards a runway at Perpignan airport when a group of what had appeared to be ground personnel suddenly donned balaclavas and aimed Kalashnikovs at the flight deck. The startled captain found himself staring into a banner held up by two of the gang. "Stop your motors now. This is a robbery." A few rounds of automatic gunfire helped the pilot make up his mind.

Within minutes the gang had blown off the cargo hold doors and lifted £800,000. As with all their raids, it had lasted less than ten minutes.

"That was so good it almost seemed funny," Insp Bernabe admits. "Each job required masses of preparation. And they always behaved, in the meantime, as if the police were following them."

Having invented the airport runway robbery, the Dream Team perfected a technique for assaulting security vans. First practised in Limoges in 1996, this involved wedging the van between two trucks and putting thick metal blinds - attached by industrial magnets - across the holes the security guards usually used to shoot at raiders.

A concentrated explosive charge then blew a small hole in the truck and the terrified guards were forced at gunpoint to hand out the money. An amateur video of their last raid, in Paris's Gentilly district, shows the six robbers operating like a well-trained army commando unit. "On these raids they carried more than 20kg of material each," Insp Bernabe says. "They were equipped with body armour, grenades, machine guns, spare magazine clips and munition belts." Other raids included a £2m cash and diamonds heist at Malaga airport and a raid on a security company deposit in France when they literally bulldozed their way in.

Police believe that, if necessary, the Dream Team would have killed. In fact, they never had to.

"As professionals, they knew it was better not to kill anyone," says Insp Bernabe "That did not, however, stop them shooting at French police when they turned up"

In one raid, when they tried to hijack the takings of a gang of hashish traffickers in Algeciras, southern Spain, the group's second-in-command, a former soldier called Michel Crutel, was killed in a shootout. It was a sign that the gang's luck was running out.

Police in Perpignan had begun to hear tales of their adventures. They had tipped off Insp Bernabe.

The suspect's homes were bugged. One alleged team member, Bruno Celini, was discovered living in Budapest. "What did for them in the end was that we found out where they all lived," Insp Bernabe says.

fields.bodyText: They called themselves "the Dream Team" - a band of armed robbers so skilled, daring and meticulous that their average haul for a five-minute raid, with no clues left behind, was a million pounds. For four years this tight-knit band tormented police in Spain and France, carrying out swift and brutal raids from Paris to Malaga. They struck at security vans, airport cargo zones, security company vaults - even a passenger plane as it taxied on a runway. They always employed massive firepower, explosives, body armour and fast cars. They always disappeared without trace. Their hauls, usually cash or jewels, were so huge that they only needed to do two or three jobs a year. Nine raids netted them £15m. The gang's spectacular heists often appeared to come straight out of a Hollywood script. In fact, police say, the Dream Team hero-worshipped Robert De Niro and modelled themselves on the gangs he led in the films Heat and Ronin. They even gave themselves code-names based on the films' characters and used the same Audi 8 get-away cars as in Heat. Police across Europe were baffled by the brilliant robbers.Were they Serbs, Albanians, Italians, French, Spaniards, Moroccans or a mixture? Interpol was called in. Underworld sources from Hamburg to Marseilles and from Naples to Marbella were quizzed. Nobody had heard of them. For Inspector Daniel Bernabe, head of Barcelona's armed crime group, they became an obsession. Just 33 years old but prematurely aged by his job, and with two bullets wounds from shoot-outs with armed robbers, he found it hard to believe they were so good. "They are simply the best that Europe has ever seen," he says. "They were the best-organised, the most disciplined, the most security-conscious and most tightly-knit group anybody had come across." Now, after a series of raids in Marbella, Barcelona and Paris last December, he believes he has the nine Dream Team members behind bars. A massive arsenal of weapons and munitions, including 20 sub-machine guns and a hand-held anti-tank rocket launcher, as well as the evidence of witnesses and wiretaps, form a large body of evidence which Insp Bernabe hopes will send them to jail for up to 30 years each. The Dream Team members, allegedly led by a Frenchman, Daniel Bellanger, are charged in Spanish and French courts with belonging to an armed group, robbery and possession of arms. They have all denied the charges. Mr Bellanger led a life of unostentatious luxury. He shared a villa with his wife and children in the resort of Sitges, south of Barcelona. He partied with Spanish aristocrats and film stars, telling them he was a successful luxury car dealer. "We believe Bellanger was the chief - an ice-cold, intelligent, superior character who picked the targets and planned the jobs," Insp Bernabe says. "They were a small army, united by quality and friendship. They knew they were all good." Like the rest of those charged, which included two former rugby players from the French club Perpignan, Jean-Jacques Naudo and Karim Maloum, he was obsessive about personal fitness. "They were a close group. They would go to see Barcelona play football, then they would go out nightclubbing. But it did not matter what they had been doing the night before, they would be in the gym, playing tennis or golf, riding or jogging the next morning." Nobody knows how the Dream Team, most of whose alleged members do not have significant police records, was brought together. However, their first job showed just how inventive and disciplined they could be. An Air Inter Airbus carrying 200 passengers was taxiing towards a runway at Perpignan airport when a group of what had appeared to be ground personnel suddenly donned balaclavas and aimed Kalashnikovs at the flight deck. The startled captain found himself staring into a banner held up by two of the gang. "Stop your motors now. This is a robbery." A few rounds of automatic gunfire helped the pilot make up his mind. Within minutes the gang had blown off the cargo hold doors and lifted £800,000. As with all their raids, it had lasted less than ten minutes. "That was so good it almost seemed funny," Insp Bernabe admits. "Each job required masses of preparation. And they always behaved, in the meantime, as if the police were following them." webTitle: Capital letters: Meet the neighbours from hell

fields.headline: Meet the neighbours from hell
fields.trailText: Senora Herrero, my downstairs neighbour, wants to send me to jail. She is not without her reasons.
fields.body:
Senora Herrero, my downstairs neighbour, wants to send me to jail. She is not without her reasons. The false ceiling in her dining room fell down recently, showering her mock- Chippendale furniture with sodden plaster and bringing down a chandelier. The cause, it turned out, was a leak from our roof terrace.

"If you try to fool the judge, you will go to prison," she threatened in her last scrawled note.

In Madrid it has rained for weeks and neglected buildings are beginning to collapse. Two abandoned 19th century mansion blocks have fallen down so far this month, killing three people.

Nothing like that happened in Senora Herrero's flat. But now she would like to see me go down for what would best be translated as "near homocidal negligence". It took two gun-toting Madrid policemen to deliver a note to my door informing me that she wanted to press charges.

Relations with our neighbour had gone downhill since we bought our flat a year ago. We stopped speaking the day she complained that Spain had been a nicer place without foreigners. "These things didn't happen under Franco," she muttered.

Our run-in has introduced me to that nightmare Madrid institution, the comunidad - the inappropriately named "community" of neighbours. The comunidad is the democratic assembly that runs each building in the city.

It is made up of the owners of each apartment or office, with voting rights strictly dependent on the amount of floor space owned. My insurance company claims the comunidad is to blame for the state of my terrace. We are set for tense negotiations.

The annual meeting of the comunidad is, traditionally, where you learn the ugly truth about your neighbours. These quarrelsome, heated assemblies are almost always held in a back room of the local bar. Hours are spent angrily debating mundane matters such as whether the lift floor should be covered in lino or rubber. As often as not, votes are cast not on the merits of argument, but to even old scores whose origins are lost in the mists of time.

It was at a meeting of our comunidad that I learned that Senora Herrero was at war with almost everybody in the building. I also discovered that Paco, the pleasant man across the landing from us, is her brother. They have not spoken for 20 years.

The meeting revealed other things. Our building, it seems, has a fair share of old-style fachas , as Spaniards call their home-bred brand of fascists.It was put up shortly after the Spanish civil war, built to house the families of the winners - those who had come to Madrid to work for General Franco's Falangist-inspired regime. Some are still here.

When we moved in, the president of the comunidad was a doctor with a practice on the third floor. A visit to his office revealed a Falange flag, its emblematic bundle of arrows spiking proudly upwards, on his bookcase.

As neighbours, some old fachas are not so bad. In the lift they greet you politely. Avoid discussing Franco, immigration or the merits of democracy and relations remain sweet.

Last year's most popular Spanish film was a dark comedy called La Comunidad. It features a group of Madrid neighbours who try to kill a newcomer. I, at least, have only been threatened with a spell in Madrid's jail.

webTitle: Nuclear activists gather to stop train

fields.headline: Nuclear activists gather to stop train
fields.trailText: Thousands of environmental activists will gather on the heaths of northern Germany today in preparation for Europe's biggest anti-nuclear protest in years.
fields.body:
Thousands of environmental activists will gather on the heaths of northern Germany today in preparation for Europe's biggest anti-nuclear protest in years.

Fifteen thousand protesters are planning to halt the journey of a train carrying reprocessed nuclear waste from the French border to Germany's nuclear dumping ground at Gorleben, about 80 miles north-west of Berlin. The train is due to leave La Hague, France, at dawn on Monday.

In one of the biggest police actions in postwar German history, up to 30,000 officers with water cannons and teargas are being drafted in to protect the train on its route through the country.

Today's meeting is a dress rehearsal for next week's battle. Demonstrators are expected from all over Europe and at least 2,000 local community members will take part, including a strong farming lobby, who have said they are prepared to use physical force to stop transport of the nuclear material.

The figure at the centre of the protesters' wrath is Jürgen Trittin, the Greens' environment minister. Mr Trittin has stressed Germany's moral duty to take back the waste produced by the country's 16 nuclear power stations, and sent abroad for reprocessing.

"We have legal and political obligations.

"We can't simply dump our waste on our next-door neighbour's doorstep," he said.

fields.headline: Biggest US warships 'out of date'
fields.standfirst: Radical defence review alters military priorities and signals new hostility to China
fields.trailText: Radical defence review alters military priorities and signals new hostility to China
fields.body:
The most radical strategic review in a generation of the United States' military priorities is about to conclude that the world's largest warships are dinosaurs of 20th-century warfare, and will inaugurate an era of direct confrontation with China.

Establishing the Pentagon study, President George Bush ordered his defence secretary, Donald Rumsfeld, and his team of advisers to "challenge the status quo" and to "skip a generation of technology". All the early signs are that this is exactly what the planners have done.

The key person in the review process is a career Pentagon official, Andrew Marshall, 79, a man routinely described in profiles as "legendary" and "the most influential person in the world you've never heard of".

Mr Marshall has been an adviser to every US defence secretary since the Nixon administration and is a long-term advocate of US missile defence and of a more confrontational stance towards China, both of which are central tenets of the Pentagon rethink.

Mr Rumsfeld has entrusted Mr Marshall with the decisive role in a review which is intended to impose lasting changes in the way that the Pentagon budget, set this year at $310.5bn - or a third of the total amount spent on the military in all parts of the globe - is divided up. Mr Bush has indicated that US defence spending will get an even bigger increase than this year's $14.2bn - or 4.8 % -rise.

By putting Mr Marshall in charge of the review, Mr Rumsfeld has signalled that he does not want the armed services to set their own agenda. Reports in Washington say that the three service chiefs have been largely excluded from decisive stages of the review process. Mr Rumsfeld briefed the service chiefs this week about the preliminary findings of the review in a manner that was said to be "brusque".

It will mark a sharp shift in emphasis. Less than three weeks ago President George Bush presided at the Virginia launching ceremony for the USS Ronald Reagan, the ninth and latest of the US Navy's massive Nimitz-class aircraft carriers that have been the centrepieces of American battle planning since the end of the Vietnam war more than 25 years ago.

But the ship that Mr Bush hymned on March 4 as "one hundred thousand tons of American power" and which the Pentagon boasted would "serve the fleet for 50 years" now looks certain to be the last of its kind, and may even be held back from the frontline role for which it was originally conceived.

Gargantuan $5bn aircraft carriers like the Reagan, each carrying 80 aircraft and with a crew of 6,000, have been identified by the Pentagon as too big and too expensive a target in the missile-dominated warfare that US military chiefs now believe will characterise the 21st century.

Initial leaks from the wide-ranging US defence review set in motion by the Bush admin istration suggested yesterday that Mr Rumsfeld is about to order the Navy to stop building Nimitz class carriers immediately. Instead the Navy will be instructed to rethink its carrier capacity in favour of smaller, faster and more manoeuvrable vessels that are less vulnerable to missiles.

"The big loser is the carrier," a source told the Washington Post yesterday, which broke the story. The big winner in the review, by contrast, is likely to be the US Air Force (USAF).

Pentagon planners have decided that the key to the future of warfare is likely to lie with long distance bombers and unmanned aircraft and that "long range power projection" - including the requirement to airlift large numbers of troops and matériel halfway around the world from bases in the US - is the challenge of the future.

However, the USAF will be disappointed by the review's emphasis on less spending on jet fighter planes. The central question here is the future of the F-22 stealth fighter, which is scheduled to replace the existing F-15 as the principal US combat plane during the next decade in a $350bn programme.

Reports yesterday suggested that the air force will be told to cut the number of F-22s on its order books, largely on the grounds that its range may not be sufficient to fit the new thinking.

The US currently has 1,384,000 military personnel of all types on active duty, divided between the army with 482,000, the navy with 373,000, the air force with 356,000 and the US Marine Corps with 173,000. The overwhelming majority of these - around 1.13m - are based in the continental US and in American territories overseas, such as Guam and Puerto Rico.

The US has 117,000 service men and women stationed in Europe, including 69,000 in Germany and 11,000 in each of Britain and Italy. There are just over 5,000 US troops in Bosnia and the same number in Kosovo.

In East Asia and the Pacific, the US has 101,000 service personnel, of whom 40,000 are in Japan and 37,000 in South Korea. The other major concentrations of US forces are in Saudi Arabia 7,000 and Kuwait 5,000.

In retrospect, Mr Bush seemed to be hinting only a few weeks ago that a turning point had been reached in military planning on the use of aircraft carriers.

"For the last 60 years, every president has had to ask, 'Where are the carriers?' None has ever been disappointed by the navy's response," Mr Bush said at the launch of the USS Ronald Reagan. "But he cannot live forever on that legacy. Our challenge is to build a military that will deter and win the wars of the future."

The nuclear-powered Nimitz-class aircraft carriers have been in service since the first of them, the USS Nimitz, was commissioned in 1975. At present, five of the eight commissioned Nimitz carriers are with the US fifth fleet in the Arabian gulf and with the sixth fleet in the Mediterranean. The other three are with the much larger seventh fleet in the Pacific ocean, and are mostly based in Japan.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Greenpeace founder killed
fields.body:
Greenpeace founder killed

David McTaggart, the Canadian co-founder of Greenpeace, was killed in a car crash in the Italian city of Perugia yesterday.

McTaggart, 69, helped found the environmental pressure group in the early 1970s and was its chairman for more than a decade until 1991.

Reuters, Rome

Man held for China bombings

China's most wanted man, accused of several bombings in which more than 100 died, has been arrested. Jin Ruchao, a 40-year-old deaf-mute, was arrested in Beihai city, near Vietnam. Police said that he confessed to the explosions in Shijiazhuang on March 16.

John Gittings, Shanghai

Body-snatchers demand ransom

A ransom of several million pounds has been demanded for the body of Enrico Cuccia, once Italy's most powerful banker, who died in June. The body was stolen from the family tomb last week.

AP, Rome

webTitle: Time to look up if you're hemmed in on all sides

fields.headline: Time to look up if you're hemmed in on all sides
fields.trailText: A garden from a hundred packets of seeds
fields.body:
At the start of this series, I mentioned a garden I had seen last summer in New York, which consisted of nothing more than Morning Glories growing up a fire escape. I saw the remains of it again the other day, high above 43rd Street, the dead vines washed grey against the dark metalwork. If I had appreciated it and remembered its location, no doubt I was one of many who had enjoyed it and thought: that was a success.

Suppose it were a success not to be repeated. Suppose the instigator of this garden had simply thought: this year, I feel like seeing Morning Glories every morning, and for a summer had revelled in the triumph of the project - but the following year were to turn to something else. Would there be something wrong with that?

I imagine the flower forever having a particular association for the owner of this "garden" - this nondescript container dumped on a fire escape, which suddenly, and so satisfactorily, took off. Whatever the summer of 2000 meant would be summed up by the sight of Heavenly Blue Ipomoea tricolor (no 76).

To me it means sleeping under a trellis in Greece, but Ipomoea is historically associated with Central America. A quick check in the Codex Badianus, an Aztec herbal now in the Vatican, gives us the Fever Flower, Tontonquixochitl, and a recipe against hair loss: "falling hair is checked by washing the head, and if the herb called xiuhhamolli is applied to it, ground and cooked in the urine of a dog or a stag, with tree frogs and the small animals auatecolotl" (apparently a kind of caterpillar).

What the codex fails to impart is the recipe for deriving LSD from I tricolor , which was the standard Aztec hallucinogen. An illustration of the associative power of the flower is the fact that Morning Glory always lifts the heart, whereas the common white convolvulus (so very similar in form) always causes it to sink. I have not tried the white version of Morning Glory ("Pearly Gates") for that reason. There are reds on offer as well. I batatas, as the name more than hints, is the Sweet Potato.

The smaller the garden, the greater the interest in extending it by means of climbers. Some small town houses have no garden at all, but the house itself has been interpreted as, first and foremost, a support for a rampant clematis or wisteria. I like these examples of horticultural excess very much, but where there is the opportunity to grow just a few more plants, it is the smaller climbers that will attract the attention of the householder. They are less likely to crowd their neighbours out.

Early on, I mentioned the common nasturtium, Tropaeolum majus, grown in the courtyard of a Boston museum, massed in windowboxes. The windows in question are extraordinary, having been transported from Venetian palazzi. The planting might have looked foolish had it been done with anything less than total conviction. As it was, with cascades of nasturtiums, one felt one was seeing the flower used properly for the first time.

An illusion, of course, that the self-confident can create. There are many other tropaeolums, including one that features in that useful book, Lost Crops of the Incas. T tuberosum, known to us in the form "Ken Aslet" (boil the tubers with meat), and to South Americans as mashua, a crop for high altitudes which (mark this now) repels many insects and pathogens, and is handy for farmers who cannot afford pesticides.

But the tropaeolum I am recommending from seed is no 77, the delicate yellow-flowered Canary Creeper T peregrinum, which comes from Peru and Ecuador and is for us a half-hardy annual. Another with which we have had success in southern England is a Chilean, no 78 T ciliatum, which we have growing up a yew hedge, where in Scotland one would more likely see the wonderful Flame Nasturtium T speciosum.

Another Chilean/Peruvian, to pursue the theme, is the Glory Flower (no 79) Eccremocarpus scaber, which is a perfect climber for the small garden since it can climb through a shrub without giving it too much hassle. Orange and red tubular flowers, bright and small, are its contribution. We also grow Tresco Cream, which is presumably one of the constituents of Chilterns Seeds' offering, Tresco mixed. Listed as half-hardy, it is very likely to survive a town winter.

Returning to Mexico, we encounter no 80, the astonishing Rhodochiton atrosangineum, another tender vine, with blood-black flowers (as its specific name warns us to expect) and a surprisingly pronounced calyx. Its colour is similar to that of the popular chocolate Cosmos.

And Aconitum Hemsleyanum (no 82) is a Chinese climbing Monkshood, and therefore presumably (I haven't tried it) poisonous. The flowers are dark blue, as you'd expect.

Sweet peas I have mentioned earlier in the context of their great ancestor, Lathyrus cupanii. No 83 is a blue-flowered pea, L sativus varazureus, known, the books tell me, as Riga or Dogtooth Pea. And since a mere two peas might sound stingy, I would add a packet of no 84, Chiltern's Old-fashioned Sweet Peas, Mixed (the word old-fashioned in this context holds out an expectation of a better scent than that of more recent varieties, but scent is not my strong point).

Finally, Phaseolus coccineus ( no 85) is the Scarlet Runner Bean, a plant I am always happy to grow, if not obliged so much as to think about eating it. As a flower it is unanswerable, and that is all we need or wish to know about it.

fields.headline: The last word on.. Meat
fields.trailText: It is useless for the sheep to pass resolutions in favour of vegetarianism while the wolf is of a different opinion - Inge
fields.body:
It is useless for the sheep to pass resolutions in favour of vegetarianism while the wolf is of a different opinion - Inge

There is something ancient and dreadful about the pyres of burning animals currently reddening our nights. They are reminiscent of classical antiquity's greatest exercise in holy sacrifice, the hecatomb, in which 100 oxen were slaughtered and burned to elicit the gods' favour. That number of beasts represented an immense oblation of self-impoverishment by the community, undertaken to prove its earnest to the gods. (Such things still happen; the Taliban are sacrificing cows this week to apologise to God for taking so long over destroying Buddhist statues - thus annoying Hindus, too, for whom cows are sacred.)

Our contemporary burnt offerings address a single god, Mammon, who does not care that the slaughtered beasts had little wrong with them physically, but who hates the vileness of their economic disease: reduced yields of milk and meat, leading to reduced profits.

Some newspapers speak of angry farmers guarding their cherished herds against the cull. The impression given is misleading. Every normal week, 100,000 animals die in abattoirs around the country, so it is not the vast industry of death which the farmers contest, but the fact that they get less for vet-slaughtered than abattoir-butchered beasts.

From the Cumbrian pyres to the thousands of acres of grazing that were once Amazonian forest, from the cardiology wards to the lorries crammed with bleating lambs on their way to die, the costs of meat-eating are immense. The arguments against it are severally persuasive and jointly compelling. There is an economic argument, which points out that two people can be fed from an acre of land on which livestock are run, as against 20 if it is cultivated for grain. There is a health argument, which points out that meat is full of fat and bacteria, and if non-organic then full also of growth hormones, antibiotics and vaccines. And strongest of all there is a moral argument against using and then killing sentient creatures for our pleasure, when we do not need to do so to live well and wisely.

One does well to take the health argument seriously. We do not eat "fresh" meat; we eat carrion, for the former would be stiff with rigor mortis, and meat only becomes soft enough to cook and eat once it has begun to rot. We like our game especially rotten, which is why we leave it hanging for days so that the microbes swarming in it can do their work.

Microbes are the meat-eater's friend; without them there could be no tender steak, no juicy roast, no tasty chop or rib. To see how they work, put a dead mouse in the garden and watch what happens. The little corpse decomposes with such fury that it seems to be wriggling and trying to run away, such is the pullulating mass of microbes consuming it within.

Once the proteins in a corpse have become cheesy, the "cheese skippers" (piophila casei) arrive to do what they do to old cheese (and dirty feet - which is why the French call choice gorgonzola "les pieds de Dieu"). Everything is finished off by bacteria, which in 10 hours multiply from 100 to 100 million in number. They are present in these numbers on the meat in your kitchen; they eat your meat as they ate the mouse, and since everything that eats must defecate, it is their lack of toilet training that gives exposed meat its gamey aroma.

The health argument is a prudential one; the moral argument is one of principle. A frank look at what is involved in rearing, transporting and killing the animals we eat daily should fill any normal person with more revulsion than the microbial tale just told. How many meat-eaters would cut the throat of a cow themselves, and hack open its belly with a knife to empty its intestines? But the thousands of daily deaths of animals are hidden away, and on the butcher's shelf meat looks innocuous, nothing like the living thing it was.

It is odd: we prosecute anyone who is cruel to a cow - by beating it or giving it electric shocks, say - yet the connection between that fact and the dinner table is rarely made.
