fields.headline: The colour of emotion
fields.standfirst: At five, he knew he wanted to be an artist. But it took until his 50s, and a period of personal upheaval, for his paintings to receive worldwide acclaim. fiery and forthright, he is a renowned art collector and one of the great aesthetes of the age. Nicholas Wroe reports
fields.trailText: At five, he knew he wanted to be an artist. But it took until his 50s, and a period of personal upheaval, for his paintings to receive worldwide acclaim. fiery and forthright, he is a renowned art collector and one of the great aesthetes of the age. Nicholas Wroe reports.
fields.body:
A few years ago, Howard Hodgkin was on holiday in Italy with the novelist Julian Barnes and Barnes's wife, the literary agent Pat Kavanagh. While in the small town of Taranto, Hodgkin decided he wanted to buy a black towel and happened to see one in a shop window. "So we all went in and they brought out a black towel," recalls Barnes. "'No, that's not black,' said Howard. So they brought out another, and another, and he said, 'No, I want one like the one in the window'. They eventually emptied the entire shop and were reduced to delving in the window. And that towel was indeed true black, when set beside the others. You know intellectually that painters have a more highly developed sense of colour, but this was a brilliant and unwitting public demonstration."

Now aged 68, Hodgkin has been in the first division of living artists for a quarter of a century. He is a Turner Prize winner, has been knighted, and enjoys a reputation which is just as strong abroad, particularly in America, as it is at home. But while it is perhaps no real surprise that a man who is routinely described as Britain's greatest colourist should be able to differentiate between shades of black, Hodgkin's precise daily calibration of the visual world still remains exceptional.

He was once invited to a performance of Wagner's opera, Siegfried, by his friend, the soprano Anne Evans. Although Evans only sings in the last act, Hodgkin walked out of the theatre after just a few minutes because he found the production so visually offensive. ("It was just a few twigs sticking out of sand, which was totally inadequate," he explains. "But I did go back in at the end to hear Anne sing.") On several occasions he has changed dealers because the rooms in which they displayed his work weren't acceptable, and on a more mundane level he sometimes has to move tables in a restaurant two or three times if he can see his own reflection anywhere in a mirror.

All this, as well as his extraordinary eye as a collector of Indian art, undoubtedly ensures Hodgkin's place as one of the great aesthetes of the age. But to think of him as a delicate creature cruelly buffeted by the coarseness of modern life would be misleading. Nicholas Serota, the director of the Tate Gallery, curated Hodgkin's first museum exhibition in 1976. He says: "You wouldn't use the word sensitive about Howard; that implies something far too ineffectual. He is more passionate than that. He is a man who loves and hates with a passion, and is very emotional. He will cry very easily and flares up, both in terms of colour and of temper, very quickly. That can be quite disturbing and it is sometimes quite difficult to deal with. But it is because he holds his convictions so strongly. And that passion has become much more evident in the paintings over the last 15 years or so."

Hodgkin's lusciously colourful paintings, although often quite small at just a few feet each way, are comprised of full-brushed medleys of boldly recorded dots, slashes, curves and other grand sweeps. He always paints on board, not canvas, with the picture spreading over the frame. Both board and frame are as often as not bought at car boot sales. The pictures can take years to complete, with him continually adding more marks which, he says, "may look like free gestures, but very rarely are". His work is often mistakenly seen as abstract, but as Hodgkin has explained, he is, "a representational painter, but not a painter of appearances. I paint representational pictures of emotional situations."

In his monograph of the artist - revised and reissued next month - the critic Andrew Graham-Dixon illustrates the difficulty of this apparently straightforward statement. "Howard Hodgkin paints emotional situations, Cezanne painted apples." With reference to the late-80s painting, On the Riviera, Graham-Dixon describes Hodgkin's conception of his memory of these emotional situations: "something illogical, subject to the vagaries of feeling and attention - pushed, as it so often is, in Hodgkin's mature art to the extremes of near-illegibility. Remembered things (flags, sea and sky, perhaps the whitewashed side of a building) merge and blend, melt into each other like the elements of a collage that have been liquefied. The painting phrases itself boldly as a surrogate for an experience that cannot be recaptured, and creates a new world out of the chaos of a memory."

A painting is finished when it "replaces" the event or emotion that inspired it. "The picture is instead of what happened," Hodgkin once explained to the critic Robert Hughes. "We don't need to know the story: generally, the story's trivial anyway. The more people want to know the story, the less they'll want to look at the picture." Hughes has described Hodgkin' s work as, "feelings declared in colour. They are intelligent not in the way argument can be, but in the way painting is - though in most cutting-edge art, actually isn't."

Julian Barnes - who says he likes to maintain that the green patch in the middle of the painting, When Did We Go To Morocco? (1988-93), is in fact him behind the Michelin guide - has witnessed the moment of artistic conception. "We'll all be sitting in a cafe in a ruminative mood and I might say, semi-teasingly, 'I think I feel a picture coming on,' and Howard might chuckle, 'I think I feel one too'. There's no evident frisson. You have a sense of him sitting a little further back in his chair, of his head tilting slightly upwards, hoovering in the entire scene of a small Italian piazza or a fishmarket. Although, of course, his final representation of it will be at several visual removes."

This process might have made Hodgkin an exception as someone in the British art world that the public has heard of, but looking at his family background, high-profile achievement seems much closer to the norm. On his father's side of the family tree are the 19th-century physician, Thomas Hodgkin, after whom the lymphatic cancer is named; Dorothy, who is a Hodgkin by marriage, and was awarded the 1964 Nobel prize for chemistry for her work on the structure of Vitamin B12; and the Bloomsbury artist and critic, Roger Fry. On the maternal side, his grandfather, Gordon Hewart, was a Lord Chief Justice.

Howard was born in Hammersmith in 1932 and has one sister, Ann, two years older than him, who is now retired, having been a school secretary. His father, Eliot, was a manager for ICI, and his mother, Katherine, a housewife. There was a certain amount of casual exposure to art during his childhood, with one family friend keeping an Epstein bust in their chicken run. The house of his cousin, Margery Fry, was full of items from the Omega Workshop, the applied arts company founded by Roger Fry, which produced ceramics, furniture and textiles designed by Fry, Duncan Grant and Vanessa Bell.

Hodgkin describes his own family unit as "middle-class but bizarre", and says that there were social tensions. While his grandfather, the Lord Chief Justice, ended up as a friend of Lloyd George, he was a self-made man whose own mother had run a draper's shop in Bury. His grandfather "loathed" his father, having hoped that his daughter would have made a better match. But while his father was financially compelled to work for ICI in order to support his family, his life was not without a hinterland. During the war, he ended up working for a unit that broadcast black propaganda on the radio to break German morale. As part of the first wave of allied forces who entered Paris after the liberation, he brought back books on Bonnard and, as a noted amateur horticulturist, he advised the government on the planting of motorway verges.

"When he was dying, he was given a wonderful art nouveau gold medal by the Royal Horticultural Society," says Hodgkin. "My father really wanted to have a creative life of some kind, and he loved looking at paintings. Although my mother was a very good botanical illustrator, painting didn't really mean anything to her." His parents did buy one of Hodgkin's paintings from his third exhibition in 1967. "But eventually, my father said that he couldn't possibly hang it up in the house. And he was quite right. It was a brown furniture sort of house, and there was just nowhere for it to go. Eventually, they gave it to the Tate."

In 1940, Howard, his sister and his mother moved to the United States to get away from the war. They stayed with a lawyer friend of his grandfather in Long Island, which Hodgkin remembers as being like, "something out of the Great Gatsby". Having declared his intention to be an artist at the age of five, he was repeatedly taken to the Museum of Modern Art and was doubly precocious in that he could not only draw, but could also discuss art.

Hodgkin says the family response to his ambition was that it was all right to be an artist as long as it was as an amateur. This stance led to a battle throughout his childhood as to what sort of education he should have. With money left by Hewart, he was sent to a series of expensive schools, including Eton, where he was taught by Wilfred Blunt, brother of the art historian and spy, Anthony. To this day, he has mixed feelings about the place, and still gets angry when the school is characterised as a snobbish enclave.

"These people don't know what they are talking about. I think the school was a university for children. You were given freedom and encouragement, and you were made responsible." However, as all his judgments were filtered through the calculation "will this help or hinder me to be an artist?", he reasoned that it wasn't for him.

He says that it was his mother who continued to push the square peg back into the round hole in terms of persevering with an orthodox, privileged education. "I didn't get on with my mother," he acknowledges. "She even wanted me to join the diplomatic corps. I told her it was ridiculous - I would have started a war."

It was partly with the help of his cousin, Margery Fry, that when Hodgkin left school in 1949 he won a place at Camberwell Art School, and then moved on to the Bath Academy of Art, Corsham. At Camberwell, he was taught by leading Euston Road School painters Victor Pasmore and William Coldstream, and remembers considerable peer pressure to conform to a house style. "I was already an outsider even then," he recalls, and by the time he went to Corsham, he already had his own artistic language.

Hodgkin appears happy to be thought of as a one-off, but there have been attempts to place him within a tradition. One of the more interesting sees him as following on from Ivon Hitchens, whose vividly colourful depictions of the English landscape from the 40s to the 70s hover between abstraction and figuration. Richard Shone of the Burlington magazine says that while Hodgkin has developed his own very personal synthesis of various artistic traditions, "all young artists take on an aspect of their time. You can't come out of nowhere, and certainly in his early work with the bright, frontal colour and the relaxed young people sit ting in rooms, there are aspects of pop art with a small p." Hodgkin says that he was very proud to once appear in the index of a book on pop art under the entry: "Howard Hodgkin is not a pop artist."

The critic David Sylvester sees a longer heritage. "There is an atmospheric lyricism in his work that is very English and can be traced back to Turner. I think Howard is steeped in Turner." Hodgkin has spoken about the importance of Matisse and the Intimist work of the French painter Edouard Vuillard, but says that as a young artist, the key exhibitions he saw in London were of contemporary American art put on by the United States Information Service. He was struck by the work of Barnett Newman and Stuart Davis, but the most influential was Jackson Pollock. "Seeing the Pollocks was amazing for an ambitious young artist. They were there as, say, mountains outside your holiday window are there. They became part of my world, and that was a revelation. Seeing work like that can give you a new idea as to what is physically possible. It's not so much the content of the picture, but just the thought that, 'yes, that can be done'. It is often forgotten that paintings are what they are made of. Painting is a very physical thing."

After finishing as a student in 1954, Hodgkin spent a brief period teaching at Charterhouse School, and then returned to Bath as a teacher, where he stayed until 1966. After that, he taught for six years at the Chelsea School of Art. He says he enjoyed teaching, but of most benefit to him was mixing with other artist-teachers. The artist, Robyn Denny, who was both a colleague and subject of two well-known Hodgkin portraits, remembers him as very ambitious as an artist. "He was extremely clever, but not in a pejorative sense. He was complicated, learned, insightful and sort of duplicit and opaque. It is an odd combination that makes him an extremely interesting man. And combined with his ambition as an artist, it made him a powerful force."

Chris Garrett, the cartoonist, and half of the Guardian's Biff cartoon team, was one of Hodgkin's students. He says Hodgkin was more like a dance teacher in that he always demanded the best. "He scared the living daylights out of us. He'd set an exercise and then walk round the studio. You'd hear him saying, 'that's terrible, rub it out', and then a whimper from the student. 'Stop trying to look like an artist, just be one'." Garrett adds: "Maybe in the third year he'd offer you a Woodbine, which was a sign something was good. He was difficult to fathom. He always wore a dark suit and tie and had this very austere, punctilious way of teaching. But his paintings were packed with these great bloody colours blasted on the canvas, which had been the product of an obviously very intense kind of operation. I once saw him in his suit, and there was a tiny spot of brilliant viridian green on his black Oxford shoes. It was the only hint of what he had been doing."

By this time Hodgkin was married with a young family. He and Julia Lane met as art students at Corsham and they married in 1955. She went on to teach art in a school, and then to run the florist shop at Heal's furniture shop in London. Hodgkin commuted to Bath from their flat in Shepherds Bush, where he remembers holes in the carpets were covered with dog skins - "a little Scottie here, something else there. It was revolting, and we got rid of them in the end."

Their first son, Louis, was born in 1958, and then Sam in 1960. "Louis lives in the country and cultivates his garden," says Hodgkin. "I don't know how he gets by but he is completely happy. People go and see him because he's so happy. He's like a guru or something. Sam, on the other hand, is not so happy." He laughs. "He works in television."

Hodgkin was not very productive when his children were young. "Julia once asked me how can I call myself a painter when I don't actually paint. It wasn't so neat that I started to paint immediately, but I was upset by it and it struck home." This tentativeness was reflected in his business relationship with dealers. When the Arthur Tooth gallery in Dover Street put on his first show in 1962, they offered him a contract that would double every year. "But I insisted it stayed the same," says Hodgkin. "I always worried where the next picture was coming from and it would have been too much pressure. Little did I know what was to come in terms of pressure."

As well as teaching and being an artist during the 60s, Hodgkin became a serious collector of 16th and 17th-century Indian painting. His collection became one of the best in the world, and has been widely exhibited. "For a while it was a wonderful other activity," he says. "It was nice to meet other collectors, and I was good at it. But the collection becomes a monster with a life of its own. You have to have things to go with other things. It probably has affected me as an artist, but not in the way that people think. The Indian paintings haven't influenced my paintings, but collecting has made me very aware of quality, and increasingly demanding of my own work."

Such was Hodgkin's commitment to his collection that he once sold 60 of his own paintings - "not for huge amounts of money" - to fund the purchase of one Indian work. His friend, James Fenton, the poet and writer on art and gardening, says that is the essence of a collector. "It's more than being an accumulator. The important expression is 'the best is the enemy of the good'. If you have good things in the collection, and then you get something that is the best, the other paintings somehow have their noses put out of joint. I told him once that something was coming up for sale and it looked to be a bargain. He said this whole business of bargains is a diversion. 'Don't collect bargains, collect masterpieces.' That is Howard."

Julian Barnes says Hodgkin's astonishing eye for quality means he can visually gut a municipal art gallery in eight to 10 minutes. "And he would have seen, and more importantly remembered in incredible detail, the things that qualify as masterpieces. It's an extraordinary experience going round a church or a gallery with Howard. Typically, we'd be in a church with, say, a one-star Bellini altar piece in the second chapel on the left. We'd get there and there would be a deep, dark chuckle from Howard - 'I think not'. And then within 20 seconds he'll locate a small piece of baroque carving at the bottom of a tomb which was in fact the only thing worth seeing in the church."

While there has not been a school of Hodgkin, his influence on the British art scene has been considerable. His reputation abroad has bolstered the image of British art, and his collection is significant, but equally important was his work as an artist trustee of both the Tate and the National in the 60s and 70s. In her history of the Tate gallery, Frances Spalding identified his importance in relation to purchases made by the national collections. "With his immense knowledge of art and the art market, Hodgkin had a unique gift for either promoting or killing a potential purchase," she wrote. "He might merely lower his eyes and begin to doodle, but it had devastating effect."

Hodgkin has said he was amazed at how much clout the artist trustees had, and was instrumental in buying important work by Picasso, Matisse and Degas. He also paved the way for more radical purchases, recalling that, "work by the likes of Beuys had only just come in and no one quite knew what to do with them. They just didn't quite know how to deal with a work that was made of felt and fat."

Although always seen as ambitious, and a skilled operator in the art world, it took a long time for Hodgkin to break through as a first-rank artist. He was 45 before he had a major show in New York, and 52 when he finally won world-wide acclaim after representing Britain at the Venice Biennale. It is generally accepted that at some time in the mid-70s his work seemed to move up a gear. There is a neat psycho-sexual explanation, which was first posited by his friend, Bruce Chatwin. Howard had, "a newfound engagement with the erotic", Chatwin coyly wrote. It had led to a "new persona". What Chatwin meant was that Hodgkin's marriage had come to an end - although he and Julia have never divorced - and he was living as a gay man. Chatwin excitedly, and hyperbolically, wrote to a friend in 1977 that Howard's had become, "the most publicised private life of the century". In reality, it was a rather more smooth transition, and he has now been in a relationship with the music writer, Antony Peattie, since 1983.

Hodgkin sees less of a clean break in his life than is popularly portrayed, pointing out a continuity in his art. "The early pictures are to some degree a rehearsal for what was to come. The continuum might be a bit bumpy, but that's not for the obvious reasons everyone always talks about," he says. "I had terrible trouble finding a way of painting. To some extent, I found my voice early and knew what I wanted to do. But learning how to do it took longer. Nothing is so simple as 'he's gay, look how the pictures have changed'. It just doesn't work like that. The processes are still going on."

David Sylvester agrees that Hodgkin, "has a more consistent line of development than you see in most artists. He found himself fairly early and remained himself." The critical consensus is that his work has improved over time, but some observers still prefer the much more schematic and hard-edged early work when his portraits, although his subjects never sat for him, still contained more conventional representations of identifiable people.

Robyn Denny claims: "His later work seems to coast with less tautness and greater serenity than before. It seems to lack the rawness, the rough edge, the sense of fear that permeated his earlier work and made it always surprising and remarkable." But the more orthodox view comes from Nicholas Serota. "There is a consistent artist and a consistent eye there, but his work did become bolder and freer. His colours had always been very intense and hot, but they became much more complex. They were never beautiful paintings early on, they were regarded as being slightly awkward. They are not awkward in the same way now. They have an elegance and a beauty."

It seems difficult to envisage now, but in 1976, when Serota was putting together the Hodgkin exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art in Oxford, not only was it a struggle to get hold of Hodgkin's paintings from the private collectors who owned them, but even getting photographs of some of the works was impossible. However, within a few years Hodgkin was an art superstar. In 1984, he was expected to win the inaugural Turner prize. In fact, it was awarded to Malcolm Morley, and David Sylvester recalls that, although Hodgkin was clearly disappointed, "he came to a dinner with Morley afterwards and was very graceful in defeat". He won it the following year. He was awarded a CBE in 1977, and knighted in 1992. Did the long wait make him any better equipped to handle success when it arrived? "Not really. I find it terribly difficult to believe in. I've retrospectively regretted the knighthood," he says. "I try hard to get it chopped off whenever I can."

His success has had a dramatic impact on the price of his work. Two years ago, Christie's sold one of his paintings for a record $672,000. An astonishing change since Chris Garrett balked at paying £75 for a painting from Hodgkin's second Tooth show in 1964. While the work has also been seen in more accessible formats - he has designed stamps, book jackets, ballet sets and the exterior of the Imax cinema in London - he has been criticised for producing work that can amount to pretty things for rich people.

Richard Shone says: "There are a series of middle-aged white male critics who think that someone who paints attractively and sensitively can't possibly be any good. Then they get hold of the fact that he's from a well-known family and that he is well to do - from his art - and it all counts against him. But he doesn't produce luxury goods. His paintings come out of him through blood, sweat and tears."

The critic, Waldemar Januszczak, went on the attack after seeing the first painting on display at a show in 1999 which Hodgkin had, "the temerity to entitle After Matisse. What! When did Matisse ever use a brush wide enough to sweep a station concourse? Hodgkin is not the English Matisse. Rather, with his increasing sentimentality, his cheerful colours, his obvious plotlines, he is the Walt Disney of British abstraction."

Hodgkin says: "There is an idea that if a subject is not grandiose and tragic, then it is trivial. Just imagine if Matisse had made today his famous remark about wanting to paint pictures that were like comfortable armchairs for tired business men to sit in. That would be the end of him."

Hodgkin's next exhibition of new work opens in Milan later this week, and in June some of his older work will be hung alongside the old masters at the Dulwich Picture Gallery. Seeing the 17 oils for Milan against the whitewashed walls of his studio, a converted dairy round the corner from the British Museum, they are like a series of dazzling jewels that strangely transfix and draw in the exhilarated viewer. Julian Barnes sums up the powerful ongoing relationships the paintings can engender. "On a first visit to a Hodgkin exhibition of 12 paintings you'll think there are three obvious masterpieces, six or seven very good pictures, and two that you just don't get. But if you go back, you find they all get hold of you and they never let go. So when you see a painting again after several years, it's much more than just an aesthetic reconnection: it's also a direct, emotional response, like meeting a person again."

This chimes with Hodgkin's own long-term relationship with the works. He says the emotion that sparked their creation is left in the work by the time it has been completed. "I remember seeing a picture of mine that I hadn't seen for a very long time, and thinking: 'ah, yes.' It was an instant recognition of that time." He now says he has many things in his mind, "queuing up to be turned into something else", and is increasingly anxious to complete the process. "I can't think of anything rational that allows things to get to the front of the queue and be painted; perhaps an echo of something that happened now and also happened then. But now I do feel that time is creeping up on me and I've got to hurry up. I don't care a damn about what happens when I'm dead, but I do have a sense of increased urgency. And I think it's made me more courageous."

Education: Schools include St Andrew's, Pangbourne, Eton, Bryanston; Camberwell School of Art 1949-50; Bath Academy of Art 1950-54

Family: Married Julia Lane, 1955; two sons, Louis and Sam

fields.bodyText: A few years ago, Howard Hodgkin was on holiday in Italy with the novelist Julian Barnes and Barnes's wife, the literary agent Pat Kavanagh. While in the small town of Taranto, Hodgkin decided he wanted to buy a black towel and happened to see one in a shop window. "So we all went in and they brought out a black towel," recalls Barnes. "'No, that's not black,' said Howard. So they brought out another, and another, and he said, 'No, I want one like the one in the window'. They eventually emptied the entire shop and were reduced to delving in the window. And that towel was indeed true black, when set beside the others. You know intellectually that painters have a more highly developed sense of colour, but this was a brilliant and unwitting public demonstration." Now aged 68, Hodgkin has been in the first division of living artists for a quarter of a century. He is a Turner Prize winner, has been knighted, and enjoys a reputation which is just as strong abroad, particularly in America, as it is at home. But while it is perhaps no real surprise that a man who is routinely described as Britain's greatest colourist should be able to differentiate between shades of black, Hodgkin's precise daily calibration of the visual world still remains exceptional. He was once invited to a performance of Wagner's opera, Siegfried, by his friend, the soprano Anne Evans. Although Evans only sings in the last act, Hodgkin walked out of the theatre after just a few minutes because he found the production so visually offensive. ("It was just a few twigs sticking out of sand, which was totally inadequate," he explains. "But I did go back in at the end to hear Anne sing.") On several occasions he has changed dealers because the rooms in which they displayed his work weren't acceptable, and on a more mundane level he sometimes has to move tables in a restaurant two or three times if he can see his own reflection anywhere in a mirror. All this, as well as his extraordinary eye as a collector of Indian art, undoubtedly ensures Hodgkin's place as one of the great aesthetes of the age. But to think of him as a delicate creature cruelly buffeted by the coarseness of modern life would be misleading. Nicholas Serota, the director of the Tate Gallery, curated Hodgkin's first museum exhibition in 1976. He says: "You wouldn't use the word sensitive about Howard; that implies something far too ineffectual. He is more passionate than that. He is a man who loves and hates with a passion, and is very emotional. He will cry very easily and flares up, both in terms of colour and of temper, very quickly. That can be quite disturbing and it is sometimes quite difficult to deal with. But it is because he holds his convictions so strongly. And that passion has become much more evident in the paintings over the last 15 years or so." Hodgkin's lusciously colourful paintings, although often quite small at just a few feet each way, are comprised of full-brushed medleys of boldly recorded dots, slashes, curves and other grand sweeps. He always paints on board, not canvas, with the picture spreading over the frame. Both board and frame are as often as not bought at car boot sales. The pictures can take years to complete, with him continually adding more marks which, he says, "may look like free gestures, but very rarely are". His work is often mistakenly seen as abstract, but as Hodgkin has explained, he is, "a representational painter, but not a painter of appearances. I paint representational pictures of emotional situations." In his monograph of the artist - revised and reissued next month - the critic Andrew Graham-Dixon illustrates the difficulty of this apparently straightforward statement. "Howard Hodgkin paints emotional situations, Cezanne painted apples." With reference to the late-80s painting, On the Riviera, Graham-Dixon describes Hodgkin's conception of his memory of these emotional situations: "something illogical, subject to the vagaries of feeling and attention - pushed, as it so often is, in Hodgkin's mature art to the extremes of near-illegibility. Remembered things (flags, sea and sky, perhaps the whitewashed side of a building) merge and blend, melt into each other like the elements of a collage that have been liquefied. The painting phrases itself boldly as a surrogate for an experience that cannot be recaptured, and creates a new world out of the chaos of a memory." A painting is finished when it "replaces" the event or emotion that inspired it. "The picture is instead of what happened," Hodgkin once explained to the critic Robert Hughes. "We don't need to know the story: generally, the story's trivial anyway. The more people want to know the story, the less they'll want to look at the picture." Hughes has described Hodgkin' s work as, "feelings declared in colour. They are intelligent not in the way argument can be, but in the way painting is - though in most cutting-edge art, actually isn't." Julian Barnes - who says he likes to maintain that the green patch in the middle of the painting, When Did We Go To Morocco? (1988-93), is in fact him behind the Michelin guide - has witnessed the moment of artistic conception. "We'll all be sitting in a cafe in a ruminative mood and I might say, semi-teasingly, 'I think I feel a picture coming on,' and Howard might chuckle, 'I think I feel one too'. There's no evident frisson. You have a sense of him sitting a little further back in his chair, of his head tilting slightly upwards, hoovering in the entire scene of a small Italian piazza or a fishmarket. Although, of course, his final representation of it will be at several visual removes." This process might have made Hodgkin an exception as someone in the British art world that the public has heard of, but looking at his family background, high-profile achievement seems much closer to the norm. On his father's side of the family tree are the 19th-century physician, Thomas Hodgkin, after whom the lymphatic cancer is named; Dorothy, who is a Hodgkin by marriage, and was awarded the 1964 Nobel prize for chemistry for her work on the structure of Vitamin B12; and the Bloomsbury artist and critic, Roger Fry. On the maternal side, his grandfather, Gordon Hewart, was a Lord Chief Justice. Howard was born in Hammersmith in 1932 and has one sister, Ann, two years older than him, who is now retired, having been a school secretary. His father, Eliot, was a manager for ICI, and his mother, Katherine, a housewife. There was a certain amount of casual exposure to art during his childhood, with one family friend keeping an Epstein bust in their chicken run. The house of his cousin, Margery Fry, was full of items from the Omega Workshop, the applied arts company founded by Roger Fry, which produced ceramics, furniture and textiles designed by Fry, Duncan Grant and Vanessa Bell. Hodgkin describes his own family unit as "middle-class but bizarre", and says that there were social tensions. While his grandfather, the Lord Chief Justice, ended up as a friend of Lloyd George, he was a self-made man whose own mother had run a draper's shop in Bury. His grandfather "loathed" his father, having hoped that his daughter would have made a better match. But while his father was financially compelled to work for ICI in order to support his family, his life was not without a hinterland. During the war, he ended up working for a unit that broadcast black propaganda on the radio to break German morale. As part of the first wave of allied forces who entered Paris after the liberation, he brought back books on Bonnard and, as a noted amateur horticulturist, he advised the government on the planting of motorway verges. "When he was dying, he was given a wonderful art nouveau gold medal by the Royal Horticultural Society," says Hodgkin. "My father really wanted to have a creative life of some kind, and he loved looking at paintings. Although my mother was a very good botanical illustrator, painting didn't really mean anything to her." His parents did buy one of Hodgkin's paintings from his third exhibition in 1967. "But eventually, my father said that he couldn't possibly hang it up in the house. And he was quite right. It was a brown furniture sort of house, and there was just nowhere for it to go. Eventually, they gave it to the Tate." In 1940, Howard, his sister and his mother moved to the United States to get away from the war. They stayed with a lawyer friend of his grandfather in Long Island, which Hodgkin remembers as being like, "something out of the Great Gatsby". Having declared his intention to be an artist at the age of five, he was repeatedly taken to the Museum of Modern Art and was doubly precocious in that he could not only draw, but could also discuss art. Hodgkin says the family response to his ambition was that it was all right to be an artist as long as it was as an amateur. This stance led to a battle throughout his childhood as to what sort of education he should have. With money left by Hewart, he was sent to a series of expensive schools, including Eton, where he was taught by Wilfred Blunt, brother of the art historian and spy, Anthony. To this day, he has mixed feelings about the place, and still gets angry when the school is characterised as a snobbish enclave. "These people don't know what they are talking about. I think the school was a university for children. You were given freedom and encouragement, and you were made responsible." However, as all his judgments were filtered through the calculation "will this help or hinder me to be an artist?", he reasoned that it wasn't for him. He says that it was his mother who continued to push the square peg back into the round hole in terms of persevering with an orthodox, privileged education. "I didn't get on with my mother," he acknowledges. "She even wanted me to join the diplomatic corps. I told her it was ridiculous - I would have started a war." It was partly with the help of his cousin, Margery Fry, that when Hodgkin left school in 1949 he won a place at Camberwell Art School, and then moved on to the Bath Academy of Art, Corsham. At Camberwell, he was taught by leading Euston Road School painters Victor Pasmore and William Coldstream, and remembers considerable peer pressure to conform to a house style. "I was already an outsider even then," he recalls, and by the time he went to Corsham, he already had his own artistic language. Hodgkin appears happy to be thought of as a one-off, but there have been attempts to place him within a tradition. One of the more interesting sees him as following on from Ivon Hitchens, whose vividly colourful depictions of the English landscape from the 40s to the 70s hover between abstraction and figuration. Richard Shone of the Burlington magazine says that while Hodgkin has developed his own very personal synthesis of various artistic traditions, "all young artists take on an aspect of their time. You can't come out of nowhere, and certainly in his early work with the bright, frontal colour and the relaxed young people sit ting in rooms, there are aspects of pop art with a small p." Hodgkin says that he was very proud to once appear in the index of a book on pop art under the entry: "Howard Hodgkin is not a pop artist." The critic David Sylvester sees a longer heritage. "There is an atmospheric lyricism in his work that is very English and can be traced back to Turner. I think Howard is steeped in Turner." Hodgkin has spoken about the importance of Matisse and the Intimist work of the French painter Edouard Vuillard, but says that as a young artist, the key exhibitions he saw in London were of contemporary American art put on by the United States Information Service. He was struck by the work of Barnett Newman and Stuart Davis, but the most influential was Jackson Pollock. "Seeing the Pollocks was amazing for an ambitious young artist. They were there as, say, mountains outside your holiday window are there. They became part of my world, and that was a revelation. Seeing work like that can give you a new idea as to what is physically possible. It's not so much the content of the picture, but just the thought that, 'yes, that can be done'. It is often forgotten that paintings are what they are made of. Painting is a very physical thing." After finishing as a student in 1954, Hodgkin spent a brief period teaching at Charterhouse School, and then returned to Bath as a teacher, where he stayed until 1966. After that, he taught for six years at the Chelsea School of Art. He says he enjoyed teaching, but of most benefit to him was mixing with other artist-teachers. The artist, Robyn Denny, who was both a colleague and subject of two well-known Hodgkin portraits, remembers him as very ambitious as an artist. "He was extremely clever, but not in a pejorative sense. He was complicated, learned, insightful and sort of duplicit and opaque. It is an odd combination that makes him an extremely interesting man. And combined with his ambition as an artist, it made him a powerful force." Chris Garrett, the cartoonist, and half of the Guardian's Biff cartoon team, was one of Hodgkin's students. He says Hodgkin was more like a dance teacher in that he always demanded the best. "He scared the living daylights out of us. He'd set an exercise and then walk round the studio. You'd hear him saying, 'that's terrible, rub it out', and then a whimper from the student. 'Stop trying to look like an artist, just be one'." Garrett adds: "Maybe in the third year he'd offer you a Woodbine, which was a sign something was good. He was difficult to fathom. He always wore a dark suit and tie and had this very austere, punctilious way of teaching. But his paintings were packed with these great bloody colours blasted on the canvas, which had been the product of an obviously very intense kind of operation. I once saw him in his suit, and there was a tiny spot of brilliant viridian green on his black Oxford shoes. It was the only hint of what he had been doing." By this time Hodgkin was married with a young family. He and Julia Lane met as art students at Corsham and they married in 1955. She went on to teach art in a school, and then to run the florist shop at Heal's furniture shop in London. Hodgkin commuted to Bath from their flat in Shepherds Bush, where he remembers holes in the carpets were covered with dog skins - "a little Scottie here, something else there. It was revolting, and we got rid of them in the end." Their first son, Louis, was born in 1958, and then Sam in 1960. "Louis lives in the country and cultivates his garden," says Hodgkin. "I don't know how he gets by but he is completely happy. People go and see him because he's so happy. He's like a guru or something. Sam, on the other hand, is not so happy." He laughs. "He works in television." Hodgkin was not very productive when his children were young. "Julia once asked me how can I call myself a painter when I don't actually paint. It wasn't so neat that I started to paint immediately, but I was upset by it and it struck home." This tentativeness was reflected in his business relationship with dealers. When the Arthur Tooth gallery in Dover Street put on his first show in 1962, they offered him a contract that would double every year. "But I insisted it stayed the same," says Hodgkin. "I always worried where the next picture was coming from and it would have been too much pressure. Little did I know what was to come in terms of pressure." As well as teaching and being an artist during the 60s, Hodgkin became a serious collector of 16th and 17th-century Indian painting. His collection became one of the best in the world, and has been widely exhibited. "For a while it was a wonderful other activity," he says. "It was nice to meet other collectors, and I was good at it. But the collection becomes a monster with a life of its own. You have to have things to go with other things. It probably has affected me as an artist, but not in the way that people think. The Indian paintings haven't influenced my paintings, but collecting has made me very aware of quality, and increasingly demanding of my own work." Such was Hodgkin's commitment to his collection that he once sold 60 of his own paintings - "not for huge amounts of money" - to fund the purchase of one Indian work. His friend, James Fenton, the poet and writer on art and gardening, says that is the essence of a collector. "It's more than being an accumulator. The important expression is 'the best is the enemy of the good'. If you have good things in the collection, and then you get something that is the best, the other paintings somehow have their noses put out of joint. I told him once that something was coming up for sale and it looked to be a bargain. He said this whole business of bargains is a diversion. 'Don't collect bargains, collect masterpieces.' That is Howard." Julian Barnes says Hodgkin's astonishing eye for quality means he can visually gut a municipal art gallery in eight to 10 minutes. "And he would have seen, and more importantly remembered in incredible detail, the things that qualify as masterpieces. It's an extraordinary experience going round a church or a gallery with Howard. Typically, we'd be in a church with, say, a one-star Bellini altar piece in the second chapel on the left. We'd get there and there would be a deep, dark chuckle from Howard - 'I think not'. And then within 20 seconds he'll locate a small piece of baroque carving at the bottom of a tomb which was in fact the only thing worth seeing in the church." While there has not been a school of Hodgkin, his influence on the British art scene has been considerable. His reputation abroad has bolstered the image of British art, and his collection is significant, but equally important was his work as an artist trustee of both the Tate and the National in the 60s and 70s. In her history of the Tate gallery, Frances Spalding identified his importance in relation to purchases made by the national collections. "With his immense knowledge of art and the art market, Hodgkin had a unique gift for either promoting or killing a potential purchase," she wrote. "He might merely lower his eyes and begin to doodle, but it had devastating effect." Hodgkin has said he was amazed at how much clout the artist trustees had, and was instrumental in buying important work by Picasso, Matisse and Degas. He also paved the way for more radical purchases, recalling that, "work by the likes of Beuys had only just come in and no one quite knew what to do with them. They just didn't quite know how to deal with a work that was made of felt and fat." Although always seen as ambitious, and a skilled operator in the art world, it took a long time for Hodgkin to break through as a first-rank artist. He was 45 before he had a major show in New York, and 52 when he finally won world-wide acclaim after representing Britain at the Venice Biennale. It is generally accepted that at some time in the mid-70s his work seemed to move up a gear. There is a neat psycho-sexual explanation, which was first posited by his friend, Bruce Chatwin. Howard had, "a newfound engagement with the erotic", Chatwin coyly wrote. It had led to a "new persona". What Chatwin meant was that Hodgkin's marriage had come to an end - although he and Julia have never divorced - and he was living as a gay man. Chatwin excitedly, and hyperbolically, wrote to a friend in 1977 that Howard's had become, "the most publicised private life of the century". In reality, it was a rather more smooth transition, and he has now been in a relationship with the music writer, Antony Peattie, since 1983. Hodgkin sees less of a clean break in his life than is popularly portrayed, pointing out a continuity in his art. "The early pictures are to some degree a rehearsal for what was to come. The continuum might be a bit bumpy, but that's not for the obvious reasons everyone always talks about," he says. "I had terrible trouble finding a way of painting. To some extent, I found my voice early and knew what I wanted to do. But learning how to do it took longer. Nothing is so simple as 'he's gay, look how the pictures have changed'. It just doesn't work like that. The processes are still going on." David Sylvester agrees that Hodgkin, "has a more consistent line of development than you see in most artists. He found himself fairly early and remained himself." The critical consensus is that his work has improved over time, but some observers still prefer the much more schematic and hard-edged early work when his portraits, although his subjects never sat for him, still contained more conventional representations of identifiable people. fields.headline: Hot stuff
fields.standfirst: The knack is to make lip-smacking puddings, not the leaden horrors of childhood memories
fields.trailText: The knack is to make lip-smacking puddings, not the leaden horrors of childhood memories
fields.body:
Thank God it's March, and the agonies of the shortest month are now but an unpleasant memory. The cheery presence of forced rhubarb, the first pink of the year, is in abundance and brightens winter's weary eyes. But don't let's get carried away just yet. Spring may be around the corner but, given our climate, there's always the chance of a chilly surprise or two - and the excuse still to indulge in warming puddings (as if we needed one).

The classic puds of the British Isles are as rich in tradition as they are in flavour. The knack is to make puddings that are lip-smacking, rather than the leaden horrors of childhood memories. Spiking pears with vinegar and ennobling rhubarb with almonds are just two notable ways of enhancing such puddings. If there are other households out there like my mother's, with store cupboards crammed with all manner of jams, jellies and marmalade, there are few better ways of using some of those conserves up than in a steamed sponge or suet pudding - the marmalade pudding here is a real stonker, even if I do say so myself.

All recipes serve six.

STICKY PLUM PUDDING
The dried fruit of San Francisco's farmers' market is the best I've ever seen: it offers a quite stunning array of sultanas, raisins, apricots, figs et al. Agen prunes are the only dried fruit I've come across of a similar quality. A moment of excess led to this dish: a pot of prunes needed using up and so were added to a cake batter. It may have been a wanton use of such a noble fruit, but it made for a marvellous dessert.

120g sultanas
230g Agen prunes
125g unsalted butter
360g soft, dark brown sugar
2 eggs
450g plain flour
1 tsp baking powder
570ml water
2 tsp bicarbonate of soda
1 tsp vanilla extract

For the topping

100ml whipping cream
1 tbsp soft, dark brown sugar
1 tbsp treacle
1-2 drops vanilla extract

Preheat the oven to 190C/375F/gas mark 5. Place the sultanas in a pan, and pour in enough water just to cover. Place on a high heat and cook until the water evaporates. Stone the prunes.

Line a 25-27cm diameter, 4-5cm deep cake tin. Beat the butter and sugar until creamed. Crack the eggs into a jug, mix with a fork, then, beating continuously, pour into the butter mix. Sift the flour and baking powder on to the mixture, and fold in. Boil the 570ml water, tip over the prunes and stir in the bicarb. The reaction will be instantaneous, so stir and pour on to the cake mix with haste. Add the sultanas and vanilla extract, and stir until you have a smooth batter of dropping consistency. Tip the lot into the cake tin, bake for 15 minutes, then lower the heat to 150C/300F/gas mark 2. Bake for a further 50 minutes to one hour. When the cake is done, set aside to cool in its tin.

In the meantime, make the topping. Boil together the cream, sugar, treacle and vanilla until dissolved, then pour over the cake, which is at its best served slightly warm with a spoonful of lightly whipped cream.

BURNT PEAR AND GINGER CREAM
It rarely makes sense to alter something so perfect as a crème brlée. That said, I happened on this recipe - which, to my shame, is adulterated crème brlée for sure - quite by fluke. I was making a batch when, among all the paraphernalia in the kitchen, I came across a Le Creuset dish filled with quartered pears strewn with bits of crystallised ginger. It was awaiting a crumble before being baked. My custard split, so I poured it over the pears and put the offending dish in the fridge. Out of sight, out of mind: or so I thought. When I came across it again a long lunch service later, the custard had set, so I gave it a dusting of sugar and a fiery blast from a blowtorch, then returned it to the fridge. Once cooled, it was tasted and pronounced very fine indeed. So there you go: not everything we do is by design.

1 lemon, juiced and zested
6 good pears
1.5 litres water
200g sugar
1 vanilla pod, unsplit
1 nugget crystallised ginger

For the custard

5 very fresh free-range egg yolks
2 heaped dssp caster sugar
500ml double cream
1 thumb-sized piece fresh ginger, scraped clean and sliced thin

Reserve a quarter of the grated zest, and put the rest, along with the strained juice, into a steel pot. Peel the pears, pop them in the pot also, rolling them in the lemon juice to prevent discolouring. Tip in the sugar, water and vanilla pod, and set the pot over a high heat and bring to the boil. Lower the heat to a gentle simmer - weigh down the pears with a plate if they start to bob above the surface. Simmer for 20-40 minutes, depending on the size and ripeness of the pears; the pears should be whole but fully cooked. Quarter the pears lengthways, and remove all trace of core and stem. Lay over the base of a baking dish. Cut the crystallised ginger into small pieces and dot among the pears.

Now make the custard. Put the egg yolks and caster sugar in a bowl, and beat until pale and voluminous. Pour the cream into a pot. Remove the vanilla pod from the syrup, split it open and scrape out the seeds, and add these and the fresh ginger to the cream. Set the pot to warm over a high heat. Once it has come to the boil, pour on to the beaten eggs then tip the whole lot back into the pot. Over medium heat, stir slowly and continuously until thickened, then pour through a fine sieve and stir again for a minute to cool. Pour over the pears and chill.

To finish, shower the dish with a light crust of demerara sugar on top and then glaze until the sugar is melted and coloured a deep caramel; ideally, do this with a blowtorch, but under the grill will do. Cool and refrigerate. It is best to make the caramel just before dinner, as the crust will go damp and soggy quite quickly.

RHUBARB AND ALMOND CRUMBLE TART
I apologise in advance for the first impressions created by this lengthy-looking recipe. It looks an awful lot, sure, but it is merely a list of parts set out in the correct order of preparation. The sum of those parts is a truly memorable tart. Its origins are quite good, too. I was working in Frith Street with Alastair Little, who had only recently convinced me of the joys of rhubarb. The eponymous one was dabbling with crumble tarts at the time, and there always seemed to be a pot of rhubarb and container of crumble in the fridge. One day, I just put it all together and came up with this.

For the crumble

100g unsalted butter
100g plain flour
100g soft dark brown sugar
100g whole almonds, chopped fine

For the pastry

225g plain white flour
115g unsalted butter
1 tbsp icing sugar
1 large fresh egg
1 tbsp very cold water

For the frangipane

100g unsalted butter
100g caster sugar
1 whole egg and 1 egg yolk (both at room temperature)
100g peeled almonds, chopped fine

For the rhubarb

250g rhubarb
150g caster sugar
Thumbnail-sized piece orange zest

Preheat the oven to 190C/375F/gas mark 5. First, make the crumble. In a bowl, work the butter and flour together until they are the texture of fine crumbs. Mix in the sugar and almonds. Cover and refrigerate.

Next, make the pastry. Sift the flour and icing sugar into a bowl, then rub in the butter until the whole is the texture of fine crumbs. Add the egg and water, and knead into a smooth dough. Form into a disc, wrap well and refrigerate.

Now, make the frangipane. Cream the butter and sugar together until pale, then mix in first the whole egg and then the yolk. Stir in the chopped almonds, and refrigerate.

Finally, prepare the rhubarb. Trim and cut the rhubarb into roughly 3-4cm lengths. Place in a wide, shallow dish and scatter the sugar over the top. Drop on the sliver of zest, and cover. Place in the preheated oven and cook for 20 minutes or so, until tender but not mushy. Leave to cool undisturbed, then tip into a colander and drain.

Now, you're ready to make the tart. Line a deep tart case (at least 1.8-2.2cm) with the pastry and leave to sit, covered, in the fridge for half an hour or so. Spread a generous layer of frangipane over the tart, then cover with rhubarb. Cover with crumble, gently pressing it down, then slightly roughen the surface by running a fork lightly over the surface.

Place the tart on a tray, and bake for 15 minutes, then lower the heat to 150C/300F/gas mark 2 and cook for a further 30 minutes or so, taking care that the crumble colours well but does not darken.

STEAMED MARMALADE PUDDING
The season for Seville oranges may have been and gone, but at least all that marmalade made in January is at hand - I hope. I cannot help but feel that a pudding made with the fruits of one's own labours may encourage a domino effect with the other fruit crops as they come into season. Anyhow, this recipe makes a very, very good steamed pudding. Having eaten them regularly since childhood - having athletic children was not high on my parents' agenda - I have developed a rule for such dishes: namely, if it's going to add to the waist, it had better be damned good. This one is - and, as with all recipes that appear straightforward, depends entirely on good ingredients, notably a marmalade that is neither too runny nor too stiff. Only a marmalade made from Seville oranges should be used, as other confections just do not cut the mustard. It is obligatory to serve this with home-made custard, perhaps one spiked with a little ginger.

3 large tbsp Seville orange marmalade
125g plain white flour
125g suet
125g fresh white breadcrumbs
tsp ground cinnamon
1 tsp bicarbonate of soda
1 tsp baking powder
1 egg
2 tbsp Golden Syrup
3 tbsp Seville orange marmalade
1 tsp grated orange zest
1 tsp grated lemon zest
120ml milk

Lightly butter a pudding basin, cut a small square of greaseproof paper and lay it upon the bottom of the basin. Put three large tablespoons of marmalade on it. In a big bowl, mix together the flour, suet, breadcrumbs, cinnamon, bicarbonate of soda, baking powder. Crack in the egg, add the syrup, marmalade and zests, and stir thoroughly. Pour in the milk; add a wee bit more if the pudding consistency is too thick.

Pour this mix into the prepared basin, and seal thoroughly with greaseproof paper and baking foil. Pour 4-5cm of water into a wide, deep pot and bring up to the boil. Carefully place the basin in the water, and lower the heat to a murmuring simmer. Cover the pot completely, and leave the pudding to cook gently for three hours or so. Check the water from time to time, and top up with hot water if required

 Jeremy Lee is chef at Blue Print Cafe, Butlers Wharf, London SE1.

webTitle: Julie Burchill on adults and cuddly toys

fields.headline: The  bear facts
fields.standfirst: When I think about adults messing around with cuddly toys, I feel quite angry. They should probably have their voting rights removed
fields.trailText: When I think about adults messing around with cuddly toys, I feel quite angry. They should probably have their voting rights removed.
fields.body:
A recent survey claimed to prove conclusively that children and young babies do not, in fact, like teddy bears at all but would, given the choice, choose a cuddly dog, cat or, best of all, a stuffed monkey, as their faces so closely resemble those of humans. But if babies can exhibit such good taste, it makes it even sadder that so many adults cannot seem to get enough of all things Bruin.

Perhaps you've seen that dozy bint on the TV who announces pertly,"I'm in love! - with a pilot, a doctor and a musician" - or something like that. Then, just as you're about to denounce her as a raving slag, up pop three teddy bears clothed in the appropriate garb. This, believe it or not, is an advert for a part-work magazine aimed at adults, which eventually results in a collection of some 20 tiny teddies all dressed up as something different; interestingly, Drug Dealer Teddy and Pimp Teddy do not seem to be available, which is a shame with Mother's Day coming up.

Talking of which, perhaps you've seen the adverts for - wait for it - "R*Fur", a frankly manky-looking bear, 20cm tall, that is supposed to be a viable alternative to a beautiful bunch of blooms. DON'T SEND FLOWERS - SEND R*FUR! go the ads, assuring us that "R*Fur will deliver your personal message with huge style and massive impact - he carries your message tucked safely inside his rucksack, travelling overnight to the destination of your choice, whatever the occasion." And the Beanie Babies phenomenon - what's that all about?

I'm an equitable person these days, and not much given to intolerant outbursts, but when I think about adults wanting to have anything to do with cuddly toys, I really feel quite angry, to the extent that I think they should probably have their voting rights removed. I don't know what makes me angrier: if it's an affectation, and they think it makes them look "cute" or Bridesheadish, or if it's for real and the sad bastards really derive some measure of comfort from cuddling up to a nice bit of plush.

Apparently, in America there are people known as "furverts", who can only become sexually excited by cartoon animals or people dressed up as them. But then, sex is a funny thing, for which one generally has to bend the rules a little, and so I find the idea of someone being sexually attracted to a stuffed beastie far less alarming than someone telling it their secrets.

Of course, one of the reasons that we all aspire to be in love relationships is that they have the ability to make us feel gloriously grown-up (non-stop frantic kinky sex) and beatifically babyish (silly voices and pet names) at the same time. I'll come clean here and confess that, if you took away the non-stop frantic kinky sex, silly voices and pet names from my current six-year dalliance, there would be precious little left - but surely that's what it's for. To bring in a commercial middle man, however, who'll sell you bears to be silly with seems to me as strange and dysfunctional as seeking out a man who'll sell you a prostitute to have sex with. Are you really so weird that you can't get it the way the rest of us do?

I'm not putting myself down here, but at my age and my weight, if I can get it without paying for it, anyone can. It is, of course, mostly women who turn to the comforts of plush, and it really does speak volumes about the failure of the alleged Sexual Revolution and the infinite resistibility of male genitalia to a vast swathe of the female population that so many of them would rather go to bed with Ted than with Tom, Dick or Harry. I've always thought it a real hoot, and quite telling, that the women who have sex with men most - prostitutes - invariably like it least, whereas the men who have the most sex with women like it the most. Surely this tells us something about the relative repulsiveness of the sexes.

And, sure enough, it's invariably tarts and virgins who have the biggest cuddly toy collections, in order to keep the dreaded meat and two veg at bay. Think of Mike Leigh's Candice Marie in Nuts And May, forever clinging to Prudence to ward off the attentions of the vile Keith, or David Copperfield justifying to nosy hacks the reason why he and Claudia Schiffer always booked separate rooms when they travelled, because, apparently, he couldn't be bothered to clear her vast collection of furry friends off of the bed. Yeah, right. Funny how dishy Matthew Vaughn doesn't seem to have the same problem.

Even sadder than the lengths a girl will go to to keep Copperfield out of her bedroom is the practice of certain types of counsellors and analysts of encouraging their patients to buy themselves teddy bears, which they are then told to hug, cry to and confide in. Apparently, this is common in many 12-step programmes to treat alleged drink, drug and sex addiction, and it's soppy enough then. But where it really becomes grotesque, I feel, is when victims of child abuse are told to do the same thing - something that my academic friend, a specialist in this area, assures me is the case. As usual, our old friend the Inner Child is to blame here - has there been any more irritating or damaging pseudo-discovery, apart from feng shui, over the past 20 years? (If I ever find my Inner Child, I'm going to make sure I find my Inner Adoption Agency PDQ.)

Surely the last thing anyone who's been abused as a child needs is to remain in a state of childlikeness, in which they will surely remember and relive that terrible vulnerability all over again. What they really need is to grow up, toughen up, see the bastard behind bars and put it all behind them. But, of course, if this were to happen, counsellors and analysts would have to start shopping at Primark - and we can't have that.

Playfulness in an adult is a lovely thing, and should be encouraged in every way as a valuable antidote to today's bean-counting, worry-wart, work-obsessed climate. But, as with sex, playfulness is something that flourishes only when it's free. The minute commerce raises its ugly head in this most delicate of impulses - be it selling adults teddy bears, Harry Potter books or paint-balling weekends for lonely bachelors - you're screwed, sad and sorry. That means you, fingering that Flat Eric doll thoughtfully! Put it down. Now.

Surely the last thing anyone who's been abused as a child needs is to remain in a state of childlikeness, in which they will surely remember and relive that terrible vulnerability all over again. What they really need is to grow up, toughen up, see the bastard behind bars and put it all behind them. But, of course, if this were to happen, counsellors and analysts would have to start shopping at Primark - and we can't have that. Playfulness in an adult is a lovely thing, and should be encouraged in every way as a valuable antidote to today's bean-counting, worry-wart, work-obsessed climate. But, as with sex, playfulness is something that flourishes only when it's free. The minute commerce raises its ugly head in this most delicate of impulses - be it selling adults teddy bears, Harry Potter books or paint-balling weekends for lonely bachelors - you're screwed, sad and sorry. That means you, fingering that Flat Eric doll thoughtfully! Put it down. Now.

fields.headline: Pot luck
fields.standfirst: You won't need green fingers to transform that sad balcony or windowledge into a mini Eden. You will need ideas. By Susan Berry and Val Bradley
fields.trailText: You won't need green fingers to transform that sad balcony or windowledge into a mini Eden. You will need ideas. By Susan Berry and Val Bradley
fields.body:
Bamboos and grasses
Slender, arching grasses or delicate, rustling bamboos will create an eye-catching architectural feature. Try a black-leaved grass, such as Ophiopogon planiscapus 'Nigrescens', or Festuca glauca (left) for striking effect. Slender bamboos planted in a trough will create a useful windbreak or screen on a balcony. In addition to elegant foliage, some of them, such as various species of Phyllostachys , have interestingly coloured canes. Good examples for containers are P. nigra, known as the black bamboo (green canes that turn black in their second or third year), and P. bambusoides 'Allgold' (rich golden yellow canes, occasionally striped green).

Structure shrubs
Neat rows of plants of the same kind bring a formal quality to an outdoor space: little pots of clipped box, say, or auricula primroses. Big containers in pairs look good around a doorway. You can ring the changes with a different flowering display for every season: parrot tulips for spring, cannas or regal lilies for summer, and dahlias for the late summer. Flowering shrubs for containers include the silvery-leaved evergreen Brachyglottis 'Sunshine', with its yellow daisy flowers in summer, or hydrangeas, which last well into autumn. Good evergreens include Hebe pinguifolia 'Pagei' or miniature junipers (such as J. communis 'Compressa').

Hostas
Hostas, with their striking, architectural foliage and delicate, trumpet-like flowers (left) are a good bet for a long-lasting display. Plant up a 25cm diameter terracotta pot with a showy, big-leaved version such as Hosta sieboldiana 'Elegans'. It will look good from late spring to early autumn. Try surrounding it with early bulbs such as crocuses or dwarf narcissus ('T te-à-T te') to create a touch of colour before the hosta leaves unfurl. Hostas are suitable for a shady area.

When it comes to creating a beautiful garden in a small space, a little knowledge goes a surprisingly long way. As well as a supply of good-looking containers and multipurpose compost to fill them, an awareness of which plants do what and at which particular times of the year, really helps. But this should not put you off. For example, small-leaved, evergreen shrubs such as box, and evergreen climbers such as ivy, are a good start - persuade them to grow into interesting shapes by clipping the former a couple of times during the summer or training the latter up wires and trimming out straggling shoots. Ivy also thrives in shade, as do ferns and heucheras, which have broad, coloured leaves. There are a few tips for making the most of your space. Think vertically as well as horizontally, and use shelves, racks and even the table you eat from for your display. Grow climbers over frames or plant trailing annuals positioned on a high wall, so that they cascade and make the most of vertical space. Dead-head flowering perennials regularly to encourage a longer display from your limited stock. As for what to put into those containers to maximise the display year-round, try these for size:

Summer annuals
Keep one pot for summer annuals and create an instant flowering display with trays of young plants from garden centres or flower markets. Lobelia, zinnias, nemesias, salvias, purple heliotrope, trailing petunias, verbena and orange French marigolds are favourites. Or you can be more adventurous and try planting seed - a packet of mixed annuals, say - making sure you read the instructions first. Nasturtiums are easy to grow from seed, and can be rampant, too. If you are the neat and tidy sort, best to go for a dwarf variety.

HERBS
Purpose-made containers with planting pockets designed for strawberries look good filled with herbs. Put bushy herbs in the side pockets - thymes (Thymus), marjoram (Origanum) and purple-leaved sage ( Salvia officinalis 'Purpurascens'), which will give year-round interest, and plant the top with annuals such as parsley and basil (easily grown from seed). Bon appetit .

Bulbs
Layer bulbs for a long-lasting display. In autumn, plant crocuses or dwarf Iris reticulata (above) with narcissus around the edge of a large pot (30cm diameter), with a central deeper planting of foxtail lily ( Eremurus ). Another idea is a scented display using 'Paper White' narcissus for spring followed by Lilium regale in summer. Planting depths are given on the bulb packets, but try not to plant the bulbs directly over each other. Don't remove foliage until it has died away: it feeds next year's bulbs. Instead roll up the leaves and tie them neatly.

 Gardening On Balconies And Terraces, by Susan Berry and Val Bradley, is published by Collins & Brown at £18.99. To order a copy for £14.99 (plus p&p), call Guardian CultureShop on 0800 316 6102.

fields.headline: Superplonk
fields.trailText: The recession session
fields.body:
During the last serious recession of the last century, there was a period when it became PC to have wines on the dinner table that not only proudly admitted their provenance from a yet-to-be-chic wine region, but also advertised that they were from a supermarket. One acquired kudos with such a display; conspicuous consumption was frowned upon, and such a wine advertised one's parsimony perfectly.

Are those days still with us, I wonder. Let us be honest here: who among us would invite new neighbours to dinner (assuming, for the purposes of this argument, that you are one of the rare British households that would commit such an outrageous act of overt friendliness) and serve them Sainsbury's own-label Australian Chardonnay?

What would these fresh faces to the voisinage think? That you knew zilch about wine? That you didn't consider the guests prestigious enough and that therefore any old wine would do? That you were a skinflint? What tortuous processes would you embark upon to find reasons not to serve such a splendid 16.5-point (out of 20) wine?

Never mind that it is understated, clean, with excellent structure and a crisp-to-finish stylishness that leaves behind a deliciously sly suggestion of oiliness. If Sainsbury's was really smart, it would have trebled the price and called it Shagger Kookaburra Private Reserve. Instead, it has lowered the price from £3.99 to three bottles for a tenner until March 31. It doesn't stop there, either. Sainsbury's, desperate to turn wine drinkers away, offers various other insulting bargains. Would you dare give the new neighbours a glass of Vins de Pays d'Oc Chardonnay from a three-litre box? Think of the gossip among the mothers in the 3.40pm nursery school queue waiting to pick up young Thucydides, Charlemagne, Atalanta, et al. Yet this 15.5-point chardonnay comes across like a burgundy: gently fat, vegetal, dry, with both quaffability and with food matchability. It costs a laughable £11.99, which, at three litres, works out at a socially unacceptable 49p a glass (the equivalent of a shocking £2.99 a bottle).

Another way to lower the tone of the neighbourhood is to serve a well-known branded wine: say, Nottage Hill Cabernet Sauvignon/Shiraz 1999 (16.5 points, down to £4.99), from Australia, which has thrilling tannins and a subtle spiciness improved by decanting, and which has the further advantage that the label is not exposed to public view. With Baron de Lestac Bordeaux 1998 (14.5 points), however, that comfortingly fancy title and birthplace are reassuring. The wine offers soft, rich, plummy fruit and university-educated tannins, which make it a claret of some decency and decorum. Embarrassingly, it costs £3.99.

What do you serve if Jilly Goolden and spouse are your new neighbours? I suggest Danie de Wet Call Of The African Eagle Chardonnay Reserve 2000, from the Cape. This is on offer for £5.99 at 140 Sainsbury's branches (call 0800 636262 for details). It's very delicate, subtle, dry yet vaguely melony and nutty (with a hint of peach and cream), fresh yet textured and gently rich, and it finishes with aplomb - more of a small sigh than a wallop. A very assured wine of great class, it rates 17 points.

At Thresher, things are no better, though at least these are not special offers but everyday prices. Mitchelton Blackwood Park Riesling 1999 (16 points, £6.99), from Australia, is delightfully sophisticated tippling, very elegant and tangy. Concha y Toro Casillero del Diablo Chardonnay 1998 (16.5 points, £4.99, also at Victoria Wine and Unwins), from Chile, has superb layered riches in which smoky melon combines with fluent apples and lemons to hugely stylish effect. Isla Negra Chardonnay 1999 (16 points, £5.49), also from Chile, has superb texture, ripe, plump fruit and offers a sustained attack on the tastebuds to marvellous effect. It is also at Victoria Wine, Somerfield and Oddbins.

Not so Graffigna Shiraz Cabernet 1999 (16.5 points, £3.99), from Argentina, with its chocolatey, blackcurranty fruit and chewy tannins. This is to be found at the Co-Op. Tell the neighbours it cost £25 at Harrods. They won't suspect a thing.

 For the latest wine news, and to email Malcolm Gluck, visit superplonk.com.

fields.headline: Trouble sleeping
fields.standfirst: 'Am growing two panniers of fat with which I knock people off pavements'
fields.trailText: 'Am growing two panniers of fat with which I knock people off pavements'
fields.body:
I am having trouble sleeping. Last night I dreamed I went to see a psychotherapist from Auckland - a nice young man, incidentally. Unfortunately, it remains incidental these days. "I'm having trouble sleeping," I told him, even though I was actually asleep at the time. What a perfectionist. "I keep waking up really early in the morning, about 3am. I know that's a classical symptom of depression, but I don't think I'm depressed. However, I am worried that my brain's not working properly. Sometimes, I don't recognise words. For instance, I thought a newscaster said, 'And now over to our reporter on a hill farm in the middle of Paris'. It was Powys really, of course."

The psychotherapist conducted a word-recognition test. He looked away and whispered "Sausages."

"Sausages!" I echoed. Even a dog can do that one.

"The inscription," murmured the psychotherapist.

"The inscription!" I cried in triumph. He beamed.

"Your word recognition is actually very good."

"So it should be," I replied. "I'm a writer."

At this point I woke and, discovering it was dawn, switched on the bedside radio for the news. My brain, which had identified words so accurately when I was asleep, immediately started to play tricks. With one conceptual glissando I had transformed a dissident republican group to a diffident republican group - although, let's face it, that's a step in the right direction.

Switch off radio and think about my dream. How I miss my nice young psychotherapist. Gone in a flash, and I never even had time to tell him about my panic attacks. The birds are singing. Gradually, my intestines join in the warbling. Strange how haddock and chips can be thus transformed into song.

Suddenly remember I am supposed to be going to London today to see my agent, a new bod called Greg. We must resurrect my career. Although I told the psychotherapist I was a writer, that is hardly true any more. It's more than 10 years since Charley The Chickpea, and though I was hoping to make a series of it with Martha The Mung Bean, etc, somehow it all dissolved into piss and wind, as legumes do.

As for my historical fiction, well, that's history, too. It seems I shall not lie on a cloudy sofa in old age fondling my chihuahua and dictating details of regency amours to my trusty amanuensis. I shall instead be coaching dim rich kids for their GCSEs well into my dotage.

Heave myself out of bed. I am growing two panniers of fat, one on each hip, with which I knock people off pavements. Demolishing a small shed would be easy. Perhaps there is commercial potential here. But resurrecting the writing career is preferable. And I have a brilliant idea. It's a sitcom based on a Roman family living in Bath in AD99. Greg will love it. He'll sell it to Hollywood by the end of the week. I see Robin Williams as Gluteus Maximus getting into wacky scrapes at the baths.

Take an early train, as one does, allowing an extra two hours for a one-hour journey. At Didcot there is an unexpected halt. "Ladies and Gentlemen," announces the guard (or should I call her the "customer service operative"?), "we think the signal up ahead must be faulty, as a man with a red flag has appeared." We have now rejoined the 19th century, it appears. Good news for novelists. This means bodice-rippers are now contemporary fiction.

Greg doesn't like my idea about the Romans. "Too middle class," he says.

"Even with Richard Wilson saying Haud credo?"

Greg looks blank. Lunch not a success, as my quinoa goes cold on me.

Glad to get back to provincial England, though distressed to find a pair of palpitating tits on the front path. Blue tits, my favourite - dear little things. Alive, but only just. Run in and ask advice of aged aunt, an ornithologist since the days of the dodo. "Och, it'll just be the males fighting overrr terrrrrritory ," she advises. Go back out and the tiny feathered Mitchell brothers take off in unison. Evidently only winded.

Astonished by this evidence of testosterone in the tiny. Make plans for a screenplay in with lashings of sex, violence and swearing, set on the birdtable. But I don't think Robin Williams will be playing the Robin. Wonder if Ross Kemp's available.
