fields.headline: The questionnaire: Chris Bart-Williams
fields.standfirst: Chris Bart-Williams was born in Sierra Leone in 1974. Raised by his mother, he came to live in London aged four. He started playing football at 11 and turned professional at 16, joining Leyton Orient. At 17, he moved to Sheffield Wednesday, and at 21 joined Nottingham Forest. He is now club captain, and lives in Leicestershire.
fields.trailText: Chris Bart-Williams was born in Sierra Leone in 1974. Raised by his mother, he came to live in London aged four.
fields.body:
What is your idea of perfect happiness?
Going on holiday - permanently!

What is your greatest fear?
Being tortured for information that I don't have.

Which living person do you most admire?
My mum - I don't know anyone as strong and loving.

What is the trait you most deplore in yourself?
My lack of compassion.

What is the trait you most deplore in others?
Indecision.

What vehicles do you own?
A Morris Minor.

What is your greatest extravagance?
Good timepieces.

What objects do you always carry with you?
A good timepiece.

What makes you depressed?
Apart from playing badly, women crying.

What do you most dislike about your appearance?
Nothing springs to mind at the moment - or that I'm admitting to.

What is your most unappealing habit?
My arrogance.

What is your favourite fantasy?
To be the first black president of the US.

What do you consider the most overrated virtue?
Honesty.

Have you ever said 'I love you' and not meant it?
Not in the past eight years.

Which words or phrases do you most overuse?
'The pot calling the kettle black.'

What is your greatest regret?
Not being around in the 60s.

How often do you have sex?
Too often in my dreams.

What single thing would improve the quality of your life?
My mum to stop nagging me.

What would your motto be?
Always wear a good pair of shoes.

How would you like to die?
Saving someone else's life.

Do you believe in life after death?
Yes, because I believe in Casper the friendly ghost.

How would you like to be remembered?
As being controversial.

What is the most important lesson life has taught you?
It's really all about love, isn't it?

Always wear a good pair of shoes. How would you like to die? Saving someone else's life. Do you believe in life after death? Yes, because I believe in Casper the friendly ghost. fields.headline: The wild west
fields.standfirst: At just 30, Martin McDonagh is one of the most exciting playwrights to emerge from Britain in decades. Yet his plays, all set in rural Ireland, have also been branded sadistic, inflammatory and dangerous. His latest finds him on familiar ground - and still trading shots with the theatrical establishment. By Sean O'Hagan

fields.body:
Imagine, if you can, JM Synge, the spiritual godfather of modern Irish drama, collaborating, across time and history, with Quentin Tarantino, the bad boy of contemporary US cinema. Imagine Synge's ground-breaking 1907 masterpiece, The Playboy Of The Western World, remade as a blood-spattered black comedy, the green, rain-swept hills of his beloved wild west of Ireland peopled not by blighted peasants with the fabled gift of the gab, but by gun-toting, would-be gangsters spouting lines learned from John Woo action movies. Now, into this surreal mix, add an element of cutting-edge social satire in the form of a psychopathic, pet-loving Irish terrorist who imagines "an Ireland free for cats to roam about without fear". Still with me? Good. You've just imagined your way into the new Martin McDonagh play, The Lieutenant Of Inishmore.

In the Royal Shakespeare Company's rehearsal space in Clapham, south London, the 30-year-old McDonagh, looking dapper in a suit and crisp, white shirt, is overseeing preparations for the imminent staging of a work that, he gleefully tells me, "will have more gunshots and squibs going off on stage than any play you've ever seen". It will also involve, in no particular order of outrage: a trussed-up man, hanging upside down, who has had his toenails pulled out; the blinding of three characters by a woman with an air gun; the chopping up of a corpse; and the painting of a cat. It is, it might be worth adding at this point, a comedy; a sometimes absurd, often angry, and relentlessly cruel comedy, but a comedy all the same.

Not everyone has got the joke. The play, which receives its world premiere at Stratford next month, has taken five years to reach the stage. In that time, it has been passed over by various prestigious dramatic institutions, including the National Theatre. According to McDonagh, the National's Trevor Nunn thought the play so inflammatory that its production might threaten the Northern Irish peace process. Nunn's suitably theatrical overreaction might, McDonagh suspects, be symptomatic of a certain self-important luvvie culture that blights English theatre. Then again, it might be born of the not altogether absurd notion that making fun of extreme Irish Republican terrorist groups - in this instance, the Irish National Liberation Army - may, quite literally, be a deadly serious business. Whichever, McDonagh is not impressed. "There's a certain big-headedness about that kind of reaction, isn't there? Plus, if it was the case, which it isn't, surely we should be writing stuff that stirs it up."

And stir it up The Lieutenant Of Inishmore will most surely do. Its plot hinges on the mysterious killing of a cat that belongs to Inishmore's resident INLA terrorist, Padraic, and attempts to replace the beloved moggy with a ginger tom, covered in black shoe polish. Around this raggedy premise - part old-fashioned farce, part Father Ted-style surreal sitcom - McDonagh has pulled off his usual trick of creating a world that is both utterly recognisable and disturbingly unreal, comical and cruel. In many ways, then, The Lieutenant Of Inishmore is not unlike McDonagh's other plays, most notably The Beauty Queen Of Leenane and The Cripple Of Inishmaan, each of which premiered in the mid-90s to both critical acclaim and packed houses; at 27, McDonagh became the first playwright since Shakespeare to have four plays performed simultaneously in London. Since then, he has been garlanded with prizes in Britain, Ireland and America, where one critic recently dubbed him "the first great dramatist of the 21st century".

Following this sudden, and unexpected brush with success, McDonagh found himself feted both here and in New York as the latest enfant terrible of theatre, a role he initially relished, but then reacted against in some unexpected ways. "You think it's what you want," he frowns, "then, of course, it's nothing like you expect. I think as a writer you never have to flee from fame because you're not that visible in the first place, but, after the Broadway success of Beauty Queen, people were coming up to me all the time, and I wasn't really prepared for that level of attention. It's a really uncomfortable and unsettling experience to suddenly be public property."

More unsettling still was the press furore that attended his now legendary brush with the higher echelons of British thespian establishment after he won Most Promising Newcomer prize at the 1996 Evening Standard Theatre Awards. For a while back then, it looked as if McDonagh would be known primarily not as a major new writer, but as the man who told James Bond to "fuck off". Despite his brief spell of tabloid notoriety, he remains unrepentant. "It was drunken eejit stuff, really," he grins. "That wanker journalist, Max Hastings, was toasting the Queen. I mean, come on - it was bullshit. Do these people take no account of how many people in there were actually British, let alone how many even supported her? Anyway, me and my brother, John, were taking the piss, and next thing I know there's a hand on my shoulder, and Sean Connery is standing over me, saying, 'Shut up, or leave', in that James Bond voice of his. It was surreal. I mean, is this guy supposed to be a Scottish Nationalist, or what? Anyway, I initially said, 'Sorry, no offence, mate', then I thought about it, and went, 'Yeah, right, fuck off mate'." All he remembers after that is "this awful silence" as every head in the room turned in his direction.

Later, in the early hours of the morning, a tabloid journalist somehow got hold of his home phone number and rang him. Still drunk, he slagged off Connery some more. "It was good journalism, I thought, but it just grew and grew. The worst thing about it was that my mother was totally mortified - wouldn't speak to me for a week."

You get the feeling that McDonagh, and, indeed the Royal Shakespeare Company, are bracing themselves for another tabloid storm when The Lieutenant Of Inishmore opens. Like its illustrious predecessors, the play is a traditionally structured narrative that belts along on the sheer brio of the dialogue, and whose unlikely plot is set in a rural west of Ireland landscape familiar from Synge, who remains the most obvious touchstone. Except that, in McDonagh's work, this almost mythic rural Ireland of cottages and colleens clashes with what Irish theatre writer, Fintan O'Toole, describes as "a postmodern Ireland shaped by media imagery, by multinational companies, and by tourism".

The new play also possesses what are, perhaps, this young playwright's two key signatures: an exaggerated-to-the-point-of-grotesque cast of characters who skate dangerously close to caricature, and a humour that emerges from an almost casual, but never less than vicious, cruelty. "I suppose I walk that line between comedy and cruelty," admits McDonagh, sipping a Coke in a bar around the corner from the rehearsal studio, "because I think one illuminates the other. And, yeah, I tend to push things as far as I can because I think you can see things more clearly through exaggeration than through reality. It's like a John Woo or a Tarantino scene, where the characters are doing awful things and, simultaneously, talking about everyday things in a really humorous way. There is a humour in there that is straight-ahead funny and uncomfortable. It makes you laugh and think."

This is a tightrope that McDonagh, London-born and bred but of Irish parents, has walked before to dazzlingly dramatic effect. The celebrated Irish theatre director, Garry Hynes, who first staged McDonagh's work with the Druid Theatre, recalls a "particularly revealing incident when we premiered The Beauty Queen Of Leenane in Galway. A woman came up to me in the lobby, wiping the tears from her eyes, and said, 'I have a funny feeling that I shouldn't be laughing so hard'. That, for me, is a pure Martin McDonagh moment."

A few years back, I experienced something similar, albeit on a much larger scale. While staying in County Monaghan, on the Irish border, I attended a touring production of The Lonesome West, the final play of the celebrated Leenane trilogy. In a packed village hall, where the audience ranged from nine-year-olds and tots in pushchairs to pensioners with rugs across their knees, every surreal twist and turn of the play was greeted with whoops of delight or gasps of horror; every Keatonesque visual gag met with hoots of laughter. The penultimate scene, in which Coleman Connor blows a hole in his brother Valene's beloved new cooker, caused complete uproar in the audience. For a confirmed theatre-phobe such as myself, it was a salutary lesson in living, breathing theatre - of the people, for the people.

"That's what Beauty Queen was like when we performed it on Inisheer," grins McDonagh when I relay the story to him. "Leaving aside that nobody turned up on time because of the weather and we were sweating, looking at an empty theatre at 8pm, it was a complete vindication. People loved it. Same all over Ireland. The only place I've had any grief is here in London from a few English punters going on about how I was taking the piss out of Irish people." How does he respond to the inevitable accusations of cultural stereotyping? "I don't even enter into it. I mean, I don't feel I have to defend myself for being English or for being Irish, because, in a way, I don't feel either. And, in another way, of course, I'm both. That's exactly what the work arises out of, and it's interesting to me that it tends to be English people who have problems with that. But, ultimately, I don't really feel I have to defend anything, really."

The Lieutenant Of Inishmore, however, crosses over into territory that is altogether more provocative, incendiary even, than his other plays. It is difficult to imagine it being staged, for example, in South Armagh or even in West Belfast, where the scars and traumas of the still fresh, and possibly unfinished, armed struggle are deep and uncauterised. Is it, the play made me wonder in places, too soon to poke fun at Irish Republican terrorism, or simply - no irony intended - beyond the pale, period? Indeed, does someone who grew up in the relative safety of south London have the right to "stir it up" with regard to Northern Ireland's bloody recent history for a middle-class, English theatre-going audience?

"I know I'll probably get a lot of shit for it, because I don't come from Northern Ireland, but I would never let that stop me," counters McDonagh after a longer than usual pause, "Plus, everyone was affected by the violence, including people in London. Having grown up Catholic and, to a certain degree, Republican, I thought I should tackle the problems on my own side, so to speak. I chose the INLA because they seemed so extreme and, to be honest, because I thought I'd be less at risk. I'm not being heroic or anything - it was just something I felt I had to write about. The play came from a position of what you might call pacifist rage. I mean, it's a violent play that is wholeheartedly anti-violence. The bottom line, I suppose, is that I believe that if a piece of work is well written, you can tackle anything."

What intrigues me, though, is why McDonagh chose to tackle the subject through the medium of comedy. Did it ever cross his mind that there were certain places that you just cannot go with comedy? Another pause. "No, never. I probably should, but it's those very places that intrigue me. I kind of felt that this stuff had to be dealt with in the blackly sick way in which we sometimes react to it. I think a lot of the stuff that has happened in the past 25 years has been a sick joke. I'm not trying to solve anything, the same way as I am not trying to damage anything; just looking at it in a different way. I mean, how else can you react to all that has happened through writing, or art or whatever you want to call it, if not through absurdity?"

After that other famous absurdist, Charlie Chaplin, McDonagh may now be the second most famous former resident of the Elephant & Castle. The son of a Sligo mother and a Galway father, he spent his early childhood in and around one of those drab, grey tower blocks that rise up like watchtowers along the Old and New Kent Roads. The family relocated to nearby Camberwell when he was still a child. McDonagh remembers a house where the Sacred Heart shared wall space with a portrait of the Pope; where Irish relatives and friends would sing rebel songs whenever drink was taken. During summer holidays from his local south-London school, where the English boys were outnumbered by Irish and West Indian pupils, his family returned like annually migrating birds to Sligo or Connemara, an hour's plane ride and a whole world away from grey and grimy south London.

Later still, his parents moved back for good to Lettermullen in Connemara; their son, left to his own devices, began to journey there through his writing. His first scripts were radio plays, which he sent out himself to little or no reaction, but which, he says, "taught me that I could do dialogue and storytelling, which is all you need for theatre".

For a playwright, however, McDonagh is singularly unenthusiastic about the theatre-going experience, citing Sam Shepard's True West, Tracy Letts' Killer Joe and David Mamet's American Buffalo as the only plays he has ever enjoyed. "I went to see the Mamet because Pacino was in it, but, mostly, the whole theatre thing just makes me intensely uncomfortable to the point where I react just like my parents - you know, 'Theatre's not for the likes of us.'"

His chief formative influences were the films of Martin Scorsese, Sam Peckinpah and Sergio Leone, alongside the raw punk rock of Nirvana, the Sex Pistols and, tellingly, The Pogues. Like Shane MacGowan, when he could be bothered to write finished songs, McDonagh's London-Irish upbringing has given him a distance from his spiritual homeland that has bred a creative freedom that native Irish writers, even exiles, have fought hard to find. From that freedom springs both a respect for Irish literary and dramatic traditions and an irreverence towards them. No native Irish songwriter could have written a song such as MacGowan's The Old Main Drag, about an ageing Irish rent boy in Piccadilly, just as no native Irish dramatist could have have rode roughshod over the ghosts of O'Casey and Synge in the way that McDonagh has done.

Thus far, his work has been primarily concerned with taking a scalpel to the remarkably enduring myth of an Arcadian Ireland that he, like Synge before him, has laid bare to reveal a dark, insular place of suppurating spite, internecine family feuding and simmering violence. He has set his plays in the only Irish places he knows intimately, the Aran Islands and Connemara, two of the most mythologised and elementally beautiful areas of rural Ireland. As one critic put it, "murder, solitude and rain are what bind the plays in the Leenane trilogy together".

In The Beauty Queen Of Leenane, a mother and daughter are locked in claustrophobic mutual antipathy that comes to a head when the daughter forces the mother's hand into the hot oil of a chip pan; in A Skull In Connemara, the title taken from Beckett's Waiting For Godot, a gravedigger whose work involves digging up old bones and smashing them up to make way for fresh corpses, is suspected of killing his wife; in The Lonesome West, two brothers, one of whom has killed their father, bait each other mercilessly and mindlessly (shades of Shepard's True West). The bleakly comic world he conjures up is both utterly isolated and connected to the hyper-real global village that we all now inhabit via satellite television, the tyranny of Hollywood cinema, and the internet. It is a world of thatched cottages and satellite dishes, frustrated bachelors and murderous terrorists, virginal colleens and dysfunctional teenage girls who get their kicks by maiming cattle and, occasionally, humans. It is this casual, and often gleefully rendered, violence that seems to disturb McDonagh's critics, one of whom spoke to me off the record about his distaste for the writer's "sadistic relish in his characters' suffering".

So, I ask McDonagh why he is drawn to extremes - of character, behaviour, emotions. "Well, we're all cruel, aren't we? We're all extreme in one way or another at times, and that's what drama, since the Greeks, has dealt with. I hope the overall view isn't just that, though, or I've failed in my writing. There have to be moments when you glimpse something decent, something life-affirming even in the most twisted character. That's where the real art lies. See, I always suspect characters who are painted as lovely, decent human beings. I would always question where the darkness lies."

The Guardian's drama critic, Michael Billington, while acknowledging McDonagh's "enormous innate gift as a writer", also wonders "if he has anything original to say". Billington prefers the work of McDonagh's leading contemporary, Conor McPherson, whose plays, The Weir and Port Authority (currently playing to acclaim in London), forego action - and, some would say, actual drama - for slow, unfolding narratives in monologue form that touch on more subtle Irish cultural issues such as male loneliness, regret over missed chances, and the mundanity of everyday life behind the old and new myths of picture-postcard Ireland and the so-called Celtic Tiger economy.

"Martin writes incredibly traditional, well-wrought plays that engage and involve audiences in a way that modern theatre has almost lost sight of," elaborates Billington. "I remember John Mortimer going to see the Beauty Queen ... at the Royal Court and writing about the scene where the girl forces her mother's hand into the chip fat, and how he had never heard contemporary English theatre-going audience crying, 'No! No! Don't!' It was an extraordinary moment in contemporary theatre because, basically, you had a sophisticated, Chelsea audience surrendering to the conventions of an old-fashioned melodrama. In fact, throughout his work, the pleasure he gives an audience is the pleasure of recognition. His sources are visible for all to see, from Synge to Tarantino, and his Ireland is based not on real experience of the place but on an almost postmodern recollection of Irish drama in the last century. A playwright of real substance gives us a new territory, and offers us moral dilemmas. For me, these elements are missing from Martin's work, but they may well come with experience."

Unsurprisingly, this is an opinion that finds little favour with Hynes, who, as the Druid Theatre's most successful artistic director, has been most instrumental in translating McDonagh's precocious gifts of storytelling and dialogue on to the stage. "Martin is a south Londoner par excellence," she laughs, "but to say he has no intimate knowledge of rural Irish life is wide of the mark. He went there every year and his writing could only come from those periods of concentrated proximity to that life. What he does is merge the parochial and the, for want of a better word, postmodern. He has that mix of influences and experiences that second- or third-generation Irish people often have, and he has an extraordinary ear for dialogue.

"People who say he has no right to write what he does, or that it is not authentic, are missing the point. If you're looking for authenticity, then do not go to the theatre. Period. We are dealing with a world of the imagination here, just like with Synge or O'Casey or whoever, and the imagination knows no limits. Surely that's the essence of theatre, not moral dilemmas or messages. I'd accept that he's young, and that he has a lot of living and a lot of writing to do, but the last thing we should be trying to do is close him off."

For now, there seems little chance of that. Although McDonagh has not written a new play for four years - "I simply haven't had the time" - he is now working on an idea that, if it comes to fruition, will be his first non-Irish work. It is set in what he calls "that dark time just before and after they abolished hanging. There was a real dark and grimy aspect to London at that time, and the miscarriages of justice are a part of it, and a metaphor for something sicker and more ingrained. I just have to get the story right. Though it may not seem like it, I never try to write about a place per se; it's always, first and last, about story. Story is everything. Story and a bit of attitude."

He grins, getting ready to return to rehearsals for a play that may make or break his already controversial standing. "It's like that great Sex Pistols' song, where he sings, 'I wanna destroy passers-by'. It doesn't really get any better, or simpler, than that. It just seems sad to me that nobody wants to shake it up any more. Everybody plays the game now. It's not good enough, is it?"

Maybe McDonagh really can do for British theatre what Johnny Rotten did (at least for a beautiful, liberating moment) for British pop music: make it vital, cathartic and life-affirming again. Whatever you think of his work, you certainly have to admire his nerve

 The Lieutenant Of Inishmore previews at the Royal Shakespeare Company, Stratford, from April 11.

Another pause. "No, never. I probably should, but it's those very places that intrigue me. I kind of felt that this stuff had to be dealt with in the blackly sick way in which we sometimes react to it. I think a lot of the stuff that has happened in the past 25 years has been a sick joke. I'm not trying to solve anything, the same way as I am not trying to damage anything; just looking at it in a different way. I mean, how else can you react to all that has happened through writing, or art or whatever you want to call it, if not through absurdity?" After that other famous absurdist, Charlie Chaplin, McDonagh may now be the second most famous former resident of the Elephant & Castle. The son of a Sligo mother and a Galway father, he spent his early childhood in and around one of those drab, grey tower blocks that rise up like watchtowers along the Old and New Kent Roads. The family relocated to nearby Camberwell when he was still a child. McDonagh remembers a house where the Sacred Heart shared wall space with a portrait of the Pope; where Irish relatives and friends would sing rebel songs whenever drink was taken. During summer holidays from his local south-London school, where the English boys were outnumbered by Irish and West Indian pupils, his family returned like annually migrating birds to Sligo or Connemara, an hour's plane ride and a whole world away from grey and grimy south London. Later still, his parents moved back for good to Lettermullen in Connemara; their son, left to his own devices, began to journey there through his writing. His first scripts were radio plays, which he sent out himself to little or no reaction, but which, he says, "taught me that I could do dialogue and storytelling, which is all you need for theatre". For a playwright, however, McDonagh is singularly unenthusiastic about the theatre-going experience, citing Sam Shepard's True West, Tracy Letts' Killer Joe and David Mamet's American Buffalo as the only plays he has ever enjoyed. "I went to see the Mamet because Pacino was in it, but, mostly, the whole theatre thing just makes me intensely uncomfortable to the point where I react just like my parents - you know, 'Theatre's not for the likes of us.'" His chief formative influences were the films of Martin Scorsese, Sam Peckinpah and Sergio Leone, alongside the raw punk rock of Nirvana, the Sex Pistols and, tellingly, The Pogues. Like Shane MacGowan, when he could be bothered to write finished songs, McDonagh's London-Irish upbringing has given him a distance from his spiritual homeland that has bred a creative freedom that native Irish writers, even exiles, have fought hard to find. From that freedom springs both a respect for Irish literary and dramatic traditions and an irreverence towards them. No native Irish songwriter could have written a song such as MacGowan's The Old Main Drag, about an ageing Irish rent boy in Piccadilly, just as no native Irish dramatist could have have rode roughshod over the ghosts of O'Casey and Synge in the way that McDonagh has done. Thus far, his work has been primarily concerned with taking a scalpel to the remarkably enduring myth of an Arcadian Ireland that he, like Synge before him, has laid bare to reveal a dark, insular place of suppurating spite, internecine family feuding and simmering violence. He has set his plays in the only Irish places he knows intimately, the Aran Islands and Connemara, two of the most mythologised and elementally beautiful areas of rural Ireland. As one critic put it, "murder, solitude and rain are what bind the plays in the Leenane trilogy together". In The Beauty Queen Of Leenane, a mother and daughter are locked in claustrophobic mutual antipathy that comes to a head when the daughter forces the mother's hand into the hot oil of a chip pan; in A Skull In Connemara, the title taken from Beckett's Waiting For Godot, a gravedigger whose work involves digging up old bones and smashing them up to make way for fresh corpses, is suspected of killing his wife; in The Lonesome West, two brothers, one of whom has killed their father, bait each other mercilessly and mindlessly (shades of Shepard's True West). The bleakly comic world he conjures up is both utterly isolated and connected to the hyper-real global village that we all now inhabit via satellite television, the tyranny of Hollywood cinema, and the internet. It is a world of thatched cottages and satellite dishes, frustrated bachelors and murderous terrorists, virginal colleens and dysfunctional teenage girls who get their kicks by maiming cattle and, occasionally, humans. It is this casual, and often gleefully rendered, violence that seems to disturb McDonagh's critics, one of whom spoke to me off the record about his distaste for the writer's "sadistic relish in his characters' suffering". So, I ask McDonagh why he is drawn to extremes - of character, behaviour, emotions. "Well, we're all cruel, aren't we? We're all extreme in one way or another at times, and that's what drama, since the Greeks, has dealt with. I hope the overall view isn't just that, though, or I've failed in my writing. There have to be moments when you glimpse something decent, something life-affirming even in the most twisted character. That's where the real art lies. See, I always suspect characters who are painted as lovely, decent human beings. I would always question where the darkness lies." The Guardian's drama critic, Michael Billington, while acknowledging McDonagh's "enormous innate gift as a writer", also wonders "if he has anything original to say". Billington prefers the work of McDonagh's leading contemporary, Conor McPherson, whose plays, The Weir and Port Authority (currently playing to acclaim in London), forego action - and, some would say, actual drama - for slow, unfolding narratives in monologue form that touch on more subtle Irish cultural issues such as male loneliness, regret over missed chances, and the mundanity of everyday life behind the old and new myths of picture-postcard Ireland and the so-called Celtic Tiger economy. "Martin writes incredibly traditional, well-wrought plays that engage and involve audiences in a way that modern theatre has almost lost sight of," elaborates Billington. "I remember John Mortimer going to see the Beauty Queen ... at the Royal Court and writing about the scene where the girl forces her mother's hand into the chip fat, and how he had never heard contemporary English theatre-going audience crying, 'No! No! Don't!' It was an extraordinary moment in contemporary theatre because, basically, you had a sophisticated, Chelsea audience surrendering to the conventions of an old-fashioned melodrama. In fact, throughout his work, the pleasure he gives an audience is the pleasure of recognition. His sources are visible for all to see, from Synge to Tarantino, and his Ireland is based not on real experience of the place but on an almost postmodern recollection of Irish drama in the last century. A playwright of real substance gives us a new territory, and offers us moral dilemmas. For me, these elements are missing from Martin's work, but they may well come with experience." Unsurprisingly, this is an opinion that finds little favour with Hynes, who, as the Druid Theatre's most successful artistic director, has been most instrumental in translating McDonagh's precocious gifts of storytelling and dialogue on to the stage. "Martin is a south Londoner par excellence," she laughs, "but to say he has no intimate knowledge of rural Irish life is wide of the mark. He went there every year and his writing could only come from those periods of concentrated proximity to that life. What he does is merge the parochial and the, for want of a better word, postmodern. He has that mix of influences and experiences that second- or third-generation Irish people often have, and he has an extraordinary ear for dialogue. "People who say he has no right to write what he does, or that it is not authentic, are missing the point. If you're looking for authenticity, then do not go to the theatre. Period. We are dealing with a world of the imagination here, just like with Synge or O'Casey or whoever, and the imagination knows no limits. Surely that's the essence of theatre, not moral dilemmas or messages. I'd accept that he's young, and that he has a lot of living and a lot of writing to do, but the last thing we should be trying to do is close him off." For now, there seems little chance of that. Although McDonagh has not written a new play for four years - "I simply haven't had the time" - he is now working on an idea that, if it comes to fruition, will be his first non-Irish work. It is set in what he calls "that dark time just before and after they abolished hanging. There was a real dark and grimy aspect to London at that time, and the miscarriages of justice are a part of it, and a metaphor for something sicker and more ingrained. I just have to get the story right. Though it may not seem like it, I never try to write about a place per se; it's always, first and last, about story. Story is everything. Story and a bit of attitude." He grins, getting ready to return to rehearsals for a play that may make or break his already controversial standing. "It's like that great Sex Pistols' song, where he sings, 'I wanna destroy passers-by'. It doesn't really get any better, or simpler, than that. It just seems sad to me that nobody wants to shake it up any more. Everybody plays the game now. It's not good enough, is it?" Maybe McDonagh really can do for British theatre what Johnny Rotten did (at least for a beautiful, liberating moment) for British pop music: make it vital, cathartic and life-affirming again. Whatever you think of his work, you certainly have to admire his nerve  The Lieutenant Of Inishmore previews at the Royal Shakespeare Company, Stratford, from April 11.

fields.headline: How to... wash
fields.trailText: Guy Browning
fields.body:
Washing is something we all do almost every day, yet there are no standard instructions on how or what we should do. No wonder the nation is in crisis.

First of all, you have to decide what implement you are going to use. The most pernicious of these is the face flannel. This is an absorbent piece of cloth that captures all the grime, bacteria and pus from your face, marinates it on the side of the bath overnight, and then deposits it all back on your face first thing the next morning. Face flannels wouldn't be so bad if they stayed on your face, but they are also used on parts of your body that only your doctor or somebody who loved you a very great deal would ever go near.

People who wash in the bath have all sorts of instruments. They have big scrubbing brushes to reach parts of their backs that nothing else can reach. But consider for a moment: if nothing can reach round there, how dirty is it likely to get?

Everyone agrees that soap is a good thing, but no one quite knows what it's for. Soap can make you smell like a lemon, which is great. But if you said you were going into the bathroom to make yourself smell like a lemon, people would understandably think you were a little odd. (Pity the poor lemon plucked from a citrus grove to end up in your armpit. It's not much of a destiny.)

If you wash only one place this year, do your armpits. Otherwise, in an interview situation, you may suddenly find yourself with someone in your armpit. You should also pay particular attention to your private areas. Genitals are the most badly designed bits of the human body, with all sorts of completely unnecessary flaps, ridges and wrinkles. If these areas aren't washed regularly, huge fungi and edible mushrooms can grow in them overnight.

Parents have this thing about cleaning the parts of the body you never think about. For example, what is so important about the behind-the-ear region? Have you ever noticed somebody in public with filth behind the ears. Of course not.

There are a lot of specialist products, such as scrubs, exfoliators, etc, for washing the face. Be careful of these, as they can actually scrub your entire face away, leaving a smooth, plate-like effect.

Men wash by applying soap to their entire body, rubbing vigorously and then sandpapering any three-dimensional dirt off. Women think they will achieve the same cleaning effect by reading OK! magazine in the bath with a drop of Ylang Ylang.

webTitle: Alexander Chancellor: The quality of service

fields.headline: The quality of service
fields.standfirst: Customers endure horrific experiences in shops and restaurants but, instead of protesting, they prefer to submit silently to their fate
fields.trailText: Customers endure horrific experiences in shops and restaurants but, instead of protesting, they prefer to submit silently to their fate.
fields.body:
I have often heard it argued that Britain's general inefficiency and lousy service are mainly a consequence of a deep-seated British reluctance to complain. This is quite possibly true. Customers may endure the most horrific experiences in shops, restaurants and so on but, instead of protesting, they prefer to submit silently to their fate. They may subsequently withdraw their patronage of the offending establishment, but they will do anything to avoid a confrontation at the time. British shopkeepers and restaurateurs encourage such cowardice by observing the time-honoured British principle that the customer is always wrong. If you complain that the fish is not fresh or that the wine is corked, you will be told, as often as not, that this is simply not so, and witnesses will be produced to persuade you of your error.

The two most efficient countries in the world are Germany and the United States, where people insist upon their rights and upon getting value for money. The Germans and the Americans spend much of their time complaining, and with excellent results. Only when they do their complaining in Britain can they be less confident of a happy outcome. An American friend, the editor and columnist Michael Kinsley, has just emailed me a copy of a letter he has written to Barclays Bank in Britain, urging me to give it whatever publicity I can. I am happy to do this, for it is an excellent example of an American letter of complaint.

"Dear Sirs/Madams," it begins, "I have had a Barclays checking account for 26 years - since I was a student at Oxford. I keep it for sentimental reasons and to cover expenses on occasional trips to London. You have an odd way of repaying such loyalty. A couple of years ago, when the account had something over £1,000 in it, I got a letter informing me it had become something called 'London Solutions'. Now it appears to be called 'Barclays High Interest Checking Account Plus'. In fact, it pays zero interest. PLUS you subtract a service charge of £10 a month. PLUS you started charging a pound a month for the privilege of having £10 deducted. (This is like the Chinese government's practice of executing people then sending the families a bill for the bullet.)"

In response to an earlier letter of complaint, Barclays credited him with £4 that it said had been mistakenly withdrawn from his account. "Thereafter, one-pound charges have been floating on and off my statement in no discernible pattern," he says. But "now you have outdone yourselves", he tells the bank in his latest letter. "Today I received a statement for February 11 through March 13 on which you have deducted £30: that's the usual tenner plus a £20 'Cert Int Fee Advice', whatever that means. PLUS a notice that a one-pound charge will appear on my next statement to cover this 'extra debit entry'. My account is now down to £679.'

His letter ends forcefully. "Are you out of your minds?" he asks. "Not many people can be as lazy as I have been about allowing this rip-off to go on. Or perhaps many are, and Barclays is raking in millions in this way. If so, you overreached with that last £20. I would like to withdraw all of my dwindling balance. PLUS the £70,000 or so I have in a Barclays savings account. Please tell me how - even if this 'advice' will cost me another £20."

For similar sentimental reasons, I have for the past eight years kept a few hundred dollars in a bank account in New York. This sum has also been dwindling because of bank charges, and recently I, too, sought advice on how to withdraw the remaining funds and close the account. "Unfortunately, we are unable to process your request at this time because your signature had changed over time," Chase Bank has written to say. "In order to process your request, please complete and sign the enclosed signature card in the two spaces indicated and have it notarized at the US Consulate Office. The notary must affix an official seal on the reverse side of the card, and we must receive the original card back. In order to close your account, the balance in the account must be zero dollars. Our departmental policy prohibits us from mailing an official cheque to your overseas address. This procedure was put in place in order to safeguard your funds on deposit."

This is Catch-22 all over again. It's no use my telling Chase that my signature has barely changed at all in the past 50 years, let alone since I opened the account with them in 1993. It seems to me that banks not only in Britain, but all over the world, are now out of their minds. Or maybe they are all engaged in seedy little rip-offs. For the first time in my life, I am beginning to believe in an international bankers' ramp.

webTitle: Charlatan of fizz gets three years

fields.headline: Charlatan of fizz gets three years
fields.trailText: A champagne charlatan who helped pocket a fortune playing up fears that the world would run out of "bubbly" during the millennium celebrations was yesterday jailed for three years.
fields.body:
A champagne charlatan who helped pocket a fortune playing up fears that the world would run out of "bubbly" during the millennium celebrations was yesterday jailed for three years.

Craig Dean, 36, and two accomplices used "slick" sales patter and glossy brochures to trick investors into handing over large sums for a promised financial killing in the run-up to the "biggest party" the planet had ever thrown.

They were promised their purchases would be safely stored in bonded warehouses until just before New Year's Eve 1999, when they would be auctioned off.

Unfortunately for the 1,000 people duped by such carefully crafted "tosh", the top quality champagne they thought they had bought turned out to be second-rate "fizz" worth a fraction of what they paid.

But for the trio behind the swindle, it was worth more than £2m, Southwark crown court in London was told.

Dean, of Redditch, Worcestershire, who was convicted at an earlier hearing of one count of conspiracy to defraud between December 1995 and August 1998, showed no reaction as Judge Robin Laurie announced his fate. Lee Rosser, 31, of Bournemouth, Dorset, and Julian Blee, 32, of Luton, Bedfordshire, who admitted the swindle, were jailed earlier this year.

Jonathan Fisher, prosecuting, said the trio got to know one another while working for a crooked whisky sales operation in Gibraltar during the early 1990s.

Then, seven years ago, Blee and Rosser set up the grand-sounding House of Delacroix. In truth, it was an off-the-shelf creation, based in Amsterdam, registered in the Dutch Antilles, and with two Panamanian nominee companies as directors. Dean played the most senior management role in the company after the others withdrew from the front line to become "consultants", said Mr Fisher.

Altogether, Delacroix's customers spent £4.5m on tens of thousands of bottles of "top quality" champagne, leaving Dean and his friends a profit of £2.1m, most of which was funnelled into offshore bank accounts, the court heard.

fields.headline: Thames Water faces disconnection in row over £1m electricity bill
fields.trailText: Thames Water, the UK's largest water company, has been accused of failing to pay its electricity bills and is being threatened with disconnection by the tiny Renewable Energy Company, the world's first green energy firm.
fields.body:
Thames Water, the UK's largest water company, has been accused of failing to pay its electricity bills and is being threatened with disconnection by the tiny Renewable Energy Company, the world's first green energy firm.

The disconnection over the £1m bill would leave 300 sewage plants without power and rapidly cause chaos.

In a David and Goliath fight, REC won a temporary injunction on Thursday night against Thames Water, which was planning to switch to London Electricity next week. The dispute has been referred to the high court on Monday.

Two years ago Thames Wa ter entered into a long-term contract with REC worth about £20m a year. The two companies also own a joint venture which supplies green electricity. REC supplied its "Ecotricity" to the Millennium Dome on behalf of the joint venture.

The Ecotricity scheme was launched in 1999 by the then energy minister John Battle and if REC goes out of business it would be politically embarrassing to the government. Tony Blair restated his commitment to renewable energy only two weeks ago. REC won a Queen's Award for environmental achievement last year.

Under its contract with REC, Thames is supposed to pay its 24-hourly bills of about £100,000 daily but 10 days ago it stopped paying.

Thames Water says that it has given notice to REC and that it is entitled to go to a new supplier. Les Williams, business services manager, said that although his company owed REC for its electricity, REC owed it more money through other contracts.

He denied that Thames Water was trying to push REC into bankruptcy and said it had been "totally dissatisfied with the service they have provided".

REC managing director Dale Vince says the battle has turned into a fight for survival. He accuses Thames Water of abusing its power and alleges that it has used threats to escape the contract. Thames Water denies the accusations.

He said: "They want to get out of their contract but our legal advice is that the earliest they can terminate it is in 12 months from now. It is true that we owe money to our joint venture; we've been supporting the cash flow of the joint venture and often the amount we owe it is identical to the amount the joint venture owes us. We were carrying the debt from the dome through the summer, and we can't pay because Thames Water won't pay us."

The regulator Ofgem said that the dispute was a "purely commercial matter" and that it had received a complaint from London Electricity against REC for trying to prevent Thames Water switching.

A four-year-old girl proved the stock market was child's play yesterday by winning a share prediction contest against an investor and an astrologer.

Amid a week of financial turbulence, Tia Laverne Roberts, from south-east London, lost the least cash after taking part in a fantasy share experiment for national science week.

Each participant chose three companies and their losses and gains were tracked. Tia picked her shares at random, financial astrologer Christeen Skinner studied the heavens and Mark Goodson used his experience as a private investor.

Ms Skinner lost 10% on her £5,000 shares while Mr Goodson lost 7% and Tia lost 4.5%.

Ms Skinner said: "I was a bit distressed by the experiments. The markets have been falling and lots of people have lost money. It's kind of sick to take part in a game while that has been happening."

She said that her stocks had performed better than she had expected.

Mr Goodson said: "I said at the outset of the experiment that I confidently expected to finish bottom and that Tia would win."

Experts insisted that investments can only properly be judged over at least 12 months. But Dr Richard Wiseman, who devised the experiment, said: "I am totally up for performing the experiments over a longer period."

webTitle: Metal detectors stir up hostility as they dig up the past

fields.headline: Metal detectors stir up hostility as they dig up the past
fields.trailText: A record number of archaeological finds was reported last year by amateurs using metal detectors - over 30,000, ranging from a gold and garnet Saxon brooch to a 16th century miniature prayer book - but the news will be greeted with dismay by some archaeologists.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
A record number of archaeological finds was reported last year by amateurs using metal detectors - over 30,000, ranging from a gold and garnet Saxon brooch to a 16th century miniature prayer book - but the news will be greeted with dismay by some archaeologists.

"Metal detecting is not a harmless hobby, it is profoundly anti-academic and would not be allowed in a country where scholarship and education were more highly valued," said Martin Henig, an expert on Roman gemstones.

The latest report on the portable antiquities scheme, a voluntary code to encourage the estimated 50,000 metal detector owners in England and Wales to report all old finds to local museums, will be published on Monday.

The 31,783 objects reported, an increase of 50%, run from bizarre to unique and valuable. Most were re turned to their owners after being recorded, but hundreds have been acquired by local museums, and some have led to the discovery of important previously unknown archaeological sites.

They include a rare Edward the Confessor silver penny, found in Romney marshes; Roman republican coins found in Dorset, which date from a century before the Roman conquest; and a little copper alloy Anglo-Saxon lidded box, found in the Yorkshire dales, which may have been an Anglo-Saxon lady's workbox, since other examples have been found holding scraps of textiles.

The finders had thought many of the objects neither old nor particularly interesting. A scrap of blackened metal, now in the Northamptonshire museum, turned out to be a rare silver Anglo-Saxon belt end, with runic inscriptions.

A badly corroded scrap of copper found 10 years ago in Wales, was brought in by the finder when he read an article in a metal detecting magazine about the scheme. Archaeologists regard it as one of the most important objects reported, an iron age model shield, unique in Wales, which may have been a ritual offering.

Officially the scheme has ended the war between archaeologists and metal detectors. But Andrew Selkirk, editor of Current Archaeology, says it is rumbling on in the background. "Just under the surface, the profession is polarised on this subject, and I am still hearing reports of archaeologists who leave a site overnight, and come back to find holes dug and huge damage done."

Percival Turnbull, an independent archaeological consultant, said: "There is a sizeable criminal element, who not only loot and trespass, often on protected sites, but who routinely create false provenances for material."

webTitle: Plan to batten the hatches on wrecks

fields.headline: Plan to batten the hatches on wrecks
fields.standfirst: International convention would ban divers from salvaging ships more than 100 years old
fields.trailText: International convention would ban divers from salvaging ships more than 100 years old
fields.body:
Wild weather was brewing on the Barents sea, off the coast of Russia, the day Keith Jessop and his colleagues finally found the bullion on board HMS Edinburgh. Years of research had prepared the Yorkshire-born diver turned treasure seeker, now aged 57, for what he might find - but he only believed it when he finally held the first of 431 gold bars.

"I did it for the money, of course," he says. "We're talking about vast amounts of money here." It was £45m of bullion, lost when the naval cruiser was sunk in battle in 1942 while carrying payment for military equipment from Murmansk in Russia to Scotland.

Jessop - 16 years after his find and largely retired - is only one of the best-known of a thriving international band of commercial bounty-hunters who have made billions from locating and recovering bullion and artifacts from historic wrecks, thanks to the unwritten law of "finders keepers" on the high seas. Viewed as romantic buccaneers or unprincipled plunderers, no ships are immune from their activities: salvage rights to the most famous wreck of all, the Titanic, belong to an Atlanta-based company, RMS Titanic Inc.

But next Monday in Paris, representatives of around 100 governments will gather at a Unesco summit expected to result in an international convention that would ban commercial divers from salvaging any wreck older than 100 years - ruling out many historic wrecks, including hundreds of Spanish fleets off the American coast, and setting the clock ticking for a host of wrecks sunk in the early 20th century.

Although the US and British governments have expressed reservations about aspects of the proposals, the summit is expected to conclude that, in the UN's words, "the commercial exploitation of underwater cultural heritage for trade or speculation, or its irretrievable dispersal, is fundamentally incompatible with the protection and proper management of the cultural heritage".

A spokesman for the culture department said: "The UK position is that [the convention] should only extend protection to shipwrecks of scientific, his torical or archaeological significance. We do not believe that blanket protection applied to all wrecks over a certain age is either workable or desirable." But for Keith Jessop and his followers, it seems, the game may be up.

"There is simply no satisfactory international instrument for the protection of underwater heritage," says Lyndell Prott, a marine archaeologist at Unesco who is coordinating the negotiations. "Finally, we are hoping to set a standard that will be the basis of international legislation."

The market in privately salvaged treasure is a vast one. Thanks to advances in sonar sea-bed scanning technologies, treasure-seekers previously confined to shallower waters, have the deepest oceans at their disposal. Christies, the leading auction house in the field, in one recent and not untypical sale raised £2.2m for 24,000 pieces of porcelain recovered from a British-registered merchant ship which vanished off Malaysia in 1917.

A vigorous market in plundered goods has grown up on the internet, too: at the website of the US-based Historical Research and Development, for example, one can purchase everything from shards of crockery ($14.95) to gold buttons from the uniforms of the perished crew of the Nuestra Senora de la Regla, part of a Spanish fleet sunk off the US in 1715, for $6,900 a pair. The eventual haul from the fleet is expected to raise $200m.

The law of the sea, meanwhile - a hotchpotch of national legislation and vague references in two international conventions - provides governments with rights only to wrecks in their coastal waters.

Even in coastal waters, the current situation produces some bizarre anomalies. Last month, in a historic ruling, the US supreme court ruled that shipwrecks of two 18th-century Spanish craft, the La Galga and the Juno, belonged not to the American millionaire Ben Benson, who had claimed them with the agreement of the state of Virginia, but to the King of Spain. "Sovereign ships are honoured graves," the US department of justice successfully argued of the ships, which were sunk in battle, and should not be "subject to exploration or exploitation." The ruling is believed to lend weight to Spanish claims for more than 250 other ships.

Marine archaeologists are also worried by a growing trend for struggling governments to sell exploration and salvage rights to private foreign speculators. Late last year Cuba sold a license to dive for gold in an estimated 16,000 Spanish wrecks in its coastal waters to an American internet millionaire, Rory Boyes-Varly, for an undisclosed sum. Boyes-Varly has enlisted a Scottish company run by a 24-year-old Edinburgh University graduate, Gordon Stove, to co-ordinate the search.

"These practices do not even make sound economic sense for the countries involved," says Lyndell Prott at Unesco. "An excavation, where the finds go to the museums of the host state - such as the wreck of the Wasa in Sweden - often provides an income they wouldn't get if they sold the material for commercial benefits."

The commercial salvors insist that without private investment the wrecks would never be found in the first place. "You don't find these things by bloody mistake," says Keith Jessop. "The governments only want to get involved when the things get found, but who gives them the right to call it history? If a treasure ship's been lost for 500 years and you've never found it by now, I'd call it abandoned."

Tom Gidus, director of the Florida-based Wreckovery salvage firm, says commercial operators do a better job of protecting heritage in any case.

Hunters' hauls

Titanic Sunk by an iceberg on its maiden voyage to the US from Belfast in 1912, salvage rights to the famous liner, and an estimated $300m in jewels and artifacts, much still to be recovered, were not claimed by discoverer Bob Ballard, and are now owned by a US firm, RMS Titanic Inc. Last year a US court forbade it to sell any relics.

Tek Sing A160ft Chinese ship that hit a reef in 1822 off Indonesia. Last year it was located by UK treasure hunter Michael Hatcher, who found 350,000 pieces of exquisite porcelain and skeletons of some of 2,000 passengers.

Lusitania The liner was torpedoed in 1915 off Cork, en route from New York to Liverpool. It remains caught in a legal dispute between US businessmen who own salvage rights and the Irish government.

Last year a divers' report warned the wreck was rotting away at an alarming rate.

HMS Edinburgh The cruiser went down in the Barents sea off Murmansk in 1942. Inside was 4.5 tons of gold - part payment for the Soviet Union's war supplies. In 1981, ingots were brought up with equipment borrowed from oil companies.

Still searching

The Empress of Britain Sunk off Ireland in 1940 and the site of the wreck never discovered. Treasure hunters believe that a cargo of gold bullion awaits them.

Laconia A Cunard liner that sank off Fastnet in 1917 while carrying an estimated £3.5m in silver.

Blessing of Burntisland Charles I's ship sank in the Firth of Forth carrying, among other things, a priceless 250-piece silver tea service. Despite a number of private searches, the wreck has yet to be found.

fields.trailText: Briton feared drowned
fields.body:
Briton feared drowned

A 24-year-old Briton is feared drowned after going missing while swimming with his girlfriend near Surfers' Paradise beach in Queensland, Australia, the Foreign Office said yesterday.

Heroin nurse struck off

A 41-year-old nurse, Suzanne O'Leary, of Hove, West Sussex, who inhaled heroin in a hospital toilet while on duty, was yesterday removed from the professional register by the UK Central Council for Nursing, Midwifery and Health Visiting.

£5m to still the wobble

Funding for £5m of modifications to fix the wobble in the Millennium Bridge in central London has been agreed.

Taking aim at the fly

The new men's urinals at Chessington World of Adventures in Surrey feature a bluebottle image, strategically placed - it is said - to reduce "splashback" if users aim at it.

UK's oldest person is 113

Britain's oldest person is 113-year-old Amy Hulmes from Bury, Greater Manchester, researchers said yesterday.

webTitle: Picasso portrait could fetch more than £30m

fields.headline: Picasso portrait could fetch more than £30m
fields.trailText: Picasso's last great portrait, of Olga, his first wife, will be sold at auction in May, for the first time since he created it in 1923.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
Picasso's last great portrait, of Olga, his first wife, will be sold at auction in May, for the first time since he created it in 1923.

It is estimated to sell for up to £30m, but Christie's experts believe it could even match the world record set for a Picasso last year, when a blue period portrait went for £38.5m.

Early in his career Picasso fell in love with a dancer in Diaghilev's Ballet Russes, Olga Kokhlova, and married her in 1918. The tranquillity of the pastel portrait, showing the influence of the Ingres portraits he admired, belies the couple's stormy marriage.

Although he had drawn OIga obsessively, there were to be no more portraits except a few drawings in 1928. They formally parted in 1935, although they were never divorced and the marriage only ended with her death in 1955.

The portrait, which has been in a private collection, went on display in London yesterday, and will be auctioned in New York on May 9.

webTitle: Report spreads blanket of blame for Thames tragedy

fields.headline: Report spreads blanket of blame for Thames tragedy
fields.standfirst:
Captain of dredger could face criminal prosecution while victims' families pledge to seek further compensation

More about the Marchioness disaster
fields.trailText: Captain of dredger could face criminal prosecution while victims' families pledge to seek further compensation.
fields.body:
The official inquiry into the Marchioness disaster yesterday blamed almost everyone involved for "a catastrophe which should never have happened".

Lord Justice Clarke condemned the captain of the dredger Bowbelle, which rammed and sank the pleasure boat with the loss of 51 lives. He also blamed the skipper of the Marchioness, and the companies which owned and managed both ships. The Department of Transport and the police also came in for criticism.

Douglas Henderson, captain of the Bowbelle and still a serving ship's officer, now faces the threat of criminal prosecution or a disciplinary hearing to strip him of his master's certificate.

After the publication of the report, families of the victims declared their renewed determination to pursue the companies who owned and managed the Bowbelle. They are consulting lawyers over fresh claims for compensation, after many settled for what they now regard as derisory sums in the aftermath of the tragedy.

Eileen Dallaglio, whose daughter Francesca, 19, was the youngest victim, said: "We have been emotionally crippled and emotionally raped over the last 12 years. It is time now for us to pick up the pieces in our lives and go forward, but first we have to see what can be done to tackle those people responsible."

Mrs Dallaglio, mother of England rugby star Lawrence, said she had received just over £300 compensation from the owners of the Bowbelle, after legal fees had been deducted.

The relatives have campaigned tirelessly for a public inquiry and were praised for their tenacity and courage by deputy prime minister John Prescott in the Commons yesterday.

The dredger, a ship the size of a football pitch which was heading out to sea to suck sand for the construction industry, struck the much smaller pleasure boat twice and capsized her with the second blow.

Packed

The Marchioness was packed with more than 100 young people celebrating the 26th birthday of financier Antonio Vasconcellos when it was struck from behind by the dredger in the early hours of a fine and warm August night in 1989. It was the worst disaster on the Thames since 1878.

Lord Clarke's report said: "The basic cause of the collision is clear. It was poor lookout on both vessels. Neither vessel saw the other in time to take action to avoid the collision."

Mr Henderson was blamed for failing to maintain a proper lookout system, to keep a good lookout himself, or to give assistance to the people who were plunged into the water when the Marchioness was rammed and capsized.

Lord Clarke said the owners of the Bowbelle, East Coast Aggregates, and the managing company for the dredger, South Coast Shipping, "must bear their share of responsibility for the collision for failing properly to instruct their masters and crews [on lookout duties] and for failing thereafter to monitor them."

The Marchioness owners, Tidal Cruises, a company which still operates Thames pleasure trips, were also criticised by the judge for failing to instruct their skipper.

The Marchioness captain, Ian Faldo, who died that night, was blamed for failing to operate a proper lookout system.

Lord Clarke criticised the former Department of Transport, who he said had been "well aware of the problems posed by the limited visibility from the steering positions" on both the Marchioness and the Bowbelle.

DoT officials had even predicted that such a tragedy might take place, with major loss of life, after the Bowbelle collided with a passenger launch the Pride of Greenwich in June 1983. But measures that were put in place then to improve lookouts and communications had "fallen into disuse" by 1989, the report said.

Turning to the search and rescue operation, Lord Clarke said the police were "ill-prepared for the disaster which occurred in that there was no specific contingency plan to deal with a major disaster on the river and that there was a dearth of rescue craft." But, he added: "The police simply did their best with the resources available to them."

Mr Prescott said yesterday that the Bowbelle captain's actions would be reviewed for a possible criminal prosecution. Mr Henderson has already been tried in 1991 on a charge of failing to keep a proper lookout. The jury failed to reach a verdict then, as did another jury at a second trial and he was acquitted.

Mr Prescott said: "The preliminary advice that I have received is that there is little prospect of a successful prosecution of Captain Henderson. I have also asked the maritime and coastguard agency to undertake an urgent review of Captain Henderson's fitness to hold a British master's certificate of competency."

Mr Henderson, who is serving as a mate on a German vessel, confessed during the inquiry to faking signatures on documents showing how much time he had spent at sea. He used the documents to obtain the master's certificate which allowed him to captain the Bowbelle.

The inquiry also heard unproven allegations that Mr Henderson had been dismissed from a ship in 1986 because of drink and continues to have a drink problem to the present day.

Mr Henderson is known to have drunk six pints of lager at five different pubs the night before he took the helm of the Bowbelle, though expert evidence showed the alcohol was out of his bloodstream by the time of the disaster.

Safety on the river has been improved since the tragedy, with the coastguard due to take over responsibility for directing search and rescue from police.

Three lifeboat stations will be established on the Thames for the first time next year. Proposed legislation will also bring in an alcohol limit on the river for the first time.

Mr Henderson was blamed for failing to maintain a proper lookout system, to keep a good lookout himself, or to give assistance to the people who were plunged into the water when the Marchioness was rammed and capsized. Lord Clarke said the owners of the Bowbelle, East Coast Aggregates, and the managing company for the dredger, South Coast Shipping, "must bear their share of responsibility for the collision for failing properly to instruct their masters and crews [on lookout duties] and for failing thereafter to monitor them." The Marchioness owners, Tidal Cruises, a company which still operates Thames pleasure trips, were also criticised by the judge for failing to instruct their skipper. The Marchioness captain, Ian Faldo, who died that night, was blamed for failing to operate a proper lookout system. Lord Clarke criticised the former Department of Transport, who he said had been "well aware of the problems posed by the limited visibility from the steering positions" on both the Marchioness and the Bowbelle. DoT officials had even predicted that such a tragedy might take place, with major loss of life, after the Bowbelle collided with a passenger launch the Pride of Greenwich in June 1983. But measures that were put in place then to improve lookouts and communications had "fallen into disuse" by 1989, the report said. Turning to the search and rescue operation, Lord Clarke said the police were "ill-prepared for the disaster which occurred in that there was no specific contingency plan to deal with a major disaster on the river and that there was a dearth of rescue craft." But, he added: "The police simply did their best with the resources available to them." Mr Prescott said yesterday that the Bowbelle captain's actions would be reviewed for a possible criminal prosecution. Mr Henderson has already been tried in 1991 on a charge of failing to keep a proper lookout. The jury failed to reach a verdict then, as did another jury at a second trial and he was acquitted. Mr Prescott said: "The preliminary advice that I have received is that there is little prospect of a successful prosecution of Captain Henderson. I have also asked the maritime and coastguard agency to undertake an urgent review of Captain Henderson's fitness to hold a British master's certificate of competency." Mr Henderson, who is serving as a mate on a German vessel, confessed during the inquiry to faking signatures on documents showing how much time he had spent at sea. He used the documents to obtain the master's certificate which allowed him to captain the Bowbelle. The inquiry also heard unproven allegations that Mr Henderson had been dismissed from a ship in 1986 because of drink and continues to have a drink problem to the present day. Mr Henderson is known to have drunk six pints of lager at five different pubs the night before he took the helm of the Bowbelle, though expert evidence showed the alcohol was out of his bloodstream by the time of the disaster. Safety on the river has been improved since the tragedy, with the coastguard due to take over responsibility for directing search and rescue from police. Three lifeboat stations will be established on the Thames for the first time next year. Proposed legislation will also bring in an alcohol limit on the river for the first time. webTitle: Coroner review ordered after Marchioness report

fields.headline: Coroner review ordered after hands severed
fields.standfirst: More about the Marchioness disaster
fields.trailText: The decision to cut off the hands of 25 victims of the Marchioness disaster for fingerprint identification was condemned in a separate inquiry report by Lord Justice Clarke yesterday.
fields.body:
The decision to cut off the hands of 25 victims of the Marchioness disaster for fingerprint identification was condemned in a separate inquiry report by Lord Justice Clarke yesterday.

He criticised Westminster coroner Dr Paul Knapman for authorising the mutilation of the bodies, which was done without their relatives' knowledge.

The government yesterday announced a sweeping review of the centuries-old coroners' system following Lord Clarke's criticisms.

The judge urged a detailed review which would establish a legal basis for coroners' powers, duties and responsibilities. He recommended that coroners should receive formal training for the first time.

The inquiry found that no-one had considered the possibility of using dental records for identification.

"The hands should not have been removed and Dr Knapman must bear the responsibility for the fact that they were," the judge said. Despite the severing of hands, in one case the wrong body was nearly released to a family.

In three cases, hands were not returned with bodies. In the case of a victim called Elsa Garcia, her mother Lucy was not told that her hands had been removed. Mrs Garcia did not discover until the inquiry last year that her daughter's hands had been kept in a freezer at Westminster mortuary until August 1993, when their presence was reported to Dr Knapman, who then authorised their destruction.

Relatives also complained of being prevented from viewing bodies.

The inquiry found that coroner's officers or police liaison officers may have discouraged relatives from doing this "from the best motives, namely to avoid distress."

Samples of tissue were also taken from four victims, without relatives' consent, and stored for more than 11 years in Westminster mortuary.

Lord Clarke recommended that coroners should receive training in the identification of bodies in disasters, and in dealing with relatives.

He also proposed that families should receive the legal right to view bodies of loved ones. DNA testing is now used instead of fingerprinting in disasters.

Dr Knapman, who is still Westminster coroner, expressed regret and said his decisions were taken in the context of a complex situation for which he had not been prepared.

"My strongest desire is that Lord Justice Clarke's report, and its clear signposts for the future, can now mark a turning point for all of us.

"I judged that what the relatives of those who feared the loss of a loved one wanted most was a swift and certain identification. To have acted otherwise could have added a week's uncertainty for those families."

Home Office minister Paul Boateng said yesterday that the coroners' system had to change if public confidence was to be maintained.

Reports' verdicts on lookouts and treatment of dead

 The basic cause of the collision was poor lookout on both vessels

 The Bowbelle owners and managers failed to properly instruct, or monitor, crews

 The Marchioness owners failed to issue proper instructions about keeping lookouts and did not properly supervise their skipper

 The Department of Transport had known for years about the problems posed by the limited visibility from the steering positions on the Marchioness and the Bowbelle

 Captain Henderson drank more than he should have on the afternoon of August 19, but by the time of the collision early on August 20 he had no alcohol in his bloodstream

 The Metropolitan police were ill-prepared in that there was no specific contingency plan to deal with a major disaster on the river

 No one considered the possibility of a deceased person being identified by dental records before the decision to remove the hands was taken

 In the case of three victims, the removed hands were not released with the body

www.marchioness-bowbelle.org.uk

Non-statutory inquiry

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Triple murder charge | Drink-drive PC jailed | Two remanded in bonfire case | Man charged on disappearance | Improvement on railways
fields.body:
Triple murder charge

A 38-year-old man will appear before magistrates in Swansea today charged with the murders of three generations of a family. Grandmother Dorris Dawson, 80, her daughter, Mandy Power, 34, and grandchildren Katie, 10, and Emily, aged eight, were bludgeoned to death at their home in Clydach in June 1999.

Drink-drive PC jailed

A policewoman who admitted driving while nearly four times over the legal limit was yesterday jailed for three months by Pontefract magistrates. Sherrida Clark, 29, who has now left the West Yorkshire force, tried to run away after her car collided with two other vehicles, and had several near-misses before hitting a garden wall. When breathalysed she was found to have 136 micrograms of alcohol per 100 millilitres of breath.

Two remanded in bonfire case

Two men were remanded in custody yesterday by Birmingham magistrates charged with killing Sonny Mohammed, 27, whose body was found on a bonfire in Sparkhill last year. Mohammed Nawaz Khan, 28, and Mohammed Sijid Khan, 21, will appear at Birmingham crown court next week.

Man charged on disappearance

One of three people being questioned over the disappearance of Gerald McGinley, 34, who went missing in August, was yesterday charged with murder. The 34-year-old from Enniskillen, Co Fermanagh, has also been accused of attempting to pervert the course of justice.

Improvement on railways

The rail network has steadily improved since the Hatfield accident which killed four people in October, according to figures released by the strategic rail authority yesterday. Twenty-one of the 25 operators had improved the number of trains arriving on time in January compared with December.

fields.headline: Army targeted for Kenya deaths
fields.standfirst: City law firm to sue over ordnance allegedly left after training
fields.trailText: City law firm to sue over ordnance allegedly left after training.
fields.body:
A City law firm is preparing to sue the British Army on behalf of hundreds of Kenyans killed or maimed by ordnance left lying around after training exercises in northern Kenya.

On a fact-finding mission to the army's training grounds in rural Kenya this week, a British legal team saw unexploded artillery shells and grenades scattered where farmers graze their herds. They recorded more than 200 related accidents, up to half of them fatal and 90% of them involving children.

Martin Day, senior partner with the civil rights law firm Leigh, Day & Co, said in Nairobi yesterday. "We found people with terrible mutilations, people devastated by the loss of their children. They have a very strong case against the British Army."

The army denies leaving behind ordnance either at Archers Post, which it shares with the Kenyan and US armies, or on a private ranch at Dol Dol, both in Samburu district.

Rufus Drabble, spokesman for the British Army training liaison staff in Kenya, said: "We don't believe these munitions are ours. When we use the place we make damn sure we clean up."

But Mr Day said: "The locals in Archers Post say the British drop most of the bombs. From what we have seen, the majority of cases happen after British training exercises."

Ngisesia Leletur, 13, stumbled across an unexploded shell while herding goats at Archers Post in November. She was fortunate to escape with broken ribs and shrapnel wounds to her legs, lungs and liver. A British Army helicopter flew her to a nearby mission hospital where she remained for three months.

Mr Day said the British Army had since begun a rigorous clean-up of Archers Post, though tribesmen claimed at least 100 artillery shells were still lying around. Local people have since been given a seven-day warning before firing begins. "But why the hell didn't they start before - how many deaths did it take?" Mr Day said, noting that the army had used the site for 40 years.

He said there was no evidence of any clean-up at the other live-fire training ground at Dol Dol. Mr Day and a colleague, Richard Stein, saw a grenade lying in a river-bank and an artillery shell in thorn-bushes 50 yards from a village.

The army has permission to train on land at Dol Dol owned by a Kenyan rancher. However, Mr Day said an adjoining ranch owned by a Maasai community, with a hut every 150 yards, was also being fired on.

The Maasai were not opposed to the training but felt they should be compensated, he said. "It's incredible, they didn't know why these people were firing round their homes. I can't see that happening on Salisbury Plain."

The Ministry of Defence said the army did not fire on land outside the ranch. An MoD spokesman, Captain Niall Macgregor, said: "We train on whatever land the Kenyan government allocates us. If it's owned by Maasai or whoever, we have to assume the government has arranged things with them somehow."

Mr Day said a suit would be filed in the high court in London in the next few weeks.

Leigh, Day & Co recently won damages of up to £100,000 each for 40 South Africans poisoned by mercury while working at the Durban plant of a British company, Thor Chemicals. That ruling followed a landmark decision in the House of Lords allowing foreign compensation claims against a British defendant to be pursued in a British court.
