fields.headline: Muslim bias
fields.trailText: The Taliban regime does not represent the sentiments of the world's Muslim population  (Kabul collection, March 23).
fields.body:
The Taliban regime does not represent the sentiments of the world's Muslim population; indeed, Shi'ite and Sufi communities in Afghanistan (and, of course, women, most of whom are, presumably, Muslim) suffer much more than any piece of stone in Afghanistan under the Taliban (Kabul collection, March 23). So why the need to trace their destruction of Buddhist shrines to Islamic teachings?

There has been little mention here that the Mufti of al-Azhar, Egypt's minister for Islamic affairs, was one of a delegation who beseeched the Taliban not to destroy the Bamiyan statues. Probably that would kill the whole Muslim-against-the-world, tabloid nature of the story.
Abdulhadi Ayyad
London

webTitle: Letters: The worst is yet to come on BSE

fields.headline: The worst is yet to come on BSE
fields.trailText: The "traditional slaughtering methods" used in small abattoirs (Age-old habits caused deadly cluster, March 22) were not restricted to Queniborough.
fields.body:
The "traditional slaughtering methods" used in small abattoirs (Age-old habits caused deadly cluster, March 22) were not restricted to Queniborough. In my evidence to the House of Commons select committee on BSE in June 1990 I condemned those widespread slaughterhouse methods of removing cattle brains because of the way they contaminated the rest of the carcass and in October 1990 Maff banned them.

Cows were first infected with BSE in 1981 and until November 1989 the brains of outwardly healthy animals which were incubating the disease went into our meat products. It follows that there will be more clusters because some of us who are susceptible to CJD (about 30%) and who ate meat pies, pates and tinned items like consomme between 1981 and 1989 are presumably incubating the disease.

The vCJD victims are hitherto so young because, being children at that time, they were shedding teeth and the raw areas in their gums enabled the organism to enter the bloodstream directly which shortened their incubation period. I fear it is a gloomy scenario.
Dr Helen Grant
London

 The inquiry into the Queniborough cluster has confirmed the lethality of a brain of a BSE-infected cow.

In 1999, random sampling of the British herd showed that 18 out of 3,900 cows had pre-clinical BSE, or 0.5%. Has anyone considered the risk to public health from the cow funeral pyres being built?

In a pyre of some 200 cows, on average one will have a brain containing almost indestructible prions, being dispersed downwind. In contrast, when cows were culled to contain BSE, the carcasses were incinerated in furnaces, to attain a temperatures of 1,000C.
Dr Helen Grant
Leamington Spa

fields.headline: Fanning the flames
fields.trailText: I'm sure Martin Amis's publishers, who fell foul of our advertising policies, will be pleased after your free ad for his book. (Young Amis caught in illegal act, March 22).
fields.body:
I'm sure Martin Amis's publishers, who fell foul of our advertising policies, will be pleased after your free ad for his book. (Young Amis caught in illegal act, March 22).

The decision to ban from the tube the image of a small boy smoking, is entirely right. I believe a significant proportion of the 3m people who use the tube each day will be pleased and we make no apologies for banning the ad and others we know will offend. Sensible adults (like Martin Amis) will know why smoking on our property is anathema to every employee of London Underground.

Sadly, the net result of this noise is that the image is portrayed for free in popular papers such as yours. The wisdom of your decision to run the ad of a small boy smoking is one that you will understand, even if many of your readers do not.

This is not solely about guidelines based on the British Code of Advertising Practice, it's also about what is responsible. Given your forthright editorial approach on tobacco, I find it surprising that you would run anything which could be seen to encourage children to smoke.
Tony Maguire
Director of communications London Underground

 You quote a spokeswoman for London Underground as saying that "it is illegal for children under the age of 16 to smoke". It's illegal to sell cigarettes to children under 16; it's not illegal to buy or consume them at any age. Stupid, yes; illegal, no.
Ian Shuttleworth
London

fields.headline: Don't panic
fields.trailText: The demographic forecasts published by the Office for National Statistics are nothing to panic about (Britain ages as pregnancies fall, 23 March).
fields.body:
The demographic forecasts published by the Office for National Statistics are nothing to panic about (Britain ages as pregnancies fall, 23 March).

Britain has an ageing population, as people live longer and fewer are born, but the effects of the change in the dependency ratio between those at work and the retired are completely spurious. Increases in productivity, national income and immigration will create enough wealth to easily compensate for more pensioners.

Raising the retirement age is both unnecessary and undesirable. Britain has the resources to give our older generation real financial security, both now and in the decades to come.
Jack Jones
President, National Pensioners Convention

fields.headline: Back to earth
fields.trailText: I would like to congratulate the Russians on the successful ditching of the Mir space station in the Pacific.
fields.body:
 I would like to congratulate the Russians on the successful ditching of the Mir space station in the Pacific. It was a spectacular metaphor for the demise of the Soviet Union and everything it stood for.
Stan Labovitch
Windsor

 Only a priest would have the audacity to complain about signing passport applications (Letters, March 22). If the snobbish proscription upon eligibility to verify applicants identity were lifted, perhaps the poor man would be relieved of this burden.
Robert Drury
Louth, Lincs
rob@drurypsm.demon.co.uk

 Your correspondent R Oxlade (Letters, March 21) incorrectly quoted the signature song of Itma. I recall the words as being "He's her pride and joy, Mrs Handley's boy, It's useless to complain, When troubles brew, It is his cue, It's That Man, That Man Again". So far from causing trouble, he gave us something to laugh about during the dark days of the war. Had he caused trouble, Miss Hotchkiss (his secretary) would soon have been on his tail.
Sylvia Henderson
Reading

 On Tuesday William Hague demanded the postponement of local elections so that people wouldn't have to tramp around the countryside. On Thursday William Hague was tramping around the Devon countryside. Are sudden u-turns are a sign of foot in mouth syndrome?
Brian Highley
Newton Poppleford, Devon

 Are those farmers who are now condemning the government for "doing too little too late" by any chance the same as those who recently complained of too much government interference in their livelihood?
David Hendy
Oxford

fields.body:
It was good to see that a parliamentary environment sub-committee has criticised the government's recycling strategy (MPs rubbish waste strategy, March 22).

But consider waste paper and newsprint in particular. Every week I take to the recycling bins (by car) heaps of unsolicited, unread, unwanted newsprint dumped on me by your newspaper. I don't need the supplements for job adverts. I reluctantly gave up taking a Sunday paper because it took my wife and I the whole weekend to cope with even a part of your Saturday edition. It ill becomes any newspaper, even yours, to be self-righteous about the recycling problems we face.

And every time I go to a supermarket I find more goods packaged, including fruit and vegetables, mainly in plastic. If I buy any large piece of equipment or furniture I am left with a mountain of card and polystyrene to get rid of.

Of course waste collection and recycling facilities are inadequate but why aren't we tackling the problem with equal vigour from both ends?
Michael Quinton Lancaster

 I operate a busy bar and have been wrestling with my waste problem for years. We sort all our bottles into green, brown, and clear, and there are over 1,000 per week, clean and used once. We squash our cardboard boxes, there are about 100 per week.

No contractor will recycle them. One senior manager told me that there is insufficient plant and the whole exercise is uneconomic. They now dump all into the general waste and landfill.

If this is the truth then all quotas mentioned in your article are a waste of time.
John Gripton
Ascot, Berks

webTitle: Letters: Fat cats get a licking

fields.headline: Fat cats get a licking
fields.trailText: Jonathan Sumption (Letters, March 23) says his "puny £1.6m" is not made at the expense of the public purse or the private purses of others. A large part of it must be, of course.
fields.body:
Jonathan Sumption (Letters, March 23) says his "puny £1.6m" is not made at the expense of the public purse or the private purses of others. A large part of it must be, of course. We all are, on these islands, working in our various ways to produce what is known as the gross national product (of goods and services). And we share it out. As the Guardian has pointed out, some get bigger shares than others. If we increase one individual's share then there is that much less for the rest. I am surprised that a highly paid barrister has failed to spot so obvious a fact.
Donald Matheson
Daresbury, Warrington
donmat@cwcom.net

 Jonathan Sumption has at least spared us the usual dubious fat-cat plea of hard work. He justifies his income by citing market forces. However, it is a safe assumption that his "hard-nosed professional clients" are on a similar gravy train, rewarded not for merit, but for routine performance in a system rigged in their favour. They consequently lack any real concept of money values and confuse cost with worth. Their pay is essentially determined by comparability, a system which was long ago condemned and abandoned as inflationary and unsustainable when used for public servants.

If these people really believed in market forces, their jobs would be put out to tender just like a contract for provision of goods or services. If a public servant went headhunting for a contractor and made his choice before accepting whatever terms the contractor sought to impose, he would soon be facing a charge of corruption. And yet that appears to be normal practice for recruitment in the higher echelons of the business world.

Society can be divided into the exploiters and the exploited and the ridiculous fortunes amassed by most of the exploiters have indeed been filched from the pockets of the masses.
Peter Moverley
Bristol
mov@cwcom.net

 I was flabbergasted by Jonathan Sumption's justification of why some workers, including himself, deserve to receive more than others. It read like the testimony of a guilty man. Surely the reason for the huge differential between the earnings of chief executives and disc jockeys and those of nurses, teachers and refuse workers is located in the fact that our society is forever trying to avail itself of the best of the private and public sector worlds, and failing those involved in the latter.

Chief executives and disc jockeys would not be in their privileged positions were it not for state-supported systems attending to national education, health and the environment. For that reason individual nurses, teachers and refuse workers make just as much "difference financially" as any director or DJ.
Paul Bonaventura
Oxford

 I'm sure that when Jonathan Sumption argues cases on behalf of clients for large fees he takes more care than when he argues his own case for free in a letter. The tired red herring that earnings are proportional to financial or practical gain for the beneficiaries of the skill deployed, and payment a recognition by "hard-nosed employers" of that skill, is nonsense.

When the Duke of Marlborough saved the nation in the 18th century he was given Blenheim palace and the equivalent of billions. His descendant Winston Churchill did the same in 1945: he got honours, and a few million in book royalties. Alan Greenspan or Gordon Brown make billions for the economy of their countries if they get things right; their salaries are pathetic in relative terms.
William Gil
London

webTitle: Leader: who will look after the Guiness book of Records now?

fields.headline: Paging Mr Olympia
fields.standfirst: Who will look after these records now?
fields.trailText: Some ideas which work when they are small disappoint old admirers by growing too big. Could that be one of the reasons why its owners have decided to dispose of their famous reference work, the Guinness Book of Records.
fields.body:
Some ideas which work when they are small disappoint old admirers by growing too big. Could that be one of the reasons why its owners have decided to dispose of their famous reference work, the Guinness Book of Records, which over the years has become the leylandii of the reference shelf?

It began as a modest object telling you in 198 pages at a cost of 25p the height of the world's tallest mountain, the length of its longest river and the name of its fastest game bird -the idea for the book having emerged when a collection of Guinness executives disagreed about that. In those days it was mainly the work of the McWhirter brothers, Norris and Ross. But in 45 years since, it has vastly expanded to accommodate a stock of information which grows steadily more bizarre.

The world's biggest Chinese dumpling, the most contestants for the title of Mr Olympia, the longest beard on a woman: all found their way into the mix. Norris McWhirter (his brother Ross was killed by the IRA in 1975) left the project. Now its new owners, Diageo, are giving it up to concentrate on their brewing. But given the way it sells, others must surely be thirsting to buy it. We can still look forward to learning next Christmas the longest time spent in a burger bar west of Rotherham on a June day by the left-handed younger son of a Marquess of Abergavenny.

webTitle: Capital letters: A better deal came to my notice

fields.headline: A better deal came to my notice
fields.trailText:
My Bradford & Bingley instant access account was paying such low rates in 1998 that I switched my £2,000 in savings to a 60 day account paying more than 4%. Since then, my interest rate has slipped back. Now I see B&B is paying 5% on instant access savings in the Premier Saver account, while my 60 day account has fallen back to just over 3%. What is going on?
RK, South-east London
fields.body:
My Bradford & Bingley instant access account was paying such low rates in 1998 that I switched my £2,000 in savings to a 60 day account paying more than 4%. Since then, my interest rate has slipped back. Now I see B&B is paying 5% on instant access savings in the Premier Saver account, while my 60 day account has fallen back to just over 3%. What is going on?
RK, South-east London

A very good question. But not one to which B&B is happy to volunteer a full answer. The recently demutualised institution opted not to discuss why the 60 day account had become bad value. When notice accounts started some 20 years ago, the clear customer proposition was the longer the notice or loss of interest in lieu, the higher the return. But with the bells and whistles, known in the trade as confusion marketing, this is no longer always the case.

On your £2,000, the Bradford & Bingley 60 day notice account pays 3.1% plus a 1% bonus if no more than one withdrawal a year is made. The Premier Saver pays 5% on a minimum £2,000, but it is not quite so instant access as it seems. There must be a balance of more than £2,000 at all times, any transactions must be for a minimum of £250 and no third party cheques can be paid from the account.

The banking code is designed to prevent savers being locked into low interest rates on notice accounts when better returns are on offer on less restrictive accounts. But because of the difficulty of comparing the small print features of the two accounts, it is likely that an appeal to the code on this ground would fail.

As B&B says: "It may well be that this new account may be more suitable for the customer and their local branch will be more than happy to advise them." But they won't be offering you compensation for the poor returns when you visit.

webTitle: Golden rules for life with the bears

fields.headline: Golden rules for life with the bears
fields.trailText: Private client broker and self-styled "great bear" David Kauders has a golden rule,  write Tony Levene and Patrick Collinson. "In a bear market, there is only one rule: Keep out. Otherwise it is all too easy to turn a nasty loss into a wipe-out - there is no room for mistakes," he insists.
fields.body:
Private client broker and self-styled "great bear" David Kauders has a golden rule, write Tony Levene and Patrick Collinson. "In a bear market, there is only one rule: Keep out. Otherwise it is all too easy to turn a nasty loss into a wipe-out - there is no room for mistakes," he insists.

Kauders, who runs his eponymous portfolio management operation from offices in Taunton and London, has consistently warned that equity investors were riding for a fall. He prefers gilts and US treasury bonds.

"We've been living on a soft diet of easy credit since 1987 so there has been more money available to go into pushing up asset prices including shares. But this roundabout has to stop eventually and everyone gets thrown off. Japan is an obvious case in point," he says.

He warns against taking notice of brokers and fund managers. "They always have reasons why a downturn will be short-term. Yes, there will be rallies of a few days to a few months and those are signs to get out."

The Kondratieff cycle, which suggests around 27 years between major bear markets, points to a fall - the last big UK bear market began in 1973.

Few of today's market participants have seen a real bear market, he says.

"Tokyo has come back by 70% since its peak, the UK stock market fell 73% between 1973 and January 1975, while Wall Street collapsed 89% in the three years after October 1929. So far we've only seen 15-20% falls," he says.

He believes that we could see 10 years of declining markets before any sustained recovery, hitting pension funds as well as Isas. "The Footsie could be down to 2,000 before this bear market is over. The only safe investments are UK and US government bonds."

Here's Kauders' keys to understanding the bear market.

In a bull market, the rules are hold on, and buy the dips. But these rules fail miserably in a bear market!

A bear market is not just a 10% decline followed by a new bull market. It is the whole cycle, leading to 60%, 70%, or even greater losses, with each new "bull market" nothing more than a counter-trend rally.

The only bull markets we can find are in gilts, US treasury bonds, and the US dollar.

But, thanks to derivatives, bears now have a second choice - they can opt for unit trust bear funds which gain as markets fall. They are currently sitting on top of the performance tables.

Over the past week, while nearly all other funds have registered painful declines, the Govett US Bear fund has jumped by 7.9%. No other fund in the 2000 on offer to investors has managed to earn more than 2% over the past seven days, and most have fallen steeply.

A Bear fund uses complex futures and options to, for example, give investors a 10% increase when the market is down 10%. Of course, it also works in reverse, so that if the market rises by 10%, the bear fund falls by 10%.

Bear funds were only authorised by financial regulators to be sold to small investors in the early 1990s. Only two fund managers, Govett and Merril Lynch, launched bear funds, and Govett stopped offering its FTSE bear fund a couple of years ago after investor interest dried up.

Conrad Preece, manager of Govett US Bear, says: "Since the US market peaked, we have seen a steady increase in interest in the fund."

But Mr Preece warns: "They are mainly a short-term tactical device, so that investors can switch between bull and bear markets at low cost and at speed. We would not advise anyone to see them as a long term home."

fields.headline: Moving with the times
fields.standfirst: Nick Pandya looks at the latest initiatives in the home loans trade
fields.trailText: Nick Pandya looks at the latest initiatives in the home loans trade
fields.body:
Shunning the falling stock markets, cash rich investors may be tempted to pile into property investment, but the Association of Residential Letting Agents (ARLA) is urging caution.

Robert Jordan, president of the association, warns that investors forsaking financial markets to join the rentier class must be careful not to be lumbered with a hard-to-rent property.

Every area comes with its own peculiarities and Mr Jordan says it would be foolhardy to plump for a buy-to-let deal without seeking expert guidance - from the local ARLA representative, of course.

Elsewhere, Capital Home Loans, the UK arm of the Irish Permanent Group, has come up with a novel let-to-buy scheme, whereby the mortgage enables borrowers to move house without having to find a buyer for their existing property. Under the terms of the deal, borrowers remortgage their existing home, realising enough equity to repay the outstanding debt and fund the deposit on their new house.

For example, a homeowner with a house worth £200,000 and a mortgage of £120,000 can borrow up to 80% of the value of the house, £160,000, which redeems the existing mortgage and leaves £40,000 to put towards their new home.

The existing house is let out and the rental income is earmarked to help meet the mortgage repayments on the new property, currently charged at 6.2%. For further details, contact the marketing team on 01252 365 888.

For borrowers keen to acquire an investment property to let, Mortgages for Business, the commercial mortgage broker, is capping the rates on its active asset buy-to-let mortgage at 5.19% for one year or 6.79% for three years.

The active asset is a current account mortgage that offers penalty-free early redemption, payment holidays and a redrawing facility. For full details, tel: 01732-763-660 or visit www.mortgagesforbusiness.co.uk.

NewWorld, the money lending arm of the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, is also offering buy-to-let mortgages at a discounted rate of 4.95% for the first six months and 6.74% thereafter. The discounted rate will save around £107 a month for the first six months on a 25-year £100,000 mortgage. Full details from 0845 845 4455.

In a separate move for borrowers who prefer the long-term stability of constant repayments, the Manchester Building Society is offering home loans fixed at 6.29% for their entire 25-year life.

And Alliance & Leicester has introduced a base rate tracking mortgage aimed at borrowers wishing to switch from a basic variable rate mortgage. The new flexible home loan, that allows overpayment and payment holidays, is priced at 0.95% above base rate, currently working out at 6.7%. Under the terms of the flexible base rate tracker mortgage, interest is calculated monthly and a monthly statement is issued.

webTitle: Jobs and money: Talking heads: Professor Amin Rajan

fields.headline: Talking heads
fields.standfirst: Professor Amin Rajan.  Chief executive, Centre for Research in Employment and Technology in Europe, a research consultancy
fields.trailText: Professor Amin Rajan.  Chief executive, Centre for Research in Employment and Technology in Europe, a research consultancy.
fields.body:
What was your first career aspiration?

To enter politics: I've always felt like a rebel with a cause.

What has been your best moment in your role?

Giving the Royal Society of Art's lecture on leadership at the dawn of a new millennium.

And your greatest mistake?

Believing that senior civil servants in the Thatcher period were apolitical. They came down on me like a ton of bricks when one of my research studies found that out of every pound spent by government on reducing youth unemployment, 96p served no more than a cosmetic purpose. I learnt a lot from their rebuke.

How would you describe your management style?

A revolutionary gentleman, an appreciator of ideas. I like to think I'm a good active listener.

What management wisdom is most over-rated?

Focus and decisiveness. Today, success is about balance: that is, juggling many balls in the air whilst running on an ever-quickening treadmill.

What is the biggest challenge facing UK plc?

It does not have enough business leaders who can give a greater social expression to today's shareholder-first capitalism. Growing affluence should be used as a springboard for progress.

What lesson would you pass on to budding managers?

Use simple language: mean what you say and say what you mean. Clarity of expression leads to clarity of action.

Which management guru do you believe in?

My late mother. She possessed an unusual degree of common sense: strong on ideas and strong on deliverables. I use her quotes a lot in my lectures. And the audience love them because they run with the grain of human nature.

Who is your management hero?

Hillary Cropper, chair, FI plc; Chris Mellor, CEO, Anglian Water Group; and Jayne- Anne Gadhia, MD, Virgin One Account.

Who is your favourite politician?

David Blunkett, an outstanding example of courage, determination and persistence.

If you could change one aspect of British business, what would it be?

I would banish hype. Clever words have almost become a substitute for action in business and politics alike. We need a new tradition of simplicity, openness and action.

Do you have a view on British membership of the EMU?

We are ready to join. But first we need a public debate that helps to overcome the deep scepticism. My other worry is whether the EMU is ready for us. Major imbalances persist between member economies.

What annoys you most?

Declining standards of civility in business and personal dealings.

How do you relax?

Jogging, reading and writing.

What is your favourite city?

Aswan. It combines the best of old and new.

What is your biggest fear?

The fear of failure.

What would you really like to have been?

I feel lucky to be me.

What management wisdom is most over-rated? Focus and decisiveness. Today, success is about balance: that is, juggling many balls in the air whilst running on an ever-quickening treadmill. What is the biggest challenge facing UK plc? It does not have enough business leaders who can give a greater social expression to today's shareholder-first capitalism. Growing affluence should be used as a springboard for progress. What lesson would you pass on to budding managers? Use simple language: mean what you say and say what you mean. Clarity of expression leads to clarity of action. Which management guru do you believe in? My late mother. She possessed an unusual degree of common sense: strong on ideas and strong on deliverables. I use her quotes a lot in my lectures. And the audience love them because they run with the grain of human nature. Who is your management hero? Hillary Cropper, chair, FI plc; Chris Mellor, CEO, Anglian Water Group; and Jayne- Anne Gadhia, MD, Virgin One Account. Who is your favourite politician? David Blunkett, an outstanding example of courage, determination and persistence. If you could change one aspect of British business, what would it be? I would banish hype. Clever words have almost become a substitute for action in business and politics alike. We need a new tradition of simplicity, openness and action. Do you have a view on British membership of the EMU? We are ready to join. But first we need a public debate that helps to overcome the deep scepticism. My other worry is whether the EMU is ready for us. Major imbalances persist between member economies. What annoys you most? Declining standards of civility in business and personal dealings. How do you relax? Jogging, reading and writing. What is your favourite city? Aswan. It combines the best of old and new. What is your biggest fear? The fear of failure. What would you really like to have been? I feel lucky to be me.

fields.headline: From the top
fields.trailText: I used to think that boredom was a prerogative of the young, but in working as a career coach I have discovered it is an attitude of mind which knows no boundaries.
fields.body:
I used to think that boredom was a prerogative of the young, but in working as a career coach I have discovered it is an attitude of mind which knows no boundaries.

Individuals who hold down jobs that others would give their eye teeth for, in sectors which are perceived as glamorous, in roles which bring proximity to power and attract high rewards, frequently confess that they are bored.

The solution they usually bring with them is a logical one. Since work no longer stimulates, they search around for something outside work which brings them a sense of enjoyment and assume that swapping accountancy for the visual arts or legal work for travel guiding will revitalise their zest for life.

The challenge is how to find a way in, how to downshift lifestyle, and how to sell the idea to a partner whose life will be unsettled by a change they may not welcome.

The flaw in the argument is that the ability to draw pleasure from a leisure activity is directly related to the fact that it is free from the anxieties of responsibility, accountability and a sense of lack of control that mark much work. Don't feel like completing that ceramic piece? Then leave it. Don't want to be in the next amateur dramatic production? Then pull out. Luxuries that are rarely available on paid time.

So if the answer is rarely to simply transfer a hobby into a career, how should individuals deal with career boredom? There is a current school of thought that argues boredom is unavoidable and may even be healthy.

Some jobs simply are boring and to pretend otherwise is an act of delusion. Allow that the work is intrinsically meaningless and employees will discover ways of managing their own boredom. The theory is proven. Having worked in jobs of little intrinsic interest, I have observed the creativity which people will apply to managing their own boredom: from the factory cleaner who ran his own unqualified veterinary service on work premises, to theft, drug taking and sabotage.

The business costs of unchallenged boredom are unfortunately too high to allow the experiment free rein, and when the most bored may be those in the most critical roles, the challenge is to find an alternate solution to the usual panaceas of a change of employer or an office affair.

There are clues in the activities which individuals enter freely as to how boredom can be removed. Twenty-five years ago, psychologist Mihaly Czikszentmihalyi undertook a study of individuals in activities which made them feel good: they were as diverse as rock climbing, gambling, chess playing, composing music and playing sport.

Those surveyed reported that while doing them they felt totally involved; they became merged with the activity, as distinct from the sense of being an onlooker that they often reported in daily life. They had a total focus which absorbed them, and which provided them with rewarding feelings. For some those feelings related to risk and chance, for others it was problem solving, a sense of competition, friendship or creativity.

In speaking of why these activities were so satisfying, an important part was that they tested them to the limits of their abilities, and provided them with rewards which were almost entirely intrinsic. They felt through their involvement that they were creating a world of their own.

The logic of Czikszentmihalyi's work is that rather than looking to increase variety when individuals report boredom, individuals should be encouraged to understand what rewards are of most significance to them, and then to focus their efforts more intensely on fewer tasks which are more meaningful to them.

Carole Pemberton is managing consultant, CareerMatters

webTitle: Jobs and money: Incubators hatch new intrapreneurs

fields.headline: Incubators hatch new intrapreneurs
fields.standfirst: Enterprising thinkers can be rewarded and retained by their firm says Andy Gaule
fields.trailText: Enterprising thinkers can be rewarded and retained by their firm says Andy Gaule.
fields.body:
Creating and managing your own business can be one of the great learning experiences. Making an idea a reality can test an almost limitless range of skills. While concentrating on your core product or service, you need to draw on a range of knowledge and expertise including concept development, raising capital, marketing, negotiation, people recruitment and management.

Conventional university and business school incubators have provided a protective environment in which new ideas can be tested and proved through a mix of advice centres, networks and seed corn funding.

Typically, business school incubators act as midwives to budding entrepreneurs providing facilities such as a floor or corner of a converted warehouse, back office support, reception, finance and office equipment and most critically, capital. They operate at seed or first round funding level and are a vehicle by which venture capital or private equity funds get into entrepreneurial activities.

However, for some large organisations, the existence of business school-based incubators is a cause for concern. Just as they have invested heavily in sponsoring an MBA for their most talented managers, the newly qualified managers spot a real chance of leaving corporate life in pursuit of independence and complete control over their careers.

The more enterprising, creative and risk-taking individuals - the very people that organisations need to nurture and encourage as potential future leaders - are then lost to the corporation.

The Henley Incubator helps to solve this dilemma, as a corporate incubator. It is aimed at "intrapreneurs" who can see a new wealth-creating business opportunity inside their own organisation.

Organisations can benefit by releasing the potential business ideas of their employees and so retaining and effectively managing the best talent.

A corporate incubator captures and recreates the birth of an enterprise buzz within the company. It can help to create a new dynamic in a company and develop a culture in which original thinking is encouraged and supported. It allows risk-taking and experimentation, with managers positively re-directing their corporate frustration in a way that will benefit the company.

It can provide a low-risk, low-cost solution to enabling the best employees to explore new ideas outside the core business for the long-term health of the company. The company demonstrates its support for the individual, enhancing loyalty and retention. At any point, it can take a stake in the new business, bring it inside or walk away.

BT Brightstar is a good example of one such corporate incubator which is rapidly creating new value for the parent company. It has launched a project for corporate start-ups where a group of BT people has a patent or an idea so powerful that the team wants to give them a chance to work this up internally.

"We nurture them through the early stages," says BT Brightstar's Harry Berry. "The power of it being internally incubated is that they don't have to re-mortgage the house straight away - they can grow the concept within BT and at the end of the exercise they get some asset value if it works and so does BT."

To promote the idea, Henley Incubator launched a competition. The most creative and innovative new business idea wins a personal IBM T21 ThinkPad, provided by the main sponsor IBM, and an investment of up to £20,000 in management support for the idea.

Winning ideas must radically improve a business process, provide new ways of leveraging an organisation's expertise or make original use of a customer or contact base. Entries must be submitted by April 22 on forms provided on the Henley Incubator website www.henley-incubator.com.

 Andy Gaule is chief executive of Henley Incubator, based at Henley Management College

fields.headline: WWF urges managers to recycle used ink cartridges
fields.trailText: The World Wildlife Fund, the global conservation organisation, has joined forces with UK company Exy Group to encourage the recycling of printer cartridges.
fields.body:
The World Wildlife Fund, the global conservation organisation, has joined forces with UK company Exy Group to encourage the recycling of printer cartridges.

WWF is urging office managers to take up the offer from Exy Group's recycling arm Office Green, which will organise free collection from its offices. Exy group's manufacturing business IT Image, then strips and rebuilds the exhausted toner and ink cartridges to be resold at around 25% less than the original manufacturer's price.

People can also deliver spent cartridges to small charities, which will receive a donation of up to £40 for every 20 empty cartridges that it gives to the company.

The Office Green collection service will also pick up clapped-out office machines of all types, and fluorescent light tubes. For details, freephone: 0800-833-480 or visit www.officegreen.co.uk.

Almost half of Europe's employing organisations use information and communications technologies to carry out work at a distance, according to a pioneering survey by the Institute for Employment Studies of 18 European countries.

Peter Johnson, head of the new methods of work unit in the Information Society's Directorate General of the European Commission, says: "Relocation of work is one of the most striking features of the emerging knowledge economy. It is vital that we understand and monitor this change for the benefit of all Europeans in access to new jobs and in their ability to better balance work and social commitments." For details: www.emergence.nu. Unum, a leading income protection insurer, this week launched a national campaign to improve workplace opportunities for disabled people. Unum believes that a co-ordinated and sustained national approach by the government, the voluntary sector and industry could help a third of the UK's 750,000 unemployed disabled people into the workplace by 2010.

Lawrence Churchill, chairman of Unum, says: "Achieving greater social inclusion and economic participation for disabled people has been a shared aim for the past 20 years, yet it is difficult to find evidence to indicate that this ambition has been realised, or that any significant progress has been made at all."

fields.headline: Send the right signals
fields.trailText: Adrian Ashworth is a London-based television subtitler and a self-confessed late-starter on the career ladder, having worked in various seasonal jobs before taking a degree course in his mid-twenties.
fields.body:
Adrian Ashworth is a London-based television subtitler and a self-confessed late-starter on the career ladder, having worked in various seasonal jobs before taking a degree course in his mid-twenties. This presented certain problems with writing a CV when he first graduated - he did not want to come across as a drifter - but these receded as he gained a track record.

Having been at both the sending and the receiving end of job applications, Mr Ashworth, 35, is convinced that as you gain experience, so your CV should be stripped down. What may be appropriate for a school or college leaver - those lists of achievements and hobbies to differentiate yourself from all the others in the same boat -starts to look embarrassing once you are past 30.

"Who needs to know that you swam 25 metres breast-stroke at primary school?" he said. "I once had a CV from someone who said he could play Blackbird by the Beatles on the guitar. I felt like writing back, 'If you could play Mother Nature's Son the job would be yours'."

A word of warning: some of the worst CVs Mr Ashworth has seen, those with two-page essays detailing every aim and ambition, often went down well with the directors of his last company. "It was a case of recognition - they'd think: 'That's what I was like 20 years ago'."

Mr Ashworth also feels you can send out misleading signals by leaving out your age or family details. "The employer starts to think age is a problem for you - and then it becomes a problem." Similarly, it is hard to second guess what an employer will make of your parental status: three children, for instance, may count against you with some employers, but others will see it as a sign of stability.

Val Ashby, who teaches design and French to teenagers in Oxford, is facing burn-out after 13 years in the teaching profession, and wants to change direction. So far she has sent out her CV to various employers on spec, without any success.

For her, total honesty in the CV is of paramount importance. She has two young children and wants to work part time until the youngest reaches school age - and there is not much point in hiding this aim. "I don't want to put myself in a position where I am under more stress," she says.

Before teaching Ms Ashby worked in marketing and the travel industry, in a culture where it was normal for staff to be at their desks until 7 or later in the evening. "It was like a competition, but I just can't play those games now."

What she wants in her new career is something that builds on the skills she has as a teacher, rather than starting from scratch at the bottom, and that can engage her passion and commitment in the way that teaching once did.

Fields she has explored so far include careers advice, personal development and project development within the education sector.

webTitle: Fashion degree was the reel thing

fields.headline: Fashion degree was the reel thing
fields.standfirst: Cathryn Avison combined her unique style of embroidery with clothes making; and her new collection is all the rage. Michael Edmands met her
fields.trailText: Cathryn Avison combined her unique style of embroidery with clothes making; and her new collection is all the rage. Michael Edmands met her
fields.body:
From a tiny workshop in the countryside town of Midhurst, West Sussex, practically single-handed, Cathryn Avison is turning out fashion clothing that's in demand from South Molton Street in London to New York and Colorado.

Making room at one of the sewing machines in her studio by shifting her mother, who is ironing, Ms Avison says: "Because of the nature of my work, there cannot be many involved. I draw with a sewing machine. The thread is both my paint and my colour. Before I start my embroidery, it's very like a painter facing an empty canvas and, like the painting of a particular artist, it's hard to copy and difficult to find skilled labour to help."

Born in Newcastle in 1969, she still counts herself a member of the Toon Army, as members of United's supporters are known, although she moved to Cumbria at an early age and attended grammar school. By the time she was 14, she had her mind set on going to art college. "My father was an architect, ['a failed one', mother interjects], while mum loved her garden. I loved drawing and painting and was accepted at Carlisle Arts College," she says.

When she was 18, she was accepted on a degree course at the University of Ulster in Belfast. "I just loved it there and really I couldn't have coped with London at the time," she says. But it wasn't long before she headed south, clutching a first in embroidery.

"I ended up staying with a friend in Richmond, Surrey, which was a bit of a compromise I suppose," she says. She worked part-time in a clothes shop and was also a dresser at Richmond Theatre.

However, she says: "It was a terrible time to have just graduated, but I had a first-class degree and bags of confidence in my own ability and I applied and got into the Royal College of Art.

"This turned out to be my big break, since a customer had seen my work at a display of Irish fashion in Berkeley Square put on by the University of Ulster. The customer introduced me to Professor John Miles at the Royal College and he invited me to do a Master of Fashion degree," she says.

"I was a guinea pig because I had been working in textiles, that's what they call embroidery, and now I was to add fashion when at that time I didn't even know how to make a dress.

"It was unheard of for someone with a textile background to move into fashion, but this was the chance that the college was giving me," she says. It was a chance she took with both hands. She was chosen to show her graduate collection in the window of Browns on South Molton Street. In 1995, she was only the third graduate to be granted that opportunity.

She works in rich velvets and fine silks, chiffons and organza, all enhanced with elegant embroidery. Her designs have a very English look. She calls it feminine without being "girly". She prefers muted colours such as dusky pink, jade green and creams.

On the wall of her tiny workshop are her paintings of flowers and leaves, including lilies, inspirations for her embroidery. Since the dresses are all hand-made, the process takes several days.

After her debut at Browns, from then on it snowballed, she says. In 1996, she was awarded a place at London Fashion Week and the following year some of her work was included in the Victoria and Albert Museum's The Cutting Edge - 50 Years of British Fashion. "I was immensely proud to be part of that show," she says, "alongside my heroes Mary Quant and John Galliano." But Ms Avison is no slouch either; her clients now include Jennifer Aniston, Patsy Kensit, Cate Blanchett and Jemima Khan.

Following last month's London Fashion Week, Ms Avison reports, Barney's of New York are putting in orders. "They looked at my new collection and they liked it," she says. "My dresses are expensive at £900, but you are paying for my design and ideas as well as time and effort. I'm also ripped off more than usual because I'm so innovative."

For the new season she is working with denim and chiffon designs. "It is bolder and more modern but also scary and drastic," she says, "but the orders are starting to roll in."

Jemima Khan, sharing the next booth at the show, has expressed an interest, as has Nuages in Aspen, Colorado. Come to think of it, Jane Austen wouldn't have looked bad in them either.

fields.headline: Capital letters
fields.trailText: Have I been ripped off at cashpoint?
fields.body:
Have I been ripped off at cashpoint?

NatWest and the other banks now boast that there are no more cash machine charges. But despite this, when I used an ATM a few weeks ago, I was charged £1.50. On top of that, they also hit me with a 39p interest penalty.

It's not a lot of money but added up across the entire NatWest customer base, it adds up to a pretty penny for some banker. Have I been ripped off?
CL, Chester

No. You've had to pay the £1.89 because you used your NatWest credit card to access the cash rather than a debit card such as Switch or Connect. Credit cards always charge a percentage of the sum involved if you withdraw cash rather than pay for goods, because you are borrowing rather than withdrawing money which is yours.

In fact, you are lucky to have NatWest plastic. They charge 1.5% - First Direct imposes 1.75% and the Co-op Bank 2%. Many also have a higher minimum payment - £2 at Boots and Capital One, £2.50 at Goldfish and Marbles, and a staggering £5 at Budgens.

You are also likely to pay a higher interest rate for cash - in your case, the card charges 19.4% on purchases and 21.2% on cash. And most cards ignore special "come-on" rates for cash.

Would I miss out on any windfall?

Last week, I took money out of my Nationwide savings account to pay for a holiday. The balance dropped below £100 for the first time in years, although I shall make a sizeable deposit at the end of the month.

Does this mean I'll miss out on a windfall if the Nationwide converts?
MB, Edinburgh

You have lost some membership rights, such as the ability to nominate a director or back a resolution. These depend on having at least £100 for two years. But provided the £100 is restored by April 4, you will be able to vote in the July election when an anti-mutuality director could stand. Nationwide maintains its mutuality stance and won't discuss contingency plans for any change. But based on other conversions, it seems likely that you would get a payout, although no two have used the same rules.

Shopping around for a new lender

I currently have a 50% mortgage on a shared ownership property with Portman Building Society. My fixed rate has expired and I am shopping around for a new deal. But when I started three years ago, there were only a few banks and building societies providing loans for this way of buying a home. Can you suggest how I might find out what deals are on offer short of phoning every lender in the phone book?
PC, North-west London

You are right in suggesting that there are not many lenders in this market. The best source is Moneyfacts magazine - available at larger libraries - which lists 17 banks and building societies, including the Portman.

The biggest names involved are Abbey National, Nationwide and Woolwich, but there are also some smaller building societies such as Kent Reliance or Saffron Walden.

Some will lend you the entirety of your share; others demand a 5% to 10% deposit, again calculated on your side of the deal. Most offer the entire range of fixed, capped or discounted loans but some insist on the standard variable rate.

Approach the Portman, too, before deciding. It has a number of loans that might be suitable. And sticking with your existing lender will involve less hassle and cost.

We welcome letters but cannot answer individually. Write to: Capital Letters, Jobs & Money, the Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER or email jobs.and.money@theguardian.com. Do not send original documents but do enclose a daytime phone number. Information is general and offered without any legal responsibility. Always take professional advice if in doubt.

fields.headline: Cash 18-30
fields.trailText: Tony Lord graduated last year and is working for his former university as a welfare officer. Although he is planning to apply for a (relatively well-paid) job in recruitment when his contract runs out in July, he is currently earning £9,500, and has, as he says, "rather large debts".
fields.body:
The problem

Tony Lord graduated last year and is working for his former university as a welfare officer. Although he is planning to apply for a (relatively well-paid) job in recruitment when his contract runs out in July, he is currently earning £9,500, and has, as he says, "rather large debts".

These are £1,850 in overdrafts (owed to HSBC and Smile) and £1,500 to credit card companies (HSBC and Egg), a graduate loan of £4,500 and student loans totalling £6,000. His assets are 40p in an Egg savings account and shares worth around £8.

"I have the prospects of getting a fairly good job next year, but my priorities are to reduce my debt and sort out my cashflow. I always end up with no money in the last week before pay day," he says.

The solution

Our experts agree that Tony is in a difficult situation. Bringing debts together under one low-cost roof seems to be the best way to pare down interest payments on debts until he is earning more.

1 Credit cards are the scourge of modern day society. I would say that one of the basic differences between those that have successful financial lives and those that don't is credit cards or loans. I enjoy getting my clients into the situation where they cut their card in two and the account is closed.

You need to work on your philosophy and attitude to money and I suggest that you read Get Out of Debt and Prosper by Peter Cutler or Debt free Living by Burkett and Tondeur.
Alan Moran, Interface Financial Planning

2 However Tony arranges his finances, money will be tight simply because he has accrued debt and is on a very low income. Tony should keep the student loan in deferment until his income increases next year, when he can start repayments.

He should maintain repayments of £82.92 a month to the HSBC loan, as the interest rate appears to be very low. And Tony needs to consolidate the Egg, Smile and HSBC credit card balances into a personal loan of £1,900 with the Na tionwide, repayable over seven years at a monthly cost of £30.94 (without insurance).

He should not repay the HSBC overdraft as this is on 0% interest and can be repaid later when Tony's income increases.

Including rent and council tax, this would see his mon- thly outgoings at £442.86. I've calculated that his net income is £658, leaving him £215.14 a month to live on.
Ian Hart, Timothy James & Partners

3 I'm afraid there's not too much I can do for this client. As he has the prospect of a better job next year, all he can really do in the meantime is to ensure he is paying as little interest as possible on his borrowings.

He should consider consolidating both credit card balances into one account charging lower interest. There are a couple of cards he could consider: Boots Advantage Visa (internet only), which charges 10.9% on balance transfers plus 0% on new purchases for the first six months, or the Capital One card, which charges a fixed rate of 7.9% on balance transfers.

In the short term I suggest he speaks to his HSBC manager to enquire if he can defer repayments on his graduate loan, as he has done with his student loan, until his income improves.
Jim Gillespie, Independent Financial Services

fields.headline: Stand up and be counted
fields.standfirst: Quiet little character drama You Can Count On  Me has turned Hollywood on to Mark Ruffalo -  and now he's getting parts in loud action  movies
fields.trailText: Quiet little character drama You Can Count On Me has turned Hollywood on to Mark Ruffalo - and now he's getting parts in loud action movies
fields.body:
Mark Ruffalo is on the up. After years of toil in the theatre, the brooding 33-year-old has broken into the public consciousness with an acclaimed turn as Laura Linney's directionless sibling in You Can Count On Me. US critics are hailing Ruffalo as the new Brando, and producers are taking notice - the film has led to, among other things, a supporting part in John Woo's second world war thriller, Windtalkers, and to a leading role opposite Robert Redford in The Castle. It has been a struggle, but at last Mark Ruffalo is standing at the brink of stardom.

How difficult has it been getting this far?

I've had a very difficult time, and actually quit at least four or five times. I did 30 plays in Los Angeles and yet I couldn't get a job. I thought, 'I've done all this work, why isn't it paying off?' That really starts to hurt your self-image, and I already had a questionable self-image coming into the game. I was really insecure and I didn't particularly like myself very much.

You seem to be making up for that lack of work now. Where does your drive come from?

Maybe it's a fear that I don't have much time to fill up and I have to put as much in as I can now. Also, I feel creatively quickened at the moment, really creatively alive. Artists have spurts of very creative times in their careers and I know better now that when you're on that wave, you should just take it and ride it.

So, what exactly has You Can Count On Me done for your career so far?

It's blown the doors off. It's put me on the map. It turns out that people just needed to be told about me. You can be the best actor in the world but unless something like this happens, you're not going to get the jobs. Certainly there are actors out there who should be working their asses off because they are 100 times better than 90 per cent of today's movie stars; they just haven't had a break that made them known to the public world on a big scale. You Can Count On Me did that for me.

Working with John Woo must have been a totally different experience to YCCOM. Did you get much action in?

I ended up doing a lot of action. I don't know how my body stayed in any athletic form in the debauched theatre scene, but I could immediately do the things that he was asking. I was running and jumping, throwing grenades, getting blown up, doing hand-to-hand combat. Basically, it was what I did when I was a kid. It was great fun.

Acting-wise, the demands must be very different.

You don't really have to act when there's a bomb going off next to you. After a five-gallon gasoline explosion went off behind me, I just went flying to the ground, scared shitless. I realised then that I'd wasted all that money and all that time on acting classes.

Has this left you hungry to do more work in Hollywood?

John Woo is the least Hollywood person you could imagine. He's family-oriented, he's a loving, gentle human being, and he respects the hell out of actors. Now I've not had to work with Michael Bay, but I get a feeling that Michael Bay and the Jerry Bruckheimer machine is much more harsh and impersonal. That makes me a little nervous. Ultimately, though, unless someone is outrageously horrible to me when I meet them, the material will decide whether I do the work.

fields.headline: Villains of the Peace
fields.standfirst:
Hollywood has a dilemma -
which foreign stereotype should play the bad
guy next? Andrew Mueller casts around for
some worthy contenders
fields.trailText: Hollywood has a dilemma - which foreign stereotype should play the bad guy next? Andrew Mueller casts around for some worthy contenders
fields.body:
The Afghans

Afghanistan's rulers, the perennially zany Taliban, may well point to the favour they performed for the free world in the 80s by dishing out a spectacular thrashing to the Soviet military, but what have they done for us lately? The Taliban have an abundance of the qualities that will have audiences from Montana to Alabama hiding behind their seats: an unswerving religious conviction, an unholy capacity for violence, more heavy weaponry than most American fifth forms, and terrifying connections - top international fugitive Osama bin-Laden is believed to live somewhere outside Jalalabad. A possible screen debut could see the Taliban's recent demolition of the giant Buddhas of Bamiyan relocated to the Statue of Liberty - hey, if the facts of what happened in 1942 or 1776 don't matter, neither do the facts of last week.

The Chechens

Granted, the considerable and formidable annoyance of this proud warrior breed is currently directed largely at Tony Blair's drinking partner Vladimir Putin, who has pulverised this budding nation and slaughtered thousands of its people on pretexts that most of us wouldn't have dared submit as an explanation for an overdue maths assignment. But it wouldn't be stretching credibility too far to suggest that the Chechens might also be somewhat miffed with the west for not giving two hoots.

The Colombians

The success of Traffic and Proof Of Life indicates that Americans are over any lingering guilt about the mess they made in Central and South America in the 70s and 80s, but there is much unexplored mileage in Colombia. A goodly swathe of the country is run by amusingly acronymed guerilla army FARC (Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia), 80% of the 300 tons of cocaine that Americans hoover up every year is grown there, and the US government has just assigned US$1.3bn to train Colombian counter-narcotics forces, equip the military and conduct the sorts of airborne defoliation missions which were such a rousing success in Vietnam. Either a setting for Oliver Stone's next conspiracy theory potboiler or inspiration for a thriller about a sinister Latin genius with a huge moustache who commands a private army of mutant babies on crack.

The French

There is, perhaps, a slight credibility problem attendant to the idea of French cinematic evil: any moviegoer with the most rudimentary knowledge of 20th-century history will spend the whole film wondering why the forces of good don't simply put on a German helmet and affect a vaguely threatening demeanour, as that usually does the trick. If this glitch can be overcome, there is ample material here: fondnesses for sinking civilian boats in foreign harbours, blasting tropical islands out of the water, chucking their rattles out of their prams if anyone else tries to call their own fizzy drinks "champagne", doing unspeakable things to geese and helping various put-upon African nations into the abyss. Studio executives who doubt the populist wisdom of this tack need only remind themselves of the raucous joy with which London cinema audiences greeted the demolition of Paris in Armageddon.

The Albanians

There really is no pleasing some people. After deploying the air power of NATO to bomb the new Albanian state of Kosovo into existence, the west finds itself policing a shambolic criminal state whose resident mafiosi, and their pet paramilitaries, are tiring of their occupiers. As if that wasn't enough, khaki-clad Albanian brigands are now at large outside Kosovo's borders, attempting to create free and independent republics of From This Tree Here To That Rock Over There. From the studios' point of view, the region has the advantage of having had so much publicity that most Americans should have at least a vague idea of where it is. Whether or not their new president is among them is uncertain at time of writing.

The Americans In fairness, Americans are not averse to giving themselves a going-over on film: in recent memory, Hollywood has suggested, probably quite correctly, that Richard Nixon was a half-mad drunk (Nixon), that Bill Clinton was a lecherous, amoral creep (Primary Colors), that the Gulf War was a cynical charade (Three Kings) and that America's entire political process is a ghastly burlesque of the comprehensively corrupt performing for the irredeemably stupid (Wag The Dog, Bulworth). A jolly good start, but there's much further to go. There has not yet been the definitive cinematic examination of the menace posed to America and all who sail in her by the private militias of squirrel-eating inbreeds who lurk in the backwoods, or by spotty Marilyn Manson fans with rifles up their trenchcoats, or by a military now apparently doing a sideline in joyrides for tourists. Coming soon, Sub For Hire: a cross between Das Boot and Herbie Goes Bananas. Just when you thought it was safe to go back in the water.

fields.headline: Et cetera
fields.standfirst: Steven Poole reviews Being Good by Simon Blackburn, On Playing the Flute by Johann Joachim Quantz and The Spark of Life by Christopher Wills
fields.trailText: Steven Poole reviews Being Good by Simon Blackburn, On Playing the Flute by Johann Joachim Quantz and The Spark of Life by Christopher Wills
fields.body:
Being Good Simon Blackburn
Oxford
£9.99
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Is the study of ethics a useful pursuit, or is it all just made-up metaphysical noodling? Aren't ethical rules just arbitrary social conventions? Blackburn has noticed that people these days indolently assume ethical claims to be a "sham", a diaphanous robe for naked self-interest or an institutional cloak for power. So he has organised his estimably slender introduction to the subject around just such objections - those of atheists, egoists, determinists and relativists. (Getting a particularly welcome slapping are the kind of evolutionary scientists who seek to explain away ethical concepts by appeals to genetic programming.) Blackburn approaches subjects likely to be of interest to the normal reader - abortion, justice, "human rights" and so on - in a sparklingly clear, pleasurably dry tone. Smug Rortean ironists and mad-eyed Foucauldians won't like it, but anyone else should.

On Playing the Flute
Johann Joachim Quantz trans & ed Edward R Reilly
Faber
£16.99
Buy it at a discount at BOL

"It seems as if the majority of flute players today have fingers and tongues, to be sure, but are deficient in brains," complains Quantz in this classic text from 1752. He also offers his judgments on what is "good taste" in music generally, dispensing practical wisdom to singers and sections of the orchestra, and notes on public performance. (Choose your programme according to your audience's humour: "majestic and serious pieces" for choleric persons, chromatic and minor-key pieces for melancholics.) The irascible author is as entertainingly disdainful of egotistical virtuosos ("some fantastic dunces among the Italian singers") as he is of ignorant amateurs. In among the anecdotal nuggets is Quantz's offhand reference to having seen J S Bach play the harpsichord: the great man's fingers slid admirably off the keys. Not a mere scholarly curiosity, but a fruitful browse for anyone who likes baroque music.

The Spark of Life

Christopher Wills & Jeffrey Bada

Oxford

£8.99
Buy it at a discount at BOL

"Waiter, there's a fly in my primordial soup." "How the hell did that get there?" Indeed: the question of why inanimate stuff in the choking hot mud of early Earth suddenly decided to organise itself into living stuff is a hard one. The authors examine the best guesses so far, from DNA seeding by Martian meteorites to mysterious reactions deep in volcanic vents. Their own favoured hypothesis has a quasi-Darwinian "sorting-out process" combining organic molecules to make a rudimentary self-replicating lifeform on a beach. How? Um, we still don't know. The book has a pleasing narrative of detection, and the final speculations on extraterrestrial life are bracing. Sadly, you can't make life in a lab yet, even with a melodramatic Frankensteinian leer and a big lightning machine. It's fun to try, though, isn't it?
fields.bodyText: Being Good Simon Blackburn Oxford £9.99 Buy it at a discount at BOL Is the study of ethics a useful pursuit, or is it all just made-up metaphysical noodling? Aren't ethical rules just arbitrary social conventions? Blackburn has noticed that people these days indolently assume ethical claims to be a "sham", a diaphanous robe for naked self-interest or an institutional cloak for power. So he has organised his estimably slender introduction to the subject around just such objections - those of atheists, egoists, determinists and relativists. (Getting a particularly welcome slapping are the kind of evolutionary scientists who seek to explain away ethical concepts by appeals to genetic programming.) Blackburn approaches subjects likely to be of interest to the normal reader - abortion, justice, "human rights" and so on - in a sparklingly clear, pleasurably dry tone. Smug Rortean ironists and mad-eyed Foucauldians won't like it, but anyone else should. Hear an extract
You will need RealPlayer to listen to this clip. You can download it here free.
fields.trailText: A Sea of Troubles by Donna Leon Hear a RealAudio clip
fields.body: Two clam fisherman are murdered on the Venetian lagoon. Being Italy, the first question is: which police force will pick up the case? Then the hard bit. People don't talk to cops, or not openly. Comissario Brunetti, in his 10th adventure, placidly accepts the futility of seeking witnesses. It's all to be done by family contacts and calling in dodgy favours. Lunch is part of it, too. American fictional cops swill in their cars from polystyrene buckets, Brits save their lunch money for the pub, but your Italian 'tec plans everything around a decent restaurant three-courser with trimmings. Then there is the old-fashioned formality and observance of titles within the Italian force. No American contempt or British bolshiness. Leon conjures a Venetian atmosphere that just about survives abridgement. Andrew Sachs reads with a capuccino mildness that is apt for a light and diverting thriller.

webTitle: Reviews: Life Stories and Why Elephants Have Big Ears

fields.headline: Non-fiction
fields.standfirst: John Dugdale reviews Life Stories by David Remnick and Why Elephants Have Big Ears by Chris Lavers
fields.trailText: John Dugdale reviews Life Stories by David Remnick and Why Elephants Have Big Ears by Chris Lavers
fields.body:
Life Stories
ed David Remnick
Pavilion
£12.99

Buy it at a discount at BOL

The New Yorker coined the term "profile" and pioneered the form. Gathering together examples from every decade of its 75-year history, this superb selection fields a fantasy team of interviewers including A J Liebling, Lillian Ross, Truman Capote, Ken Tynan, Janet Malcolm and Mark Singer. Although David Remnick modestly avers that his anthology contains no "hidden lessons", it clearly does: in an era when those profiled tend to be on the way up, the portraits here of, say, Hemingway, Brando and Roseanne show that catching icons after they've peaked can be far more compelling. I'll be amazed if anyone produces a more enjoyable book all year.

Why Elephants Have Big Ears
Chris Lavers
Phoenix
£7.99

Buy it at a discount at BOL

Watching David Attenborough's wildlife series as a child, Chris Lavers found the great whispering ringmaster's failure to "grapple with the really obvious questions" - why, for example, are there so few big reptiles based on land, or big mammals in rivers and lakes? - perplexing and frustrating. After 25 years of "intellectual groping", the Nottingham University geography lecturer reckons he's solved some of the puzzles, and his answers (as in the case of the elephant's ears) tend to revolve around fuel consumption and body heat. Engagingly self-mocking, Lavers strikes a canny balance between buttonholing colloquialism and scientific rigour.

fields.headline: Fiction
fields.standfirst: Isobel Montgomery reviews To the Hermitage by Malcolm Bradbury, Blackberry Wine, by Joanne Harris, The Man Who Rode Ampersand by Ferdinand Mount and Five Miles from Outer Hope by Nicola Barker
fields.trailText: Isobel Montgomery reviews To the Hermitage by Malcolm Bradbury, Blackberry Wine, by Joanne Harris, The Man Who Rode Ampersand by Ferdinand Mount and Five Miles from Outer Hope by Nicola Barker
fields.body:
To the Hermitage
Malcolm Bradbury
Picador
£6.99
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Unhappily, what turned out to be Bradbury's last novel comes with valedictory prefaces from his friend, David Lodge, and his student, Ian McEwan, that lend an air of solemnity to a fleet-footed, humorous piece of historical fiction. In his own preface Bradbury tells us he will play Baron Haussman with people and geography. Thus he sends Enlightement philosopher Denis Diderot to the court of Catherine the Great and keeps a bunch of modern academics at sea for an unfeasibly long 250 page ferry trip from Stockholm to St Petersburg. Bradbury's digressions do not make for a trim read, but his historical and contemporary tableaux vivants always amuse.

Blackberry Wine
Joanne Harris
Black Swan
£6.99
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Jay Mackintosh is a blocked writer living, unsatisfactorily, with the slightly shrewish Kelly. He hasn't written a decent sentence in years until the day he opens a bottle of home-brewed blackberry wine that invokes Proustian remembrances and renewed creative impulses. Narrated by a bottle of 1962 Fleurie, Blackberry Wine alternates between Jay's childhood adventures on a Yorkshire allotment tilled by Joe, ex-miner, adventurer and wine-maker, and his decision to up sticks for Lansquenet, that fantastical French village where another of Harris inventions runs a sweetshop. Thickly sensuous, wildly indulgent magical escapism: Chocolat lovers will drink deeply.

The Man Who Rode Ampersand
Ferdinand Mount
Vintage
£6.99
Buy it at a discount at BOL

This first part of Mount's "Chronicle of Modern Twilight" has been republished to coincide with the appearance of Fairness, the fifth instalment. Mount, when not delving into history, is a keen observer of the post-war Englishman in gentle decline, and a wonderfully slow-paced descriptive writer. Harry, an amateur jockey who once rode Ampersand to Gold Cup victory, now lives from pub to pub and from bet to bet. As he falls further into his cups, his son, Aldous, watches on with amused, occasionally shocked, detachment. There is nothing attention-grabbing about Mount's style, but that is its dependable charm.

Five Miles from Outer Hope
Nicola Barker
Faber
£6.99
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Medve is a six-foot-plus lump of adolescent angst who lives in a half-derelict art-deco hotel off the Devon coast. She is full of tricks and tropes as she describes the summer of 1981 when Soft Cell were in the charts and a ginger-haired stranger turned up in her life. Yes, this is a coming-of-age novel, but Barker gets away with her retelling. Medve is not just physically huge, but also full of the hyperbole that makes teenage feelings and reactions so disproportionate. Sharing her pop culture references does help, but her perversity, bad temper and weird, distorted view of the world, contain immediately recognisable features.

fields.headline: Crime pays in the city of angels
fields.standfirst: Robert Crais tells Nick Hasted how he came to live the American dream
fields.trailText: Robert Crais tells Nick Hasted how he came to live the American dream
fields.body:
Robert Crais arrived in LA as a stranger in 1976, carrying with him the writing ambitions that had marked him as a misfit in his family of cops and chemical-factory workers, in the blue-collar Louisiana town of Baton Rouge. Teleplays claimed him for a decade - episodes of Cagney and Lacey , Miami Vice , Hill Street Blues (for which he was Emmy-nominated), LA Law and more. But it's the 10 LA crime novels he has written since 1987 that have established him as the most mythically minded yet concrete observer of the city in his genre since Chandler.

While James Ellroy maps LA's secret history, Crais charts today's media-manipulable law and venal Hollywood. In L.A. Requiem (1999), a dark tale of death, childhood brutalisation and betrayal, he also finds room for urban wonder: baking heat flinging up burnt forests as ash to rain down on the city; desert settlements so hot the inhabitants can't move; hidden parks that once housed missile silos; mountainside vistas that give Crais's private eye Elvis Cole hope, even as his life crumbles.

"My Los Angeles is different to Chandler's," Crais says. "It's more ethnically diverse now, there are places which are purely Chinese, Vietnamese, Lithuanian. But it always has been a feeding ground where people from all over the world come, hungry to reach their dreams. And any time you have so many people risking so much, there's a potential for crisis, and crime. Not everybody wins the race. People search for an identity here, and often they fail, and feel rootless, desperate. All of this in a place which physically, by its nature, moves. Here, you cannot even trust the ground beneath your feet."

Crais's first novel, The Monkey's Raincoat (1987), was on the surface a standard-issue private eye story, wisecracking, Hawaiian-shirted Vietnam veteran Cole solving the disappearance of a distressed pretty damsel's husband. But a wrenching moment when the man's little girl chats happily about her father to Cole (who knows he's dead), and the widow's numb inability to live by herself, were horribly personal.

"I had wanted to be a novelist for so long," Crais remembers, "but I didn't have a story. That story came from the death of my father, and wrestling with how to help my mother. Writing it allowed me to work through my fears, frustrations and desires. I wanted control over the situation. And I wasn't sure I would have any in real life. But through the character of Elvis Cole, I could exercise a measure of the control and resolution I wanted. He's me, idealised."

Cole's partner, the unsmiling, almost silent, fiercely loyal fellow veteran and supernaturally adept killer Joe Pike, is another side of Crais. Pike shoulders pressure, doesn't snap; neither does the hero of his new novel Desolation Angel : scarred, borderline alcoholic bomb squad detective Carol Starkey (it is his first without Cole and Pike).

"Joe Pike does embody some of my inner traits. His focus, his tattoos - red arrows, pointing forward - and what they mean, that you never back up. That's the way I've pursued my writing. Joe says: 'I don't like people with no will, no commitment, no pride.' I'm more tolerant than Joe. But I know that if you don't have those things, you are hampered."

Crais learned that discipline in his Baton Rouge youth, when he was viewed as a "Martian" as he blazed out stories, comics and Super-8 films with isolated intensity while his family waited for him to become an engineer.

He was influenced by crime fiction, and by seeing his police relatives as human beings (his books all sympathise with the LAPD). But science fiction freed his mind "in all directions", while the flawed, troubled superheroes in the early Marvel comics of Stan Lee and Steve Ditko deeply informed his own heroic fiction. And rugged individualist, right-wing SF writer Robert Heinlein reached his heart.

"Heinlein's male characters generally started as poor kids from shabby backgrounds, and they were able to rise above their past, not succumb to it. They worked hard, and achieved a certain competence.

"That was an important lesson to me. I modelled my life on it. I didn't have to stay where I was, do what my family did. I could move on, if I only applied myself."

The catalyst for Crais's transformation came in 1975, at the Clarion Writers' Workshop in Michigan. In this "boot camp for young writers", under the guidance of authors including revered SF veterans Gene Wolfe and Samuel R Delaney, he and 25 others were locked in a basement for days, subjected to "brutal" criticism, barely sleeping, exhaustion cracking their subconscious - a fittingly Pike-like test of his writing desire. The next year he was in Hollywood. Despite working for American TV's most brilliant writer-producers of the 1970s and 1980s - Hill Street Blues ' Steven Bochco, Miami Vice 's Michael Mann - he quit to be a novelist, tired of the "vampires" diluting his words.

Now he is a bestselling, wealthy man, happily married in the Santa Monica mountains (where Elvis Cole also lives). As it did for his Heinlein heroes, but doesn't for the failing criminals of his fiction, his journey to LA has ended in a waking American Dream.

"I know. I came here, and made it happen. LA's magic has let me see every level of the dream. It's this place, and what is possible here, that gives strength to Elvis, and me."

Read an extract from Demolition Angel
