webTitle: Review: Our Word is Our Weapon by Subcomandante Marcos

fields.headline: War of words
fields.standfirst: Peter Tatchell reviews Our Word is Our Weapon: Selected Writings by Subcomandante Marcos
fields.trailText: Peter Tatchell reviews Our Word is Our Weapon: Selected Writings by Subcomandante Marcos
fields.body:
Our Word Is Our Weapon: Selected Writings
Subcomandante Marcos, ed Juana Ponce de Léon
456pp, Serpent's Tail
£20

The title of this book sums up the great paradox of the Zapatista revolution: the EZLN guerrillas are armed to the teeth, but rarely fire a shot. Their principal weapons are words and ideas, rather than guns and bullets. This unorthodox strategy of non-violent warfare has created a once-unthinkable situation in which the Mexican state has felt obliged to begin negotiations on the long-neglected rights of 10m indigenous people.

The Zapatistas are clearly a very unusual group of revolutionaries. What other guerrilla army sees the battle for minds as more significant than the fight for territory? Our Word Is Our Weapon explains these postmodern insurrectionists, as articulated by their spokesman, Subcomandante Marcos. This anti-leader calls himself "subcomandante" because, he argues, the real comandante of the Zapatista struggle is the people; he is merely a conduit for their will.

We have heard such sentiments before, from other revolutionaries who ended up interpreting the people's will in tyrannical ways. But perhaps Marcos is different. His writings certainly feel a world away from the prescriptive texts of Marx, Lenin and Mao. For a start, they are often lyrical and humorous. They pose questions, rather than dictating answers. There is no grand theory, only a series of observations and reflections: novel ideas expressed with none of the dogma, arrogance and elitism that have so frequently blighted other revolutionary movements.

Sure, Marcos has his big idea: a moving, passionate critique of the new world order in which the neo-liberal politics of market economics and free trade condemns a third of the world's people to abject poverty - and frequently death. The next world war has, he suggests, already begun. It is a war of "money versus humanity", where the poor are trampled on "like weeds in the road - silenced, faceless, nameless". His recurrent theme is the struggle for democracy, justice and liberty in the southern Mexican state of Chiapas, which he sees as a metaphor for the global battle against all forms of social exclusion and oppression. He likens these struggles to an echo that does not fade but "breaks barriers and re-echoes" from the "local and particular" to the "intercontinental and galactic".

These writings are an engagingly eclectic compilation of conference speeches, military communiqués, news releases and open letters, interspersed with poems, short stories, allegories and folk legends. This is politics with a human face, and you sense immediately that Marcos is no ordinary politician when you read his tales of "The Lime with an Identity Crisis" and "The Schizophrenic Pig". These simple fables are embedded with political messages that reflect the challenges and aspirations of dispossessed people everywhere. The narrative is Mexican, but the theme is universal.

Even the Subcomandante's hard-core political essays have a gentle, poetic quality, with titles like "Deep Inside the Cave of Desire" and "Flowers, Like Hope, Are Harvested". There is humour, too, including self-deprecating tales of misadventure. Marcos recalls one especially arduous guerrilla retreat in 1995 when, starving and thirsty, he and his companeros tried to drink their own urine and ended up vomiting all over their jungle campsite - leaving them even more hungry and dehydrated than before.

Such comedies aside, Our Word Is Our Weapon articulates a new and important grass roots: a participatory, non-hierarchical style of politics. It is not about seizing state power, but dissolving it. Marcos's goal is to make a political space for the empowerment of civil society. His politics is more a way of thinking than a specific doctrine.

"Zapatismo is not a party, nor a guerrilla force," writes Ana Carrigan in her afterword. "It is a catalyst, an instigator, a creator of possibilities. It provides a platform for the widest possible convergence of democratic forces, multi-ethnic, multiparty, multicultural . . . [to] return power to society." In this struggle, the means are as important as the ends, which is why Marcos styles his movement as a network. Eschewing traditional party organisation, he writes: "This network is not an organising structure, nor does it have a central head or decision maker, nor does it have a central command or hierarchies. We are the network, all of us who speak and listen." The Zapatista revolution, by and for an outcast people in a remote corner of a distant developing country, has much to teach us about the creation of a genuinely pluralist, inclusive democracy.

There is no grand theory, only a series of observations and reflections: novel ideas expressed with none of the dogma, arrogance and elitism that have so frequently blighted other revolutionary movements. Sure, Marcos has his big idea: a moving, passionate critique of the new world order in which the neo-liberal politics of market economics and free trade condemns a third of the world's people to abject poverty - and frequently death. The next world war has, he suggests, already begun. It is a war of "money versus humanity", where the poor are trampled on "like weeds in the road - silenced, faceless, nameless". His recurrent theme is the struggle for democracy, justice and liberty in the southern Mexican state of Chiapas, which he sees as a metaphor for the global battle against all forms of social exclusion and oppression. He likens these struggles to an echo that does not fade but "breaks barriers and re-echoes" from the "local and particular" to the "intercontinental and galactic". These writings are an engagingly eclectic compilation of conference speeches, military communiqués, news releases and open letters, interspersed with poems, short stories, allegories and folk legends. This is politics with a human face, and you sense immediately that Marcos is no ordinary politician when you read his tales of "The Lime with an Identity Crisis" and "The Schizophrenic Pig". These simple fables are embedded with political messages that reflect the challenges and aspirations of dispossessed people everywhere. The narrative is Mexican, but the theme is universal. Even the Subcomandante's hard-core political essays have a gentle, poetic quality, with titles like "Deep Inside the Cave of Desire" and "Flowers, Like Hope, Are Harvested". There is humour, too, including self-deprecating tales of misadventure. Marcos recalls one especially arduous guerrilla retreat in 1995 when, starving and thirsty, he and his companeros tried to drink their own urine and ended up vomiting all over their jungle campsite - leaving them even more hungry and dehydrated than before. Such comedies aside, Our Word Is Our Weapon articulates a new and important grass roots: a participatory, non-hierarchical style of politics. It is not about seizing state power, but dissolving it. Marcos's goal is to make a political space for the empowerment of civil society. His politics is more a way of thinking than a specific doctrine. "Zapatismo is not a party, nor a guerrilla force," writes Ana Carrigan in her afterword. "It is a catalyst, an instigator, a creator of possibilities. It provides a platform for the widest possible convergence of democratic forces, multi-ethnic, multiparty, multicultural . . . [to] return power to society." In this struggle, the means are as important as the ends, which is why Marcos styles his movement as a network. Eschewing traditional party organisation, he writes: "This network is not an organising structure, nor does it have a central head or decision maker, nor does it have a central command or hierarchies. We are the network, all of us who speak and listen." The Zapatista revolution, by and for an outcast people in a remote corner of a distant developing country, has much to teach us about the creation of a genuinely pluralist, inclusive democracy.

webTitle: Review: Trigger Happy: The Inner Life of Videogames by Steven Poole

fields.headline: Video stars
fields.standfirst: Nicholas Lezard  on the subtle pleasures of videogames in Trigger Happy: The Inner Life of Videogames by Steven Poole
fields.trailText: Nicholas Lezard on the subtle pleasures of videogames in Trigger Happy: The Inner Life of Videogames by Steven Poole
fields.body:
Trigger Happy: The Inner Life of Videogames

Steven Poole

Fourth Estate
£7.99

Buy it at a discount at BOL

I once made a gaffe in conversation with Martin Amis by suggesting that his clunkily titled appreciation of arcade space games, Invasion of the Space Invaders , was one of the best things he had written, and that it was remiss of him to have allowed it to go out of print. The expression on his face, with perhaps more pity in it than contempt, remains with me uncomfortably. Amis's book appeared in 1982, and there was much - such as the emergence of visually complex games playable on cheap, powerful home consoles - that was hardly detectable in the pipeline.

As there are many who are anxious about the effect of videogames, and their accelerating technology, on ourselves and our children, it pays to be up-to-date in these matters, and Steven Poole's book is timely indeed. And, as those of you who are familiar with his work for these pages should hardly need to be told, it is very intelligent, and very well written and witty.

There is a rumour - scarcely creditable, I know - that the publishers placed some pressure on Poole to deliver a more personal testament, a kind of Fever Pitch about his love of videogames. That may have been entertaining but it wouldn't have done anyone any good, or contributed to the debate. For a debate there is, as there should be when the videogame industry, in brute financial terms, leaves every other entertainment form on the planet more or less standing still.

Those whose interest in the form is either marginal or historic (ah, those endless games of Battlezone and Defender - the absolute monarch of the genre - in the old college games room; so much more rewarding than studying for a mere degree) need not be put off by Poole's analyses of Resident Evil, Crash Bandicoot, or Metal Gear Solid, or other games which he or she suspects of being an awful waste of time, and bad for the eyes to boot. He inspects the idea of the videogame right from its origins - indeed, back to its origins in the very idea of play itself. It is particularly winning of him, I feel, to make such a point of unpacking the Greek etymologies that are behind so much of the gaming and programming vocabularies. Moreover, this is a book which considers it important not only to articulate precisely why it is so much fun to play Tekken 3, but to remind us that the idea of virtual geometry is surprisingly close to Plato's ideas in the Timaeus on the reducibility of the universe to geometrical shapes based on the first four whole numbers.

If the book has a problem, it is that the serenity and intelligence of Poole's own mind has allowed him to stray too far into thinking that videogames are either harmless or beneficial. In his drive to reassurance, he misses out in some degree on acknowledging the alienation, the paradoxical sterility of the videogame experience, the way that while offering the illusion of control, everything about it is, so to speak, out of your hands. Not that this is a problem he doesn't address. I can't think of one he doesn't.

"Academically worthy, thoroughly contemporary and eminently readable," said a magazine called Arcade of this book - and with a name like that, I imagine they know what they're talking about.

webTitle: Review: Tunnel Visions by Christopher Ross

fields.headline: Notes from underground
fields.standfirst: Gary Younge reviews Tunnel Visions by Christopher Ross and Subterranean City by Antony Clayton
fields.trailText: Gary Younge descends into London's nether regions to find a tube philosopher
fields.body:
Tunnel Visions: Journeys of an Underground Philosopher
Christopher Ross
192pp, Fourth Estate
£12

Subterranean City
Antony Clayton
192pp, Phillimore
£15.95
Buy it at a discount at BOL

In London it would be foolish to try to plan precisely how long it would take to go from A to B," writes wanderer, philosopher and underground station assistant Christopher Ross in Tunnel Visions . "In Tokyo all you need is a timetable of the local train and subway systems and an accurate watch. If your watch stops, you can reset it by the time of the next train to arrive. In London things do not work quite like that."

Tube systems are often metaphors for cities and cultures: you can tell as much about a place by what is going on several feet below the surface as you can in broad daylight. In Moscow you can map the political, ideological and stylistic course of Stalinism through the city's four main lines. Years after Stalin's death, the vast, ornately decorated stations were used by many youngsters, living in cramped communal flats with their parents, as a warm, dry place in which to court and flirt. The New York subways, where the Guardian Angels first spread their wings, once reflected the city's decay and paranoia. When Bernhard Goetz shot two black men in the 1980s, the "subway vigilante" became the touchstone of the city's key obsessions - crime, race and guns.

Meanwhile, take the first tube into town from south London on a weekday and you will see little else but the red eyes and black faces of men and women on their way to cleaning and catering jobs in the City. Get the same train a few hours later and it will be packed with mostly white-faced white- collar workers going to the offices they have just cleaned.

When it came to choosing our first elected mayor, the tube - underfunded, overpriced and overcrowded - was the central issue. Given the huge amount of capital needed to construct an underground system in the first place and the vast amounts needed to keep it going once it becomes an essential service, this is not surprising. "The most important thing about the evolution of the subway as a symbol," writes Michael W Brooks in Subway City , "is that it starts by expressing faith in the city's future and, once built, quickly becomes a handy rhetorical tool for expressing discontent with its present."

So the vantage point of a station assistant on platform six of Oxford Circus station is as good a place as any from which to observe humanity. But then Ross is not just any station assistant. He describes himself as "a philosopher . . . in search of truth". His previous employment includes "oriental carpet smuggler in Dubai; camel cowboy in Australian outback; Jesuit priest in a daytime Japanese television soap". Now he stands in an ugly uniform with his job title on a glowing orange vest, explaining train delays, checking fire extinguishers, chasing beggars, giving directions and coping with bomb scares while mulling over the following: "How might we best behave in various situations? How should we use our time? What duties, if any, were ours to fulfil? How can we say we know anything? Can we discover the purpose and potential of our lives?" The mix of lowly tasks and highbrow thoughts is strongly reminiscent of Robert M Pirsig's Zen and the Art of Motorcycle Maintenance . Both in style and content, this is an ambitious project treading a narrow path between the banal and the pretentious. But with the help of humour, contemplation and sensitivity, Ross has produced a truly brilliant book.

In the ill-fitting shoes of a station assistant, the world does start to look different. "The Central line's fine, it's the passageway - it's flooded," Ross incants to thousands of passengers. "Try repeating this continuously for two hours, with only the occasional break to answer someone asking, 'What the fuck?' or 'Call this a railway?'"

Every now and then it doesn't work; his tirade against begging Irish travellers, whom he describes as "overweight, sluttish women . . . loaded with soiled and drooling infants", is as offensive as it is unexpected. And what must have felt like deep insights at the time can become self-indulgent in print. The double question "is breakfast a measure of cross-cultural tolerance? If I can stomach your breakfast, and only then, can I sincerely say we may live together without fear?" sounds like a transcript from an interview between David Carradine and Richard and Judy.

But Ross has embarked on such an original literary journey - largely by staying still - that it would be churlish to expect the balance and perspective to be struck evenly throughout the book. His musings are, for the most part, both relevant and illuminating; his descriptions of his job, colleagues and passengers are always honest, sometimes funny and usually humane. His account of the suicide of a young homeless man surrounded by the conspicuous consumption of the Christmas season is particularly moving.

Through Ross we meet the random swathe of eccentrics that pass through the bowels of the capital. The man brought back to life by paramedics; the woman with the "ugliest baby" he has ever seen, which turns out to be a chimp in a nappy; the pet dog that is actually a tame fox. We learn that, on average, two people throw themselves in front of tubes every week; that there is a special squad to clear up the mess; and that green grapes are the number-one slip hazard - the underground's answer to the cartoon banana skin.

"The tube system is like the city's bricked-over tributary rivers," thinks the protagonist in Tobias Hill's first novel, Underground . "A network hidden under the surface and visible only sometimes, like the blue veins where they lie near skin." Subterranean City by Antony Clayton is a dogged, valiant attempt to get under London's skins. Whereas Ross chronicles human behaviour through the tube, Clayton takes a long hard look under the paving slabs and down the drains and maps a London few of us will ever see.

One would think there would be a limited market for a non-fiction book detailing the history and flow of London's sewage, people, power, gas, electricity and a whole lot else besides. But a book with an almost identical aim, London Under London: A Subterranean Guide by Richard Trench and Ellis Hillman, has been through two editions and four reprints since it was first published in 1984. Unfortunately for Clayton, any work in this area will inevitably be compared to that tour de force. Bravely, he rises to the challenge, insisting that: "This work is intended to replace London Under London ," which, since it was last revised in 1993, is "becoming increasingly out of date".

With a chapter on the Jubilee line extension and plenty on other recent developments with an impact on subterranean London - be it the advent of a cable network, Docklands or the proliferation of underground car parks - he has certainly updated our knowledge of the subject. But while London Under London attracts the reader with first-person accounts and conversational prose, Clayton's work is more academic in style and scholarly in content. Before you're halfway through the first page, he has drilled 1,200ft below Tottenham Court Road and is talking about "Devonian Palaeozoic rocks". As an addition to the body of work that exists, the book succeeds; as an attempt to replace the set text it falls well short.

webTitle: Our love affair with nautical novels

fields.headline: All at sea
fields.standfirst: Jonathan Sale charts our ongoing love affair with the nautical novel
fields.trailText: Jonathan Sale charts our ongoing love affair with the nautical novel
fields.body:
In spite of the decline of the Navy, emotionally we are still a seafaring nation, and we have our nautical novels to prove it. So popular - and so lucrative - does the tradition continue to be that publishers are falling over each other to discover the next big thing.

C S Forester's Hornblower novels are the most famous and probably the most accessible of the genre. Published between 1937 and the author's death in 1966, they recreate the Napoleonic wars with an eye for detail that has come to characterise the nautical novel. But in terms of sheer power of writing, Forester is outgunned by both Captain Marryat (1792-1848), author of Mr Midshipman Easy , and Patrick O'Brian (1914-2000), whose man-o'-war skipper Jack Aubrey has become a cult for armchair sailors. Each has recently been celebrated with a biography that is at least as intriguing as anything they themselves ever wrote.

While Marryat was fascinating for what he was, O'Brian was enthralling for what he wasn't. For a start, he was not originally Patrick O'Brian; nor was he, as he later claimed, Irish. As Dean King describes in his excellent Patrick O'Brian: A Life Revealed (Headline, £9.99), he was born in Chalfont St Peter, Buckinghamshire, as Patrick Russ, the name under which he wrote his early books. He produced his first, about a panther, at the age of 15, receiving £10 in royalties plus extra for Danish translation rights. A string of novels and stories followed, initially concentrating on the animal kingdom and then shifting to maritime matters. At 30 he changed his name to O'Brian (his brother, a platypus poacher, had earlier made a similar swap of surnames, calling himself O'Brien).

It was not until he was 52 that he signed a contract with a publisher who was looking for the next C S Forester. Master and Commander was the result, the first in the 20-novel series featuring the bluff Captain Aubrey, who was partly based on a real frigate captain, Thomas (Lord) Cochrane. It also introduced Aubrey's buddy, the doctor and secret agent Stephen Maturin.

Set largely - like most nautical novels - in the Napoleonic wars, the sagas contain much more than the clashing of cutlasses and booming of broadsides. They combine historical accuracy, wit, political intrigue and the flavour of London clubland in the early 1800s. Although the comparison has been made, it has to be said that O'Brian is not a second Joseph Conrad, whose soulful intensity he lacks. The enormous success of the Aubrey books was a long time coming, but when it came, it came big. Between the ages of 74 and 79, O'Brian published five new books in the series. By the time of his death, more than three million copies had been sold.

While O'Brian was a navy reject whose books were based on meticulous research, Frederick Marryat was the real thing - a midshipman as a teenager, who fought the French. While O'Brian drew heavily on the character and exploits of Lord Cochrane, Marryat risked death with the man himself. He deserves to be remembered, and Tom Pocock's Captain Marryat: Seaman, Writer and Adventurer (Chatham Publishing, £19.95) does a rattling good job of it. Marryat, we learn, was lucky to survive his first voyage, since a package of iron stored too close to the compass caused the needle to veer off course and the ship to scrape over hidden rocks. In a later raid, the apprehensive teenager was required to light the blue touchpaper on a fireship. The enemy was bad enough, but his own side could be just as lethal: a subsequent captain who disapproved of the cut of his jib tried to have him drowned.

By his early 20s, Marryat had reached the rank of captain, devised a code of inter-ship signals, made an unsatisfactory marriage and achieved some notoriety as a nautical cartoonist. He saw action against West Country smugglers and Burmese war-canoes. He later gave up his day job in His Majesty's Navy, inherited a fortune and ran a literary magazine. The fiction that he had begun during quiet periods at sea turned him into one of the leading novelists of his time.

As for the next big thing, one publisher claims to have found it in Jonathan Lunn, whose second novel, Killigrew and the Golden Dragon (Headline, £17.99), declares its hero to be "the Victorian Hornblower". In fact, this is a clear case of sailing under false colours. The mantle of C S Forester is not to be inherited by Lunn's competent adventure novel about firing pistols in Hong Kong harbour, and the scientific but unseamanlike surgeon who stumbles into the first paragraph invites unfavourable comparisons with Patrick O'Brian's doctor.

Much greater claims could be made by Julian Stockwin, whose Kydd (Hodder & Stoughton, £12.99) is the first in a promised 11-book series about a lower- deck equivalent of captains Hornblower and Aubrey. Thomas Paine Kydd is a wig-maker from Guildford who is pressed into service and is destined to rise to the top. Stockwin, who went to sea-training school at 14 and ended up as a lieutenant commander, gives a terrifying account of the brutal life and casual death aboard an 18th-century warship. There may be nothing new in his period or setting, but his vantage point of a common sailor gives the nautical novel a fresh twist. In his hands at least, it seems, the sea story will continue to entrance readers across the world - many of whom, it must be added, are more likely to be run over by a bus than ever to set foot on a ship.

In a later raid, the apprehensive teenager was required to light the blue touchpaper on a fireship. The enemy was bad enough, but his own side could be just as lethal: a subsequent captain who disapproved of the cut of his jib tried to have him drowned. By his early 20s, Marryat had reached the rank of captain, devised a code of inter-ship signals, made an unsatisfactory marriage and achieved some notoriety as a nautical cartoonist. He saw action against West Country smugglers and Burmese war-canoes. He later gave up his day job in His Majesty's Navy, inherited a fortune and ran a literary magazine. The fiction that he had begun during quiet periods at sea turned him into one of the leading novelists of his time. As for the next big thing, one publisher claims to have found it in Jonathan Lunn, whose second novel, Killigrew and the Golden Dragon (Headline, £17.99), declares its hero to be "the Victorian Hornblower". In fact, this is a clear case of sailing under false colours. The mantle of C S Forester is not to be inherited by Lunn's competent adventure novel about firing pistols in Hong Kong harbour, and the scientific but unseamanlike surgeon who stumbles into the first paragraph invites unfavourable comparisons with Patrick O'Brian's doctor. Much greater claims could be made by Julian Stockwin, whose Kydd (Hodder & Stoughton, £12.99) is the first in a promised 11-book series about a lower- deck equivalent of captains Hornblower and Aubrey. Thomas Paine Kydd is a wig-maker from Guildford who is pressed into service and is destined to rise to the top. Stockwin, who went to sea-training school at 14 and ended up as a lieutenant commander, gives a terrifying account of the brutal life and casual death aboard an 18th-century warship. There may be nothing new in his period or setting, but his vantage point of a common sailor gives the nautical novel a fresh twist. In his hands at least, it seems, the sea story will continue to entrance readers across the world - many of whom, it must be added, are more likely to be run over by a bus than ever to set foot on a ship. webTitle: Review: Lewin of Greenwich by Richard Hill

fields.headline: Life of an ocean brave
fields.standfirst: Andrew Spark  reviews Lewin of Greenwich: The Authorised Biography of Admiral of the Fleet Lord Lewin by Richard Hill
fields.trailText: Andrew Spark reviews Lewin of Greenwich: The Authorised Biography of Admiral of the Fleet Lord Lewin by Richard Hill
fields.body:
Lewin of Greenwich: The Authorised Biography of Admiral of the Fleet Lord Lewin
Richard Hill
443pp, Casell
£25
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Naval biography in this country has a long and distinguished history, naval autobiography less so. In the tradition of "the Silent Service", as the Royal Navy is sometimes known, most admirals have preferred to leave their memoirs to others. There have been many biographies of Nelson, of course, and John Winton wrote perhaps the classic of the genre in his biography of Admiral Cunningham. This included the hilarious detail that anti-submarine tactics of the first world war were initially limited to sending out a rowing boat containing the ship's blacksmith, a large hammer and several sacks. If the blacksmith were unsuccessful in smashing the protruding periscope with the hammer, a sack was placed over it, thus blinding the submarine.

Of biographies of postwar admirals, including Mountbatten, none has covered the career of an officer who was more important or influential in the development of the post-colonial Royal Navy than Admiral of the Fleet Lord Lewin. Chief of the defence staff during the Falklands conflict, in the course of his 40-year career he watched the Royal Navy shrink from the largest and arguably the most powerful navy in the world to almost its present size. He saw the introduction of radar, the replacement of the battleship by the aircraft carrier, and the introduction of nuclear-powered submarines (Polaris and Trident). He witnessed the Sandys and Nott defence reviews, which severely diminished the role of the Navy, and the cancellation of the Royal Navy's aircraft-carrier programme under Denis Healey in the 1960s.

Richard Hill, himself a retired rear admiral, writes knowledgably and consistently about Lewin - at, it should be said, his subject's invitation. They served together on several occasions, and Hill interviewed 150 people in the course of his research. His most important source was Lewin himself, who while dying of cancer dictated more than 50,000 words for the benefit of his biographer.

Born in 1920, Terence Thornton Lewin had the typical background for an officer in the Royal Navy: he did not come from a wealthy background (Nelson was the son of a Norfolk vicar), had no family connection with the Navy and did not attend a public school. Unusually - at a time when most putative naval officers joined Britannia Royal Naval College in Dartmouth at 13 - Lewin was a Special Entry cadet, joining at the last possible opportunity at the age of 18, having failed to get into university. Although promotion in the Navy has been based at least partly on merit since the time of Pepys, the Special Entry officers were viewed with some suspicion by those who joined by the traditional route, and relatively few were expected to reach the highest ranks.

Lewin's training was cut short by the outbreak of war: after HMS Belfast (preserved today at Tower Bridge) was badly damaged by a new "secret" weapon, the magnetic mine, he was posted to the battleship HMS Valiant, which had just undergone a major refit, including the fitting of one of the first radar sets. His time in Valiant included the shelling of the French Fleet at Mers-el-Kebir and the attack on Taranto, which was the model for the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor. He spent much of the rest of the war on the Arctic convoys and afterwards specialised in gunnery, commanded a frigate, served as second in command of the Royal Yacht, and worked in frigate design at the Admiralty.

Much of the remainder of the story concerns Lewin's role in the reconsideration of British naval power that came with the retreat from empire. This is why he is important: for the first time since the defeat of the Armada, national identity would cease to be associated with that old and increasingly expensive tune, "Britannia rules the waves".

Lewin saw it all. In 1964 he was again appointed to the Admiralty, which under Mountbatten was being merged with the Air Ministry and the War Office to form the combined Ministry of Defence. The Labour victory of that year bought about an immediate major defence review under Denis Healey. A bitter argument between the Navy and the RAF led to the cancellation of the Navy's new aircraft carriers and their planned (later cancelled) replacement with RAF jets flying from land bases.

Within a few years, and with Lewin's involvement, the Royal Navy was tentatively working towards procuring the Sea Harrier, to operate from what were being euphemistically called "through deck cruisers". It is even said that the politicians were carefully shown only side views of the ship, so that they wouldn't realise that they were actually ordering a smallish aircraft carrier. If such arguments had not eventually succeeded, the Falklands task force would have been impossible.

Lewin became First Sea Lord - the professional head of the Navy - in 1977. From this lofty viewpoint he was able to witness the success of some of his earlier work, such as the launching of the first of the new aircraft carriers (HMS Invincible) and a fly-past of the new Sea Harrier.

But the Navy's troubles were far from over. In September 1979, under a newly elected Margaret Thatcher, the decision to purchase Trident was taken. However, the service would have to pay for it out of its own budget. Defence Secretary John Nott's associated review of naval resources caused trauma throughout the fleet. Invincible was to be sold to Australia; the specialised landing ships Fearless and Intrepid were to be scrapped; the South Atlantic patrol ship HMS Endurance was to be withdrawn. It seemed, if things went on like this, that the Royal Navy would be reduced to nothing but a "coast defence force". One government minister, Keith Speed, resigned on principle against the cuts. Lewin did not resign, probably reasoning that it would only make matters worse, but he must have been bitterly disappointed.

Then came the Falklands conflict, in which many of the remaining resources were put to the test. Thatcher was told that a task force not only could, but should, respond to the Argentine invasion. Lewin himself never doubted the decision to sink the General Belgrano, though he regretted the heavy loss of life. It is now generally felt by the Navy that this was unnecessarily heavy, but that the blame must be placed on the Argentinian response to the attack.

Lewin retired in October 1982, and died 17 years later. He wanted to be remembered for bringing about social change, making the Navy "more egalitarian and family-conscious" without losing "its traditions and heritage". He was not against women at sea, but was concerned about his experiences of homosexuality at sea and its link to indiscipline. His wider legacy - at least as perceived in this readable and comprehensive, if not exactly exciting, biography - is that of an officer whose battles were more often with the civil service, politicians and on occasion other services than with the enemy fleet. But they were necessary battles and ones he fought bravely. No one was more closely involved in bringing the Royal Navy into the modern era.

webTitle: Review: Rivals: Conflict as the Fuel of Science by Michael White

fields.headline: Laboratory rats
fields.standfirst: Chris Lavers  on scientific squabbles and self-interest in Rivals: Conflict as the Fuel of Science by Michael White
fields.trailText: Chris Lavers on scientific squabbles and self-interest in Rivals: Conflict as the Fuel of Science by Michael White
fields.body:
Rivals: Conflict as the Fuel of Science
Michael White
417pp, Secker & Warburg
£17.99
Buy it at a discount at BOL

You are charged with deciding who - a group of footballers or a group of scientists - will make a momentous decision on behalf of mankind. Which would you choose? My colleagues in science may arguably have the edge in brain cells, yet I'd plump for the footballers: they at least get to run around in the fresh air and listen to the public once a week. But how would the public vote stack up? If you like your science rational and your scientists heroic, this is not the book for you. As an introduction to the thoroughly human, often irrational and frequently nasty face of science, however, Rivals is probably the best thing on the market.

White's subjects include disputes between Isaac Newton and Gottfried Wilhelm von Leibniz over who should receive credit for the development of calculus; Joseph Priestley and Antoine Lavoisier about oxygen's role in chemistry; Thomas Huxley and his enemies over Darwin's theory of natural selection; various scientists in the 1940s over the construction of the atomic bomb; James Watson and Francis Crick and their competitors over the structure of DNA; the US and the USSR during the space race; and Bill Gates and his rivals over who should be crowned king of cyberspace and appropriate all the royalties. (The last has nothing to do with science, but is so fascinating that it would have been criminal to leave it out.) White's writing style is, as ever, simple, erudite and entertaining, and his topics are carefully chosen and thoroughly researched.

The vehemence of some of the academic infighting in Rivals is surprising even to one prepared by experience to expect the worst. Isaac Newton, that paragon of objective rationality (or so the traditional story runs), was not beyond using his position to inject considerable misery into the lives of his enemies. His attempts to turn the Astronomer Royal into his personal research assistant will strike a chord with many graduate students today, but the way in which he set out to destroy the reputation of his chief intellectual rival gives startling insights into the man's character.

Leibniz developed the mathematical techniques of calculus a decade after Newton and published his results in 1684, thereby precipitating a four-decade catfight with his English counterpart. Leibniz was willing to accept that they had both contributed to the development of calculus, but such magnanimity cut no ice with Newton, who tended to see himself as the one true intermediary between mankind and the mind of God. Quite apart from the nasty letters and pamphlets, Newton used his position as president of the Royal Society to convene a committee of underlings to rule on the dispute, overseeing every detail of the investigation and writing the final report himself (he later denied all involvement). If he knew that today we use only Leibniz's notation for calculus, he would spin in his grave like a flywheel.

Each of White's stories illustrates how supposedly objective thinkers can be led to the very outskirts of morality and beyond. It is a fascinating read and a timely contribution to the public understanding of science. My only quibble concerns the subtitle. "Conflict as the Fuel of Science" implies a coherent thesis, but the brief conclusion hardly qualifies. Does conflict fuel science more often than mire it? One wonders, for example, just how much both Isaac Newton and the hapless targets of his wrath could have achieved had the great man dedicated more of his time to science, and less to being a git.

fields.headline: Bad dreams
fields.standfirst: Matt Thorne  on Stephen King
fields.trailText: Matt Thorne on Stephen King
fields.body:
Dreamcatcher Stephen King
688pp,Hodder
£17.99
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Dreamcatcher is the first novel Stephen King has published since his horrendous road accident in 1999. Written in longhand between November 1999 and May 2000, it is a dark book, originally called Cancer and referred to by his wife as "the one about the shit-weasels".

It's always been hard to keep tabs on King's incredible output. He once described the process of artistic inspiration as "having someone crap on your head", and this seems to happen to him with incredible regularity. Completed novels are often shuffled back in the publication schedules when a new book seems more pressing, as when he surprised his publishers with The Girl Who Loved Tom Gordon two years ago. This appears to be the case here, as King had previously indicated that his next book would be From a Buick Eight . Alongside the novels, he has also recently completed several screen plays, published an award-winning short story in the New Yorker and ventured into e-publishing with a new novella, Riding the Bullet , and a serialised novel, The Plant , that he first started 20 years ago.

The sheer amount of material has led some critics to question the quality of the writing. King has always been sensitive to this, claiming in On Writing : "Nobody ever asks about the language. They ask the DeLillos and the Updikes and the Styrons, but they don't ask popular novelists. Yet many of us proles also care about the language, in our own humble way, and care passionately about the art and craft of telling stories on paper."

The language has become much more important to King in recent years. In my opinion, two of his most recent novels, Bag of Bones and Hearts in Atlantis , are not only the best work he's ever done, but the equal of anything by DeLillo or Updike. Dreamcatcher , however, is something rather different.

The way you read King depends on your usual taste in film, TV and literature. If you tend towards the naturalistic, your favourite King novels will probably be early books, such as Carrie and Cujo , and psychological thrillers such as Misery and Gerald's Game . If, however, you are a fan of supernatural horror, science fiction or fantasy, you will no doubt prefer his more baroque achievements, like his extraordinarily odd fantasy sequence The Dark Tower , or the crazier sections of novels such as The Tommyknockers , Insomnia or Rose Madder (where a character escapes her pursuer by entering a painting).

Dreamcatcher falls squarely into the baroque category, and will probably be most enjoyed by fans of The X-Files . It begins with four old friends in Derry, Maine, about to go on a hunting trip together. The first surprise is that King makes explicit reference to his accident; one of his characters is hit by a car within the first few pages. In his afterword, King explains that several elements of his physical discomfort during the time of writing followed him into the narrative, and there is a painful, nightmarish quality to much of the action.

It is a familiar device in King's fiction to have groups of characters united by a stand they have taken together in the past. Here it was a stand for good, when they stopped a gang from bullying a child with mental difficulties. It is not until much later in the novel that the men realise exactly how this good deed has changed their lives.

It would be easy to make this book sound ludicrous. One of the main subplots concerns aliens who seem to be made of cancer and who put the aforementioned "shit-weasels" inside people. But the most enviable element of King's writing has always been that whenever the action gets really weird, his prose tightens up to take the strain, justifying his excesses and taking the reader into new fictional territory.

He also continues his habit of interweaving stories from his other novels into the current narrative, with a scene concerning Pennywise, the demonic clown killer from his earlier Derry-based novel It . Nevertheless, Dreamcatcher has to be read slowly and carefully to follow the action, especially towards the end, with characters possessed by aliens, reading each others' minds, and popping in and out of the plot. At almost 600 pages, it is slightly heavy going, but by no means a disappointment. King retains his crown.

Read excerpts from Dreamcatcher

fields.headline: First novels
fields.standfirst: Cannibals by Dan Collins, Mouthing the Words by Camilla Gibb, Love in Idleness by Charlotte Mendelson and David Francis's Agapanthus Tango
fields.trailText: Cannibals by Dan Collins, Mouthing the Words by Camilla Gibb, Love in Idleness by Charlotte Mendelson and David Francis's Agapanthus Tango
fields.body:
The short prose pieces that make up Dan Collins's Cannibals (Cape £10)Buy it at a discount at BOL seem at first glance to be little more than the musings of a bright but lazy talent who perversely refuses to write a joined-up novel. But five pages into this seemingly random sequence of monologues and exchanges, it is clear that we are in the company of a highly inventive and gifted writer. All contemporary western life is here: from London to LA, restive housewives squander their love on inappropriate partners while desperate models sleep with adulterous politicians.

It is easy to get lost in the maze of rapid-fire episodes in which the characters may or may not be connected, but are certainly united in their constant questioning of whether they are sufficiently loved or good enough. Irish-born Collins's aim is to expose what happens to our humanity in the media-driven and strangely loveless beginning of a new century. His dispassionate delivery may be mistaken for cynicism, but in fact it so exactly parallels the world we constantly witness in print or on screen that we hardly notice the satire.

By contrast, it would be easy to dismiss Canadian writer Camilla Gibb as someone who wears her heart too completely on her sleeve. In Mouthing the Words (Heinemann, £12.99), her heroine Thelma has suffered every emotional indignity life can throw at a girl (multiple-personality disorder, incest, anorexia, nervous breakdown, attempted suicide). Thelma is an isolated and highly imaginative child, and her tales of growing up in Canada with neglectful parents are both funny and alarming. Longing to be adopted, she approaches one adult role model after another until she eventually becomes deranged by her father's repeated abuse. Gibb seduces the reader with sparky prose and charming storylines before drawing us onto a heart-wrenching rollercoaster ride through one breakdown after another. Thelma wins through, but we suspect it is Gibb who has bravely triumphed over adversity, making this a confessional of the most uncomfortable kind.

In Love in Idleness (Review, £12.99), Charlotte Mendelson has drawn on the venerable tradition of middle-class neuroticism made newly fashionable by the likes of Rachel Cusk and Raffaella Barker. Anna, fresh from university and desperate for adventure and romance, leaps at the chance to housesit her enigmatic aunt's Bloomsbury flat.

Working in a bookshop leaves the ingénue with far too much time on her hands and, more than intrigued by various letters, photographs and a copy of Djuna Barnes's Ladies Almanack left lying around like a tantalising game of Cluedo, she sleuths her way into the secrets that surround her aunt's mysterious love life. fields.headline: New worlds
fields.standfirst: Maya Jaggi on a vision of Inca and conquistador in The Dark Jester by Wilson Harris
fields.trailText: Maya Jaggi on a vision of Inca and conquistador in The Dark Jester by Wilson Harris
fields.body:
The Dark Jester

Wilson Harris

109pp, Faber

£9.99
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Wilson Harris is undoubtedly one of the great originals. As a government surveyor in Guyana, where he was born 80 years ago, he was known to disappear into the Amazonian rainforests with volumes of Hegel and Heidegger. He has lived in England since 1959, writing complex, philosophical, visionary novels that can be bewilderingly arcane yet also dazzlingly illuminating. His oeuvre runs to more than 20 works of fiction - beginning with Palace of the Peacock (1960) - and several volumes of essays.

Guyana, unlike the Anglophone Caribbean islands with which it shares much of its history, has a South American landscape and an Amerindian presence. Harris is fascinated by both, an inspiration he shares with other Guyanese, such as the writer Pauline Melville and the late painter Aubrey Williams. His recent fiction is haunted by the ruins of pre-Columbian cities, and the mysterious abandonment of some of them before the conquest.

Like his previous novel, Jonestown (1996), which was set in the aftermath of the mass suicide instigated by the Reverend Jim Jones in 1978, The Dark Jester takes its cue from a shard of history: the encounter between the Spanish conquistador Pizarro, who conquered Peru, and its last great Inca king, Atahualpa. Atahualpa is sentenced to be burned at the stake, but escapes through conversion to Christianity. Promised his freedom for a roomful of gold, he is betrayed by Pizarro and killed.

Events unfold in a dream of the narrator, known as the Dreamer, creating a new perspective on the past. Harris is acutely aware of how the past lingers and can imprison the present, and of how this region's past in particular has been one of repeated conquest and catastrophe. The inadequacy or one-sidedness of recorded history lead him to myth, to intuitive re-creation and re-imagining. Like Gabriel García Márquez, also from South America's Caribbean coast, he abolishes linear time in favour of a cyclical reconstruction, an open dialogue with the past.

The 20th-century Dreamer is a shape-shifting narrator, a vessel occupied in turn by Pizarro, a noble of Atahualpa, the prophet Laocoon and Tupac Amaru, Atahualpa's last heir. The landscape also mutates, as the pyramid of Palenque melts into a skyscraper, and the Dreamer envisions the volcanic upheavals that fashioned primordial hills, mountains and valleys millennia ago. There is no authoritative vantage point in the fiction of Harris, who rejects realism as blind to the imagination's "parallel universes". Rather, there are "infinite rehearsals", where every view is partial, and there is no final version.

The novel is a meditation on the encounter between the materialist age ushered in by Pizarro, who sees only "reptilian gold" in the Incan art of Bird and Beast, and the lost civilisation of Atahualpa, son of the Sun. Pizarro, the "King of Thieves", becomes master of a slave ship where "dark flesh is painted in Inca gold" and the trade is in "works of art that can labour, cut cane, create dams and canals". Yet Harris acknowledges antecedents in both conqueror and victim. He sees creative possibilities in the impure mix, the promiscuous melding of world-views.

The Dreamer is a prophet of the past, just as he has a "memory of the future", and the novel is filled with unheeded warnings - including the seeds of corruption sown long before Pizarro's advent and witnessed in the ruins of Macchu Picchu or Espiritu Pampa, and in the Incas' final rout. "They were as unconscious of the dangers they faced as my century was of the undercurrents that threatened its existence," says the Dreamer. In the novel's climax, he encounters Cortez, passing on his way to conquer the Mexican Aztecs in 1519 - before Pizarro conquered Peru. The Dreamer tries to warn Cortez of the consequences of his quest; "to warn him, or to kill him as a dictator whose deeds one foresees".

The Dreamer is accompanied in his adventures by the Jester, and among the novel's epigraphs are Milton's lines: "Jesting decides great things / Stronglier and better / Oft than earnest can." Jest, Harris tells us, "revises repetitions of something we take for granted", breaking the "ritual habit, ritual normality, that seals our eyes and ears". The Dreamer sees the conquest as having set a seal on civilisation that must be broken and transfigured, to recover resources lost to "conquistadorial ages". The conquistador's descendant "picks a word or two from here and there from ruined temples, a gesture or two here and there, a ritual or two, and sums up the psyche of a lost civilisation in terms that are imposed everywhere on the past, the present, and the future". The novel is in part an attempt to intuit the spirit of the pre-conquest era other than through the eyes of its materialist conquerors, who deemed it a finished age - "So finished it could be sold again, without insight, or understanding of the unfinished past, the unfinished present."

Harris habitually links the myths and stories of diverse ages, with Caribbean culture emerging, as he says, from a "complex womb". Here, he finds echoes of King Priam's daughter, Cassandra, and the wooden horse in El Dorado, the "Troy of the Americas". Atahualpa's arrival at "my age and time to die again, to live again" recalls Christian redemption, while Prometheus mirrors the Incan ruler as son of the sun. There are also recurring motifs - of time's ladder, and the ship travelling through imaginative space.

The juxtaposition of the abstractly philosophical and the sensuous can often be jarring, a crunching of gears in a shift from poetry to essay. But at moments, the marriage is profound. The Jester laughs soundlessly, "like a gathering storm on a butterfly's wing", or the Dreamer muses: "How does one measure time and distance in the moment of dying? Does an inch bring a million, does a minute erase all the clocks?"

Harris's singular vision can result in a baffling privacy of meaning. Yet often he recalls Blake, with a prophetic vision that challenges and renews the senses and contorts the syntax. The Bird, he writes, "sang in the faint orchestration of igneous words they seemed, survivor blood that stained its feathers in rare fire. The fire was so unnerving, so matchless, it created a sound that was red , a scarlet sound." Harris is a firm believer in the regenerative power of the imagination. Threading together the myths of different cultures, he creates his own.

webTitle: Review: The Bonesetter's Daughter by Amy Tan

fields.headline: Mother's little helper
fields.standfirst: Alex Clark  sees two ages collide in Amy Tan's The Bonesetter's Daughter
fields.trailText: Alex Clark sees two ages collide in Amy Tan's The Bonesetter's Daughter
fields.body:
The Bonesetter's Daughter
Amy Tan
308pp, Flamingo
£16.99
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Perhaps the secret of Amy Tan's enormous popularity - this novel is as likely to find success as its predecessors The Joy Luck Club and The Kitchen God's Wife - is her ability to give a western audience nicely finessed representations of the exotic while convincing them of the universality of her themes. Here, as previously, her subject is the tension between a first-generation Chinese-American woman and her awkwardly semi-assimilated mother. Tan is at once standing on the inside - the purveyor of secret histories and forgotten traditions - and shaking her head in bewilderment from without.

When Ruth, the heroine of The Bonesetter's Daughter , asserts that her mother "is not like other Chinese people", she is both bemoaning LuLing's cussed individualism and pointing to her own sense of other ness. Is she herself "like Chinese people"? If not, what exactly is she?

LuLing is not like other Chinese people; nor, in fact, like many other human beings one would care to meet. She stretches the reader's sympathy through a mixture of coercion, depression, manipulation and outright abuse. Reclining on her battered La-Z-Boy, she is "a petulant child on a throne"; as Alzheimer's begins to claim her, she is a child in need of ceaseless attention.

How to give unstinting affection to a mother who, for as long as you can remember, has been depressed and angry, threatening suicide at the slightest incursion? At the novel's outset, Ruth, her mother's chief interpreter, aider, abetter and all- round whipping girl, faces the prospect of an increase in her dependence with a sinking heart. And yet for compliant Ruth, a ghostwriter whose days are spent coaxing into life books with titles like Internet Spirituality and Defeat Depression with Dogs while ministering to the needs of her New Man partner and his whiny teenage daughters, refusal is simply not an option.

Tan is an efficient narrator of the undercurrents of mother-daughter relationships; she has a talent for small comic touches, but all too frequently they are deluged by a wave of explication. The first part of the book sags under the weight of Tan's earnestness, and Ruth's dilemma seems over-determined. Her annual period of muteness - which she ascribes variously to allergies, mould, viruses and psychic disturbance - is too clearly a novelistic symbol of choked emotions and repression.

Where the novel really takes off is in its second section: a translation of "things I should not forget" discovered by Ruth in the seat of her mother's La-Z-Boy just as LuLing's grasp of language seems to falter irredeemably. Here we are treated to high drama that, paradoxically, has more verisimilitude than Ruth's domestic trials, despite its Mongol bandits, dragon bones, self-mutilation and suicide, and a broad historical sweep ranging from the archaisms of rural Chinese life to the terrors of the Japanese invasion and the civil war. Delivered to the reader as both pure, plotty adventure and a slowly unfurled tragedy, it provides a key to the present while reinforcing the mysterious unknowability of the past.

Ruth's bizarre under-reaction to her mother's memoir is perhaps the novel's weakest point. "It feels like I've found the magic thread to mend a torn-up quilt," she tells her partner, and that imagery - redolent of trite, homespun wisdom and ad-hoc reconciliation - is symptomatic of the cloying feel to some of Tan's writing. In the end, it is LuLing who is Tan's most ingeniously ambiguous creation. She alone appears to have a sense of the power she wields and of its dependence on the continuation of secrecy, as witnessed by her scornful rebuff to a doctor enthralled by Beijing's Forbidden City: "In those day, so many thing forbidden, can't see. Now everyone pay money see forbidden thing. You say this forbidden that forbidden, charge extra."

webTitle: Wild West at the London Book Fair

fields.headline: Wild West at the London Book Fair
fields.trailText: Tense times for the administrators of the Commonwealth Writers Prize, who learned this week that Amitav Ghosh - whose The Glass Palace was awarded the Best Novel in the Eurasian section - has withdrawn from the competition.
fields.body:
 Tense times for the administrators of the Commonwealth Writers Prize, who learned this week that Amitav Ghosh - whose The Glass Palace was awarded the Best Novel in the Eurasian section - has withdrawn from the competition. Ghosh objects to the term "Commonwealth" and the unfairness of the prize's English-language requirement. Given that "Eurasia" yokes together, among others, India, Malta and the UK, one can see his point. But what now for the runners-up, one of whom will surely be called on to step into the breach? Will J G Ballard, Kazuo Ishiguro and Jane Stevenson support Ghosh? And will Zadie Smith, winner of best first novel, follow suit?

 Blame the relentless winter if you will, but publishers seem to be falling prey to an uncommon number of cock-ups at the moment. When Canongate decided to publish David Margolick's Strange Fruit - a "biography" of Billie Holliday's song of the same name - it must have seemed like a great idea to reproduce the lyrics on the back cover, and to bring the book out on Holiday's birthday. Alas, the latter has gone for a Burton because of a spectacular error in the former. "Here is a strange and bitter crop," ends the song, describing a lynching in the Deep South. "A strange and buffer cry", the words that appear on the book, lack the same impact. What would a buffer cry sound like? "Tally-ho", presumably.

 With countryside literary festivals under threat of cancellation owing to foot and mouth, the city is the safest place for publishers to exhibit their wares. So the Loafer will be toddling off to the London Book Fair this weekend, despite the fact that the opening day encompasses both the clocks going forward and Mother's Day celebrations. Apparently, however, there will be an emissary from the more rugged side of life: Alan Gallop, author of Buffalo Bill's British Wild West, who has promised to don fringed leather bucksins, boots and Stetson to publicise his book. (Buffalo Bill himself performed at Olympia in April 1903, drawing even Edward VII to his spectacular show.) Luckily, Gallop is not planning to bring any cloven-hooved animals - although the Loafer wouldn't rule out disinfectant baths for some of publishing's less salubrious elements.

 Absinthe and Babycham do not mix. In particular, they do not mix with the notoriously thirsty ranks of booksellers, who gathered at a party to celebrate the launch of The Look: Adventures in Pop and Rock Fashion. There they stood, sipping like fury in duffel coats and tank-tops, while fashionistas including Wayne Hemingway and Mark Powell swanned about. And the never did the twain meet, until the close of play when the venue reverted to its original purpose and turned into a strip club, complete with pole dancing. The Loafer thinks it best to draw a veil over what followed next.

 You need a certain amount of nerve to make a speech at your own launch party, but if anyone has the bottle, you would imagine it to be Esther Rantzen. And thus she duly thanked, praised and flattered at the gathering for her autobiography in a swish hotel in Park Lane. Shame, then, that an insistent voice threatened to eclipse the great woman's words with idle chatter. Who could it possibly be? None other, the Loafer's most reliable spies report, than the effervescent Vanessa Feltz, fresh from her speedy eviction from the Big Brother house and eager to "share" news of her ordeal.

Shame, then, that an insistent voice threatened to eclipse the great woman's words with idle chatter. Who could it possibly be? None other, the Loafer's most reliable spies report, than the effervescent Vanessa Feltz, fresh from her speedy eviction from the Big Brother house and eager to "share" news of her ordeal.

fields.headline: Saving grace from bonny banks
fields.trailText: Bank of Scotland is offering savings bonds paying 6% gross, 4.8% clear of tax, fixed for three or five years. The minimum deposit is set at £5,000, and the offer closes on April 12.
fields.body:
Bank of Scotland is offering savings bonds paying 6% gross, 4.8% clear of tax, fixed for three or five years. The minimum deposit is set at £5,000, and the offer closes on April 12. For an application form or further information call Bank of Scotland Investors Club on freephone 0800 807 777 or you can apply through the net at Bank of Scotland Investors Club.

And Chelsea Building Society's new Fixed Rate Plus account also returns 6% before tax, 4.8% net, on a minimum investment of £2,500 until January 1, 2002. Thereafter, the society pledges to keep the rates at no less than 0.25% below the prevailing Bank of England base rate until April 1, 2003.

Savers with a deposit of at least £500 can also get a return of 6% gross (4.8% net) by investing in Northern Rock's fixed-rate bonds and can choose a term from one to three years. The bank's bonds are available from March 30. For application details, tel 0845 600 4466.

Consumers asking about surrender values on with-profits endowment policies should now be told that they also have the option to sell their policy, as a result of a regulatory update issued by the Personal Investment Authority. The regulator believes that consumers should be made aware that they may be able to sell their policy, especially as in some cases it is likely to give them a better cash return than surrendering it. And for investors who want to profit from people selling up their endowment policies, specialist trader Beale Dobie has produced a guide to investing in traded endowment policies. For a free copy of the guide, tel 01621 851133.

The UK taxpayer routinely misses out on unclaimed tax allowances. To help savers make the most of the generous tax breaks through investing in Venture Capital Trusts (VCTs) that can be used to shield capital gains against tax - with the addition of up front income tax relief at 20% reducing the net cost of investing in a VCT to as little as 40% of the gross investment - Northern Venture Managers is offering a free guide to the tax rules governing investment in VCTs. Call 0191 244 6000 or visit Northern Venture Managers.

Digitallook, a financial website, and stockbroker Hargreaves Lansdown, have launched an online perks tracker, which alerts investors to perks associated with their shareholdings, such as discounts on goods and services. It offers shareholders free registration to keep in touch with the latest share perks and all the other news and information about their portfolio.

For example, investors with 500 Next shares may qualify for a discount voucher which entitles the shareholder or their immediate family to a 25% discount off the price of all purchases made at any one time at any branch of Next. Go to Digitallook.

Justgiving is a website that raises money for charities, such as Barnardo's, Scope and Centrepoint and other organisations working to boost the quality of life in the developing world. With thousands of people dying from cholera on the African island of Madagascar, just £1 will pay for clean drinking water for one person for life - which is vital for combating cholera. By donating through Justgiving, 28p of tax is reclaimed on every £1 of the total donation. Visit Justgiving.

Elsewhere, HSBC Bank will cash in any spare shares free of charge and give the proceeds to good causes. Contact your local branch for details.

Tesco Personal Finance is advising England football fans travelling to the World Cup Qualifier tie in Albania on March 28 to take a mixture of German marks, sterling notes or sterling travellers cheques. Albanian New Lek is a restricted currency which is not easy to get here.

To order your travel money call 0845 600 6667. It offers a next day delivery on orders placed before 2pm.

Homeowners Friendly society says over 300,000 elderly people every year are so seriously hurt by accidental falls in their homes that they require hospital treatment. The society has launched Over 50s Accident Protection Policy that offers lump sums of up to £6,000. The premiums start at around £5 a month for a single policy and from under £9 for joint ones. The cover requires no medical report and policyholders can use the payout on such expenses as hiring help to undertake household chores while they recover from their injuries.

Supermarket chain Asda is offering pet owners an insurance policy priced from £6.79 a month. The policy covers up to £5,000 worth of vet bills with no limit on the number of claims. For Instant cover, tel 0800 064 6688.

webTitle: B&B leads way out of market

fields.headline: B&B leads way out of market
fields.standfirst: Major lender opts to sell other banks' home loans, as  Patrick Collinson  reports
fields.trailText: Major lender opts to sell other banks' home loans, as Patrick Collinson reports.
fields.body:
As Halifax and Nationwide slug it out in the "mortgage war", Bradford & Bingley this weekend becomes the first major lender to effectively quit the market and just sell other banks' home loans instead.

Bradford & Bingley believes that it is no longer profitable to offer its own ultra-low discount and fixed rate mortgages, as home-owners are becoming increasingly astute at remortgaging from one provider to the next.

In its place it will this weekend launch "The MarketPlace" in all of its 500 high street branches, which will act as an independent service offering advice on mortgages from 35 other lenders who make up 90% of the UK home loan market.

Bradford & Bingley has for years stood alone on the high street as the only independent provider of advice on pensions, insurance and investment products, and is now extending the principle to mortgages as well. Commercial director Ian Darby says: "How long would a supermarket last if it only sold own-label products? Banks have got away with that for years because consumers didn't have a high street alternative. Now they do."

First Direct has also switched to offering independent financial advice, although in mortgages it is tied to those offered by parent group HSBC only.

B&B insists that its advisers will be paid on a flat-rate irrespective of what mortgage they select for a home buyer. "Because our advisers are not biased by differing commission levels, B&B can truly say it offers customers what's best for you, not for us," says Mr Darby.

But B&B's altruism extends only so far. It will charge a fee for advice of 0.4% of the loan, with a minimum charge of £200. It says its average loan size is £60,000, so the average fee will be £240. Bradford & Bingley also earns a "procuration" fee from the lender. According to mortgage advisers, these fees can run as high as £1,000 per loan, but are usually in the hundreds of pounds.

Some customers may be surprised to hear that the range of mortgages on offer at MarketPlace is less comprehensive than that available to customers of mortgage broker Charcol, which Bradford & Bingley bought last year for £100m and which operates a highly popular mortgage website, charcolonline. co.uk. Users of the website (and marketplace.co.uk) who do the entire transaction online, will also avoid the 0.4% fee.

Bradford & Bingley sees its in-store MarketPlace concept appealing to middle England, while the Charcol brand will be separately marketed to higher income brackets.

Despite taking the moral high ground in the mortgage market by going totally independent, Bradford & Bingley is maintaining its 7.49% standard variable rate for existing loan customers.

Shouldn't they now just walk into a B&B branch and ask an independent mortgage adviser to find a better loan deal for them?

Mr Darby says: "We have factored in an increase in remortgage business. If someone doesn't have a penalty attached to their mortgage, I have to admit it is hard to find a reason why they pay 7.49%."

He says that B&B customers who want to remortgage should first call their local B&B branch, which have "retention" products which borrowers can switch to, but if they are not tempted by these then they can see an in-house independent mortgage broker.

Unfortunately, Bradford & Bingley is not stretching its MarketPlace concept to savings, where it will continue to offer its own-brand products only. B&B's instant access account currently offers an interest rate of just 1.7% gross, compared with the 6% savers can earn on an equivalent account at Intelligent Finance or Capital One Bank.

Mr Darby says Charcol has looked at a "sweeper" savings account using the internet to place a saver's money in the highest-rate account, but it has hit stiff resistance from providers.

webTitle: Now your say about the Nationwide

fields.headline: Now your say about the Nationwide
fields.trailText: I am locked into a Nationwide SVR in the third year of a five-year discounted deal. I feel very angry and let down with my omission from the new 6.49% "base mortgage rate" that the building society has brought in.
fields.body:
I am locked into a Nationwide SVR in the third year of a five-year discounted deal. I feel very angry and let down with my omission from the new 6.49% "base mortgage rate" that the building society has brought in.

The point was made to me that whenever the base rate fell we would also benefit on our discounted rate.

I feel that the "goal posts have been moved" now, and that they have been rather deceitful to say the least with there now being these two different rates. I am a big supporter of mutuality, but I think on this issue Nationwide are acting as bad as some of their "banking" rivals. With a possible conversion vote in the pipeline, perhaps they should ponder reactions to this policy.
Mark Galliott
Yeovil
Somerset

I chose to take a four year discount period since I trusted Nationwide to treat their existing customers fairly and on the absolutely held belief that I would be given a discount off the rate that I would otherwise be paying.

By allowing other customers to take up the BMR while basing my discount on the (0.5% higher) SVR the value of my discount has been slashed.

How Nationwide have the audacity to claim the SVR is the "standard" rate is beyond me. As far as I can see the SVR is no longer the "standard" rate in any reasonable "plain English" definition of the word "standard" - perhaps they should rename it the EVR or Exceptional Variable Rate!

The fact that my trust has been betrayed has cost me hundreds of pounds. Suffice to say lesson learned - and all loyalty to Nationwide (which was high largely due to their mutual status) has totally evaporated. I will not use Nationwide for any savings or borrowings again. I was interested to read about the latest carpetbagging move.

If and when the vote comes I may well support de-mutualisation, regardless of whether or not my windfall goes to charity, and then promptly change mortgage providers. There is only one way they can get that loyalty back - scrap the arbitrary BMR/SVR distinction.

I would be interested, therefore, in any advice on going further and/or email addresses from like minded Nationwide customers (feel free to pass my email address on to anyone who makes a similar request).
David Kirk
Godalming, Surrey
david@the-kirk-family.co.uk

I am one of the 125,000 customers unfairly (and perhaps illegally) locked into the SVR. I am no longer benefiting from any discount, and chose the product four years ago precisely because it returned to the SVR after 2 years. I could not have known, and the Nationwide certainly did not tell me before taking out the mortgage, that what I believed to be "standard" would subsequently be split into a first class SVR (the BMR) and a second class SVR.

Further more, I accepted the "early redemption fee" (their term) lasting for the first five years of the mortgage as exactly that: a penalty on repayment. But I am not wishing to redeem my mortgage. I simply wish to be treated like other customers on the SVR. In recent ballots I have supported Nationwide's mutual status in the belief that the organisation would share the benefits equally between members. Now I am cynical and see not a mutual but an organisation which targets the benefits of mutuality upon new customers and those members who are in a position to go elsewhere.

Unless the society backs down on this one I will be one of those supporting the carpetbaggers, claim my stake and once my five years are up move my mortgage to another provider. I would urge others to do likewise.
Jonathan Prest
Via e-mail

Can there really be two standard variable rates at any one time? I am disappointed in Nationwide after their stance on being there for their members. Maybe they should be carpetbagged.
Mary Wild
York

I was delighted to see your article on Saturday about the mistreated mortgage borrowers with Nationwide. I took out my mortgage in 1997, borrowing the not inconsiderable sum of £100,000.

I had a two-year fixed rate, and accepted that I would then be locked into the SVR for three years. I was willing to commit to this on the basis of the society's commitment to mutual status and its avowed aim to keep its SVR competitive. I am now halfway through the three-year period and would have to pay hefty charges to remortgage or to take advantage of Nationwide's new rate.

I was outraged at the cynical and hypocritical manoeuvring the society has gone through in this latest mortgage war. To invent the new base mortgage rate (BMR) with the sole intention of preventing those customers on lock-in arrangements from benefiting was bad enough. Insult was added to injury with the trumpeted claims that all members would benefit, with a tiny footnote explaining the significant exception.

The Nationwide then proceeded to launch its onslaught on the Halifax, claiming again that all members would benefit from the new rate.

The most annoying thing is the disingenuous nature of Nationwide's communication with me as member and borrower. The letter notifying me of my new mortgage rate said how delighted the society was to be able to cut my rate again - to 6.99%.

I believe there was a moral obligation on the society to explain in that letter why the much-publicised BMR was not, despite the media hoo-ha, available to me and other customers in my position. The failure to do so makes a mockery of the society's sanctimonious claims that it values its members, and puts principles before profit.

I wrote to complain, and received the usual emollient pap in response. The society claims it would be unfair to other borrowers for those who have benefited from a fixed-rate deal to get the new rate.

My view is that by moving the goalposts in creating a standard rate that undercuts its SVR, the society has betrayed the spirit of the bargain between us - so all bets should be off. The analogy is the practice of keeping savers' money in obsolete accounts when they could do better in a different account. It is not the behaviour of a member-driven organisation that values its members. I feel exploited rather than valued.

Alison Cawley
London

The main point Nationwide make is that, as a borrower who has already benefited from a reduced rate for two years, I cannot be considered for this new base rate until my three-year early redemption period has run out. But I will only have benefited by about £100 by the time I can switch to the new rate.

The redemption penalty period was mainly to stop people from moving the mortgages straight after their reduction period. I think they are being incredibly "un-loyal" to their "loyal" members. I no longer feel like a "valued" and "loyal" member.

Francis Atkinson
Leyton, East London

fields.headline: Damon Albarn monkeys around
fields.standfirst:
Scala
London
Rating: **
fields.trailText:
Scala
London
Rating: **
fields.body:
Hey hey, they're the monkeys, ushering in the silly season a good three months early. This "lo-fi thriller event", as it said on the ticket, was proof that no matter how foolish the concept, it will sell tickets if a famous name is involved. The name in Gorillaz' case is moonlighting Blur boy Damon Albarn, who, with Tank Girl creator Jamie Hewlett, conceived the idea of a fictitious cartoon band, just 30 years after the Archies did it first. And despite clocking up a woozily catchy debut single, Clint Eastwood, it's silly indeed. Gorillaz are the indie answer to Hear'Say: a passably mammalian outfit concocted out of thin air and straight into the charts.

Had Albarn been in doubt about his latest solo fling, he would have been reassured by the sight of the sold-out... well, "event" describes it as well as anything. The ticket promised that Gorillaz' made-up members (guitarist Noodle, rapper Russel and singers 2D and Murdoc) would be playing, but guess what? Being cartoons, they couldn't make it, so they sent their spokespeople: Albarn, San Francisco rapper Del Tha Funkee Homosapien and a milling cast of others.

We had to take it on faith that they were actually there, though, as they played the whole set behind a screen. Albarn appeared only as a ghostly, baseball-capped silhouette. As he might have retorted to anyone who objected to paying for not seeing his face, it's art, innit?

The music, mostly booming hip-hop and dub, with interludes of Song 2-style thrashing, was synchronised to the images on screen. The idea was that Albarn and friends were the soundtrack to the images, which ranged from horror-movie footage to Hewlett's Japanese-inspired graphics, all flashed at warp speed. Someone will undoubtedly come up with the ultimate audiovisual extravaganza one day, but Gorillaz' stab at it - pairing, for example, droning dub with a clip from The Mummy - isn't it.

There was a whoop of relief for the first notes of Clint Eastwood, which they performed twice. A sequin-encrusted Del appeared briefly on a balcony, and that was it. Damon gets an A for effort, and for exploring different terrain with every new project, but Gorillaz are one bit of monkey business he'd be best off chalking up to experience.
