Gorillaz are the indie answer to Hear'Say: a passably mammalian outfit concocted out of thin air and straight into the charts. Had Albarn been in doubt about his latest solo fling, he would have been reassured by the sight of the sold-out... well, "event" describes it as well as anything. The ticket promised that Gorillaz' made-up members (guitarist Noodle, rapper Russel and singers 2D and Murdoc) would be playing, but guess what? Being cartoons, they couldn't make it, so they sent their spokespeople: Albarn, San Francisco rapper Del Tha Funkee Homosapien and a milling cast of others. We had to take it on faith that they were actually there, though, as they played the whole set behind a screen. Albarn appeared only as a ghostly, baseball-capped silhouette. As he might have retorted to anyone who objected to paying for not seeing his face, it's art, innit? The music, mostly booming hip-hop and dub, with interludes of Song 2-style thrashing, was synchronised to the images on screen. The idea was that Albarn and friends were the soundtrack to the images, which ranged from horror-movie footage to Hewlett's Japanese-inspired graphics, all flashed at warp speed. Someone will undoubtedly come up with the ultimate audiovisual extravaganza one day, but Gorillaz' stab at it - pairing, for example, droning dub with a clip from The Mummy - isn't it. There was a whoop of relief for the first notes of Clint Eastwood, which they performed twice. A sequin-encrusted Del appeared briefly on a balcony, and that was it. Damon gets an A for effort, and for exploring different terrain with every new project, but Gorillaz are one bit of monkey business he'd be best off chalking up to experience.

webTitle: Jobs and Money: Collect film posters

fields.headline: Here's looking at you
fields.standfirst: If you are interested in collecting art, but find popular culture more fun, film posters can fit all pockets and are rising in value, as Stewart Dalby explains.
fields.trailText: If you are interested in collecting art, but find popular culture more fun, film posters can fit all pockets and are rising in value, as Stewart Dalby explains.
fields.body:
For five years now I have watched the vertiginous rise in the price of some film posters. In 1995 a poster from the James Bond film, From Russia With Love, sold for £50. Last year it was worth between £1,000 and £1,500. Now it would probably sell for £2,000.

These prices come from Tony Nourmand who runs The Reel Poster Gallery in Notting Hill, London. He says: "You can date the increase of interest in film posters as collectibles from 1995. This is when Christie's started holding their regular auctions. They have such a terrific publicity machine. They created an awareness that posters are available, relatively cheap compared to paintings and make good decorations."

He might add that he has played his part in popularising film posters. His gallery is world-renowned. A great expert on the subject, he has written and contributed to a number of books on the genre. He also assembles collections for serious collectors and is a consultant to Christie's.

So, what is new in this world, as Christie's comes up for its sixth annual auction next Tuesday and The Reel Poster Gallery publishes its fifth colour catalogue?

When Christie's South Kensington creates a new niche, as it has done with James Bond memorabilia and ski posters, as well as film posters, it seems to ensure that the supply increases to meet demand. People read about prices that are realised and pieces start coming out of the woodwork. And this year's sale, which comprises more than 300 lots, includes two private collections that have never been on the market before, with some particularly rare pieces of cinema artwork.

The introduction to the Reel Poster gallery's latest catalogue says: "Throughout our four previous catalogues, no poster has been repeated, and we have maintained this policy for the fifth catalogue. In this catalogue we have included a rich variety of striking and intriguing posters from over 15 countries, including for the first time Romania, Denmark and Cuba."

The field is definitely widening. So what are the categories most sought after and at what price?

One popular area is science fiction and horror movies. The first collection at the Christie's sale has quite a few of these. They form part of a group of 65 one-sheet posters rediscovered almost 50 years ago in a garage in Arizona by the vendor and his father-in-law. The latter, who managed a movie theatre in Jerome, Arizona during the late 1920s and early 1930s, retrieved the posters when the theatre closed and could not bring himself to throw them away. When the posters were discovered they were glued to five pieces of cardboard. The theatre did not have display cases and the cardboard was propped against the walls to advertise the attractions. Now largely detached from the cardboard, the collection is expected to realise £100,000.

Paramount's poster for Supernatural is expected to realise £8,000 to £12,000. From the same year (1933), a Universal Studios one sheet for Murders in the Zoo carries an estimate of £3,500 to £5,000.

The star attraction, however, is a Universal one-sheet poster for what is considered one of the classic horror films of all time, The Mummy, starring Boris Karloff. A poster for this film holds the record for any film poster. Some years back one sold for $450,000. At that time it was thought to be one of only two in existence (early film posters were not made to last). Now this third one has been discovered. However, as it is not in as good a condition as the earlier ones, the estimate is between £30,000 and £50,000.

Mr Nourmand says, as a rule of thumb, the more popular the film, the more popular the poster. Thus, anything from James Bond, the Clint Eastwood Dirty Harry movies and spaghetti westerns and the Marx brothers are sought after. Also, certain directors, particularly Alfred Hitchcock and Orson Welles, are collected. Leading ladies such as Marilyn Monroe and Audrey Hepburn are also sought after. And there is an interest in cult films and in well-known designers such as Saul Bass.

In the other collection at Christie's a poster for the Marx Brothers classic Duck Soup (1933) is estimated at £2,000 and £3,000. A Universal three sheet for The Seven Year Itch (1955) starring Marilyn Monroe is expected to realise up to £5,000.

From The Reel Poster Gallery catalogue, the original Alfred Hitchcock film of the famous John Buchan novel The 39 Steps has sold for £15,000. But Mr Nourmand points out that the Irma La Douce poster in its catalogue went for £650. "Prices here start at £300," he says.

Sarah Hodgson, the specialist at Christie's South Kensington, agrees. "Everyone talks about the James Bond poster, but many posters have risen steadily in price rather than dramatically. Many are affordable. Prices in our sale start at £200."

 For further information: Christie's South Kensington, tel: 020 7581 7611 or visit www.christies.com. The Reel Poster Gallery, tel: 020 7727 4488 www.reelposter.com

fields.headline: Policing the professionals
fields.trailText: The OFT's report, Competition in the Professions, is one of the most radical documents to emanate from the organisation for years.
fields.body:
The OFT's report, Competition in the Professions, is one of the most radical documents to emanate from the organisation for years.

Unfortunately, director general John Vickers has rather undermined the impact of the report by incorrectly insisting that it has taken into account the public interest as well as competition issues.

Although its title suggests a broader remit, the report confines itself primarily to lawyers. And, as ever when there are suggestions of doing away with lawyers' restrictive practices, there is a near-hysterical reaction. Within hours of its publication, Bar Council chairman Roy Amlot QC described the report as "glib and dogged in its ignorance of how the interests of justice play a role in the issues at stake".

The most blatant - and perhaps indefensible - of the practices highlighted is that which prevents the public going directly to a barrister rather than through a solicitor, thus paying two lots of lawyers' fees. The bar's only attempt to defend this rule was to point out that an exception has been made for a number of large organisations, most of which employ solicitors anyway.

A more complex anomaly is "legal professional privilege". This long-standing rule means lawyers can never be required to disclose - even to a court - what their clients tell them. The OFT accepts there are good reasons for the existence of this rule, but questions whether applying it exclusively to lawyers is fair. Someone seeking advice on whether, for instance, a particular form of tax avoidance is a criminal offence might well get better advice from an accountant than a solicitor. However, the accountant could be questioned by the authorities about whether the client had admitted doing anything that amounted to an offence. For that reason alone the client would be better off with a solicitor.

The question of allowing solicitors and accountants to practise together is another matter the OFT considers. Rules currently forbidding this, it says, are anti-competitive, particularly the one preventing solicitors employed by accountancy firms from giving advice to clients. Even worse is the rule prohibiting barristers from entering into partnerships with other barristers, let alone members of other professions. Relaxing these restrictions might allow more competition, but there is a genuine fear that large accountancy firms will end up dominating the legal services market. Of more immediate concern to consumers may be the charging recommendations made by some professional bodies. The Royal Institute of British Architects and the Law Society, in relation to probate work, both have scale charges, which many would argue are excessive. The OFT recognises that such charges are not mandatory. However, they could be anti-competitive in the sense that they do make shopping around more difficult than it otherwise would be.

Several other rules that are welcomed by most reputable professionals also come under fire from the OFT on its anti-competitive criteria, including that imposed by both the Law Society and Institute of Chartered Accountants forbidding their members from cold calling prospective clients. The rules that prevent solicitors paying inducements to those who introduce clients are also found to be a fetter on competition. The report also questions the rule prohibiting barristers advertising their success rate, something few would wish to do, if only because of the impossibility of defining "success" in this context.

The OFT even points out that banks have not been given much opportunity to enter the conveyancing market. Rules could be made under the Courts and Legal Services Act which would allow this. At present banks do undertake probate work, but there is no evidence to suggest they do it cheaper or better than solicitors. Allowing banks to do the legal work in buying houses is something many would find alarming.

These are instances where anti-competitive practices may in fact be in the public interest. While the report deals comprehensively with competition matters, it does not appear to address public interest. Indeed, last autumn the consultants helping the OFT with the report told the Bar Council they had not been asked to carry out "a full public interest assessment". Bizarrely, though, John Vickers insisted that the OFT had in fact done that.

The legal professions will want the opportunity to persuade the OFT that all their restrictive practices are in the public interest, and attempts to deprive them of that are likely to result in litigation that will slow down reform. Despite the hope the report may give that the professions will be reformed, it is likely to be several years before the recommendations result in tangible changes.

 Richard Colbey is a barrister.

webTitle: Small firms pushed to the edge

fields.headline: Small firms pushed to the edge
fields.trailText: Insurance is also causing problems for small businesses affected by the foot and mouth crisis - however, in this case, at stake is not the deposit paid on a holiday, but an entire livelihood.
fields.body:
Insurance is also causing problems for small businesses affected by the foot and mouth crisis - however, in this case, at stake is not the deposit paid on a holiday, but an entire livelihood.

Thousands of rural businesses are finding that their policies will not pay out, in spite of the fact that they are losing thousands of pounds a day as people are not there to use their shops or services.

The Association of British Insurers says that entrepreneurs are unlikely to be able to claim for loss of profits, interruption of business or even denial of access cover. The policies only pay if your firm misses out on business as a result of physical loss or damage to premises, due to fire or flood, for example.

Hotel or guesthouse owners who thought they may be able to claim under the disease clause, contained in the majority of small business policies, will be disappointed.

This states that cover will be given for the loss of business as a result of notifiable contagious or infectious diseases on your premises or within a 25 mile radius, but it applies only to human disease and not to a foot and mouth infection.

Events organisers may be more lucky, however. Insurex Expo-Sure says it will pay out on cancellation claims, provided the cover was taken out before February 22.

A spokesman says the company is being inundated with claims, ranging from the organisers of Crufts Dog Show to people organising antique fairs.

Liz Stuart

fields.headline: Prudential brightens the gloom
fields.standfirst: New move brings some hope for angry pensioners, but the critics remain. Patrick Collinson reports
fields.trailText: New move brings some hope for angry pensioners, but the critics remain. Patrick Collinson reports.
fields.body:
Prudential this week offered a glimmer of hope for pensioners furious at being forced into buying annuities at rock-bottom rates.

It is to launch what it calls "a new era in retirement planning" with an annuity that pays up to 5% more than current income levels, as well as allowing pensioners greater freedom to change their an nuity during their lifetime and control where it is invested.

But campaigners against annuity rules may be less than impressed, as the new Prudential deal still fails to answer one of the main criticisms of annuities - that once a pensioner has handed over their capital to the life company, the money stays with the life company rather than being passed to their estate when he or she dies.

Currently there a number of strictly applied rules concerning what you can do with your pension savings at retirement. A minimum of three quarters of the total sum saved has to be invested in an annuity by the age of 75, which is a guaranteed income for life. Unfortunately, because of falling yields on government stock (called gilts) on which annuity rates are based, the income levels from annuities have plummeted in recent years.

Ten years ago a married couple who saved £100,000 into a pension would have been able to pick up an inflation-proofed annuity of £11,000 a year at age 65 until they died. Today the same £100,000 will give a married couple little more than £7,000.

The annuity rules are currently under challenge from one 75-year-old pensioner who is being represented by Cherie Booth, QC, the Prime Minister's wife. Joe Singer, of Preston, Lancashire, claims that the age limit contravenes the European Convention on Human Rights, and Ms Booth is understood to be considering whether there could be grounds for a judicial review.

There were hopes before the Budget that the Chancellor would relax the annuity rules, but Mr Brown rejected calls for a wide-ranging review.

A frequent concern expressed by successive governments is that if the annuity rules are dropped, high spending pensioners will blow their pension cash quickly in the knowledge that they can fall back on the welfare state. Former Labour MP Oonagh McDonald, who heads a high-profile annuity reform group, says one way around this is for pensioners to be obliged to buy an annuity only up to the level at which it matches minimum state benefits - after that, they should be free to do what they want with their cash.

Prudential sides broadly with the government. Tom Boardman, managing director of Prudential Annuities says: "Oonagh McDonald's proposals will only help 10% of the population - the rest will be forced to buy an index-linked annuity to cover the cost of state benefits. If anything it would result in reduced choice for pensioners. What our new annuity does is go a long way to providing a flexible income and flexible investment while still satisfying the Inland Revenue."

But initially the new Pru annuity will only be available to people with pension savings above £100,000. Mr Boardman also admits that it is a complex product - a hybrid mix of with-profit annuity plus income drawdown product - so it is not selling it direct.

 Anyone wanting it should approach a specialist broker, such as Annuity Direct (020 7684 5000) or Annuity Bureau (020 7902 2300) for advice.

fields.headline: Good deal for users as cards are shuffled off again?
fields.standfirst: Rival issuers move in on Abbey customers dismayed at switch to MBNA. Rupert Jones reports
fields.trailText: Rival issuers move in on Abbey customers dismayed at switch to MBNA. Rupert Jones reports.
fields.body:
Abbey National's 500,000 credit cardholders might not be too pleased to discover they have been off- loaded on to a US-based card company which has come under fire for failing to sign up to the banking industry's code of practice.

But the good news is that, after the intervention of a banking watchdog, these people will continue to be protected by the code, which lays down minimum standards that banks and card companies must meet.

Nevertheless, some cardholders may decide that now is the time to switch to another provider. So, it's no surprise that rival card issuers, including Egg, have already started making a play for any disgruntled Abbey cardholders out there.

Abbey National this week announced that MBNA has bought its existing credit card customer base for £289m. The sale formed part of a deal that will see MBNA developing a new range of Abbey National-branded cards including cashback and platinum products.

Abbey says the link-up will deliver "more choice" and "better value" to its customers, and adds that MBNA's "ability to provide excellent service to our customers was the primary reason we chose them as a partner".

But while there was lots in the press release about the new cards that are planned, there was hardly any mention of how the deal will affect the half a million existing Abbey cardholders.

When asked about this, a spokesman for the bank says these people "should not worry" as the change in ownership should be seamless as far as they are concerned. Their cards and statements will continue to be branded Abbey National and the terms and conditions they signed up to will remain unchanged for the moment.

"They [the fees and charges] will not immediately reflect MBNA's charging structure," adds the spokes-man, while MBNA says: "Customers will be advised in due course of any change that may affect their accounts."

This suggests the terms and conditions could well be amended at a later date, which is both good news and bad news. Abbey currently imposes an annual fee of £9.50 if a cardholder does not have one of its bank accounts, while MBNA does not charge anyone an annual fee, so if everyone moved over to MBNA's terms and conditions they would presumably see their annual fee abolished.

MBNA's standard annual percentage rate (APR) for purchases is also slightly lower - 16.9 APR compared with Abbey's 18.9 APR - and in addition, MBNA offers customers 59 days' interest-free credit compared with Abbey's 49.

But on the other hand, MBNA's fees and charges tend to be higher. It imposes a hefty £18 fee for late payment, and charges the same amount if you exceed your credit limit. Abbey's fee in each case is £12.

However, the biggest downside looked like being that the Abbey cardholders were going to lose the protection offered by the banking code of practice because MBNA has refused to sign up to this (Abbey is a subscriber).

The latest version of the voluntary code came into force in January and it commits those who subscribe to making sure their terms and conditions are fair and set out "clearly and in plain language". It also means they must consider cases of finan cial hardship sympathetically, and correct mistakes and handle complaints quickly. Every company that signs up to the code must belong to either the banking ombudsman scheme or another independent complaints-handling scheme so people's gripes can be dealt with properly.

Things didn't look good in that MBNA doesn't seem to have any plans to sign up to the code - but the Banking Code Standards Board, the body which polices the banks and punishes any company that falls out of line, has ridden to the rescue. It has told Abbey that even though it has sold its credit card business, because the cards will continue to carry its name they must carry on being covered by the code.

"The customer is entitled to think this is an Abbey National product. As Abbey National is a subscriber, those cardholders must also be cov ered by the banking code," says Seymour Fortescue, who runs the board.

If despite this you're thinking about ditching your Abbey card, Egg is one of the companies that was laying out the welcome mat this week. Egg says it is extending its special six-month 0% balance transfer rate offer to all new customers who apply for one of its cards before April 30.

"The extension is intended to give Abbey National credit card customers, who are perhaps unhappy with being migrated by the bank to MBNA, the opportunity to apply and instantly begin to save money," says a spokesman.

Egg's rate on purchases is a competitive 11.9 APR and you can earn up to 2% cashback on your spending. But the card has to be applied for and managed online so it won't suit everyone.

fields.headline: A bruising, intelligent Henry V
fields.standfirst:
Henry V
Barbican
London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Henry V
Barbican
London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
Henry V is the play we whip out in a crisis. Laurence Olivier rallying the troops in the 1945 film version is as imprinted upon English consciousness as Land of Hope and Glory. But Edward Hall's modern-dress production takes a more sceptical look at Shakespeare's play, and the result is a bruising, intelligent consideration of what heroism and national identity mean in a more fragmented world. Despite being three and a half hours long, it has a racy feel, and the stage boils with furious energy, red smoke and rose petals.

With design by Michael Pavelka, Hall sets the play at the pithead. A lot of the battles have a second world war feel, but the cries of "Engerland" are pure Euro 2000. Hall suggests that the same raucous energy that is part of the national character that got the country through the war can also be a negative thing. Henry's army here is a rabble of unemployed, disenfranchised, regional voices made into a cohesive whole only by the dogged determination of the young king.

William Houston's Henry V is a man, not a myth. This is a chap trying to do the right thing, but it never comes easily; a man testing himself, who discovers, almost to his own surprise, that he is a natural leader. He's not a natural wooer, though his final scene with the French princess Katherine has a funny, gawky charm as he tries to penetrate her proud resentment.

Just as Hall's production is the calling card of a premier-division director, so Houston's performance should allow him to lay claim to any number of major classical parts. His Henry, after all, is a man who is almost trying on roles to see if they fit. He is not naturally charismatic but makes himself seem that way. He is full of complex ambiguities as he weighs up what is right and what is necessary. He has Bardolph hung with a curt nod of the head, the prisoners of war dispatched in a volley of machine-gun fire. But behind the cool, ruthless exterior there lurks self-doubt and a man who loves to be liked.

However, this is no star vehicle, but a real company piece that brings the play vividly alive and reminds that winning the war is the easy bit - it is peace that is the real test of character.

 Until April 21. Box office: 020-7638 8891.

fields.headline: Outsider Art/Music
fields.standfirst:
Barbican
London
Rating: **
fields.trailText:
Barbican
London
Rating: **
fields.body:
Musical outsiders don't come more extreme than Harry Partch, the first composer featured in the Barbican's Outsider Art/Music concert. Partch, who died in 1974, spent a lifetime creating a world of new instruments and microtonal tuning systems. The American Festival of Microtonal Music Ensemble here played four of his Li Po Songs for cello and voice, and two larger ensemble pieces, Dark Brother and Incident at Drake's Bay, which required a selection of Partch's own instruments. His kithara was a huge box containing rows of strings, while an enormous tubed bass marimba was made from industrial piping.

The Li Po Songs were performed without visuals, and their bewildering austerity actually provoked a fight in the audience. The larger pieces were performed underneath a video of Henry Darger's bizarre paintings. Darger, who lived as a recluse in Chicago and died in 1973, made his life's work a vast narrative of words and pictures called The Story of the Vivian Girls, in What is Known as the Realms of the Unreal, of the Glandeco-Angelinnian War Storm, as Caused by the Child Slave Rebellion. The scrolling images told a reduced version of the story.

The Story is an elaborate myth of corrupted innocence, populated almost entirely by pre-pubescent, androgynous girls. Armies of marauding adult males dressed in first world war costumes encroach on their pastoral idyll, shooting, crucifying and mutilating the children. The final image is of a starkly depopulated landscape. Darger's kitschy style, like a mix of manga, Japanese prints and children's illustrations, could not be further from Partch's ritualistic dissonance. Beyond their superficial lifestyle connections, it was difficult to see why these artists had been chosen for each other. The ensemble's performance only became involving at the end of their set, and Partch's singular vision was partially glimpsed.

Joe Coleman's artwork dominated the second half, with music by the Clerks' Group, who sang works by Renaissance composer and murderer Carlo Gesualdo, and Glaswegian indie band the Delgados. In a technique developed from the comics of Robert Crumb and the drawings of Hans Bellmer, Coleman creates vast canvases that seethe with orgiastic depravity. Gesualdo's serene lamentations were transformed into disturbing soundtracks for the dead, damned, and decaying.

What Coleman lacks is a sense of perspective, either painterly or emotional. The relentless horrors of his material soon became hackneyed and one-dimensional. But the Delgados' soundtrack for Coleman's Portraits series created a musical depth that counteracted the limitations of the paintings. Their music was an impassioned commentary on Coleman's dark pantheon of America's underworld, which included Ed Gein, the murderer who inspired The Texas Chainsaw Massacre, adolescent killers, and even Coleman himself. This final set succeeded where the rest of the concert failed - in creating moments of genuinely multimedia collaboration.

webTitle: Why cash would have been safer

fields.headline: Why cash would have been safer
fields.standfirst: The UK economy may be strong but this is small consolation for those watching their shares tumble, says  Robin Stoddart
fields.trailText: The UK economy may be strong but this is small consolation for those watching their shares tumble, says Robin Stoddart.
fields.body:
Officially, the UK economy is set firmly on a path of sustainable growth. Yet investors are seeing the value of their shares tumble. For many with holdings in privatised utilities or savings vehicles benefiting from a broader equity spread and tax incentives, it is a new and daunting experience. Even at declining interest rate returns, cash would have been so much safer.

Even that old spur to put money to good use, inflation, is about to become a mild embarrassment on the downside, calling for a letter of explanation from the governor of the Bank of England to an unruffled chancellor of the exchequer. That happy state may not last. Acute problems in agriculture and the regional fringes are not enough to derail the financial system. But when more powerful overseas economies are in trouble, gloom can feed on itself.

So far, the blame for the se vere fall in share prices falls entirely on the sudden downturn in US output. The official line that Britain and Europe need not be badly affected is losing credence. The consensus still is that we should be fine for some months, given the strength of government finances and the employment market. Ahead of the election, the government certainly hopes so. But further ahead recession will almost inevitably extend to the UK if the statistics confirm that it already afflicts the US. American companies are a vital ingredient in the health of the UK economy. Mercifully, they are still spending on new facilities in some of the most needy areas. There need be no universal crisis of confidence while there is such support for job creation.

Decisions not to lower interest rates on the pound or euro anything like as fast as the US Federal Reserve has been cutting them on the dollar reflected the more phlegmatic attitude of financiers on this side of the Atlantic. The latest heavy falls on Wall Street were caused by the limitation of the last reduction in dollar rates to another half per cent. Many commentators said that anything more might have seemed like panic.

So far there has been only intermittent disturbance on the currency scene. The belief that the dollar will remain king, even as interest rates on it become still less rewarding, and the US trade gap yaws still wider, is unshaken. The counterpart of this is the weakness of the yen as the internal financial crisis in Japan led to negligible interest rates there once again. Japan's trade surplus helps the dollar in these circumstances. The sharp midweek rebound on the Tokyo stock market did foreign investors little good after the dire experience of most of the past 15 years and recent decline in the yen. Anyway, the rally was brief.

Europe presents a rela tively unflurried scene, even though the most prominent multinational success stories in mobile phones and other advanced products have suffered from the downgrading of performance and prospects by US rivals. Euro-zone growth forecasts are being lowered mainly because of fears that German exports will fall back from their record levels in the US. Its building industry is in recession. But France and most other countries will continue to benefit from the high demand for luxury goods and services from the vastly increased numbers of the well-off. This could apply to Britain, except that the supply side is looking increasingly battered. Yet industrialists remain surprisingly buoyant, except, of course, in electronics and in chemicals where most volume producers are now foreign-owned.

Buyers of index tracking funds are seeing their holdings fall sharply in value, making the saving on expenses in such passively managed funds a minor consideration. Holders of income bonds with a few years to run can only grit their teeth and hope for better times when they receive bonuses on top of any income they may have drawn meantime. They would have been better off in gilts as interest rates fell, though some profit-taking, free of any tax liability on gains, would be wise when there is any hint of a rebound in inflation.

Almost all investors in unit trusts have lost a significant proportion of their savings over recent months. Over a year perhaps 3% were still in the black, at least until the latest setback, thanks to income-oriented investments in old-economy stocks and property issues. Now the building sector has taken a knock on the realisation that last year's profit upturn is unlikely to be sustained in present weather conditions. There must already be some cheap buys available at much-reduced prices. But the odds are probably against digging them out at immediate benefit, such is the scourge of a bear market.

Where prices have fallen below the value of underlying investments, as in a few of the specialist European investment trusts, they may be said to be cheap. This barely applies to the best recent performer Fidelity European Values, which had achieved growth of around 15% over the last year. Shares of the previous top performer TR European growth are also priced closely in line with underlying holdings. But recent poor performers, such as Perpetual European and Gartmore European, which have suffered from the slide in telecommunications issues, particularly Ericsson and, before its recovery against the trend in the last week Nokia, are now priced at large discounts. Yet Nokia, Finland's giant that dominates its stock market and has been a favourite investment for international funds, is still achieving growth well into double figures. Ericsson shares have been further weakened by the fall in the Swedish currency.

Recent changes in management and ownership appear to have been adverse for some funds investing in Europe. But Fleming's European trusts have performed creditably in recent years and do stand at sizeable discounts. A weaker pound and stronger euro would boost the whole sector and support hopes of economic growth throughout Europe.

fields.headline: When guides lead you astray
fields.trailText: Equity Isa sales are slumping, with many providers admitting sales have fallen by at least a third. And the biggest number of stayaways may be the clients of discount financial advisers, reacting against Isa guides in which the only advice is for funds which have paid for adverts.
fields.body:
Equity Isa sales are slumping, with many providers admitting sales have fallen by at least a third. And the biggest number of stayaways may be the clients of discount financial advisers, reacting against Isa guides in which the only advice is for funds which have paid for adverts.

Some independent financial advisors (IFAs), whose selling efforts are largely focused on printing and distributing millions of guides with midmarket newspapers, have seen business fall by half.

Last year, many Isa investors were pushed into then-big-selling technology funds by the advert-dominated guides. One from IFA Elson Associ ates, paid for by five sets of ads from technology funds, said: "The explosive growth in the technology sector has been matched by technology shares. They have massively outperformed world equity markets over the last few years and most experts predict similar dynamic growth in the years to come."

But "most experts" were wrong. The five funds featured, including the highly hyped Framlington NetNet and Gartmore Techtornado, have fallen by between two-thirds and three-quarters since their peak. No fund which did not pay for an advert appeared in the guide.

"This leading of investors up an ad-led garden path may be one reason for their disenchantment with guide-led advice," says one IFA who refuses to accept ads.

And now investors may be even more confused: the funds that one IFA recommends varies according to which guide they read. A recommended purchase in one guide is replaced by another, rival fund in a second guide from the same IFA.

Leeds-based IFA Bates Investment Services has issued two Isa guides this year. Each contains separate recommendations. But while one is dominated by the Bates logo, the second comes from WiseUp, an "appointed representative" of Bates - which is regulation-speak for a sales set-up for which Bates takes full responsibility. Some 7m copies of WiseUp guides have been distributed in two midmarket Sunday newspapers. The Bates guide has a lower circulation; it was sent out to previous clients and those who asked for a copy.

The WiseUp guide features Invesco GT European Growth, a one-time high flier which has fallen to near the bottom of its sector over the past year. The guide, while accepting the trust has "a risk rating above the sector average" ignores the fall from grace.

Instead, it talks of the fund bearing "the crucial hallmark of consistent good performance". It offers a £227.50 discount on a £7,000 investment. And the guide carries an ad for the Invesco product.

Ads cost fund companies £70,000 to £100,000 a time - ruling out most small unit trust groups on cost grounds.

Readers of the Bates Isas Focus guide are offered the rival Gartmore European Selected Opportunities Isa. This is hailed as "consistently among the top performers". Unsurprisingly, the guide carries an ad for the Gartmore trust. Here, the discount is £105 on a full equity Isa.

WiseUp goes for the newly launched Fidelity Healthcare, while Bates opts for Schroder Medical Discovery. There is a similar split between a Norwich Union high yield trust in WiseUp and a rival Threadneedle fund in Bates Isa Focus.

James Dalby is head of research at Bates and is responsible for selecting funds. He says: "I get a brief from the marketing department to produce recommendations for Isa guides and find suitable trusts. There are a number of quality funds in each sector. We use more than one with those clients whom we advise individually."

Dalby says that because of the long lead times for these guides - marketing of advertising space for the WiseUp product started last July - some funds may have fallen or risen since selection.

"It would be more open and present more choice to have several funds in each guide. I'm not against it, but my brief was to come up with a limited number of funds. I do take the issue of inconsistency [recommending one fund to one set of readers and a second to another] on board."

But this could be the last time that Bates - and many rival discount guide producers - goes down this route, because Graham Bates says his business from the guides is down 50%. Many others have experienced similar falls.

The decision to push Gartmore to previous clients instead of Invesco is because "many already have Invesco. They might want a change of focus," says Mr Bates.

He adds: "We take a contribution from those we have chosen to go in. We don't make a profit from these sums. If they didn't pay, we wouldn't have a product and investors would not get discounts. It is an expensive business. Distribution in a newspaper can cost £350,000 a time. Taking ads is a commercial reality."

Mr Bates admits that he could not mention one fund while another in the same sector is paying for an ad. "You could not expect payment from Fidelity for its health fund if we give Schroder's rival trust a free mention or vice versa, so we have to put them in separate books," he says.

Don Clark at Wolverhampton IFA Torquil Clark is one of the growing number who are speaking out against the ad-dominated guides. He says: "These guides purport to be independent recommendations when many are little more than a collection of ads stapled together. Innocent readers accept them as best advice - especially if they have a newspaper logo. Funds are included because money changes hands and that can't be healthy."

Clark and some other IFAs have urged the Financial Services Authority to act on the loophole that allows independent advisers to push funds through magazines and mailshots without the normal "best advice". But so far, the watchdog has not ruled on the issue.

webTitle: Know your rights and wrongs as a shopper

fields.headline: Know your rights and wrongs as a shopper
fields.standfirst: As half the country goes on a spree to clothe their families for the summer, Jill Papworth  looks at how UK law protects consumers
fields.trailText: As half the country goes on a spree to clothe their families for the summer, Jill Papworth looks at how UK law protects consumers.
fields.body:
With the new season's fashions flooding into stores, now is the time of year when many people start hitting the shops to kit out the family for the spring and summer. But before embarking on a spree, it's worth checking that you are clued up on your shopper's rights and know where you stand should you need to return faulty goods.

You have certain statutory rights under UK law when you buy or hire goods from a trader and these are the same whether you buy from shops, street markets, mail order catalogues or over the internet. These rights are also the same if you buy something in a sale. The law says that goods must be:

Of satisfactory quality

The Office of Fair Trading says this means that goods must meet the standard that a reasonable person would regard as acceptable bearing in mind the way they were described, what they cost and any other relevant circumstances. This covers, for instance, the appearance and finish of goods, their safety and their durability. Goods must be free from defect, even minor ones, except when they have been brought to your attention by the seller, for example, if they are labelled "shop-soiled".

Fit for their purpose
Including any purpose mentioned by you to the seller. If, for example, you explain you want a child's waterproof jacket for an outdoor activity holiday, the seller must not supply you with one that lets in water when it rains.

As described on the package, display sign, on the website or by the seller

A dress described as 100% cotton should not turn out to be cotton and polyester.

You have no grounds for complaint about a faulty item if you were told about the specific flaw when you bought it or if you did the damage yourself.

Likewise, you have no right to return an item and expect redress because you made a mistake when you bought it or simply changed your mind about it later. But though you are not legally entitled to anything in these circumstances, it's always worth asking if the vendor is prepared to help out.

Many traders have goodwill policies which go beyond your statutory rights, giving you an exchange or refund for items which are not faulty but which you decide, for example, are the wrong size, colour or style.

If an item you buy is faulty and you tell the seller promptly that you don't want it, you should be able to get your money back and not have to accept a replacement or repair instead of a refund. As long as you have not legally accepted the goods, you can still reject them; that is, refuse to keep them.

One of the ways you accept goods is by keeping them, without complaint, after you have had a reasonable time to examine them. What is reasonable is not fixed, but normally you can at least take your purchase home and try it out. If, however, you delay in examining what you've bought or in telling the seller about a fault, then you may lose your right to reject.

Note that if you sign an acceptance note on receiving goods, say through mail order, this does not mean you have signed away your right to reject. You still have a reasonable time to examine them.

Letting the seller try to put faulty goods right also has no effect on your rights. If the repair fails, you still have any right to reject them that you had when you agreed to the repair.

Some vendors may use ploys to try to get out of their responsibilities, but try not to be put off by these. The law says it is up to the seller to deal with complaints about faulty goods. So don't fall for the line that: "It's the manufacturer's fault." Demand that the seller puts things right.

You have the same rights even if you lose your receipt, though the onus will be on you to prove when and where you bought the goods.

And remember, too, that you have the same rights when you buy sale goods as at any other time.

So it is illegal for vendors to display disclaimers saying that there are no refunds on sale goods; you should think twice before buying from a seller who shows a notice like this.

You have fewer rights if you buy goods from private individuals or at an auction, so in these cases it is doubly important to check that you are getting a good deal before you buy.

fields.headline: Emerson Quartet
fields.standfirst:
Wigmore Hall
London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Wigmore Hall
London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
Last year the Emerson Quartet brought a complete Shostakovich cycle to London. This year they were less ambitious but still displayed the musical intelligence and integrity that is their hallmark.

Nobody plays second fiddle in this group - literally, as the two violinists trade seats from piece to piece. From his pivotal position at the centre of the quartet, cellist David Finckel is often cast as the anchor. It was this very individual balance - thick, full textures from the upper three parts, simple, open notes from the cello - that characterised the opening of Mendelssohn's Op 13 quartet.

Mendelssohn's chamber music remains underrated. The fiery first movement of this work perhaps betrays his youth (he was just 18), containing more heart-on-sleeve drama than one piece can easily hold, but those that follow are mature and full of character. Philip Setzer took the first violin part. He could have been more declamatory in the allegro of the opening movement, but had grown in authority for his softly spoken monologue in the finale. The quartet despatched the scherzo with wit and charm, and Lawrence Dutton projected his exposed viola solos beautifully.

Gyorgy Kurtag's 12 Microludes, averaging less than a minute each, made an astringent contrast, and the Emersons amply conveyed their introspective, concentrated beauty.

Eugene Drucker took over the leader's chair for Beethoven's Op 130 quartet, which seemed the more effective seating arrangement on this occasion - or perhaps the players relaxed as they entered more familiar repertoire. In any case, this was a searching account of an elusive work.

The climax of the evening was the finale - the Grosse Fuge, Op 133. This baffling movement can seem like a free-for-all, whereas it's finely balanced. There was no lack of machismo in the Emersons' playing, but at the same time they kept an eye to an overreaching structure. The quartet teased with a transformation of the aggressive theme into a well-behaved classical scherzo before bringing the work to its magnificent ending. I have heard more graceful performances of the Fuge, but probably none more convincing.

webTitle: Equitable Life says no to the OFT

fields.headline: Equitable Life says no to the OFT
fields.standfirst: Pensions
fields.trailText: Mind the gap: Equitable is the only provider making a 'market value adjustment'
fields.body:
Mind the gap: Equitable is the only provider making a 'market value adjustment'

Equitable Life has snubbed the Office of Fair Trading's requests to change the way it decides on exit penalties for with-profits pensions policyholders locked into the beleaguered firm.

These "market value adjustments" have just been increased from 10% of the fund transferred, to 15%. Equitable says this is a response to falling share prices.

The penalty was set up to prevent policyholders bailing out of Equitable. The life company's crisis came to a head in December when no buyer could be found following a defeat in a House of Lords case which forced it to pay out on expensive guaranteed annuities to some pension holders.

This increase, which has convinced many policyholders and financial advisers that there is little light at the end of the Equitable tunnel, has been approved by the Financial Services Authority.

But while the OFT is not officially concerned with its size, it has worries over the contract wording which gives Equitable "absolute discretion" over escape penalties. The OFT says it wants the terms reworded to be "fair".

It adds: "They should show detail so that policyholders will know what details are taken into consideration when an adjustment is calculated. Otherwise consumers could suffer detriment."

The ultimate sanction is for the OFT to take Equitable to court. However, Equitable Life has now told the OFT that it will not change. In a strong defence of the status quo, it claims that every life office has absolute discretion, and that it cannot change contractual terms after the contract has been signed.

The OFT has refused to comment on Equitable's response, although it is "aware of the interest and concern". It says: "The more they increase the percentage, the more urgent action becomes."

But that is not the only hit Equitable customers have to take. The 90,000 guaranteed annuity customers face an even more effective lock-in.

They had been promised a bonus if they voted for a capping of their guarantees as part of the general restructuring of the firm following the sale of the salesforce and other assets to Halifax for £750m to £1bn, depending on future performance.

Most assumed they would receive a bonus later this year - part recompense for the cancellation of some recent bonuses. But now it appears that any extra money will be drip fed into their pension pots, with most paid when they cash in policies.

Despite the problems, Equitable says "lots of policyholders" are continuing to pay premiums. But this is just pouring good money after bad, according to IFA Kean Seager of Bristol-based Whitechurch Securities.

"No one in their right mind should pay further premiums," he says. "The Halifax package is just 3% of the total in the with-profits pool. Their reserves are very thin. Things could get worse if shares continue to fall. They will then have to up the exit fee again."

Seager is closely linked with the Equitable Policyholders Action Group. It hopes the government will act to compensate the majority of policyholders who do not have guarantees but whose cash could buttress the annuity warranties.

The vote on whether guarantee holders will accept a deal has now been put off from summer to autumn. IFA Brian Dennehy of Kent-based Dennehy, Weller, says: "No one else is applying a market value adjustment. Equitable is very exposed and if interest rates fall, the guaranteed annuity bill will go up as well. The FSA seems to be ignoring its duty to investors to maintain an orderly market in this area."

One possible, penalty-free escape for those over 50 is a phased retirement plan with another provider. This involves switching the fund and taking out a small annuity, leaving the rest until it is needed.

Those under 50 with guarantees should stay in for now, Dennehy suggests. Their funds will have to produce a third less than rivals before the guarantee effect is negated. But for those without guarantees, the penalty increase makes life harder.

"When it was 10%, I calculated it would take six years elsewhere to make up the loss. Now it stands at 15%, it will take nine years. No one should put in more. For many, there will be peace of mind if they clear out of Equitable," he says.

webTitle: Theatre review:  A Midsummer Night's Dream

fields.headline: Dawn French's mildly funny Bottom
fields.standfirst:
A Midsummer Night's Dream
Albery Theatre
London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
A Midsummer Night's Dream
Albery Theatre
London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
I feel in two minds about this new West End Dream. Dawn French, though a big draw, is not the greatest Bottom I've seen. And Matthew Francis's chosen setting of a 1940s manor house is whimsically odd. But if the play teaches us anything, it is to exercise charity, and by the end I felt Shakespeare had just about managed to win through.

What strikes you about the setting is that it makes total nonsense of the opening scenes. Why should these rural denizens be invoking "the ancient privilege of Athens"? And few Sussex girls, I suspect, were threatened with death, as Hermia is, for failing to marry their father's choice. The setting also undermines the testy relationship of Jemma Redgrave's captive Hippolyta to Michael Siberry's Theseus, which is later echoed by their antagonism in the roles of Titania and Oberon.

Updating Shakespeare is neither good nor bad: it all depends on the use made of it. Here the anachronisms outweigh the advantages until one gets to the wood, where the period setting becomes irrelevant. And it is the quartet of lovers who give this production its vital energy. Their great quarrel scene is wonderfully played, with Gillian Kearney's vixenish Hermia doubling the wounded spite of Tilly Blackwood's muddied Helena and hurling Will Keen's scornful Lysander to the ground.

But it is Dawn French's Bottom people will come to see and she strikes me as no more than mildly funny. The main joke is that she is translated not merely into an ass but one with a furry male appendage. It gives her the chance to find unsuspected double entendres but robs her transition back to human form of its magic. The point is that Bottom has been entangled in a dream, not that a woman has found herself sporting an ass's member.

For me the production misses the play's transfigurative strangeness. It is typical that Theseus's great speech on imagination is upstaged by the rearrangement of the furniture in his oddly restored house. In place of strangeness, we get high spirits. The Pyramus-Thisbe scene is nicely done - I particularly liked Debbie Chazen's revolving wall - and it is capped by an invigorating dance to a Benny Goodman swing number. But in a truly great Dream, as opposed to a merely pleasant one, you should feel the characters have emerged from chaos into a self-realising state of liberated concord.

 Until May 12. Box office: 020-7369 1740. A version of this review appeared in later editions of yesterday's paper.

webTitle: Market crisis: How to get protected

fields.headline: Where to take shelter in the eye of the storm
fields.standfirst: With shares tumbling and sales of Isas down heavily, nervous investors are wondering what to do to protect their money. But, as Phillip Inman  and  Rupert Jones  report, shaky times also offer opportunities
fields.trailText: With shares tumbling and sales of Isas down heavily, nervous investors are wondering what to do to protect their money. But, as Phillip Inman and Rupert Jones report, shaky times also offer opportunities.
fields.body:
Turmoil in the world's stock markets is the kind of phrase that makes even battle hardened investors think twice about buying shares. After the steep rise last year in the share prices of dot.com companies and telephone companies such as BT and Vodafone, the London Stock Exchange now appears to be in free fall, tumbling day after day with the occasional breathing space before traders again watch their screens turn red.

In the past six months the London market has dropped nearly 20% and now stands at its lowest point for 18 months. Last year the index of the UK's top 100 companies touched 7,000 points. Now there are queues of analysts willing to bet the market has further to fall and is likely to dive below 5,000 and keep going.

Forget that many of them said last year the market was set to grow for ever and firms such as Lastminute.com would be worth billions of pounds. Analyst reports that gushed about promising dot.coms have long since been shredded. Today there are some hard realities to deal with.

They point to a slowdown in the US economy that is rapidly turning into a recession. UK companies are suffering too, especially ones that run businesses on the other side of the Atlantic. A long list of them have over the past few weeks reported declining profits and worse to come if the US economy fails to turn around quickly.

Anyone looking to use an Individual Savings Account (Isa) as a safe, tax-free home for their investment money could be forgiven for saying to themselves that stock markets, like Las Vegas casinos, are not the places to hang around if staying solvent is the objective. Those people who have already taken the plunge and spent the maxi mum £7,000 in their Isa allocation on unit trusts, investment trusts, or even individual shares are also likely to be nervous about the prospects for their money.

Isa sales are down by anything between a quarter and a half, which shows how the falling market is jangling the nerves of ordinary investors. Many are not first-time buyers and are nursing big losses from their investments last year in dot.com unit trusts like Framlington's NetNet fund and trusts that invested in media and telecoms stocks.

But hang on, there's an old market saying that goes something like "when there's blood on the carpet, that's the time to buy". There are scores of subscribers to this strategy and many of them are the same analysts who predict further big falls in the market. They all predict a bounce back and reckon get ting back into the market before the end of the tax year, or sticking with it, is a sure fire hit.

Unit trust manager Colin Morton of BWD Rensburg says the market is suffering from an over reaction to the dot.com debacle and further falls are likely. "It is probably a good time to buy, even if this isn't the bottom of the market. You've just got to close your eyes and do it. The FTSE 100 might go down to 5,000 before it bounces back, but I would bet the market will be much higher than it is today in two years' time."

Like Mr Morton, Neil Woodford spent last year refusing to believe that dot.coms had invented a new business model that justified multi-million pound valuations based on thousand pound turnovers. Mr Woodford, who manages £3bn for small investors at Perpetual, was in the doghouse because Perpetual funds were refusing to buy the technology stocks that most other managers were jumping into. Twelve months later his High Income and Income funds are still up by 15-20% over the year when nearly everything else is down. He believes the current turmoil is overdone, and is very confident that the market will recover, though not in the technology sector.

Mike Young of Goldman Sachs believes that shares are still overpriced. He says the trough in the market will be reached some time in the next six months and by next year the markets will be back on an upward track.

The trouble for Isa buyers is that they can't wait that long. If they hold back until they see an upswing they will miss out on this year's allocation. Amanda Davidson of independent financial adviser Holden Meehan says that could be a mistake. She also recommends buying now.

There are ways of minimising the volatility.

One way is Fidelity's Funds Network fund supermarket (www.fundsnetwork.co.uk) and similar sites such as Wolverhampton-based IFA Torquil Clark's www.tqonline.co.uk, which allow you to phase your investment. You hand over your Isa money now and it is divided into six equal chunks and drip-fed in over the next six months. While your money is waiting to be invested it is sitting in a cash account earning interest (which is taxed).

More sophisticated investors might want to consider self-select Isas. With these, you buy individual stocks and shares instead of purchasing a unit trust or in vestment trust. Where they score during times of volatility is that you don't have to invest immediately - you can open one and hold your investment in cash for perhaps a few months until you are ready to buy. In the meantime your money earns interest, which is taxed. Self-select Isas tend to be the preserve of stockbrokers. Several online brokers offer them including iDealing.com (www.idealing.com), E*Trade (www.etrade.co.uk) and DLJ Direct (<A HREF="http://www.dljdirect.co.uk)."

Corporate" TARGET="_NEW">www.dljdirect.co.uk).

Corporate bonds are usually seen as a safe haven during periods of market volatility. These are issued by companies as a method of borrowing money. Individuals can invest via corporate bond funds, and these are good for income-seeking investors - they will not give you capital growth over the long term, says Mike Attree at Torquil Clark. Investment brokers Allenbridge recommends the Norwich Union Higher Income Plus Fund, which has an income yield of more than 8%, and the Legal & General Fixed Interest fund, which offers a yield of 6.6%.

A new type of Isa invites small investors to put money into hedge funds, traditionally the preserve of the super-rich. They are being marketed as offering people the opportunity of making money whether stock markets are rising, falling or moving sideways.

However the Financial Services Authority has warned investors to "be wary" of them. Several fund management firms including Jupiter, Deutsche Asset Management and Credit Suisse First Boston have introduced or are planning hedge fund Isas where the minimum investment is usually £7,000. They are "funds of hedge funds" which means they invest people's money in several different hedge funds.

There are also protected equity funds which typically might guarantee that if you invest and the market falls, perhaps 90%-95% of your capital will be protected and the most you could lose is 5%-10%. While most of the money you invest goes into equities a small portion is used to buy options. The options provide a safety net and cushion your fund's fall so the original investment is not lost. But the options are expensive to buy, and are even more costly at times of market volatility.

fields.headline: Is cover on if that country trip's off?
fields.standfirst: The foot and mouth epidemic is playing havoc with holidays and short breaks around the country.  Liz Stuart  looks at the position of tourists when the restrictions force cancellation
fields.trailText: The foot and mouth epidemic is playing havoc with holidays and short breaks around the country. Liz Stuart looks at the position of tourists when the restrictions force cancellation.
fields.body:
While foot and mouth is having a severe impact on farmers, its malign reach has now extended as far as the country holiday, as hills usually tramped and waterways navigated are closed to the public.

For some, this will mean the disappointment of having to wait until the summer or even the autumn before they can make their trip. But others who are unable to postpone, may face hefty financial penalties if they are forced to cancel.

Currently the advice from the chief veterinary officer Jim Scudamore is that people can go anywhere in the countryside, including outdoor attractions - providing there are no susceptible animals - and sporting events, although this weekend's Ireland v England rugby match in Dublin has been cancelled.

You can also stay in hotels or guest houses in the countryside and in some places you are still able to camp, walk, ride, cycle, sail, fish and row. However, you may not use closed footpaths or go on farmland which is being used by livestock.

Many organisations, such as the National Trust, English Heritage, the Forestry Commission and British Waterways are considering lifting their restrictions and bans on visitors. And the impact on UK tourists to date has been limited because the holiday season has not yet started.

But, inevitably, several thousand holidays will be affected. Either people will have been intending to stay in a guesthouse or cottage in an exclusion zone, or they will live in such a zone which they are not able to leave or - and this is likely to affect the largest numbers - preplanned activities such as hill walking will not be possible.

Some holidaymakers will face the further shock of finding that their travel insurance does not cover them for cancellations.

Primary Direct, a leading low cost insurer, says it will cover individuals who live in quarantine areas, but it will not refund any money already paid by those who had intended to travel to infected areas, because the small print says that the policy relates to mishaps affecting the individual, rather than events. However, managing director Tim Berry says: "We are taking further advice and we are sympathetic to the issue."

Similarly Fortis Insurance says its policies explicitly exclude claims relating to travel which is hindered because of government regulations. "But we're waiting to see what happens. We haven't had any claims yet, but should it happen and there are only a few cases then we might be willing to make an exception. But this whole thing could get very big," says a spokeswoman.

Boots takes the same line as the majority of companies: if you are travelling to a hotel or farm which is in the infected area and so is closed, you will be refunded. If, however, your hotel is near a quarantine area and the walks you had intended to do are not possible, you will not automatically be covered. "We will consider each case on its own merits," says a spokeswoman. This is frequently a euphemism for "no".

A spokeswoman for Saga, which sells a single trip travel insurance policy, says that it will now only sell insurance to people travelling to a hotel or area which is not foot and mouth affected. "If they want to go to an area which is closed at the moment, then we cannot sell them insurance," she says.

Paul Dittmer, marketing manager of Columbus Direct, says it is currently handling 33 claim cases for foot and mouth-related cancellations. "The key word is "enjoyment". If the policy has been block booked by a rambling group, then it is obvious that walking would be central to their enjoyment of the holiday and so a claim would be valid. But if I had booked a holiday in Northumberland, say, with my family, there would be several other activi ties for us, such as going to the swimming pool." He adds that policies had to have been taken out by February 21 - the day when the Government stopped the transportation of cattle - for claims to be eligible.

If you are not insured - and the majority of people do not take out cover for domestic holidays, although they may be automatically covered under their annual travel policy - you may find the tour company or hotel will refund your money in full in any case.

This is because they have not be able to provide you with the holiday for which you have paid.

The Association of British Travel Agents (Abta) agrees that this is a "tricky issue". A spokeswoman says that problems should only arise where people have booked a package and walking or fishing or boating was not an integral part of the holiday, just something which you had intended to do while there. "In this case it's not the tour operator's problem and you would not be able to claim," she says.

Contours Walking, a company which organises breaks in Scotland, England and Wales and which has seen the majority of its customers cancel their trips, says it is is giving a full refund to customers, unless the company has had to pay a non-refundable deposit to hotels or guest houses on the client's behalf.

Managing director Mark Townsend says he is receiving 150 emails a day from concerned customers.

"The perception is that this country is just not a safe place to come to. We had one from an American who was obviously fairly clued up about British farming issues. He said that first we had salmonella in eggs, then in poultry, then we had BSE, then scrapie and swine fever and now we have foot and mouth. 'Is there anything left safe to eat over there?' " he asked.

Holidays in Ireland are affected, too. South West Walking Ireland, based in Kerry, says most people are choosing to postpone, but it is offering a full refund if this is not possible.

A recent survey carried out by the Post Office showed that almost 50% of people who take out travel insurance do so without checking the small print.

webTitle:
Cracking the faulty 
 
down on surveys

fields.headline:
Cracking the faulty 
 
down on surveys
fields.standfirst: Restrictive practices under fire
fields.trailText: The Court of Appeal has found for a Cornish homeowner in a ruling that closes one of the last bases on which negligent surveyors could try to escape liability.
fields.body:
The Court of Appeal has found for a Cornish homeowner in a ruling that closes one of the last bases on which negligent surveyors could try to escape liability.

Diana Merrett bought a house in Falmouth with her mother. Their mortgage lender, the Bradford & Bingley, commissioned a valuation report which was carried out by John Babb.

Mr Babb, who was employed as branch manager by Plymouth chartered surveyors, Clive Walker Associates, failed to notice some fairly significant cracks in the walls and, as a result, the house was worth £14,500 less than his valuation suggested.

Had she known its true state, Ms Merrett wouldn't have bought it at all. When she discovered the defects she tried to get Clive Walker Associates to compensate her. However, that firm had ceased to exist as its owner had been made bankrupt. In the course of the bankruptcy the insurance policy that should have covered such a claim had been cancelled. The only person who could be sued for the loss was the unlucky Mr Babb.

He argued that he hadn't been negligent at all. But after hearing all the evidence at Truro county court, Judge Sean Overend decided that any competent surveyor should have seen those cracks.

The judge also rejected Mr Babb's claim that he personally did not owe Ms Merrett any duty of care and hence could not be liable. It was primarily on this point that the case went to the court of appeal. Mr Babb argued that when preparing the report he did not know who it was intended for. When the report was forwarded by Bradford & Bingley to Ms Merrett she did not know who had prepared it. Although she had to pay for it, all reference to Mr Babb or his firm had been removed from the signed version that was sent to Bradford & Bingley.

In recent years the courts have become reluctant to allow professional people to escape liability on the basis of such technical arguments, and the decision in Ms Merrett's favour was a logical extension of that principle.

The court had regard to a decision of the House of Lords in 1989 where a young couple sued Wyre Forest council. The local authority - as councils frequently did - gave them a mortgage on a privately purchased property in Kidderminster. The valuation was even more negligent than Mr Babb's, missing subsidence that left the house virtually worthless.

In that case, the law lords had taken what seems like a common-sense approach, accepting that most purchasers rely on the valuation obtained for mortgage purposes as many can't afford another. Surveyors, whether employed or working on their own account, know that reality and it is artificial to argue they should not have the purchasers' interests in mind when drawing up the valuation.

This logic was followed in Ms Merrett's claim. The decision will affect not only homeowners, but also employed surveyors and possibly accountants and architects. There is always a risk that they, like Mr Babb, will be left to pick up the tab, if things go wrong at the firm they work for. The court of appeal suggested they might wish to insure against the risk of that happening. Homebuyers, though, will get the peace of mind of knowing that an event completely outside their control, like an insolvency at a firm they did not even select, does not deprive them of redress should their property have been negligently valued.

Although she had to pay for it, all reference to Mr Babb or his firm had been removed from the signed version that was sent to Bradford & Bingley. In recent years the courts have become reluctant to allow professional people to escape liability on the basis of such technical arguments, and the decision in Ms Merrett's favour was a logical extension of that principle. The court had regard to a decision of the House of Lords in 1989 where a young couple sued Wyre Forest council. The local authority - as councils frequently did - gave them a mortgage on a privately purchased property in Kidderminster. The valuation was even more negligent than Mr Babb's, missing subsidence that left the house virtually worthless. In that case, the law lords had taken what seems like a common-sense approach, accepting that most purchasers rely on the valuation obtained for mortgage purposes as many can't afford another. Surveyors, whether employed or working on their own account, know that reality and it is artificial to argue they should not have the purchasers' interests in mind when drawing up the valuation. This logic was followed in Ms Merrett's claim. The decision will affect not only homeowners, but also employed surveyors and possibly accountants and architects. There is always a risk that they, like Mr Babb, will be left to pick up the tab, if things go wrong at the firm they work for. The court of appeal suggested they might wish to insure against the risk of that happening. Homebuyers, though, will get the peace of mind of knowing that an event completely outside their control, like an insolvency at a firm they did not even select, does not deprive them of redress should their property have been negligently valued.
